fields.headline: Mummy dearest
fields.standfirst: Being a mother in the 21st century is more complicated than ever before. You can start early or wait until your 60, you can be married or unmarried, you can work or stay at home, you can even be a man... Nicci Gerrard speaks to five mother figures about love, labour and loss

fields.body:
Baby banks; surrogate mothers; eggs frozen in laboratories; women giving birth in their early sixties, aided by science; single mothers, gay men adopting babies and being apparently better mothers than the mothers... Over the past few years, there has been an enormous amount of attention given to what a father means in the contemporary world, where all roles are up for grabs. But the word 'mother' still carries its ancient thrill. There may be thousands of ways of being a mother, but there's still only one dominant way of perceiving her. And as the psychoanalyst and writer Adam Phillips says, mothers are 'caught in the crossfire between their own experiences - of being a mother, of having a mother - and what society is telling them; all those images and demands'.

In an experiment in the 1950s, baby chimpanzees were taken from their mother at birth. In her place, they were given a round, soft object embedded with spikes. The baby chimps would hold on to it, no matter how sharply they were pricked. When soldiers die in battle, they often cry out for their mothers; at a deathbed, the person most often invoked is Mother. The image of the mother is cradled deep in our unconscious. It's the Madonna - the self-effaced purity of the tender woman who gives birth to the future. It's the pietà- the same virgin, holding her son dead at her breast and made up entirely of sorrow. It's the woman who kisses her child goodnight and sings a lullaby as her baby slides into dreams. The woman who is there as the child grows - baking cakes, washing clothes, putting plasters on knees, who hears the first word, crows over the first steps, who teaches it how to read, to learn the world.

Ah, mother: beatific, saintly, sweet, self-denying, dolorous, invisible. Not cross, not impatient, not full of desire and fear, ambition, jealousy, rage and thwarted hopes. Not us, then. Against this picture of the ideal mother, we are bound to fail. And if there are dominant cultural images of the Good Mother, so are there for the Bad Mother. Rosemary West: the dumpy, motherly, meat-and-two veg woman who killed her children. DH Lawrence's mother figure, forever clinging, demanding and needy and deadly. The poor Home Alone mother. The Bad Mother is unnatural, monstrous. We fear her, for she lurks inside all of us.

Many of our mothers, or the mothers of our mothers, did not have the choice we have. There was one way to be a mother, and if for some that was a joy, for others it was a prison. Women fought hard to get rid of the single-track approach to parenthood. Now we've got the spaghetti junction instead: you can (with much luck and a following wind) be a mother and pursue your career; you can be a mother and work part-time; you can be a mother full-time and put your work on hold; you can be a mother and wear skimpy clothes and be sexy; you can be a mother young or older, with a partner or single, with different fathers. You can have one child, two, four... You can be a 'modern' kind of mother, or a 'traditional' one, or choose not to be one at all.

'There is a way in which the child invents the mother,' says Adam Phillips. 'There's a very powerful feedback loop. There is no fixed personality called "mother", no fixed personality called "child". Motherhood is a process.' Maureen Freely, author of two books about parenthood, says that one of the things that opened up the subject of motherhood for her was a book by the American writer Sarah Ruddick, who said that 'mother' was a verb, not a noun. 'There's this idea that you can't do, you can only be. Other people decide if you're good.' Actually, she says, 'motherhood is a practice - like medicine, or philosophy'. Freely says 'we should stop worrying about what we are and think more about what we do. I haven't met a mother yet who's not guilty about something.'

We should stop thinking about Good Mothers and Bad Mothers. Mostly we do our best, and fail and succeed all at the same time. In the rich mess and scary muddle of now, there are lots of ways of doing good mothering. Adam Phillips says: 'It is fraught, excessive, very hard to sort out. It drives people mad.' But don't go mad. Don't be consumed by guilt for all those things you did, and regret for all the things you failed to do.

Child, or mother, or both: have a happy Mother's Day.

The motherless child
Peter has grown up without a mother, and in his adulthood became the mothering figure. His story - told with no self-pity - is about loss and the search for love. He has a fugitive half-memory, one which he doesn't trust, of holding the hand of someone called Mummy, a dark solid shape beside him. But he grew up motherless, parentless, and with no sense of his own past.

'Among happy families, I was an outcast. I always felt that. My memories start when I was four and a half. My elder brother and I were rescued by an elderly couple, who fostered us. We were like their project. I spent 10 years with them. I called them Mum and Dad. They changed my name - not just my last name, but my first. I think my story is really all about names.

'But puberty was hard for them, not Robert Louis Stevenson any more, but appetites. When I was 13, they sent me to boarding school, and a year and a half later, when I was suspended, they didn't take me back. They had that choice, because they weren't my "real" parents, you see. They didn't take me home because they retained the right not to be Mum and Dad. That's the safety valve for foster parents - though it only works one way.'

Peter, in London - alone, confused, a 'teenage hybrid' adrift - traced his father, changed his name once again, met the man he had longed for ('My first thought was: you're not him'), and found also that he had a sister. He wanted, desperately, to know something about his mother. 'Just a photo, anything.' His father kept telling him he was better off not knowing - 'He told me she was a bad mother.'

Then Peter, still a teenager, 'met someone. We had a child when I was 19. Then another. She left. I brought them up.' Sometimes it was hard, but 'I was utterly ripe to be devoted; to be a mother - to be the mother I hadn't had.' He thinks, like Maureen Freely, that 'mother' is a verb, an activity, something that you do. He says, with a kind of gratitude, that 'without my childhood, I would probably not have had the opportunity or the inclination to bring up two children at the age of 20, and my wife may not have felt able to leave us, and I would have missed out on the opportunity on watching two extraordinary women grow'.

At 30, as his children were becoming more independent, he went in search of his own mother and found out that his father - the one he had traced - wasn't his father after all; the name he had taken back in an effort to claim kinship didn't belong to him. His mother had been a waitress with a hard life and a string of men, who had abandoned him as a toddler.

Peter eventually found his mother, 'and yes, I adored her, she was my Mum. God, of course I adored her. And yes, it was too late, because she was the one who needed looking after.' For the rest of her life, he would ring her every Saturday evening, the dutiful son. He felt no anger, because 'when you're left, you can't afford to feel anger. You have to bottle it up, or you'll not be loved. You have to smile.' Peter says, quite matter-of-factly, that in his life he has never been 'mothered. No one told me I'm OK.'

Shortly after his mother died, Peter wrote this: 'For most of my life, the thought of Mum and mothering meant loss and pain, hurt. Mums were warm and safe, the kinds of people who cuddled you when you needed to feel safe. For me, Mum meant someone who couldn't love me, who abandoned me to be brought up by strangers, sometimes dangerous strangers who left me with rickets, starved of food and affection and light. Mum meant wondering why you were unloveable, what you had done to drive your mother away

'You had somehow sacrificed the right to unconditional love. Love was something you had to earn, and keep earning, because it could be taken away, in anger, or because maybe you didn't fit in any more. You were born to be a Battersea dog, wagging your tail in a desperate attempt to be endearing. You learnt you were a child of an unnatural mother, one incapable of proper love, the wholesome, Christian kind of feeling

'I met my mother at 30. We cried with relief that I didn't hate her. It was too little too late, but at last I knew the answers to some of the questions Now she's dead, and it's over, I am able to put down the burden of being abandoned. In her death, I briefly rediscovered room to breathe.'

The non-working mother
Carrie Heler used to be a design editor. Her husband, Martyn Harris, was a writer. 'My career was very much part of my identity, and important in our relationship - it was good for me to be an individual, working on things outside the house, the family, us.'

After their son Joe was born, Carrie went back to work, part-time - 'Martyn travelled a lot, so I had to be flexible.' Then, on Joe's fourth birthday, Martyn's cancer was diagnosed. 'I decided to give up work, and be around for Martyn and Joe - I thought they both needed a structure, domestic stability. That became my job: I needed to be the foundation, the rock, the Good Mother. For the last six months of Martyn's life, I did not work at all. Through all those horrendous hospital appointments, through all that time when Martyn was hurtling towards death, I was parking Joe with friends, colleagues, and I felt guilty about that - I still feel guilty about that. There is a lot of guilt in me.

'After Martyn died, I felt I absolutely had to be there for Joe, to repair our relationship which, however I'd tried, had been coming second. Yet now - three years later - I'd like some kind of life outside this one. I think Joe needs that as well - to respect me outside this role of mother and be able to say, "My mum does that" and feel proud of me. I need to have self-esteem, a sense of who I am; during all those years, I almost lost that.

'Whatever you do, you are haunted by the alternatives. If I worked now, it would be for my benefit and for his, because I am his mother but I also stand in for his father.

'I read a poem once, which said that being a mother was like being a bow. The child is the arrow. A bow has to be strong and resilient and flexible. I try'

The childless mother

Joan Smith is a writer and a journalist. She has made a positive choice not to have children. She agrees that one way of being a Bad Mother is to choose not to be one at all. 'What lies at the heart of this is that the way we think of women as mothers doesn't allow women to be different from each other. For centuries, women didn't really have a choice - if they were sexually active, and most of them were, then they would become mothers. The fact that every woman, more or less, did it blinded us to the fact that they might not be choosing to do it. Now, in the UK and western Europe, about 20 per cent of women are actively choosing not to be mothers.

'I don't find this so surprising. I grew up with the pill. I came from a working-class family, an only child. My father was a working-class autodidact and he wanted me to go to university, and I guess I was brought up in quite an ungendered way. There were millions of things I could do with my life, and to be a mother was just one of them. I never enjoyed being around children that much; I didn't want to look after them, and I saw lots of girls on the estate where I lived who got pregnant at 15 or 16. They were barely adults, and it seemed to me that they never left the world of childhood. That wasn't for me. I always had a powerful sense of my identity and also I had quite a tortured relationship with my own mother. I looked around and saw women left high and dry when their children left home.

'There was no real heart-searching about not having children, no regrets. My choice apparently puts me in a hostile camp - there is the assumption that women have to be mothers, and this is a stick that beats all women, with or without children. Are women allowed to be different? Men are. No one criticises men for not becoming fathers, like the bishop who attacked women for remaining childless. No one feels sorry for Leonardo da Vinci for having no children, but they do say, "Poor virgin Queen Elizabeth". The discourse is changing now. Ten years ago, when I wrote about my choice, I got torrents of hostile mail: "I'm a grandmother, and when I die I'll have my children and grandchildren round my bed, and you'll just have your PC."

'The torrent of abuse that women get as mothers is the same as the torrents of abuse women get for not being mothers. People are often insecure; they don't see difference as interesting. Actually, come to think of it, the only good mother is the dead mother. Like the saying goes: good girls go to heaven. Bad girls go everywhere.'

Dorothy's mother died when she was 11, just entering that strange land between childhood and adulthood. She is now a mother herself. 'So much has been mythologised about her. She was an unusual woman, and she dealt with her illness in an unusual way, soldiering on, seeing the humour in it. A lot of people adored her. Afterwards they told me stories about her, which I wasn't ready for. In lots of ways, I lost her over and over again after she died. It was five years before I really believed she had died. She was this living, pulsating thing inside me - she was there. That's what a guardian angel is, I suppose. A child doesn't let go until it is ready. She's still here, but she's not my heart any longer, not the thing that keeps me breathing.

'I relinquished her in all sorts of ways. It took a long time before I dared be a mother myself. Despite everything, I found that I had to be a mother - and when I had my own children, I found her again. I wrote a lot about her. I knew how present she was for a lot of us - even those who had never known her - and I interviewed family members about how they felt about living with a dead person. I've always had problems of scale with my mother - when I was a child, she was God, enormous. Later, she became this tiny figure in my mind, hardened with age. Now, I can see her. I talk to her.

'But as a mother, I have to work. I am away from my children more than I want, and that makes me feel cut off from my self. I am absent. There are times when I feel I cannot bear it. I cannot bear it.'

The working mother
Claire is a mother of two. For the first few years of her children's lives, she had a demanding job in management. 'I'd see them in the mornings, when I was often frazzled, but not at night. I could never get home until eight; they'd be in bed by 7.30pm. While I was at work, I felt fine - I think, like many people, I am capable of having two separate lives. But in the long term, I was acutely aware I was spending too much time at work.

'It's important to work out how much you mind not being the primary carer - my children had consistent childcare, and their father was around a lot. I was third in line. I was the husband, if you like, and the father was the mother. The eldest became quite hostile to me. He wouldn't let me do things for him. It wasn't me he called out for in the night.

'It's complicated, motherhood, and my feelings about it. I was at boarding school from the age of seven - until then, my mother was the primary carer. Maybe being sent away made it easier for me to break the mould. Yet when my eldest child was seven, I had the strongest sense of a generation coming full circle, and I couldn't understand what it would mean to send your child away.

'Now, I do much more parenting; I always knew I could only do a pressured job for a short time. I always had a sense that to keep going like that would be at the cost of my children. It's partly selfish: they were fine, but I wanted to be the person who was there for them. I wanted to be able to have my say in their lives, meet their friends, know about their days, be nurturing. And pass things on - mothering wisdom, the things my mother taught me, and her mother taught her. Like a baton, I want to hand them down. But you have to ask yourself: who needs who?'

'But as a mother, I have to work. I am away from my children more than I want, and that makes me feel cut off from my self. I am absent. There are times when I feel I cannot bear it. I cannot bear it.' The working mother Claire is a mother of two. For the first few years of her children's lives, she had a demanding job in management. 'I'd see them in the mornings, when I was often frazzled, but not at night. I could never get home until eight; they'd be in bed by 7.30pm. While I was at work, I felt fine - I think, like many people, I am capable of having two separate lives. But in the long term, I was acutely aware I was spending too much time at work. 'It's important to work out how much you mind not being the primary carer - my children had consistent childcare, and their father was around a lot. I was third in line. I was the husband, if you like, and the father was the mother. The eldest became quite hostile to me. He wouldn't let me do things for him. It wasn't me he called out for in the night. 'It's complicated, motherhood, and my feelings about it. I was at boarding school from the age of seven - until then, my mother was the primary carer. Maybe being sent away made it easier for me to break the mould. Yet when my eldest child was seven, I had the strongest sense of a generation coming full circle, and I couldn't understand what it would mean to send your child away. 'Now, I do much more parenting; I always knew I could only do a pressured job for a short time. I always had a sense that to keep going like that would be at the cost of my children. It's partly selfish: they were fine, but I wanted to be the person who was there for them. I wanted to be able to have my say in their lives, meet their friends, know about their days, be nurturing. And pass things on - mothering wisdom, the things my mother taught me, and her mother taught her. Like a baton, I want to hand them down. But you have to ask yourself: who needs who?'

webTitle: These bonds bounce back with a bonus

fields.headline: These bonds bounce back with a bonus
fields.standfirst: Christine Stopp reveals increased rewards from a low-risk investment
fields.trailText: Bonuses on with-profit bonds have been falling for several years, leaving investors uncertain about their future returns. Many advisers now feel that the bonuses must be at or near the bottom of the trough, and the way forward looks more optimistic than it has for a while.
fields.body:
Bonuses on with-profit bonds have been falling for several years, leaving investors uncertain about their future returns. Many advisers now feel that the bonuses must be at or near the bottom of the trough, and the way forward looks more optimistic than it has for a while.

With-profit bonds are single-premium investment bonds and the return is in the form of bonuses which, once accrued, cannot be taken away. There are two main types of bonus: annual and reversionary bonuses, paid in to your bond each year, and terminal bonuses, paid when you cash in your bond, assuming you have held it for a minimum period.

The result is a relatively low-risk investment with a rate of growth that should be better than deposits, but will not be as strong as the stock market.

Some bonds pay returns mainly through reversionary bonuses, others through high terminal bonuses.

In practice there are many permutations of bonus. Bonuses are declared annually by the insurance companies offering the bonds. To add to the complications, with-profit bonds can have several different layers of charges, including redemption penalties for investors who cash in within the first five years. Commission of 5 to 6 per cent may be paid on these products to advisers.

Not surprisingly, the discount industry has taken up with-profit bonds, and substantial savings can be made by dealing at a discount. Discount brokers, who often deal on a no-advice basis, also publish free and detailed surveys of the bonds on offer.

It is worth consulting two or three brokers to see what deals are available.

Chartwell Investment Management is currently offering a 5.4 per cent refund of commission on bonds from its 'top 10' providers: Prudential, Norwich Union, Scottish Widows, Scottish Equitable, Clerical Medical, Scottish Mutual, Royal and Sun Alliance, CGU Life, Friends' Provident and Britannic Assurance.

Baronworth offers from 4 to 5.5 per cent discount depending on the bond. It is selling the Legal & General with-profit bond (income version) free of all charges and with an additional discount boost. The bond will maintain a bonus rate of 7 per cent after basic rate tax for five years, though with out any additional capital growth at the end of the term.

When up to £300m in Scottish Widows guaranteed bonds matures in April this year, investors will be offered a with-profit bond as a roll-over vehicle. Guaranteed bond investors taking up the new bond offer through Baronworth can boost their roll-over value by 9 per cent.

With these bonds, watch out for the market value adjuster (MVA), which allows companies to pay less than the announced bonuses if stock market conditions have been poor.

With-profit bonds are taxed like any single-premium investment bond. Returns are judged to be free of basic-rate tax by the Inland Revenue. Higher-rate taxpayers must pay the difference between basic and higher rate tax. However, if they do not withdraw more than 5 per cent a year, they can defer the tax liability until encashment.

The following are the main points to watch out for on with-profit bonds:

 Do not buy unless you plan to invest for at least five years.

 Do not be dazzled by a high first-year return - look for good potential returns over several years.

 Judge companies by past performance (see table) and financial strength (ask an adviser for details).

 Compare several bonds, particularly looking at charges. Buy through a discount broker to keep costs down.

 Check the position on withdrawal penalties and MVAs.

 Higher-rate taxpayers and basic-rate taxpayers whose income is close to the higher rate band should take advice on the tax implications of the investment.

Further information from: Financial Data magazine Life & Pensions Moneyfacts gives details of current bonds through its fax service. Dial 090 60760756 through your fax machine and press start when prompted. Calls cost a maximum of 75p per minute.

Baronworth Investment Services will publish a new survey of this market shortly. To receive a free copy call 0181 518 1218.

The Chartwell Guide to With Profit Bonds is available free on 01225 321710 or www.chartwell-direct.co.uk .

webTitle: Workers pay for Brown's stand on pensions

fields.headline: Workers pay for Brown's stand on pensions
fields.standfirst:
Council tax payers have to cover public sector shortfall, says Pamela Atherton
Money Unlimited
fields.trailText: The recent announcement that members of the Tesco pension scheme will have to pay extra contributions from this month has prompted a furious response from the pensions industry and Conservative politicians.
fields.body:
The recent announcement that members of the Tesco pension scheme will have to pay extra contributions from this month has prompted a furious response from the pensions industry and Conservative politicians.

This is because the rise from 3.75 per cent to 4.25 per cent has been attributed by the Tesco scheme to the abolition of the tax credit on dividends, which was introduced in the July 1997 Budget by the Chancellor, Gordon Brown. Its effect has been to reduce the income received by pension funds from dividends by 10 per cent.

At the time the change caused uproar from trade bodies such as the National Association of Pension funds (NAPF), which estimated that the cost to UK pension funds in the first year alone would be approximately £5 billion.

But the axing of tax credits went largely unnoticed by the public because the tax was not noticeable in their pay packets immediately and has therefore been dubbed by the Conservative Party as yet another 'stealth tax'.

However, the 10 per cent loss in income to pension funds is now starting to bite hard on pension schemes. Where there is no surplus in the fund, pension scheme sponsors face a stark choice: increase employer/employee contributions, reduce benefits or a mixture of both.

For example, a Tesco employee earning £25,000 will have to pay an extra £100 this year, and Tesco plc, the scheme sponsor, is having to stump up two-thirds of the extra contribution.

If you think this does not affect you, you are wrong. Local authority pension schemes have been badly hit by the loss of income and a number have had to raise council tax rates to top up their pension schemes.

According to trade magazine Pensions Week , the shortfall amounts to £30 million for Greater Manchester, £33m for Cornwall, and £75m for Staffordshire and it is council tax payers who are having to pick up the tab. The cost to local authorities is expected to be an average 3 per cent per annum of payroll on an ongoing basis.

Private sector pension schemes have also been hit. British Airways has calculated the loss of income due to the tax change at £177m, BT £70m, and the Post Office £600m. Where a scheme is non-contributory or a 'balance of cost' scheme, the employer has to bear the entire cost of any shortfall in the scheme's assets, so these schemes face the choice of increasing employer contributions or reducing benefits. If there is a scheme surplus and the employer is enjoying a 'contribution holiday', this may have to be reduced. However, if a scheme is a 'shared cost' scheme, both the employer and employees have to increase contributions, where there is a funding shortfall.

The NAPF says an estimated 9 per cent of its occupational scheme members are shared cost schemes and these are the schemes where employees are most likely to face contribution hikes.

Post Office pensions director Frank Calvert commented: 'The Post Office scheme has had to cut its contribution holiday from five years to two, as a result of a number of factors, one of which was the abolition of the tax credit. It has definitely had an adverse effect on the scheme's valuation.'

Other schemes, such as Sainsbury's, which is a balance of cost scheme, have reacted by closing the final salary scheme to new members, who are now offered a group personal pension.

Group personal pensions are cheaper to fund and easier to administer for the employer, but are recognised as providing inferior benefits for employees compared with final salary schemes.

Colin Hartridge-Price, BT scheme secretary and chief pensions officer said: 'BT's contributions to the fund have not changed since the abolition of the tax credit, but it has had the effect of removing what would have been a scheme surplus. The abolition of tax credit is far more serious for employers than it is for employees, because it is the employer in the majority of cases who has to make good the shortfall.'

He accuses the Government of imposing 'double taxation' on pension schemes because pensions are taxed at source when they are taken in retirement and should therefore not be taxed while they are accumulating within the fund as well.

NAPF Director General Ann Robinson said: 'The increasing burden of cost is driving employers to consider whether they need to offer a defined benefit scheme at all. The Government claimed the tax change would not affect pensions but it is savaging schemes, particularly smaller ones, which are less likely to have a surplus to cushion the blow.'

According to Incomes Data Services, the average contribution employers are paying into occupational pension schemes has started to rise, after years of falling. In 1999, total contributions rose by nearly 5 per cent in spite of excellent investment returns.

NAPF council member Lynne Ruddick is urging pension scheme managers to publicise the damaging effects of the tax change. At a recent NAPF conference, she told delegates: 'If you can relate the need for a rise in contributions or a reduction in scheme benefits to the abolition of tax credit, then tell your members who is to blame.'

fields.headline: Firming up the flexible loan
fields.standfirst: Lenders are responding to borrowers' demands for greater repayment versatility, reports  Chris Menon
fields.trailText: Lenders are responding to borrowers' demands for greater repayment versatility, reports Chris Menon.
fields.body:
Flexible mortgages are now plentiful and popular but until recently there have been few fixed-rate deals available. 'Flexible' has become a fairly ubiquitous term, describing everything from the ability to make occasional lump-sum repayments of your mortgage to a current account mortgage, where your home loan is, in effect, an overdraft secured on your property.

Research carried out on behalf of lender First Active Financial shows that flexible loans account for 11 per cent of total gross mortgage lending - or 4 per cent of total loans in place. Such loans, unheard of a few years ago, are estimated to account for 50 per cent of gross lending by the end of 2004. Until recently they have been offered mainly with variable rates of interest.

Around a dozen lenders now offer such loans with fixed rates. There are risks with flexible loans of course: borrowers need to ensure that they do not over-borrow against the value of their homes, a temptation that may grow with rising property values.

As interest rates rise, flexi-loans with fixed rates may appeal to some borrowers, especially those who feel they are likely to increase their borrowing over the short term rather than to pay off lump sums.

Once you have taken everything into account, including various perks such as no Mortgage Indemnity Guarantee (MIG) charges and free legal fees, there is not a great deal to choose between the various options.

The Skipton Building Society offers four options, all with fixed rates for two years until 30 April 2002 - the exact rate depends on the ratio of loan to property value and whether insurance is taken up, but the rates range from 6.15 per cent to 6.65 per cent. After this period the rate will be 1.35 per cent above the Bank of England base rate for three years. This compares with Skipton's standard variable rate of 7.49 per cent.

Skipton's fixed rates for flexi loans are among the cheapest in this market but there are overhanging redemption periods with penalties. If the mortgage is repaid in full, on or before 30 April 2002, there is a redemption charge of 3 per cent of the balance of the mortgage account, then 2 per cent until 30 April 2004 and then 1 per cent until 30 April 2005.

That said, it is possible to make capital repayments of up to 10 per cent of the original balance of the mortgage each year without charge. It also has other flexible benefits, such as payment holidays and interest calculated on a daily basis.

Mark Smitheringdale, head of corporate communications at the Skipton Building Society, says: 'Borrowers are now demanding both a competitive deal and flexibility from their lender.

'The society's view of interest rates is that they will continue to increase over the next 12-18 months or so and then steadily decline. Therefore, it is sensible planning to fix your mortgage at a competitive rate and then enjoy the additional benefit of falling rates.'

The latest lender to offer a fixed-rate flexible mortgage is Standard Life - pioneer of the variable-rate flexi loan - with what it calls its 'Freestyle Fixed' mortgage. This offers a three-year fix to 3 April 2003 or a five-year fix to 3 April 2005 both at 7.25 per cent. The maximum loan to value amount is 90 per cent.

There is no tie-in after the fixed-rate period, although any capital repayments made within the fixed-rate period will incur redemption charges. For example, under the three-year fix a borrower making a capital repayment in year one will be charged five months gross interest at the fixed rate on the amount redeemed, if they make a repayment in year two it will be four months gross interest on the amount redeemed and in year three it will be three months gross interest.

Interest is calculated daily and payment holidays of up to two months every year are allowed after six consecutive monthly payments.

Other lenders in the flexible mortgage market offering fixed rates include Egg, with a rate of 7.69 per cent for five years, Exclusive Connections, with rates of 6.99 per cent and 7.99 per cent, Mortgage Express, with rates ranging from 7.25 per cent to 7.75 per cent, Scottish Widows, at 7.3 per cent, and Woolwich, at 6.64 per cent or 6.69 per cent.

webTitle: Russian firms in need of revolution

fields.headline: Russian firms in need of revolution
fields.standfirst: Simon Pirani on the cultural problems besetting business
fields.trailText: There are two new people in the life of management consultant Greg Thain: Tanya and Vladimir. Tanya is a multi-skilled, multi-lingual e-tech assistant at Thain's Moscow-based management consultancy - 'typical of Russia's incredibly talented and motivated new generation', says Thain. Vladimir Putin is Russia's newly-elected President who, Thain believes, is 'setting the tone for a professional, serious attitude to business'. Last month he increased fivefold the tax-free allowance Russian companies could spend on marketing, advertising and training.
fields.body:
There are two new people in the life of management consultant Greg Thain: Tanya and Vladimir. Tanya is a multi-skilled, multi-lingual e-tech assistant at Thain's Moscow-based management consultancy - 'typical of Russia's incredibly talented and motivated new generation', says Thain. Vladimir Putin is Russia's newly-elected President who, Thain believes, is 'setting the tone for a professional, serious attitude to business'. Last month he increased fivefold the tax-free allowance Russian companies could spend on marketing, advertising and training.

In the new Russia, Thain says, bureaucracy, paternalism and political influence on businesses are real problems; gun-toting gangsters are, on the whole, not. But the biggest obstacles are cultural ones.

Thain is well placed to compare. He moved to Moscow from the UK in 1994 after selling his share of a database and marketing company. His Russian business, Integrated Marketing Solutions, has management training, market research and marketing arms.

As an example of the culture clash, Thain recalls an upmarket fashionwear manufacturer whose director is a professor of marketing and management at the local business school. When Thain asked how new lines were marketed the director replied that they were displayed at exhibitions - but under questioning admitted there was no database of prospective customers.

This company at least accepted the need for one. Thain says: 'Marketing is selling, and selling is about communication. But this is still not part of Russian culture.'

A more dramatic example of the culture clash was provided by a building materials supplier in a former Soviet republic. Thain was asked to look at its marketing by a financial institution that was thinking of lending it money.

It was a nightmare. 'Distributors and local builders were fed up to the back teeth. They would order five boxes of blue and be told: "Here's three boxes of red, you can like it or lump it".'

Thain gently suggested the company should improve customer relations, or risk damaging its dominant position over time.

'The boss screamed at us, saying he would have us arrested, and that we were going to lose them mllions of dollars of loan capital. He wouldn't listen,' he said.

Another Soviet legacy that Thain comes up against is the 'thin pyramid' - company structures where all decisions and actions emanate from the top. 'You can go to meet the chairman of a big company and find him not only answering all calls on his direct line, but also doing his own filing - because in the Soviet system, knowledge was power, and so his secretary or assistant couldn't be allowed to know what was in the files.'

Thain believes the rising generation of Russians are 'light years ahead' of their predecessors in terms of education and access to information. But none of the country's big companies have yet conquered the 'thin pyramid'. And since everything emanates from the top, it is the companies headed by the most dynamic entrepreneurs that are doing best.

One such is Oleg Deripaska, 32, named Russia's businessman of the year last year by the leading business newspaper Vedomosti , whose Sibirsky Aliumny group owns Russia's third-largest aluminium smelter at Sayansk in eastern Siberia.

The aluminium industry is an unlikely home for good management in Russia. When it was privatised in the mid-1990s, it became a byword for gangsterism. Criminals fought for control of the huge Siberian smelters in 'aluminium wars' that claimed dozens of lives. Tolling - a system under which raw alumina is imported, smelted into aluminium at a fixed price and exported, with profits from sales remaining offshore - made some foreign aluminium traders, and Russian-controlled offshore trading companies, incredibly rich. The struggling Russian economy was the loser.

When Deripaska and some fellow managers won a majority stake in Sibirsky three years ago, they began a campaign against tolling, arguing that proceeds had to be repatriated to invest in domestic industry.

Breaking from his business partners, UK-based aluminium traders Trans World Group, who used the tolling system to the full, Deripaska bought downstream aluminum processing plants and said Sibirsky was going to place its faith in domestic industry, not in spiriting profits abroad.

On 1 January this year the government abolished tax breaks on tolling, foreshadowing the end of the system. Deripaska's reputation rose.

Deripaska, 32, is the quintessential post-Soviet entrepreneur: his working life began when the Soviet Union was already collapsing and he worked as a sugar trader and at a brokerage before taking on aluminium.

The big question for Putin's Russia is whether the path cleared by pioneers such as Deripaska will be trodden by a new generation conscious of the need for team management, open structures - and even databases.

Dmitry Zelenin, president of the Russian Association of Managers, said last month: 'I have come to the conclusion that in the big enterprises that dominate the real economy, the role of prime mover of the market system belongs to new-generation managers rather than entrepreneurs.'

Greg Thain would drink to that.
fields.bodyText: There are two new people in the life of management consultant Greg Thain: Tanya and Vladimir. Tanya is a multi-skilled, multi-lingual e-tech assistant at Thain's Moscow-based management consultancy - 'typical of Russia's incredibly talented and motivated new generation', says Thain. Vladimir Putin is Russia's newly-elected President who, Thain believes, is 'setting the tone for a professional, serious attitude to business'. Last month he increased fivefold the tax-free allowance Russian companies could spend on marketing, advertising and training. In the new Russia, Thain says, bureaucracy, paternalism and political influence on businesses are real problems; gun-toting gangsters are, on the whole, not. But the biggest obstacles are cultural ones. Thain is well placed to compare. He moved to Moscow from the UK in 1994 after selling his share of a database and marketing company. His Russian business, Integrated Marketing Solutions, has management training, market research and marketing arms. As an example of the culture clash, Thain recalls an upmarket fashionwear manufacturer whose director is a professor of marketing and management at the local business school. When Thain asked how new lines were marketed the director replied that they were displayed at exhibitions - but under questioning admitted there was no database of prospective customers. This company at least accepted the need for one. Thain says: 'Marketing is selling, and selling is about communication. But this is still not part of Russian culture.' A more dramatic example of the culture clash was provided by a building materials supplier in a former Soviet republic. Thain was asked to look at its marketing by a financial institution that was thinking of lending it money. It was a nightmare. 'Distributors and local builders were fed up to the back teeth. They would order five boxes of blue and be told: "Here's three boxes of red, you can like it or lump it".' Thain gently suggested the company should improve customer relations, or risk damaging its dominant position over time. 'The boss screamed at us, saying he would have us arrested, and that we were going to lose them mllions of dollars of loan capital. He wouldn't listen,' he said. Another Soviet legacy that Thain comes up against is the 'thin pyramid' - company structures where all decisions and actions emanate from the top. 'You can go to meet the chairman of a big company and find him not only answering all calls on his direct line, but also doing his own filing - because in the Soviet system, knowledge was power, and so his secretary or assistant couldn't be allowed to know what was in the files.' Thain believes the rising generation of Russians are 'light years ahead' of their predecessors in terms of education and access to information. But none of the country's big companies have yet conquered the 'thin pyramid'. And since everything emanates from the top, it is the companies headed by the most dynamic entrepreneurs that are doing best. One such is Oleg Deripaska, 32, named Russia's businessman of the year last year by the leading business newspaper Vedomosti , whose Sibirsky Aliumny group owns Russia's third-largest aluminium smelter at Sayansk in eastern Siberia. The aluminium industry is an unlikely home for good management in Russia. When it was privatised in the mid-1990s, it became a byword for gangsterism. Criminals fought for control of the huge Siberian smelters in 'aluminium wars' that claimed dozens of lives. Tolling - a system under which raw alumina is imported, smelted into aluminium at a fixed price and exported, with profits from sales remaining offshore - made some foreign aluminium traders, and Russian-controlled offshore trading companies, incredibly rich. The struggling Russian economy was the loser. When Deripaska and some fellow managers won a majority stake in Sibirsky three years ago, they began a campaign against tolling, arguing that proceeds had to be repatriated to invest in domestic industry. Breaking from his business partners, UK-based aluminium traders Trans World Group, who used the tolling system to the full, Deripaska bought downstream aluminum processing plants and said Sibirsky was going to place its faith in domestic industry, not in spiriting profits abroad. On 1 January this year the government abolished tax breaks on tolling, foreshadowing the end of the system. Deripaska's reputation rose. Deripaska, 32, is the quintessential post-Soviet entrepreneur: his working life began when the Soviet Union was already collapsing and he worked as a sugar trader and at a brokerage before taking on aluminium. The big question for Putin's Russia is whether the path cleared by pioneers such as Deripaska will be trodden by a new generation conscious of the need for team management, open structures - and even databases. Dmitry Zelenin, president of the Russian Association of Managers, said last month: 'I have come to the conclusion that in the big enterprises that dominate the real economy, the role of prime mover of the market system belongs to new-generation managers rather than entrepreneurs.' Greg Thain would drink to that.

webTitle: A veil of secrecy covering dishonesty

fields.headline: A veil of secrecy covering dishonesty
fields.trailText: I started a new job recently and discovered that my predecessor had left suddenly under a veil of secrecy. This veil seems to cover dishonesty in regard to money and doing the job very messily. No filing has been done for two years. He was, however, moved to a similar post in another branch and my manager won't hear a word against him. I'm unhappy with the situation and worried that I could be blamed.
fields.body:
I started a new job recently and discovered that my predecessor had left suddenly under a veil of secrecy. This veil seems to cover dishonesty in regard to money and doing the job very messily. No filing has been done for two years. He was, however, moved to a similar post in another branch and my manager won't hear a word against him. I'm unhappy with the situation and worried that I could be blamed.

Your prime concern is to cover your own back - rather than to see that your predecessor is punished. You should write a note to your manager (dating it and keeping a copy) outlining the information you have that something is wrong. You should say that the filing has not been done for two years and give the evidence you have to show how the finances are out of order. Avoid personalising it if you can. The more objective you sound, the better.

If you are ever blamed for your predecessor's wrongdoings, you then have proof that you drew the issue to the management's attention. You may have some protection under the whistleblower's legislation. You could ring Public Concern at Work for more advice on 0171-404 6609. If the worst came to the worst, you can claim unfair dismissal if you are fired after a year's service because of this issue.

 Legal advice this week from Lewis Silkin

 Problem at work? Write to Neasa MacErlean, The Observer, 119 Farringdon Road, London EC1R 3ER. Answers are for guidance only.

webTitle: Ford bosses issue stark warning on Dagenham

fields.headline: Ford bosses issue stark warning on Dagenham
fields.standfirst: Rover in crisis: special report
fields.trailText: Ford bosses have warned workers to brace themselves for the closure of its main UK plant. A shutdown of the giant Dagenham factory would end car production there with the loss of thousands of jobs.
fields.body:
Ford bosses have warned workers to brace themselves for the closure of its main UK plant. A shutdown of the giant Dagenham factory would end car production there with the loss of thousands of jobs.

The news was broken during crisis talks between union representives and senior company executives in London last week. Ford blamed inefficiency at the east London plant compared with those elsewhere in Europe.

The attack on British productivity coincided with two other blows to the industry which were blamed wholly or partly on the high value of the pound. First, Honda said it planned to halve car production at its Swindon plant, also citing weak European sales and the need to retool the factory for new models.

Second, BMW revealed that it finally to dumped Rover when it realised its UK losses could double this year because of sterling, plummeting sales and a poor performance by its Longbridge workers.

Senior sources at the German carmaker admitted in Munich last week that they feared Rover would not break even until at least 2005, and that soaring losses would jeopardise the whole group. BMW last year revised the break-even target for Rover from 2000 to 2002, but the UK firm's finances deteriorated rapidly in the second half of 1999.

Rover chairman Werner Samann confirmed last week's Observer story that BMW rebuffed approaches about the UK firm from Ford, General Motors and Volkswagen because they wanted shares in the German parent. Such a deal could have prevented the break-up of Rover.

With the future of 50,000 jobs at stake in the West Midlands similar desolation now hangs over motor industry jobs in east London.

At last week's private talks, Ford European president David Thursfield told union officials that no final decision had been taken, but the future looked bleak.

A union source said: 'He painted a grim scenario. Keeping Dagenham was not likely because of the failures to change industrial practicces at the plant and recent stoppages.' He added that Ford criticised the workforce for producing cars too slowly.

Ford is responding to massive overcapacity in European plants and financial losses with a radical review of its operations.

Dagenham is the most vulnerable plant because of its relatively poor productivity, the pound and, Ford chiefs admit, the fact that the current Fiesta made there should have been replaced years ago.

Trade Secretary Stephen Byers is in continuing negotiations with Ford, and is thought to have drawn up a series of contingency plans to try to soften the blow to the local economy.

Byers is set to be grilled by the Commons Trade and Industry Select Committee on Tuesday about whether he should have picked up clear warnings from BMW that it was about to abandon Rover.

Senior BMW directors told The Observer that the final decision to ditch Rover was made when they had to present the financial outlook for the group to the BMW supervisory board on 16 March.

On top of 1999 losses of £800 million, they feared that Rover's losses this year could be up to £1.6 billion. But UK observers believe BMW exaggerated Rover's plight to justify the break-up.

fields.headline: Excite eyes £2bn float
fields.standfirst: E-finance: special report
fields.trailText: The internet search engine Excite Europe is eyeing a stock market flotation which could see it valued at more than £2 billion.
fields.body:
The internet search engine Excite Europe is eyeing a stock market flotation which could see it valued at more than £2 billion.

The subsidiary of Excite@Home, the massive US search engine partially owned by AT&T and cable operators Cox Communications and Comcast, is considering a number of ways of raising cash to finance its expansion plans.

'An initial public offering is something we are thinking about, but it's not the only way,' said Evan Rudowski, managing director of Excite Europe which is legally separate from its owner. He suggested the firm could look for funds from Excite@Home or seek alliances with other Internet companies.

Excite, whose main European operations are in the UK, has been running a big advertising campaign in a bid to boost its profile. Its core business, Excite.co.uk, jointly owned by Excite@Home and BT, has advertised heavily on television, leading to speculation that the company wants to float within months.

The move would make sense for BT which is keen to realise the value of some of its non-core investments.

The Excite website is the seventh most popular with UK users, according to analysts at the web-ranking firm, NetValue. Its close rival Lycos, whose European parent company floated earlier this month in a move which valued its business at more than £3.3 billion, has a reach of 31 per cent among Internet users, compared with Excite's 26 per cent. Excite Europe also has ventures in several other European countries.

Rudowski admitted that the Lycos float had helped to crystallise the company's thoughts about an initial public offering. 'We've certainly been made aware of the high valuations of European Internet proper,' he said.

fields.headline: Please sir, you're a bully
fields.standfirst: More than half of our teachers want to leave the job - that's hardly surprising when one in six has been bullied.  Jim Pollard reports
fields.trailText: In the average school, nearly one in six has been bullied in the past six months. No surprise there, perhaps - kids have been bullying each other since Cain and Abel - except this figure is not for pupils, it is for teachers.
fields.body:
In the average school, nearly one in six has been bullied in the past six months. No surprise there, perhaps - kids have been bullying each other since Cain and Abel - except this figure is not for pupils, it is for teachers.

Bullying is a growing problem in the workplace, particularly among professionals who are supposed to be caring for others such as teachers, prison officers, doctors and nurses. A recent survey at the Manchester School of Management (Umist) found that one in four of us had been bullied at work in the past five years. In teaching it is one in three.

The scale of the problem is often underestimated because, understandably, victims are reluctant to talk about bullying. Cary Cooper, the professor of organisational psychology who carried out the research, calculates that it is responsible for 18 million lost working days every year and causes 30-50 per cent of work-related stress illness. Ultimately, employers pay as well as employees. In a landmark High Court ruling in 1994 a social worker was awarded £175,000 following a stress-related breakdown and now an informal survey of personal injury and employment lawyers suggests more than a third of all work-related stress cases are about bullying.

'In my view there are two types of bully,' says Cooper. 'The psychopathic bully has low self-esteem and may not be particularly good at their job. He or she bullies to enhance their status. It's a personality dysfunction and the numbers are relatively small and stable. The other type is the overloaded bully who has too much to do themselves and dumps on others. This sort of bullying is increasing.'

He draws a distinction between European and Anglo-American corporate cultures. 'Downsizing, short-term contracts and long working hours all help short-term global competitiveness, but coupled with increasing technology overload from e-mails, faxes and mobile phones, they create a climate in which employees are overloaded and bullying is inevitable,' he says. 'This is unhealthy for UK plc in the long term.'

It has certainly been unhealthy for teachers. The profession offers a lesson in the long-term impact of bullying. As assistant secretary of the NAS/UWT teaching union, Les Roberts conducted a major survey of staffroom bullying in 1997. He believes the problem is getting worse and the figures bear him out. A recent Guardian /ICM poll found that more than half of teachers intend to leave the profession within the next 10 years including a third of those under 35. Cary Cooper is not surprised. 'In our survey, those who are bullied consistently report the poorest health, the lowest work motivation, satisfaction and productivity and the highest absenteeism and intentions to leave.'

Better employers are recognising this. 'We've had a bullying policy since 1994,' says Barry Gibson, chief executive of the retailer Littlewoods. 'Only in a workplace free from bullying can our potential as individuals and as a company be fully realised. I believe it was reflected in our success at the 1999 Institute of Personnel and Development People Management Awards.' The company was overall winner.

Cooper is particularly concerned about public-sector bullying. A survey by the union Unison found that two-thirds had experienced or witnessed bullying. 'Many people in the private sector may feel they're paid enough to be able to put up with some bullying,' says Cooper, 'but that's not the case in the public sector, where management training is also less good. I've never been trained for my higher education management responsibilities, and how many school headteachers have? The odd day isn't enough.' He calls for better management training, stress audits, a safe whistle-blowing mechanism and an effective complaints procedure.

So where does the bullying buck stop? 'The more hierarchical a profession, the easier it is for bullying to cascade down,' says Cooper. The NAS/UWT's Roberts agrees. 'There's increasing pressure on schools from outside,' he says, 'particularly on headteachers and they pass this pressure down the line.'

Cooper identifies certain management styles as 'bullying'. These include naming and shaming, whereby poor performance is drawn to wider attention. 'Public ostracism creates a bad atmosphere among employees. Weaker ones become fearful and defensive, better ones leave,' he says.

So how can you tell if your bullying boss is psychopathic or overloaded? Cooper believes it depends on whether they have always bullied. 'If your boss bullies regardless of circumstances, it may be psychopathic,' he says. 'If it varies with workload, he or she is probably overloaded.' Will this cheer up the 200,000 teachers who are looking to leave the job?

On the receiving end

'She abused me so much I burst into tears.' Tony teaches at an inner London secondary school. His name has been changed because his borough disciplines employees who talk to the media.

'I've been bullied in many ways - some are subtle, some aren't. There's humiliation. On one occasion I was belittled by the headteacher in front of a pupil in her office. She later denied knowing he had been there.

'There's death by memo - any slight slip and instantly there's a memo reprimanding you. There's death by monitoring - our lessons and our students' books are inspected constantly. Excessively. The kids are even asked to grade our performance, which undermines authority. 'The worst occasion was when I'd just returned after being off with stress and the head abused me so much I burst into tears. She physically prevented me from leaving her office by blocking the door. I could only have got out by assaulting her. Now I never see her without someone accompanying me.

'I don't have a problem with female managers. My head of department is a woman and it's great. It's this head. She's overworked, makes mistakes in the heat of the moment and can't admit she's wrong.

'I've had time off for stress and spent the last half-term not sleeping. It's affected my relationship with my wife and my kids. Without the support of my union I couldn't have carried on.

'Don't get me wrong. I love teaching - in the classroom, with a good class I have a lovely time - and I don't believe I'm a bad teacher.'

Bullying barometer

You are being bullied when:
 your presence or opinions are ignored
 you are denied information about your performance
 you are given an unmanageable workload
 you are given unreasonable deadlines
 you are humiliated or ridiculed
 your work is excessively monitored
 gossip and rumour are spread about you
 faults are continually found with your work

 The TUC Know Your Rights line (0870 600 4882) can advise on bullying (charged at national rate).

webTitle: Savers can hit the market in peak condition

fields.headline: Savers can hit the market in peak condition
fields.standfirst: With interest rates reaching the top of their cycle, now is a good time to buy bonds, says  Sylvia Morris
fields.trailText: With interest rates reaching the top of their cycle, now is a good time to buy bonds, says Sylvia Morris.
fields.body:
One result of the recent rises in interest rates has been a spate of launches of new limited-issue, fixed-rate bonds. Several banks and building societies now offer savers a tempting deal with some of these bonds paying 7 per cent or more a year before tax (worth 5.60 per cent after 20 per cent savings tax). The only catch is that savers must be willing to tie up their money for between one and three years.

Until recently, for example, Northern Rock, which has earned a reputation for offering top-paying bonds of this type, was offering a mouth-watering 7.50 per cent a year (6 per cent) on a minimum investment of £1,000. Savers can choose a fixed term of one, two or three years and opt for monthly income, though the rate payable fell to 7.25 per cent (5.80 per cent) if you took this option.

Woolwich and Bristol & West are also regularly among the leaders on these fixed-rate bonds, and building society members should also check what their society offers. Nationwide, Yorkshire and Britannia all run limited-issue bonds exclusively for their members, typically those of at least three years' standing.

Woolwich's latest offerings include fixed-rate bonds paying 6.65 per cent (5.32 per cent) annually for two years or 7 per cent (5.60 per cent) a year for three years on a minimum deposit of £500. Savers who choose to take income monthly will get slightly lower annual rates but the two-year deal is better than anything available on longer-term bonds. The best five-year fixed-rate bond is from Norwich & Peterborough, at 6.90 per cent a year (5.52 per cent).

Nor is it necessarily worth waiting for improvements. Analysts expect Bank of England base rates to rise further this year, but increases are already priced into the rates available on one, two and three-year bonds.

If you fix now, chances are you will be doing so at close to the top of the market. Dharshini David, UK economist at HSBC, says: 'We expect base rates to rise to 6.5 per cent by late spring but to fall to 6.25 per cent by the end of the year. Inflation is low so there is no need for aggressive rises in interest rates. These fixed-rate bonds from banks and building societies could be at or very near their peak.'

At Merrill Lynch, UK economist Paul Turnbull agrees. 'Base rates are near their peak but might rise to 6.25 or even 6.5 per cent.

'We are predicting base rates at 6.25 per cent at the end of this year and 5.75 per cent 12 months later,' he says.

Higher-rate taxpayers will, howeve, do better still with National Savings Certificates. The two-year third issue fixed-rate certificates pay a tax-free 4.75 per cent a year. This is the equivalent of earning 7.92 per cent before tax for higher-rate taxpayers, which cannot be bettered in the private sector. You can invest up to £10,000 in this latest issue, on top of any money you re-invest from any existing National Savings Certificates you have due to mature while this issue is on sale.

But be careful with escalator bonds, launches of which are currently also popular with banks and building societies. These pay a fixed rate of interest each year for the term of the bond. webTitle: Branch out for a better deal

fields.headline: Branch out for a better deal
fields.standfirst: Colin Frier guides you through the bewildering array of banking services
fields.trailText: Colin Frier guides you through the bewildering array of banking services
fields.body:
If you're unhappy with your bank, don't worry, you're not alone - 46 per cent of people in the UK feel the same way. David Middleton, a director of the Banking Relations Consultancy, is not surprised. 'It's clear that customers are looking for innovations that meet their needs, and classically the banks have never met anybody's except their own.'

What is more surprising is that despite high levels of customer dissatisfaction and attacks by consumer groups for excessive charges, rip-off products and branch closures, the UK's traditional banks have retained the loyalty of most customers.

Don Cruickshank,the Government's banking watchdog, has recommended sweeping changes to the banking industry after an 18-month inquiry. But change, along the lines he recommends, is likely to take some time to implement.

It is also worth noting that while competition is not as fierce as Cruickshank believes it should be, not all banks are alike. If the publicity generated by his report has prompted you to consider switching accounts, the first question to ask is whether you're likely to be in credit or in the red.

For those with credit balances, it is vital to compare the rates of interest available. On balances of less than £1,000, these range from a derisory 0.10 per cent offered by the 'big four', to 4.75 per cent from Smile, the Internet-only arm of the Co-operative Bank.

On balances of £1,000 and over but less than £5,000, Sun Bank offers 4.8 per cent, while those with more than £5,000 but less than £49,000 in their account will get 5.75 per cent from AMC Bank. Portman Building Society pays 6.25 per cent on amounts of £50,000 or more. With the exception of Smile, which pays interest monthly, a disadvantage with many higher rate accounts is that interest is usually paid quarterly, or even yearly.

So long as you stay in credit, free banking comes as standard with most current accounts. But some of the more upmarket accounts, such as NatWest's Advantage Gold, charge a monthly fee, and some stipulate that you must remain in credit.

For those with an overdraft, charges vary considerably, and anyone comparing them should be wary - the devil is in the detail. A simple comparison of overdraft rates shows that apart from Smile's 9.9 per cent, some of the best are provided by the Woolwich, 11.0 per cent, and the Nationwide, 11.9 per cent.

At the other end of the scale, among the highest are Barclays and Lloyds, both of whom charge 18.8 per cent; though even this is topped by the Co-operative Bank's 19.56 per cent. But don't assume you can transfer your existing overdraft to a new account - they are negotiable and subject to status.

Simplistic comparisons, however, won't always tell you the cost of running an overdraft on a particular account. With most, there is a monthly fee, usually between £5 and £8. And in addition, there may be a one-off arrangement fee, typically between £20 and £30, or a percentage of the amount overdrawn.

Stuart Coverley, information officer for the National Federation of Consumer Groups, said: 'These very big overdraft charges are not related to the interest being paid on current accounts, which on a £500 balance amounts to only a few coppers.'

However, Abbey National, Halifax and Nationwide customers don't incur either of these fees, with the added advantage of comparatively modest overdraft rates of 13.4 per cent, 14.20 per cent and 11.9 per cent respectively.

If you're overdrawn occasionally, but only by a small amount, some accounts offer interest-free overdrafts between £10 and £500. But there are often strings attached - the Halifax's £100 overdraft depends on customers having a minimum monthly income of £500. For those prone to exceeding their overdraft, many current account providers also offer an overdraft buffer, which permits customers to exceed their overdraft without the heavy additional charges associated with an unauthorised overdraft. Smile provides a buffer of £500; on most accounts it will be between £10 and £100.

For those who prefer traditional over-the-counter banking, the news that NatWest and Lloyds intend to shut 600 branches is not reassuring. But even after these closures all the major banks will retain extensive branch networks. Building societies with strong links to their local communities are also less likely than most to simply close their branches and walk away.

But when branches do close, customers become even more dependent on the 27,000 cash machines (ATMs) dispersed around the country. Many of these are no longer free, and although banks voted last week to outlaw double charging, they will be free to introduce charges at machines for non-customers from next year.

Coverley says that most customers' experience of telephone banking has been positive. He said: 'Although engaged lines can cause problems, telephone banking seems satisfactory.' But not all services are fully staffed 24 hours a day. Barclays is limited to Monday to Friday 7am to 11pm, and Saturdays, Sundays and Bank Holidays 9am to 5pm. At other times, transactions or inquiries must be made through the keypad of your telephone. First Direct is the only telephone-only bank in the UK and has been popular with customers.

Those thinking of banking online will discover that most major banks already have an Internet presence. Others, such as Abbey National, are planning to join up.

For those attracted by the prospect of higher interest rates, Smile pays 4.75 per cent. But those expecting a better deal on overdrafts may be disappointed - rates are often no better than those available at the branch, though Smile offers an attractive 9.9 per cent. Coverley says: 'I'm more concerned about those customers who don't have a way in to accessing the Internet.' And so far, he says, there have been few complaints.

webTitle: Gilts aren't as good as they look

fields.headline: Gilts aren't as good as they look
fields.trailText: The announcement that the Government intended to issue more than expected of its loan stock, or gilts, would once have been bad news.
fields.body:
The announcement that the Government intended to issue more than expected of its loan stock, or gilts, would once have been bad news.

But when Gordon Brown said in the Budget that he would issue £12.2 billion of gilts in the coming year, when no new issues had been expected, the City cheered.

This seems all the more surprising given the poor performance of the gilt market over the past year: the total return has averaged about 1 per cent, well below shares or building society deposits.

The enthusiasm had less to do with the performance of gilts than an imbalance of supply and demand. Pension funds are desperate to buy them, particularly those with some years to maturity, to comply with recent legislation on funding the cost of their pensions.

But Government borrowing has been falling so rapidly that there have not been enough to go round: indeed, the planned £12.2bn will not even compensate for the £18.6bn of gilts which will reach maturity and be repaid this year.

In most markets, the combination of investors anxious to buy and limited supply would guarantee a good performance. So should private shareholders follow the professionals into the gilt market? In this case, the answer is a definite no.

While supply is a factor in the performance of gilts, the real driver of the market is the performance of the economy. Last year's poor gilts' performance reflected the strength of the economy. A year ago, many pundits were predicting a recession. In fact, growth accelerated, interest rates had to rise to dampen demand, and some people fear that the rate of growth will mean an increase in inflation.

That is bad news for gilts, and there is no sign of the outlook changing. Indeed, some economists predict that Brown's spending plans mean that interest rates will have to rise higher than expected, putting a further dampener on the market.

To make matters worse, a review of the minimum pension funding legislation could encourage them to buy corporate bonds - debt issued by companies - instead of gilts. Long-dated gilts, with more than 15 years to maturity, have been doing much better than short ones, producing a return of 3.52 per cent over the past 12 months compared with minus 0.57 per cent. If some of the pension fund demand is switched to corporate bonds, that could change.

But this is not necessarily good news for corporate bonds. Pension funds will buy only top-grade bonds from large, established com panies, and their performance is driven by the same factors as gilts. Indeed, they did little better than gilts last year. A strong economy could be good news for higher-risk bonds, issued by smaller or less sound lenders. But it means higher profits and a greater probability of the bond being repaid.

Last year's poor perfor mance was doubly unfortunate for investors. Both gilts and corporate bonds had had five spectacular years, prompting the launch of many new unit trusts. Most have done poorly.

This underlines the investment adage: when everyone thinks it is a good time to launch a fund, it is rarely a good time to buy.

fields.headline: Loyalty pays only so much
fields.standfirst: Customers are wary of reward schemes, says   Colin Frier
fields.trailText: Customers are wary of reward schemes, says Colin Frier
fields.body:
If you are thinking of a financial clearout, why not start with the plastic loyalty cards in your wallet? There's a 75 per cent chance of you having at least one, but you may also be what is termed 'a promiscuous shopper' and have more than 20.

Despite their proliferation, however, questions remain about whether loyalty schemes are of much benefit to customers. Allyson Stewart-Allen, a director of International Marketing Partners, says: 'A major problem with loyalty schemes is the very low level of customer redemption. This is because programmes aren't enticing enough.'

She says the key to a successful scheme is the ease with which customers can cash in points. 'But with 0845 numbers, waiting on the line and paperwork, people can't be bothered.'

She adds that car rental companies 'put customers through a few hoops' and suspects that customers realise that firms don't really want them to take up offers. And she recalls an Argos scheme that died because not every petrol station honoured it.

In contrast, Stewart-Allen says, supermarket loyalty schemes are well run. 'The reason why they are successful is because redemption at supermarkets is easy.'

But Hugh Phillips, senior lecturer in retail marketing at De Montfort University, disagrees: 'With a 1 per cent reduction in prices on average, and with the amount of spending required to earn a little very high, customers are asking is it worth it?'

His view is given some credence by the 23 per cent of respondents in a 1999 Mintel survey who agreed that it took too long to earn anything worthwhile.

But though customers may be questioning the generosity of the loyalty programmes, companies such as Tesco claim to have virtually eliminated the problem of non-redemption, with 93 per cent of their Clubcard vouchers being traded in. A spokesperson says: 'We have the highest redemption figure among anyone offering a reward scheme.'

Professor Merlin Stone, senior manager with management consultant Mummert & Partner, says: 'Simple cash redemption clearly works best, and of course it can be forced through reductions on subsequent purchases, or pushed at the point of sale [as in Sainsbury's].'

He says that, compared to US schemes, those in the UK have a better financial basis, which encourages customers to redeem points. As a result, he says, 'Sainsbury's Reward scheme virtually guarantees close to 100 per cent take-up.'

But the performance of loyalty programmes can be both patchy and complex. A spokesperson for Tesco says that only one in five Clubcard coupons, which have to be exchanged for specific types of goods within a certain time limit, are recouped.

Stone says even the best-run schemes have difficulties getting customers to cash in points. 'Many customers seem not to wish to redeem but to collect for something in the future, and some become inactive with points balances.'

He says that these factors, and the time lag between issuing and redeeming points, explain why the Boots Advantage scheme's 10.5 million members have redeemed only 52 per cent of points issued.

But Stone argues that once the rate at which points are issued levels off, the redemption rate will be much higher. And furthermore, he says, it is in Boots's own interest to get its members to redeem, as they are 70 per cent more valuable to the company than other shoppers.

Stephen Foster, editor of Checkout Magazine, says loyalty cards are essentially 'the old idea of the "divi" but using new technology', to encourage people to spend so they get more. He admits that people have lots of points worth millions outstanding on different cards, but says that 'this probably works out at about 52p per person, which makes it not worth their while to drive down to the supermarket'.

No group is more zealous at travelling to collect points than members of the 120 frequent flyer programmes worldwide. These include British Airways Executive Club with 3 million members, and the smaller British Midland Diamond Club, and Virgin Atlantic's Virgin Freeway. According to the US company Frequent Flyer Services, these programmes in the airline, hotel, car rental and credit card industries have more than 75 million members, earning more than 650 billion air miles a year.

Simon Evans, industry affairs adviser at the Air Transport User's Council, is not surprised that, given the figures involved, the average frequent flyer is sitting on 50,000 air miles, which would take them between five and six years to earn.

He believes many frequent flyers don't understand that recouped air miles are usually available only on off-peak services, and 'booking is bound by flight capacity, so they can't always get the flights they want'. Despite the restrictions, however, Evans says members are keen to collect as many points as possible, with companies even suspecting executives of arranging unnecessary meetings to clock up points.

webTitle: Nat Power to halve payout again

fields.headline: Nat Power to halve payout again
fields.trailText: Electricity generator National Power is poised to halve its dividend for a second time following the planned demerger of its international power business.
fields.body:
Electricity generator National Power is poised to halve its dividend for a second time following the planned demerger of its international power business.

The group last week briefed analysts ahead of results, due mid-May. And now, forecasts of dividends from the two companies - International Power and the domestic npower - have been slashed to just 7p for the year to next March.

Last November, the group warned that dividends for the year just ended would be slashed from 28.6p to 15p because of the loss of earnings following the sale of its Drax power station. Most investors expected that 15p pay-out to continue post-demerger.

But news of the further halving is expected to prompt heavy selling of National Power shares. They have already fallen more than a quarter since the demerger was announced. After the cut, the yield will fall to just 2.2 per cent - half the average for the utility sector and less than a quarter of the 10 per cent yield at rival PowerGen.

National Power says it made it clear in November, when it announced the demerger, that the 15p dividend should not be seen as a benchmark for future pay-outs. It said that International Power would not pay dividends, as it would reinvest any earnings for future growth, and npower aims to have similar dividend cover as others in the industry, suggesting a pay-out of 2p.

The cut is the latest in a series of shocks for National Power shareholders. Chief executive Keith Henry left last year. International contracts in Pakistan have gone wrong and the company stunned the City by starting bid talks with United Utilities.

 Power giant National Grid is planning to double its electricity transmission operations in New England as part of its US expansion, writes Oliver Morgan.

Chief executive David Jones is keen to capitalise on the company's £2.1 billion acquisition of New England Electric System (NEES). Jones aims to roll out a broadband telecoms network along National Grid's US power network. Operators would lease lines and use their own electronic equipment to provide Internet, entertainment and telephone services.

National Grid is currently in talks with companies including NEES neighbour Northeast Utilities, itself recently taken over, about leasing its electricity transmission network.
