webTitle: How to tell if you are loved

fields.headline: How to tell if you are loved
fields.trailText: 1. Look at tea and coffee provision. If you pay 17p for a nasty beaker of tea from a vending machine, it's a sign that your employer isn't cherishing your essential humanity. If they have done away with the tea lady, and do not encourage tea breaks, their appreciation of your individuality is close to nil. Good employers appreciate that staff should have some degree of comfort so they can focus on their work instead of grumbling.
fields.body:
1. Look at tea and coffee provision. If you pay 17p for a nasty beaker of tea from a vending machine, it's a sign that your employer isn't cherishing your essential humanity. If they have done away with the tea lady, and do not encourage tea breaks, their appreciation of your individuality is close to nil. Good employers appreciate that staff should have some degree of comfort so they can focus on their work instead of grumbling.

2. See how much control you have over your physical environment. If you are all prisoners of your air conditioning system - and don't even know who to turn to when it breaks down - your employer is forgetting your basic human needs. Sensible employers will give you a helpline to Fred who will repair broken equipment. In unloving environments, people do not clean up after themselves because they do not care about their workplace, or do not know how to maintain it.

3. Check the toilets - 'one of the most important meeting places in the workplace,' according to Holli Rowan of architect DEGW. 'A lot of the most important and confidential discussions go on there. You can tell a lot about an organisation by its toilets.' The provision of space, the cleanness of towels and size of mirrors are all indications of how much you are loved. Mean cubicles and poor hygiene tell you your bosses' attitudes to your welfare.

4. Don't search for lavish demonstrations of care, says workplace architect and designer Kathy Tilney of Tilney Shane: 'Workplace cafes don't have to be big and grand to be good. Being flexible is more important now than the traditional approach of giving people three-course meals between 1 and 2pm.'

5. Expect to be consulted by employers who respect you. Staff who are given no control over desk design, the way they do their job, their hours and other basic terms are all square pegs being squeezed into round holes. 'Making people feel like individuals gives them greater self-esteem,' says Tilney. 'And nine-and-a-half people out of 10 understand what is needed and will respond well if they are trusted.'

webTitle: So you want to own a student house...

fields.headline: So you want to own a student house...
fields.standfirst: If your kids are at college, should you buy them a place, asks  Janet Carberry
fields.trailText: If your kids are at college, should you buy them a place, asks Janet Carberry.
fields.body:
At the end of last summer you packed their essential belongings - CD player, computer, portable TV - and drove them to their new home for the next three years, university.

Now the novelty of communal living is wearing thin for first-year students and what they really want is their own place, to share with one or two friends. So what to do? One idea is to buy a property for them. But will it really be a good investment?

Malcolm Harrison of the Association of Residential Lettings Agents (Arla) warns: 'Buy-to-let is a medium- to long-term investment, not simply for while your child is at university, you need to think of it as at least 10 years.'

The golden rule 'location, location, location' has never applied more than when buying a property for investment. It is sensible to contact an established estate/letting agent to find out where the better areas are and what kind of rents they command.

Property hot and cold spots around the country are largely linked to employment. Bristol has seen prices up 20 per cent, Manchester by 5 to 10 per cent, whereas the North and Scotland remain below the national average.

If you are considering buying in a hot spot it may be too late - the demand might already have outstripped supply. And if you're looking at a cold spot it may be that employment opportunities are limited and so is the potential for future rents.

Manchester, with its significant student population, could still be a good investment. Robert Jordan, of Robert Jordan and Associates which has seven offices throughout Cheshire and Manchester, advises: 'The capital growth a year or two back might have been around 10 - 12 per cent, you're not going to get that, more like 8 per cent, but that's not a bad rate of interest.'

His advice on location is simple - avoid the established student areas. While you may be able to buy a terraced turn-of-the-century property in Whalley Range for around £75,000, he points out: 'These are properties you might struggle to sell, have large management costs and will not give you good capital growth.'

On the other hand, around £100,000-£150,000 will buy a modern 2-3 bed apartment in Salford Quays, which will be far more lettable when your child has moved on. Current rents there are about £850 per month and attract professionals - accountants, IT workers - who rent to remain mobile.

Paul Hicks of Fulfords, which has 38 branches across Devon and Cornwall, explains the maths. 'In Plymouth a four-bed terrace can be bought for £50-60,000, on which a mortgage would currently cost around £4,200 per year.'

With your child in one room and three friends paying £40 per week rent, even for 10 months of the year, you would have £5,200 coming in - add your child's rent and the deal is worth £7,000, which is £3,000 'profit'. Add to this the capital growth in the property over the period of time you own it - but don't forget to subtract the costs of being a landlord, including agents' fees which are currently around 10 per cent of the rent.

And as Alan Thurlow of Leaders, which has offices in Sussex, Hampshire and south-east London points out: 'You've got to consider the times it will be empty, fees, insurance, maintenance - even non-payment of rent.'

If you are considering buying to let you can contact The Association of Residential Lettings Agents hotline (01923 896555). Arla will send you an advice booklet and put you in touch with a member in the area.

fields.headline: Dicing with  debt
fields.standfirst: Anyone can be a share dealer. But, asks  Jill Insley, are investors taking unacceptable risks?
fields.trailText: Anyone can be a share dealer. But, asks Jill Insley, are investors taking unacceptable risks?
fields.body:
Britain is experiencing a gold rush. Huge increases in the prices of Internet and other high technology shares, cheap dealing and easy access to information have lured a new wave of investors to start trading.

After years when share dealing was seen as a pursuit for the rich upper-middle classes, the investing public has now decided that Gordon Gekko was right. Greed is good, and shares are sexy.

Rather than seek the advice of stockbrokers, however, these new investors are doing it for themselves. Home computers are switched on at daybreak as they prepare to study the latest stock market movements and to decide what to buy and sell. Some are making small fortunes.

The demand for execution-only stockbroking services - where investors buy and sell without advice - is so high that several firms have had to suspend services temporarily while they catch up with existing orders.

Skipton Building Society's service, Dealwise, for example, stopped taking new customers in January, and is still working for existing ones only. Others have left clients hanging on the phone for up to an hour for a dealer to become available.

Barclays Stockbrokers, stopped taking deals involving share certificates - proof of ownership - over the telephone to speed up the processing time, instead accepting only nominee business. It went from handling about 6,000 deals a day last summer to 9,000 a day in November.

Steve Whiteside, managing director of Barclays' execution-only business, says: 'The stock market went up by about 500 points early in November, and we thought the number of deals might subside when the market calmed. But the volumes of deals continued.'

In fact by January the number of deals had risen to 12,000 a day (compared with 7,500 a day last year), and despite a turbulent market in March, this has fallen only slightly to 11,500 a day.

But Whiteside says it's not the actual deals that brokers are struggling with, but the sheer volume of clients contacting call centres. 'In January 1998 we had 125,000 calls, but this January we had 970,000.

'It's not just that more people are taking up dealing, they're trading more often. We are assuming this is permanent. We've taken on 150 more staff in our Scottish call centre, and we're recruiting 50-plus a month.'

Immediate access to information through Internet chat has encouraged the new investors to accept high risks. Research by Proshare, which promotes share ownership, shows that the average online portfolio has only 40 per cent of its money in collective funds and FTSE 100 shares.

More than 20 per cent of online investors have tried day trading - buying and selling a shareholding the same day for a quick profit - and 7 per cent have never owned shares before.

The question now is whether it will all end in tears. Polls indicate that these new investors see dealing as a bit of adrenaline-inducing fun.

But Barclays' Steve Whiteside says: 'A lot of the people now in the market have not experienced a correction, and I'm not sure how they will react.'

Bernice Cohen, a housewife who took up day trading in the Nineties and wrote about it, says investors are taking dangerous risks.

'Seventy per cent of day traders make losses,' she warns. 'Prices are falling as we speak. The biotech companies have come to the fore now: these are all high risk companies. They have huge debts and no revenue.

'This is not a recipe for long-term wealth. These people are dicing with debt.'

fields.headline: Mortgage crisis could hit 3m households
fields.trailText: The growing scale of the endowment mortgage crisis was revealed yesterday after Standard Life admitted that nearly half its 1.2m policies are off target and on current projections will not fully repay the mortgages of 530,000 customers.
fields.body:
The growing scale of the endowment mortgage crisis was revealed yesterday after Standard Life admitted that nearly half its 1.2m policies are off target and on current projections will not fully repay the mortgages of 530,000 customers.

Other leading life companies admit that shortfalls are affecting around half of all endowment policies, compared with predictions of 10% to 15% five months ago. In all, 5m policies could be affected. With between 13m and 14m households in some form of mortgage debt - around half of them with endowments - 3m households could be in shortfall.

A survey by the Guardian this week identifies Lloyds TSB customers as having the biggest endowment headache. A review of its 300,000 endowments has found that 80% are off target, and homeowners will have to cough up pre mium increases of between 25% and 40% to get back on track.

Only in the past few weeks have detailed letters outlining individual shortfalls started to go to the UK's 10m endowment policyholders.

The majority of endowment holders with large shortfalls are expected to bridge the gap by changing part of their mortgage into a repayment loan.

webTitle: Dear Sir, sorry - we can't pay off your loan

fields.headline: Dear Sir, sorry - we can't pay off your loan
fields.standfirst:
Up and down the country letters bearing news of broken promises are landing on the doormats of people who will now struggle to meet their mortgage commitments. Tony Levene and Patrick Collinson report
Money Unlimited
fields.trailText: Homebuyers face a double whammy. From today, they lose Miras relief - costing £18 a month extra on most loans. But that is overshadowed by the potential failure of endowments to match promises made when they were sold.
fields.body:
Homebuyers face a double whammy. From today, they lose Miras relief - costing £18 a month extra on most loans. But that is overshadowed by the potential failure of endowments to match promises made when they were sold.

We reveal that up to 80% of policyholders of some life companies face endowment mortgage failure. Our exclusive exposé of the scale of mortgage shortfall misery last October pales into insignificance compared with the figures coming out of life offices today, now that most policies have been assessed.

Legal & General is leading the way in telling customers - including many Northern Rock and Cheltenham & Gloucester borrowers - whether their plan will pass muster. Other insurers will follow in their footsteps over the coming months.

These shortfalls could cost homebuyers with typical £60,000 loans up to £90 a month extra if they decide to top up their policies. On these pages, we feature three real life case studies - all requested anonymity - and the options they can take.

One is "Aberdeen man", with a projected shortfall of £18,000 on an endowment supposed to pay off a mortgage of £60,000 in 12 years' time. The second is "East London woman" with a projected shortfall of £12,200 on a £50,000 mortgage due to be paid off in 17 years. The third is "Middlesex man", with an expected shortfall of £5,400 on a mortgage of £39,000 due for repayment in 13 years. They are just three of many readers who have sent us details of their failing endowments with almost every major life office.

Insurers are no longer allowed to 'guide' shortfall customers towards taking out an endowment top-up - and many people will not want to throw good money after bad. What should you do? You have a wide range of options; use our guide to work out the best course forward. But whatever you do, don't surrender or sell your endowment without taking advice. You have had the commission and cost pain of the early years - there could still be a gain to come.

Your options

Top up the endowment

This was the option insurers pushed shortfall customers towards until recent FSA rulings outlawed this practice. The advantage is simplicity - all the life company has to do is to amend the policy. There is no need to contact lenders or set up new plans.

But it could be throwing good money after bad. There is no guarantee that the enhanced sum will be any more successful in paying off the loan in full if bonus rates continue to fall - any stock market shake out would also knock terminal bonuses. Some companies such as Allied Dunbar charge new upfront fees.

Topping up the policy assuming a 6% return before charges would cost:

1 Aberdeen man currently paying £91 per month an extra £88 a month to meet the £18,200 shortfall on a £60,000 target with 12 years to go

2 East London woman currently paying £67 a month an extra £35 a month to meet the estimated £12,200 shortfall on a £50,000 loan over 10 years.

3 Middlesex man currently paying £51 a month an extra £23 a month to meet a £5,380 shortfall on a £39,000 loan over 13 years.

Do nothing

This can be an attractive choice for those with policies which are on track to pay off the plan at 8% and only narrowly fail at 6% - especially if you have spare savings you could use if there is a real shortfall after 25 years.

Bonus rates on endowments could change substantially over the next decade - up as well as down. If you are gambling on your endow ment performance improving, check what the company's past performance has looked like. Figures from Money Management magazine show Axa Sun Life (ex Equity & Law), Clerical Medical, Friends Provident, Norwich Union, Scottish Widows and Standard life are the only with-profits offices to appear at least 20 times in the top 10 position for 25-year plans in any one of the past 30 years for with-profits plans.

Life companies which have never hit the top 10 include: Britannia Life, Canada Life, Colonial, Co-operative, Crusader, London & Manchester, MGM, NPI, NFU Mutual, National Mutual, Pearl, Prudential, Refuge, Reliance Mutual, Scottish Equitable, Sun Life, Swiss Life, Teachers Provident and United Friendly.

Invest in an Isa

You can start building a separate cash pot through regular monthly savings into an Individual Savings Account, and figures below suggest it's slightly cheaper than topping up an endowment. Isas are free of income and capital gains tax and tend to have lower charges than endowments. If the mortgage redemption date is more than five years away, it makes sense to buy a share-based rather than cash Isa. Go for a blue chip or tracker fund rather than a risky hi-tech trust.

But remember that share Isas are not risk-free; like endowments, your payout depends on future investment conditions. What's more, for small shortfalls, the minimum monthly savings levels - usually £50 - will probably be much more than you need.

For our three case studies, Fidelity Investments calculated how much they would have to put into a fund to make up the shortfall, assuming an initial Isa charge of 3.25% and an annual charge of 1.5%. The projection is at 7%, to take into account the tax free benefits of an Isa over an endowment. Fidelity's minimum investment is £50 per month.

1 To fund £18,200 in 12 years' time, Aberdeen man will have to pay £83 per month, or £94 per month if investment growth is predicted to be 5% per annum.

2 East London woman would have to pay £33 per month to fund £12,200 in 17 years' time, or £39 if growth is 5%.

3 Middlesex man would have to pay £22 per month over 13 years to hit £5,380, or £25 if growth is 5%.

Change part of the mortgage into a repayment loan

This is expected to be the most common action taken to avoid a shortfall. You carry on paying your endowment premium and increase payments against your mortgage. Halifax is waiving its standard £50 conversion fee for all shortfall victims and C&G is waiving its £100 fee. Abbey National charges £75 and will only waive it if your shortfall is with an Abbey National Life endowment. The figures below assume a mortgage interest rate of 7.74%

1 Aberdeen man's £60,000 mortgage is £18,200 off target, and converting that part to repayment will increase his monthly payment by £80 from £387 to £467.

2 East London woman will see her mortgage go up £30 per month from £322 to £352 to ensure that £12,200 is repaid, and the balance of her £50,000 mortgage is paid off by the endowment.

3 Middlesex man's mortgage goes up to £273 from £252, an increase of £21, ensuring that £5,380 of his £39,000 mortgage is repaid when the endowment matures.

Extend the plan's life

This is very much the last resort because interest charges will continue to rack up on an interest-only mortgage. Insurers can offer two choices - extend the life of the policy so that you continue to pay the same premium or re-investing the proceeds on maturity, and leave it for a few more years to grow. The latter course could have life and critical illness cover implications - it would be longer so the interest bill would be greater.

1 Aberdeen man must wait six years three months if he stopped altogether - additional interest at 7.75% would be £29,062. Continuing present premiums would stretch the period by 4 years at a £20,925 interest cost.

2 East London woman would have to wait 4 years and 4 months if nothing extra was paid or 3 years carrying on with present premiums.

3 Middlesex man would have to wait 30 months if he stopped paying or 23 months if he carried on.

Remortgage

You could end up coming out of the endowment disaster quids in if you use it as an opportunity to switch to a cheaper lender. If you are on a standard variable rate (so long as you have no redemption penalties) it's almost certain a broker can find you a better deal. One lender, First Active, calculates that rather than topping up a endowment with £20 per month, the same money paid into a First Active current account mortgage would save £13,327 in interest and pay off the mortgage two years and eight months early.

We reveal that up to 80% of policyholders of some life companies face endowment mortgage failure. Our exclusive exposé of the scale of mortgage shortfall misery last October pales into insignificance compared with the figures coming out of life offices today, now that most policies have been assessed. Legal & General is leading the way in telling customers - including many Northern Rock and Cheltenham & Gloucester borrowers - whether their plan will pass muster. Other insurers will follow in their footsteps over the coming months. These shortfalls could cost homebuyers with typical £60,000 loans up to £90 a month extra if they decide to top up their policies. On these pages, we feature three real life case studies - all requested anonymity - and the options they can take. One is "Aberdeen man", with a projected shortfall of £18,000 on an endowment supposed to pay off a mortgage of £60,000 in 12 years' time. The second is "East London woman" with a projected shortfall of £12,200 on a £50,000 mortgage due to be paid off in 17 years. The third is "Middlesex man", with an expected shortfall of £5,400 on a mortgage of £39,000 due for repayment in 13 years. They are just three of many readers who have sent us details of their failing endowments with almost every major life office. Insurers are no longer allowed to 'guide' shortfall customers towards taking out an endowment top-up - and many people will not want to throw good money after bad. What should you do? You have a wide range of options; use our guide to work out the best course forward. But whatever you do, don't surrender or sell your endowment without taking advice. You have had the commission and cost pain of the early years - there could still be a gain to come. Your options Top up the endowment This was the option insurers pushed shortfall customers towards until recent FSA rulings outlawed this practice. The advantage is simplicity - all the life company has to do is to amend the policy. There is no need to contact lenders or set up new plans. But it could be throwing good money after bad. There is no guarantee that the enhanced sum will be any more successful in paying off the loan in full if bonus rates continue to fall - any stock market shake out would also knock terminal bonuses. Some companies such as Allied Dunbar charge new upfront fees. Topping up the policy assuming a 6% return before charges would cost: 1 Aberdeen man currently paying £91 per month an extra £88 a month to meet the £18,200 shortfall on a £60,000 target with 12 years to go 2 East London woman currently paying £67 a month an extra £35 a month to meet the estimated £12,200 shortfall on a £50,000 loan over 10 years. 3 Middlesex man currently paying £51 a month an extra £23 a month to meet a £5,380 shortfall on a £39,000 loan over 13 years. Do nothing This can be an attractive choice for those with policies which are on track to pay off the plan at 8% and only narrowly fail at 6% - especially if you have spare savings you could use if there is a real shortfall after 25 years. Bonus rates on endowments could change substantially over the next decade - up as well as down. If you are gambling on your endow ment performance improving, check what the company's past performance has looked like. Figures from Money Management magazine show Axa Sun Life (ex Equity & Law), Clerical Medical, Friends Provident, Norwich Union, Scottish Widows and Standard life are the only with-profits offices to appear at least 20 times in the top 10 position for 25-year plans in any one of the past 30 years for with-profits plans. Life companies which have never hit the top 10 include: Britannia Life, Canada Life, Colonial, Co-operative, Crusader, London & Manchester, MGM, NPI, NFU Mutual, National Mutual, Pearl, Prudential, Refuge, Reliance Mutual, Scottish Equitable, Sun Life, Swiss Life, Teachers Provident and United Friendly. Invest in an Isa You can start building a separate cash pot through regular monthly savings into an Individual Savings Account, and figures below suggest it's slightly cheaper than topping up an endowment. Isas are free of income and capital gains tax and tend to have lower charges than endowments. If the mortgage redemption date is more than five years away, it makes sense to buy a share-based rather than cash Isa. Go for a blue chip or tracker fund rather than a risky hi-tech trust. But remember that share Isas are not risk-free; like endowments, your payout depends on future investment conditions. What's more, for small shortfalls, the minimum monthly savings levels - usually £50 - will probably be much more than you need. For our three case studies, Fidelity Investments calculated how much they would have to put into a fund to make up the shortfall, assuming an initial Isa charge of 3.25% and an annual charge of 1.5%. The projection is at 7%, to take into account the tax free benefits of an Isa over an endowment. Fidelity's minimum investment is £50 per month. 1 To fund £18,200 in 12 years' time, Aberdeen man will have to pay £83 per month, or £94 per month if investment growth is predicted to be 5% per annum. 2 East London woman would have to pay £33 per month to fund £12,200 in 17 years' time, or £39 if growth is 5%. 3 Middlesex man would have to pay £22 per month over 13 years to hit £5,380, or £25 if growth is 5%. Change part of the mortgage into a repayment loan This is expected to be the most common action taken to avoid a shortfall. You carry on paying your endowment premium and increase payments against your mortgage. Halifax is waiving its standard £50 conversion fee for all shortfall victims and C&G is waiving its £100 fee. Abbey National charges £75 and will only waive it if your shortfall is with an Abbey National Life endowment. The figures below assume a mortgage interest rate of 7.74% 1 Aberdeen man's £60,000 mortgage is £18,200 off target, and converting that part to repayment will increase his monthly payment by £80 from £387 to £467. 2 East London woman will see her mortgage go up £30 per month from £322 to £352 to ensure that £12,200 is repaid, and the balance of her £50,000 mortgage is paid off by the endowment. 3 Middlesex man's mortgage goes up to £273 from £252, an increase of £21, ensuring that £5,380 of his £39,000 mortgage is repaid when the endowment matures. Extend the plan's life This is very much the last resort because interest charges will continue to rack up on an interest-only mortgage. Insurers can offer two choices - extend the life of the policy so that you continue to pay the same premium or re-investing the proceeds on maturity, and leave it for a few more years to grow. The latter course could have life and critical illness cover implications - it would be longer so the interest bill would be greater. 1 Aberdeen man must wait six years three months if he stopped altogether - additional interest at 7.75% would be £29,062. Continuing present premiums would stretch the period by 4 years at a £20,925 interest cost. 2 East London woman would have to wait 4 years and 4 months if nothing extra was paid or 3 years carrying on with present premiums. 3 Middlesex man would have to wait 30 months if he stopped paying or 23 months if he carried on. Remortgage You could end up coming out of the endowment disaster quids in if you use it as an opportunity to switch to a cheaper lender. If you are on a standard variable rate (so long as you have no redemption penalties) it's almost certain a broker can find you a better deal. One lender, First Active, calculates that rather than topping up a endowment with £20 per month, the same money paid into a First Active current account mortgage would save £13,327 in interest and pay off the mortgage two years and eight months early.

fields.headline: Tigana in the Fulham frame
fields.trailText: Jean Tigana, the celebrated former French international midfielder and former Monaco coach, appears to be rivalling Terry Venables and Ruud Gullit as a high-profile candidate to take over this summer with the brief of winning promotion to the Premiership.
fields.body:
Karlheinz Riedle, Fulham's temporary manager, enlisted the vast experience of Roy Evans as his No2 yesterday but Mohamed Al Fayed is looking beyond this pair for the man to fulfil his ambitions.

As Evans rejoined the German he signed for Liverpool three years ago, speculation over the full-time job at Craven Cottage was fuelled by the emergence of a foreign contender.

Jean Tigana, the celebrated former French international midfielder and former Monaco coach, appears to be rivalling Terry Venables and Ruud Gullit as a high-profile candidate to take over this summer with the brief of winning promotion to the Premiership.

Two months after sounding out Eric Cantona, the Fulham hierarchy turned to another Frenchman and Tigana is reportedly in negotiations with the west London club.

Unlike Venables and Gullit, however, Tigana - despite his obvious playing and coaching pedigree- would represent a clear gamble given his lack of experience of English football, which might be a distinct disadvantage at First Division level. The 44-year-old Frenchman is currently working as an agent and as a coach with the French Football Federation.

Evans's role is seen as temporary and Riedle, in charge for the last seven games of the season, is also not considered a major player for the post made vacant by Paul Bracewell's sacking this week.

Kevin Keegan's selection problems before the summer's European championship have been eased by Uefa making two changes to rules on squad announcements.

After pressure from England, backed by Germany, Spain and Italy, the European governing body's executive commitee yesterday agreed to push back by 12 hours the deadline for the selection of the final 22-man squads; the new deadline is noon on June 1.

Originally all 16 finalists had to submit their final 22-man squads by midnight on May 31 - just over two hours after the end of England's friendly against Ukraine at Wembley. England, like other countries playing that night, were concerned that they would not have enough time to assess any injuries sustained in that game.

Uefa also announced that the finalists will no longer have to announce a provisional 35-man squad by May 10, a month before the finals start. It said it was making the change "with a view to simplifying procedures... and, at the same time making life a little bit easier for the 16 coaches".

Everton's manager Walter Smith is resigned to losing his top scorer Kevin Campbell for the rest of the season. The striker sees a specialist on Monday for a check on his knee injury and it seems certain he will have to undergo surgery.

Bristol Rovers' manager Ian Holloway has been charged with misconduct by the Football Association after being ordered from the dug-out at Reading last week. He allegedly swore at a linesman.

fields.headline: The talented Mr Allardyce
fields.trailText: Caricatures of Bolton's manager are as misleading as they are cliched
fields.body:
As someone who is widely perceived to be an alumnus of football's old school, Sam Allardyce's curriculum vitae provides compelling evidence that appearances can be deceptive.

After spending the best part of three decades ploughing through the lower leagues, the Bolton manager has cultivated the popular image of the archetypal hard-liner, a gravel-voiced, moustachioed northerner with the in-built discipline of a Victorian schoolmaster.

He has grown accustomed to having his name prefixed by the word "journeyman" and accepts that tomorrow's semi-final against Aston Villa will be seen by many as his 15 minutes of fame.

Yet beneath the weather-beaten exterior, the Lancastrian growl and the authoritarian glare there lurks one of the most enterprising managers in the game, a deep thinker whose methods would have Arsène Wenger purring in appreciation.

Allardyce has enough certificates from dietary seminars and coaching courses to wallpaper his office from top to floor. His knowledge of every footballer from the Premiership to the Conference borders on encyclopaedic and he could hold his own with any academic in a debate about sports science.

An expert in health matters, he took his team to a fitness and relaxation spa this week to calm the nerves that his course books have told him can reduce stamina by up to 25%. Furthermore, since taking over at the Reebok Stadium last October he has introduced a performance-enhancing diet which means that even a half-time cup of tea is out of bounds.

However, although belonging very much to the new breed of manager, Allardyce is under no illusions about how he is viewed by the public at large.

"When this job came along I thought to myself that it was probably going to be the best chance I would have of being in charge of a team at the highest level," he says.

"I've been in the game around 30 years and I've been preparing for management since the age of 27, going on courses, taking notes and speaking to other managers about their experiences.

"If the information is there and it can help to improve a team's performance by five per cent, even one per cent, then I believe it is worthwhile to gain as much knowledge as possible.

"But I have never seen myself being offered a job by a top Premiership club for the simple reason that I'm not high-profile enough and I don't speak with a foreign accent."

Having played until 37, Allardyce took his first steps into management at Limerick, where finances were so stretched that his job regularly included raising a collection for the players' wages. But those days of scrimping and saving have stood him in good stead for his experiences in England and he has forged a reputation for producing good results despite operating on budget restraints wherever he has been.

Now, if the underdogs can bite hard enough at Villa's heels, he is on the verge of guiding Bolton to their first FA Cup final for 42 years. "There are not many First Division clubs who get this far, let alone the final. I think everyone outside Bolton expects Villa to win but we know that we can beat them if we play well," he says. "We failed miserably in the Worthington Cup semi-final against Tranmere, and there are players here who are still hurting after letting themselves down at Wembley in last season's play-off final.

"We took them to a health spa before the quarter-final against Charlton and it worked so well that we decided to do the same again this week. One of the things I've learned is that players can get too wound up by the hype of a big match. It's proven that nervous energy can considerably worsen a player's output."

Even though his passport says Dudley, Allardyce has spent most of his life in Bolton. A no-frills type of guy in a no-frills type of town. "It's been a long time since this place has had anything like this to get excited about and it means the world to me.

"I came here when I was 15, played for the club, married a Bolton girl and kept my house here even when I was manager of Notts County, so I consider myself a Bolton lad through and through. I still go down the same pub for a pint with the locals and they let me know whether we were crap on Saturday or whether we did all right.

"But I've never been in a situation like this before and a lot of it is new to me. All the media attention has been a fantastic experience. You strive to feel wanted and now we're in the limelight I'm determined to enjoy it."

webTitle: The game Platt dare not lose

fields.headline: The game Platt dare not lose
fields.trailText: At the past two home games Forest fans have turned on him with unprecedented venom. Questions are being asked. After a life of trophies, Italian villas and hero-worship, can he cope with the criticism?
fields.body:
David Platt could do with history repeating itself. As a player he arrived at Crewe an outcast and left to embark on a glittering career. This afternoon the embattled Nottingham Forest manager returns to Gresty Road for a game he dare not lose.

Platt has not been booted out by Forest, as he was by Manchester United in 1985, but he knows he may be in danger of losing a City Ground popularity contest with Pierre van Hooijdonk before long.

At the past two home games the fans have turned on him with unprecedented venom. Questions are being asked. After a life of trophies, Italian villas and hero-worship, can he cope with the criticism? Does he have the stomach for a First Division fight?

Platt seems startled. It is as if someone has suggested that goal against Belgium was a miskick. He recalls narrowly escaping demotion from the Football League with Crewe, dodging the drop with Aston Villa, going down at Bari from Serie A. And then, like one of those bursts into the penalty box, he really finds his stride.

"People see all the positives of my past," he said after training yesterday afternoon. "The England caps, the fact that I scored goals, winning the Double with Arsenal etc etc.

"What they don't see is that at Arsenal, when it came out in the newspapers that I was going to join Middlesbrough, the Highbury crowd booed me for a couple of games because they thought I was trying to get a move for myself.

"They don't see the fact that at Bari, when it came out in the newspapers that I'd signed for Juventus - which was total lies at that time - 60,000 people at Bari's stadium used to boo me at every home game. We had to train behind closed doors because the supporters were having a go at me there. Those experiences have to come to the fore now."

Together, more importantly, with a few wins. Determination and endeavour - even the meticulous training-ground studies - have not done the trick so far. Two points from the past 15 have left Forest in serious danger of a second successive relegation. They are level with Crewe, two points above the drop zone.

Platt's bitten-down fingernails hint at nerves. But the 33-year-old sounded defiant as he contemplated what lay ahead. The bust of Brian Clough in reception must twitch at the very thought of going down again.

"I don't want to sound blase," Platt said, "but I'm very, very optimistic because every time this club has been faced with a watershed we have won. We lost four on the bounce and beat Portsmouth, beat Walsall in a similar situation. But I never expected to be in this position at all." He reckons 47 or 48 points should suffice. Not surprisingly he would not feel guilty about taking three of them off the club who launched his career.

It is hard to imagine, though, that he expected to cross swords with Crewe and Dario Gradi as a manager. During his time there the club never finished higher than 10th in the Fourth Division. The memory of his freezing flat, where he wore training gear in bed to keep warm, might explain an apparent lack of emotion about going back.

"I was there 12 years ago and I had a lot of clubs so I will come up against them," he said. "I have great respect for Dario, but there will be no sentimentality. I don't feel sorry for him and he doesn't feel sorry for me."

Platt might feel sorry for himself as the abuse mounts. But he says he was prepared for it and that being the target creates a more pressure-free environment for his players. He uses golf, tennis and his horses to "release" his mind from the intensity, together with visits to a psychologist.

"It's not to pour out problems," he said. "It's to talk to people about the things that are in you. For the last 11 years I have frequently seen a psychologist. I won't stop, regardless of what I'm doing."

Gradi believes Platt will have good times to come. "He's intelligent and he has a great deal of experience," he said. "When you go into management it's often a bit daunting and you need a bit of luck. Bobby Robson got the sack at Fulham in his first job; I bet they wish they'd kept him now.

"I think David will succeed if he wants to do it. He's had other [business] ventures that haven't succeeded but they have been sidelines. You can't be a manager and have other interests." For now Platt's only interest is avoiding the drop.

webTitle: Sky Blues welcome an Oggy day

fields.headline: Sky Blues welcome an Oggy day
fields.trailText: Steve Ogrizovic will make his second appearance of the season today. It will also be his 600th game for Coventry.
fields.body:
Before Steve Ogrizovic's second appearance of the season, interested parties have been doing their sums.

More often than not at this time of year, Coventry City supporters are calculating how many points the Sky Blues need to avoid relegation. City appear to be safe this time, but the number-crunchers have another conundrum to work on: how many games has Ogrizovic played?

The Association of Football Statisticians claim the goalkeeper has made 598 City appearances, refusing to accept his participation in the 1987 FA Charity Shield against Everton as a competitive match.

Nonsense, counters the City secretary Graham Hover. "The Charity Shield is an extremely competitive game," he said. "We were hugely disappointed not to win it and to say it is just a friendly and not competitive is a nonsense.

"It is far more important than the Zenith Data Systems or Simod Cups, which count as appearances, so we are happy that Oggy's appearance at Arsenal last week was his 599th."

Which is why, with the first-choice keeper Magnus Hedman unavailable because of a back injury, Ogrizovic will become the first player to make 600 appearances for City when he lines up against Liverpool at Highfield Road today.

It is a remarkable achievement, especially at the age of 42. Not that there was any suggestion at Highbury that age was catching up with Ogrizovic, who is in his 16th season at Highfield Road after spells with Chesterfield, Liverpool and Shrewsbury Town.

A catalogue of agile and brave saves restricted Coventry's margin of defeat to 3-0 and earned praise from the Arsenal manager Arsène Wenger. Ogrizovic, in what was his first appearance for 14 months after surgery on a career-threatening neck injury, restored the reputation of 40-something keepers after Neville Southall's "Fats your Lot" outing for Bradford City last month.

According to Gordon Strachan, Ogrizovic's longevity is reward for hard work. "I've watched him here training," the Coventry manager says. "He starts 20 minutes before anybody else comes out. He warms up, because he needs the 20 minutes to warm up. Then he works again and he works again and he keeps working."

The Association of Football Statisticians claim the goalkeeper has made 598 City appearances, refusing to accept his participation in the 1987 FA Charity Shield against Everton as a competitive match. Nonsense, counters the City secretary Graham Hover. "The Charity Shield is an extremely competitive game," he said. "We were hugely disappointed not to win it and to say it is just a friendly and not competitive is a nonsense. "It is far more important than the Zenith Data Systems or Simod Cups, which count as appearances, so we are happy that Oggy's appearance at Arsenal last week was his 599th." Which is why, with the first-choice keeper Magnus Hedman unavailable because of a back injury, Ogrizovic will become the first player to make 600 appearances for City when he lines up against Liverpool at Highfield Road today. It is a remarkable achievement, especially at the age of 42. Not that there was any suggestion at Highbury that age was catching up with Ogrizovic, who is in his 16th season at Highfield Road after spells with Chesterfield, Liverpool and Shrewsbury Town. A catalogue of agile and brave saves restricted Coventry's margin of defeat to 3-0 and earned praise from the Arsenal manager Arsène Wenger. Ogrizovic, in what was his first appearance for 14 months after surgery on a career-threatening neck injury, restored the reputation of 40-something keepers after Neville Southall's "Fats your Lot" outing for Bradford City last month. According to Gordon Strachan, Ogrizovic's longevity is reward for hard work. "I've watched him here training," the Coventry manager says. "He starts 20 minutes before anybody else comes out. He warms up, because he needs the 20 minutes to warm up. Then he works again and he works again and he keeps working."

fields.headline: Dublin savours second chance
fields.trailText: Dion Dublin is determined to be standing in the Wembley centre-circle saluting Villa fans after tomorrow's FA Cup semi-final against Bolton.
fields.body:
Any footballer will tell you there is nothing worse than losing an FA Cup final at Wembley - except, of course, losing an FA Cup semi-final there. But running both close must be standing around in your Wembley suit after the final, trying to make out you are over the moon while your mates go on a lap of honour with the trophy but without you.

Dion Dublin suffered this humiliation twice in 1994 with Manchester United, not even a blushing bridesmaid on the bench as his team-mates crushed Chelsea 4-0 in the final. It had been even worse a few months earlier when United lost to Aston Villa in that other domestic cup competition, the one that no longer dares to speak its name at Old Trafford.

Dublin kept the smile on during the dressing-room celebrations after the Chelsea win but admits: "It is not the same as being on the pitch at the end with your sweaty kit on." That is why he is determined to be standing in the Wembley centre-circle saluting Villa fans after tomorrow's FA Cup semi-final against Bolton.

The striker is not, though, degenerating into footballing cliche when he says he will be happy just to be a part of the occasion; he should be that at least since he is expected to start tomorrow. When he was carried off with a broken neck last December after a collision with Sheffield Wednesday's Gerald Sibon it was feared that the only place he would watch any future football, including cup finals, would be from the wheelchair enclosure.

"The surgeon told me I could easily have ended up in a wheelchair. When he said my neck had been broken my wife Louise and I burst into tears. I was saying, 'What about my football? I need to play football'. Everything seemed to have come to an abrupt end in my career and my life."

Dublin can be thankful that Villa have someone a cut above your average physio in Jim Walker, who was by his side in an instant and walked him in tiny steps to the stretcher while holding his head between his flat palms as one might a child's. And he can be thankful for the skills of his surgeon Andre Jackowski, who in a 2-hour operation replaced the crushed bones in his vertebrae with a graft from his hip, knitting it into place with a plate and four screws.

It would now require an even lengthier operation to wipe the smile off Dublin's face, so delighted is he not only to have recovered fully but to have done so in a time that the surgeon had thought impossible. His x-rays revealed such improvement after six weeks that Jackowski swore that, had he not known the name of the patient, he would have assumed the vertebrae were three months old.

To return to Premiership action, as Dublin did against Derby last weekend, after just over three months is little short of miraculous. That might explain not just the ever-present smile but the self-deprecatory humour which is a rare trait in a footballer. Pinpointing the recovery in Villa's fortunes as the moment he was wheeled out of the ground on December 18, he says: "They won that game in the dying minutes and have now lost only once in 14 Premiership games."

There was, though, an embarrassing defeat against Leicester in the second leg of the Worthington Cup semi-final, after a draw at Villa Park which even the home players admit was a bottle job. Dublin, who kept his distance from team-mates while recovering, said: "We didn't play well and there was very little passing and movement. That's why I'm so pleased we have got a second chance and why it would be a crying shame if we let it go down the pan."

Nothing short of a bolt in his neck could have prevented Dublin, 31 this month, making his cameo appearance against Derby last week and no, he says, he was not afraid of going up for high balls or making his usual aggressive challenges. In any case, he says, those delightful team-mates Ugo Ehiogu and the captain Gareth Southgate had made sure in training that he was up to the physical challenge.

Dublin said: "I only played the last 10 minutes but because of my expectations I felt worse than I usually do after playing 90. I was absolutely shattered afterwards, though it was great when I came off and heard even the Derby fans cheering me."

His recuperation has been matched by that of Villa. So much so that Deadly Doug Ellis, normally quicker with the knife than MacHeath and who was being urged to sack John Gregory before Christmas, is now being praised for sticking by his manager. Dublin said: "The great thing about the boss is that he is exactly the same, whether we're on a winning run or a losing one. He does like people to hear his voice, though, and now he has given up his touchline seat he is no doubt causing havoc in the stands."

It will be hard for Gregory to resist a Wembley bench seat, if not tomorrow then certainly in May, should Villa finally reach the final. It is extraordinary that a club whose record of seven FA Cup wins is beaten by only two clubs have not even reached the final since 1957, despite four League Cup wins there in that time.

They are confident of going back just before the bulldozers, though Dublin has his own reasons for wanting to recover his scoring form long before then. When you diplomatically suggest the injury must have been particularly disappointing after he started the season with dreams of playing in Euro 2000, he interrupts to say: "I am still dreaming of that. If I earn my place in Villa's team and start scoring, I don't see why not. I haven't heard from Kevin Keegan. I think he has lost my phone number but I will give it to him again." A good performance tomorrow will help.

webTitle: Cool shades of gold and blue

fields.headline: Cool shades of gold and blue
fields.standfirst: West Midlands serious climb squads head for summit meeting at St Andrews
fields.trailText: If Birmingham and Wolves fans received a fiver every time they heard success was round the corner, most might be in St Lucia this afternoon. Instead they will be at St Andrews as their teams - sixth and seventh - go head to head.
fields.body:
If Birmingham and Wolves fans received a fiver every time they heard success was round the corner, most might be in St Lucia this afternoon. Instead they will be at St Andrews as their teams - sixth and seventh - go head to head.

The Premiership beckons tantalisingly once again. No one, though, should hold their breath. It is 14 years since Birmingham tumbled from the top flight and 16 since Wolves slipped out.

Sleeping giants? Amid the upheaval it would be a miracle if either had found time for a kip. Between them they have gone through 15 managers trying to restore former glories. Trevor Francis, then, might be worried by the new reading material at the home of Birmingham's chairman David Gold.

There sits a signed copy of Doug Ellis's autobiography, received 2 weeks ago. "From Deadly to David," reads the inscription from Aston Villa's chairman. "In appreciation of our friendship in football." Yet Francis, like his Wolves counterpart Colin Lee, need not fret. Both clubs see stability and financial prudence as the way ahead.

At Molineux the board appreciates Lee's first full season could be one of transition. "This is potentially the best management team since I was playing here under Bill McGarry and Sammy Chung," says John Richards, the striker turned managing director. "There's a good atmosphere, a good team spirit. That's why Martin O'Neill gets the success he does at Leicester, because he creates team spirit in the club."

The absence of such a spirit, Richards claims, has been a key reason why Wolves have trodden water for so long. "We've had players coming to make a quick buck," he says. "Wolves are good payers outside the Premier League. We were attracting players coming to finish their careers with a good pay-out, and that causes unrest in the dressing-room and in the ground because supporters don't like that mercenary attitude.

"Also we haven't had players living in Wolverhampton or around. We've been allowing players on one- or two-year contracts to live further afield, which is not good. Now new players have to relocate to within, I think, 20 miles."

Richards says many fans consider this Wolves' most promising position for 15 years, but Birmingham are a couple of seasons ahead in terms of squad depth and their top-two form either side of an injury crisis shows what might have been. "If we had gone through those injuries," Lee admits, "we would have been bottom."

Francis has rebuilt gradually over four years, reaching the play-offs last season, and will expect at least the same again. If Molineux is awash with spirit, the air at Birmingham seems full of enthusiasm.

"The club was on its knees," says Gold of his arrival in 1993. "I looked into the eyes of Terry Cooper [the manager] and I saw fear. He was a genuine man but he was dealing with a corpse. We put money in but money alone doesn't do it.

"A club has a heart - an identity - and, if you whack it into the ground, you can't simply come along, paint it and put some players on the pitch. The very heart and soul needs to be in place. You need enthusiasm and experience. Now people come up to me and say, 'We're going to do it this year, aren't we?' You can feel the buzz, the determination. It's infectious."

There is a bond between Francis and the fans. Some are more wary of the multi-millionaire board, accusing them of underfunding Francis. The manager's transfer surplus is around £10m and Gold says: "If Jack Walker walked away from Blackburn, what would they do? Unless he left a legacy they would be in big trouble. Our desire to make the Premiership is all-consuming but huge spending is not sustainable."

Even Sir Jack Hayward's chequebook is shut at Wolves after an outlay of around £40m. Molineux reeks of style and wealth, including a flat for Hayward during his visits from the Bahamas. But £24m losses from 1993 to 1998 meant Lee had to sell Robbie Keane to Coventry to rebuild his squad.

He believes the new policy and acquisition of Ade Akinbiyi and Michael Branch have given him a faster, younger, more determined team. From 22nd in late September the climb has been impressive. Lee believes he is still six men short but the lack of finance hardly seems to bother him.

"Sometimes money can breed laziness," he says. "I think if you're given £10m or £20m sometimes you don't do your homework as well as if you've got £6m to build a team with. You need to analyse every penny. And the more money, the higher the expectation and the bigger the pressure."

The pressure is high enough as it is. "Sir Jack will definitely be disappointed if we are not in the Premiership or looking to get in the Premiership this time next year," Richards says.

At Birmingham Gold would doubtless be tearing his hair out as well. But then it was ever thus. No wonder Newton never suggested what goes down must come up.

 Birmingham have signed the Everton goalkeeper Thomas Myhre on loan. The Norwegian international will make his debut this afternoon.

webTitle: Parker keeps Addicks on a high

fields.headline: Parker keeps Addicks on a high
fields.trailText: Charlton Athletic 2 - 1 Queens Park Rangers
fields.body:
Scott Parker gave Charlton victory over Queens Park Rangers and a 16-point lead at the top of the First Division with his first senior goal.

The Lambeth-born 19-year-old midfielder had been on the pitch for only three minutes after coming on as a substitute when he settled the game with an opportunist strike in the 87th minute. He met Andy Hunt's low cross from the right with a toe poke that crept in off the near post from four yards out.

Steve Brown had to be alert in injury time to block a Taylor shot which could have salvaged the game for QPR, but Charlton were worthy winners.

Shaun Newton had given the home side the lead in the second minute when Ian Baraclough's defensive header fell to him inside the box. His first shot rebounded back to him off Karl Ready and his second flew into the top corner past a despairing Lee Harper.

The Addicks had most of the first-half play, with Newton and John Robinson looking dangerous out wide and Mathias Svensson dominating the physical exchanges. But with Brown, Mark Kinsella and Anthony Barness wayward from long range, they could not convert their superiority into goals.Brown almost extended their lead in the fifth minute when he found finding himself in space just outside the box, but his 25-yard effort slipped narrowly over the bar. Then Mark Kinsella and Anthony Barness wayward from long range.

But an error from Dean Kiely gifted QPR an equaliser in the 81st minute. The goalkeeper came for a long ball but missed his punch under pressure from a crowd of players. The ball bounced off two defenders and fell invitingly for Gareth Taylor, who nodded gratefully into an empty net.

It was his first goal for QPR and QPR's first against a London club this season, and it looked to have given them a point against the league leaders until Parker's introduction.

fields.headline: England elite share £m bonus ball
fields.trailText: England's elite cricketers stand to share bonuses of more than £500,000 on top of their salaries this season. The bonuses, paid out of a players' pool funded by sponsors, were agreed in the latest round of negotiations between the 12 players selected for central contracts and the England and Wales Cricket Board.
fields.body:
England's elite cricketers stand to share bonuses of more than £500,000 on top of their salaries this season. The bonuses, paid out of a players' pool funded by sponsors, were agreed in the latest round of negotiations between the 12 players selected for central contracts and the England and Wales Cricket Board.

The protracted wrangling over contracts looks set to end early next week when the players sign six-month agreements with the governing body. Each will receive a salary of between £20,000 and £45,000 depending on seniority, as well as a guaranteed share of the players' pool, which could rise depending on the number of matches won.

Negotiations had focused on two areas: personal image rights, both in print and online, and county bonuses. Some senior players were concerned that they would be worse off under the new agreements because they would not represent their counties often enough to qualify for bonus payments. This issue has been resolved to their satisfaction. "They feel that under the terms of the revised contracts, taking into account all commercial aspects and not just salaries, they will be better off," said a source close to the negotiations.

The final few paragraphs of the contracts, relating to image rights, were drafted yesterday and the players will review them over the weekend at a training camp in Cheshire.

England have asked Durham's Steve Harmison, Northamptonshire's David Sales and Somerset's Graeme Swann and Marcus Trescothick to join the three-day camp, which begins tomorrow.

Harmison has long been considered one of England's best young fast bowlers and was to go on this winter's A tour to Bangladesh and New Zealand before being injured. Swann was selected for this winter's senior tour to South Africa but had limited opportunities. Last summer Tresco- thick enjoyed one of his best seasons and Sales, after a difficult couple of years, began to fulfil his early promise.

fields.headline: Where are they now?
fields.trailText: Four more professional sportsmen that changed career.
fields.body:
Michael Jordan
The NBA basketball legend made perhaps the most publicised switch in professional sport by quitting the Chicago Bulls in October 1993 for the Chicago White Sox baseball team. But he failed to make the grade and, after a spell with the Birmingham Barons, returned to the Bulls to inspire them to new heights.

Daley Thompson
The twice Olympic decathlon champion used his retirement to further youthful ambitions of playing professional football. Scored for Mansfield Town reserves aged 37 and made the first-team bench. Now in charge of Wimbledon's fitness sessions.

Clive Allen
The former England striker, below, began kicking for the London Monarchs in American football's World League aged 35. But, unlike his rival kicker, the ex-British Lion Gavin Hastings who won the World Bowl in 1996 with the Scottish Claymores, Allen had limited success and the Monarchs were soon disbanded.

Mick Channon
Followed his 46 football caps for England by training horses, including three Royal Ascot winners. Channon's 72 winners last year made him a top-20 trainer. Now at the Queen's former stables in West Ilsley.

webTitle: Head to head with Julian Dicks, and not a bloody nose in sight

fields.headline: Head to head with Julian Dicks, and not a bloody nose in sight
fields.trailText: West Ham's former hard man swapped his boots for spikes in the hope of becoming a professional golfer. Mike Selvey tackles him over 18 holes.
fields.body:
The skies are leaden on Tuesday morning at the Warren Golf Club in a nobby rural part of Essex beyond Chelmsford and a freezing nor'easter is whipping in from the North Sea. Occasionally, a chill rain shower stings the cheeks. It is great weather for staying indoors but on the practice range a golfer, black-suited against the weather, is beating balls into the teeth of it.

It is nine o'clock now but he has been at it for an hour and there are three more buckets of balls beside him still to hit. Julian Dicks is not totally at ease with his swing. "Inconsistent," he confides. "I used to have this sway rather than a turn and at the moment I'm cutting across the ball. Then there's my takeaway and..." And another ball disappears into the distance. It is hard work being a pro.

You are not mistaken. But having spent all of his professional football career kicking opponents into touch he has, at the age of 31, done the same to that part of his life and is now embarking on phase two, Dicks the Golfer.

Debutant's nerves

On Wednesday, at Wildwood in Surrey, Dicks will cough up his entrance fee and tee the ball up in the first event of this season's Satellite tour that he hopes one day will lead him to the full European tour. He is, he freely confesses, not daunted exactly by the prospect of his new career but is extremely nervous of the prospect of standing on the first tee and hitting a duff shot.

"I wouldn't want to top it or something and show myself up," he says. "I was playing in a pro-am last year with Per-Ulrik Johansson and he could see my hands shaking as I gripped the club. 'What's the problem?' he said, 'it's only golf' and I replied that it was OK for him but how would he feel about standing in front of 30,000 people and taking a penalty. Then he understood. It's about being confident in what you are doing and I'm only just at the bottom of a new learning curve."

Dicks has been hooked on golf for seven years, since first he damaged the left knee that has required surgery seven times and may yet leave him crippled.

"When I first did my knee ligaments I needed something to do to keep my mind off things and my brother-in-law suggested taking up golf. I said it was an old man's game and not for me. I couldn't see myself playing it. But I had a go, shot 116 with his clubs and came straight off the course, into the shop and bought my own set. That was it."

Inside six years his handicap had tumbled to five and, although he had ambition to improve on that, he never considered the possibility of hitting balls, rather than kicking them, for a living. The impetus to take it further came as a result of contemplating retirement from football last year, and a subsequent conversation with his golf coach Denis Pugh, a high-profile teacher who worked with David Leadbetter but who was the teaching pro at the Warren when Dicks first started playing.

"I was going through a bad patch with my golf and I saw Denis. The first thing he asked me was where I wanted to go with my golf. I said as far as I can, even to the European tour. He took it on board and we started from the beginning. Until then I genuinely thought I had a good swing and he said he could get me to scratch with it but that, if I was serious about playing for a living, I would need something that could hold up under pressure. So he took it apart and has been rebuilding it since - stance, posture and grip first, and then swing plane.

"I think he's happy so far and he knows that he can tell me something and I can go away and I'll hit four or five hundred balls a day and get it right. I love doing that because I've always loved training anyway and it's that and the buzz of going out in front of the Upton Park crowd that I miss most in any case rather than playing as such.

"I actually prefer practice to playing to be honest. Sometimes it might take a week or more to get something working but you can see it in the ball striking. I know I'm the sort of bloke who wants everything yesterday but Denis says it will take three to five years to get a swing that would work at the top level, so it's nowhere near finished. I'm willing to work hard and try and make a living out of it."

Money talks

Dicks, of course, has an advantage over most of his adversaries in the immediate future in that he is comfortably off from his football career. To some extent he has traded on his name too, for he is Callaway'd from top to toe, for example, something he knows would not generally come so readily to someone in his position on the ladder.

His money he thinks obviously will take some of the pressure from him but will not affect his desire any more than Tiger Woods' massive wealth takes the edge off his competitive nature.

"Not being disrespectful but, if there is a young lad and myself with a five-footer for a couple of grand and I miss, it is not going to make or break me is it, whereas to him it could be a lot of money. But I'll still be trying. I just want to be able to do it for its own sake and do it well and I'll work bloody hard to make sure I do."

webTitle: Form horses face legs of jelly in battle to clear toughest hurdle

fields.headline: Form horses face legs of jelly in battle to clear toughest hurdle
fields.trailText: History favours the First Division side but Villa's class should tell.
fields.body:
The first of the FA Cup semi-finals at Wembley tomorrow is more likely to follow the dictates of logic than the demands of neatness.

A victory for Bolton Wanderers, who won the Cup at the new Empire Stadium in 1923, would give the last final before the place is rebuilt a sense of symmetry but Aston Villa's superior status will surely be the deciding factor.

Yet the contest could be a close one. Both teams are in form, Villa having been beaten only twice in 22 matches and Bolton only twice in their last 14 in the league. A dip in performance by John Gregory's side and the First Division could well be represented in both of this season's domestic finals.

Aston Villa will look to the experience of Paul Merson, who gained a Cup-winners' medal with Arsenal in 1993, to settle any semi-final nerves. Merson is having his best season since leaving Highbury and admits that facing such a big occasion for the first time "can turn your legs to jelly".

Neither Gregory nor his players will underestimate Bolton who, like Villa, reached the last four of the Worthington Cup and knocked out three Premiership opponents - Derby, Sheffield Wednesday and Wimbledon - on the way. Bolton, moreover, were at Wembley as recently as last May, when they lost the First Division play-off final 2-0 to Watford.

Aston Villa will look to their five-man midfield to squeeze the initiative out of Bolton's football the way that Leicester City stifled the attacking ambitions of Tranmere Rovers in the Worthington Cup final. This is never easy at Wembley and, if Bolton have a presence on either wing, they may still find a way through.

Gregory will pick his team from a full squad and is even thinking of starting tomorrow's game with Dion Dublin, now fit after breaking his neck just before Christmas. At the very least Dublin will be on the bench. Either way Benito Carbone, closely supported by Merson, will look for goals through sorcery and speed.

The rumpus over Carbone's new contract has tended to obscure Villa's Cup preparations but the Italian will be the most likely match-winner tomorrow. Sam Allardyce has injury problems affecting three players after Wednesday's internationals but only Paul Ritchie is a serious doubt.

For goals Bolton will look mainly to their Icelandic striker Eidur Gudjohnsen, who has scored 17 times this season including four in the FA Cup. Gudjohnsen, however, will be up against one of the most knowledgeable defences in the Premiership. Only three times this season have Villa conceded more than two goals and they have kept 20 clean sheets.

Tomorrow's semi-final will be refereed by David Elleray, who has already aroused the wrath of Villa and their manager twice this season. When Villa were holding Arsenal to 1-1 at Highbury in September Elleray penalised David James for holding the ball too long even though the goalkeeper was injured. Davor Suker scored after the indirect free-kick and Arsenal eventually won 3-1.

In October Elleray gave a penalty against them during a 2-1 defeat at Sunderland after which the manager complained about being "fed up with referees like Mr Elleray getting away with blue murder".

Allardyce is worried that, following Gregory's griping, Elleray might instinctively lean towards Villa tomorrow. Clearly he does not know his referee.

fields.headline: Nice life... we'll take it
fields.standfirst: Erin Brockovich was delighted when they made a film about her. But others have been less than thrilled. Lucy Barrick reports
fields.trailText: Erin Brockovich was delighted when they made a film about her. But others have been less than thrilled. Lucy Barrick reports
fields.body:
Lately, among the Best Boys, Foley Mixers and Dolly Grips, there's another phrase which has been cropping up on movie credits with alarming frequency: Inspired By True Events. This week alone, you can choose from Steven Soderbergh's Erin Brockovich (Julia Roberts as a feisty single mom battling corrupt corporations) and the much-acclaimed Boys Don't Cry (Hilary Swank as unfortunate transsexual Brandon Teena).

But, while the real Erin Brockovich was so pleased with her transformation into a movie character she took a cameo in the film, other recipients of the same honour haven't been quite so enamoured of the results. In fact, some of the actual people depicted in Boys Don't Cry - not to mention other recent efforts The Insider and The Hurricane - are very, very unhappy indeed. So, since when is Hollywood so interested in making movies about nobodies and (while we're at it) why are these upstarts getting vexed about the way they've been portrayed?

Well, the problem with nobodies is there is usually good reason why they're exactly that. After all, most people's daily routines would make an excruciatingly tedious film: get up, go to work, come home, go to bed is hardly the stuff silver-screen dreams are made of. We're not talking biopics of the great and the good here, but normal people with one significant event in their lives (the infamous "arc" so beloved of Hollywood scriptwriters). The facts of the matter, while interesting enough to warrant the movie treatment, might not have quite enough dramatic edge to sustain audience interest - so characters are amalgamated or omitted, events are reordered, and certain things are simply invented for artistic purposes. And this really pisses people off.

Now you probably wouldn't be too concerned if you were played by Julia Roberts or, as in the case of Jeffrey Wigand and Lowell Bergman - the chief protagonists of The Insider - by Russell Crowe or Al Pacino. That goes double if you're not only made out to be good-looking, but brave and crusading as well. However, if, like 60 Minutes Ùber-anchor Mike Wallace, you think you've been made to look, well, a bit sneaky, you might well ask (as he did) "Where does the truth leave off and docudrama begin?"

Or, if you are Wigand's ex-wife, you might just threaten to sue backers Disney, because you claim you didn't leave your husband as a result of the mysterious death-threats depicted in the movie, but because he abused you. A big difference to those involved, perhaps, but a trifle to the film-makers.

And what if something about The Hurricane (with Denzel Washington as wrongfully convicted boxer Rubin Carter) got your goat? Well, if you are Selwyn Raab you write an article in the New York Times accusing the movie of being, "history contorted for dramatic effect" (and not just because you were annoyed that your involvement in the actual campaign to free Carter was ignored or anything). Or, like former middleweight champion Joey Giardello, you sue the producers for defamation, as you're terribly upset at the implication you only won a bout against Carter because of the racial prejudice of the judge (and also because it shows you getting a right royal ass-whupping).

Meanwhile, the only reason Brandon Teena, the transgender hero of Boys Don't Cry, can't threaten to sue anyone is because he's dead. So it was left to ex-girlfriend Lana Tisdel to try to stop distribution of the film, claiming it misrepresented the facts of the matter, and unselfconsciously announcing that it destroyed, "the spirit and the memory of Brandon as badly as the two killers destroyed his body". But, of course, there have been far worse cases of art thieving wholesale from life.

"He stole my life - he took my life and put it on the Broadway stage." So wailed convicted conman David Hampton, whose real-life case inspired John Guare to write Six Degrees Of Separation, and who then tried to sue for a share of the profits from the play (later filmed with Will Smith in the lead role). Hampton, who passed himself off as the son of Sidney Poitier and conned his way into the lives of some of Manhattan's richest inhabitants, argued he was entitled to the money made from his story, because Guare couldn't have written it without him. Guess what? He lost.

But we shouldn't find it too surprising that people don't necessarily own the rights to their own life stories. We live in a world where a modicum of media exposure can turn anyone into a pseudo-celebrity (even a two-bit cruise ship singer and a fat airline employee). Audiences have always had a problem separating fiction from reality, and the popularity of docusoaps and mockumentaries only serves to blur the boundaries even further. While some films acknowledge this - the oh-so postmodern The Blair Witch Project for one - we're all too willing to accept a fictionalisation of real events as the very last word on a subject.

And now Hollywood, sick of rehashing the minutiae of its own sordid business for subject matter, is turning to the outside world for inspiration. Nothing gives actors more satisfaction than pretending to be "real" - it lets them kid themselves they're doing something worthwhile. Julia Roberts, last seen playing Julia Roberts (badly) in Notting Hill, gets her thespian props for playing a crusading law clerk, albeit one with a penchant for mini-skirts and abundant cleavage, and I'm sure Hilary Swank would much rather be remembered for her Oscar-winning turn in Boys Don't Cry than for The Next Karate Kid.

It's OK for the actors: they get to stop playing at reality the moment the camera stops rolling, and go back to doing whatever it is actors do all day. The genuine articles are stuck living the same old life. When their story is appropriated, they become public property but, unlike the stars who play them (and get so much credit for it), there's no reward and no chance to set the record straight. So it's little wonder that people seek vindication and/or bucketloads of cash in court - and bear in mind that getting all worked up about your thinly veiled portrayal in a film is hardly a new development (press magnate William Randolph Hearst and muck-spreading columnist Walter Winchell, for example, were none too impressed with Citizen Kane and The Sweet Smell Of Success).

But the ensuing litigation is becoming more frequent, one reason being that, in the past, Hollywood usually waited for all concerned to be cold in the ground before giving their lives a spit and polish. On the other hand, the events in some of the current crop of true stories happened just a few years ago. And, while the more salacious real-life stories used to be the preserve of TV movies (with titles like Not Without My Daughter and Wife, Mother, Murderer), they're now the subject of big-budget, mainstream fare.

Denzel Washington defended the practice, saying, "Any time you base things on a true story, it offends someone." Well, he ain't wrong, but an increasingly litigious audience might make film-makers more concerned with the truth, rather than the "emotional" or "artistic" truth they need to make their films that bit more compelling.

Whatever the result, it's all symptomatic of Hollywood's lack of creativity. Where most major studio films used to have original scripts, or were adapted from novels or plays, the bulk of the recent films "Inspired By True Events" are based on magazine articles or one-column newspaper stories. With greater demand for movies, and a quicker turnover of stars, anybody's dull little life is potentially worthy of two hours of celluloid.

So, whatever you do, just make sure you don't do anything too dramatic today.

 Erin Brockovich and Boys Don't Cry are both released on Friday

fields.headline: Diary
fields.trailText: Taking the Mickey, Paolo loves Luca, and scratchcards.
fields.body:
 Can there have been a stranger reason for receiving a yellow card? Ian Dyer, a striker with Colombia in the Isle of Wight Sunday League, was late arriving for a recent game after dashing from work and grabbing a bite to eat on the way.

The referee's report takes up the story: "After 20 minutes the player entered the field of play eating an Egg McMuffin." Dyer was promptly booked.

"I think the ref must have thought I was taking the Mickey but I was just hungry," said the 23-year-old, who was later fined £6. "I was a bit annoyed at first but I can see the funny side now."

Colombia, who were 1-0 down when Ian arrived, promptly came out of their shell to win 10-1.

 Just asking. Can the Seattle Soccer League be considered PC because it is sponsored by Microsoft?

 Paolo di Canio and Gianluca Vialli share the same birth date - July 9 - and they used to share a flat when they were at Juventus. Now they are in danger of sharing a reputation.

"We sometimes meet for dinner," says the West Ham striker. "I go without my wife and he without his girlfriend. They are starting to think that we are having a gay relationship."
