fields.headline: Travelogue
fields.trailText: Teen spirit | Guardian winner | Excess-free cars
fields.body:
Guardian winner
Jean Rafferty has won the daily newspaper category in this year's Travelex Travel Writers' Awards for an article about Buenos Aires published in the Guardian's Travel section. The judges described Rafferty's article, "Dance with a stranger", published on September 11, 1999, as "inspired" and "a nostalgic tango through the wild side of the city". She received her award, an inscribed crystal trophy, and a cheque for £500, from broadcaster Mary Nightingale.

Teen spirit
Making family holidays work can be tricky and, quite often, the older the children, the trickier the balance. In July, Cosmos (0161-480 5799) will take six teenagers and their families, selected from across the UK, to the Jupiter Saturno Hotel in Majorca. They will give their views on everything from food to accommodation, holiday reps and activities. There will also be an independent researcher on hand to discover how to prevent dream holidays turning into nightmares. You just have to wait for the results.

Capital costs
London is the most expensive city in the EU and one of the most expensive in the world to visit as a business traveller. The most expensive is Almaty in Kazakhstan, which costs £288.56 a day. London costs £245 a day. The research was carried out by human resources consultancy ECA International.

Excess-free cars
Car-hire insurance excesses for all worldwide car rental bookings are being waived by Holiday Autos. Customers will no longer have to pay for the first part of any insurance claim if damage is caused to their hire vehicle. This coincides with the launch of the company's online booking site, which gives a £5 discount to online bookers and access to late deals with discounts of up to 50% for departures within 14 days.

Call of nature
Volunteers are needed to help with the long-term study and conservation of wolves, bears, pumas, monkeys, macaws, frogs and other species in South America and Poland. Anyone can join for two weeks or more, and expedition contributions are £1,790 (Bolivia), £1,680 (Peru), and £1,490 (Poland). Details on 01502-583085 and www.biosphere-expeditions.com.

Garden party
London's private garden squares will be open to the public on Sunday, June 4. Those unlocking their gates for the first time for this annual event include Westminster Abbey College Garden, Culverly Green in Lewisham and Warwick Square in Pimlico. Tickets, available on the day at the 60 gardens, cost £5 for adults, while children under 12 go free. Details from the London Tourist Board on 09064 123410.

fields.headline: Where to ski  in summer
fields.standfirst: The season may be drawing to a close in Europe, but somewhere else in the world it's only just beginning.  Roger Bray  points you in the right direction
fields.trailText: The season may be drawing to a close in Europe, but somewhere else in the world it's only just beginning. Roger Bray points you in the right direction
fields.body:
Spring is a mixed blessing for ardent skiers and snowboarders. Long, light evenings beckon but the thrill of the powder seems dismally distant. Do not despair. Those unable to face the vacuum left by the closing of resorts can find outlets for their frustration, even in blazing summer.

Europe
The most easily accessible option is glacier skiing in Europe. Most glacier runs are fairly bland, however, so do not expect too many stiff challenges. At La Plagne, for example, you can ski on the Bellecte glacier. At Tignes, an underground railway whisks skiers to the restaurant on the Grande Motte glacier in six minutes. Erna Low (0207 5842841) can offer a self-drive week at either, in an apartment, from around £350 or £400 respectively for four people and including ferry crossings. Other French resorts with glacier skiing include Les deux Alpes, Val Thorens and Alpe d'Huez.

Austria's Kaprun has 16 lifts on the Kitzsteinhorn. The glacier at Hintertux, not far from Mayrhofen, has steeper runs than most and some 11 miles of piste remain open throughout summer.

Swiss resorts offering summer skiing include Zermatt and Verbier.

Scandinavia
At Sweden's Riksgränsen - the world's most northerly resort at 20 miles inside the Arctic circle- it is possible to experience skiing under the midnight sun. Conditions are reckoned to be best in late May, but the mountain stays open until mid-summer. Off-piste and heli-skiing are available.

Slopes are mainly intermediate, with 5% of terrain graded expert, and there are 19 pistes and six lifts. Getting there demands a degree of determination, however. You need to fly to Kiruna via Stockholm. SAS (0845 60727727) offers midweek fares in May and June from £262.80. The Riksgränsen Hotel (0046 980 40080), which charges around £80 a night for a double room, will organise airport transfers. The resort has a web site at www.riksgransen.nu - but it is in Swedish.

Also in Scandinavia, there is summer skiing on the Tystif glacier at Stryn, 200 miles north of Bergen in Norway, though there are only two lifts and three runs.

South America
South America is among the best choices, though snow has often proved scarce in recent years and it would be a good idea to leave booking until late, when you have some idea of likely conditions.

In Argentina and Chile, the season usually starts in June and, depending on how far south you go, lasts until September or October. The best known resort is Bariloche, close to the Chilean border in Argentina's Patagonia region. Skiing is on the Catedral Mountain, which has some 30 lifts and 50 runs and a recently-installed covered chairlift.

Las Leñas, purpose built for mountain sports in the 1980s, has seven chairlifts and four drag lifts, and runs including about 15 miles of advanced piste.

Resorts in Chile include Portillo and Valle Nevado. The former lies 100 miles north of Santiago, has 11 lifts, 23 runs and recently-extended snow-making. With its close neighbours La Parva and El Colorado, Valle Nevado offers fairly extensive skiing served by over 40 lifts, but because it is only 40 miles from the capital, it can get pretty crowded at weekends.

Most of these resorts are high - Las Leñas is a heady 11,243 feet above sea level at its highest point - so leave time to adjust to the reduced oxygen.

Passage to South America (020 8767 8989) can put together packages to all these resorts, starting at around £1,500 for one week in Bariloche. It suggests avoiding the South American school holidays in July, and says the best time to go is the second half of August.

North America
Canada's Whistler-Blackcomb, near Vancouver, offers summer glacier skiing and a snowboarding half-pipe. Check out www.whistler-resort.com.

New Zealand
You can ski the piste or choose from a range of guided heli-skiing options on South Island second only to that in Canada.

Perhaps the best known resorts are Mount Hutt, just over an hour's drive from Christchurch up a dizzying approach road, and Coronet Peak, 25 minutes from Queenstown in the south-west. Others include Treble Cone and The Remarkables.

In the North Island, the biggest developed area is Whakapapa, which has 18 lifts, including a high-speed quad.

The length of the season varies, but most resorts open in June - Mount Hutt usually starts in May - and close in mid-October or November. Helicopter operators include the long-established Harris Mountains Heli-skiing, which flies skiers and snowboarders from Queenstown and Wanaka, to more than 200 peaks in seven mountain ranges with runs varying from 2,000-4,000 vertical feet, fitting the terrain to their abilities. A day, including three descents, costs around £185 at the current exchange rate. For further details of skiing in New Zealand, try www.snow.co.nz.

Australia
In New South Wales, Thredbo, 280 miles from Sydney, has some of the best skiing in Australia - three years ago, it was hit by a tragic mud slide in which 18 people died - and Perisher Blue has some of the most challenging runs though more than half its terrain is graded intermediate.

In Victoria, Mount Buller claims the country's biggest lift system with 28, including eight four-seaters. Other options in the state are Falls Creek and Mount Hotham The latter also has some fairly difficult skiing and should have a new airport open for the start of the season in June, enabling skiers to fly there in 21 minutes from Melbourne and 47 minutes from Sydney by Qantas regional subsidiary airlines.

The Riksgränsen Hotel (0046 980 40080), which charges around £80 a night for a double room, will organise airport transfers. The resort has a web site at www.riksgransen.nu - but it is in Swedish. Also in Scandinavia, there is summer skiing on the Tystif glacier at Stryn, 200 miles north of Bergen in Norway, though there are only two lifts and three runs. South America South America is among the best choices, though snow has often proved scarce in recent years and it would be a good idea to leave booking until late, when you have some idea of likely conditions. In Argentina and Chile, the season usually starts in June and, depending on how far south you go, lasts until September or October. The best known resort is Bariloche, close to the Chilean border in Argentina's Patagonia region. Skiing is on the Catedral Mountain, which has some 30 lifts and 50 runs and a recently-installed covered chairlift. Las Leñas, purpose built for mountain sports in the 1980s, has seven chairlifts and four drag lifts, and runs including about 15 miles of advanced piste. Resorts in Chile include Portillo and Valle Nevado. The former lies 100 miles north of Santiago, has 11 lifts, 23 runs and recently-extended snow-making. With its close neighbours La Parva and El Colorado, Valle Nevado offers fairly extensive skiing served by over 40 lifts, but because it is only 40 miles from the capital, it can get pretty crowded at weekends. Most of these resorts are high - Las Leñas is a heady 11,243 feet above sea level at its highest point - so leave time to adjust to the reduced oxygen. Passage to South America (020 8767 8989) can put together packages to all these resorts, starting at around £1,500 for one week in Bariloche. It suggests avoiding the South American school holidays in July, and says the best time to go is the second half of August. North America Canada's Whistler-Blackcomb, near Vancouver, offers summer glacier skiing and a snowboarding half-pipe. Check out www.whistler-resort.com. New Zealand You can ski the piste or choose from a range of guided heli-skiing options on South Island second only to that in Canada. Perhaps the best known resorts are Mount Hutt, just over an hour's drive from Christchurch up a dizzying approach road, and Coronet Peak, 25 minutes from Queenstown in the south-west. Others include Treble Cone and The Remarkables. In the North Island, the biggest developed area is Whakapapa, which has 18 lifts, including a high-speed quad. The length of the season varies, but most resorts open in June - Mount Hutt usually starts in May - and close in mid-October or November. Helicopter operators include the long-established Harris Mountains Heli-skiing, which flies skiers and snowboarders from Queenstown and Wanaka, to more than 200 peaks in seven mountain ranges with runs varying from 2,000-4,000 vertical feet, fitting the terrain to their abilities. A day, including three descents, costs around £185 at the current exchange rate. For further details of skiing in New Zealand, try www.snow.co.nz. Australia In New South Wales, Thredbo, 280 miles from Sydney, has some of the best skiing in Australia - three years ago, it was hit by a tragic mud slide in which 18 people died - and Perisher Blue has some of the most challenging runs though more than half its terrain is graded intermediate. In Victoria, Mount Buller claims the country's biggest lift system with 28, including eight four-seaters. Other options in the state are Falls Creek and Mount Hotham The latter also has some fairly difficult skiing and should have a new airport open for the start of the season in June, enabling skiers to fly there in 21 minutes from Melbourne and 47 minutes from Sydney by Qantas regional subsidiary airlines.  Periods when glacier lifts are open vary. webTitle: To à or not to à

fields.headline: To à or not to à
fields.standfirst: The readers' editor on... the almost insoluble Becket question
fields.trailText: The readers' editor on... the almost insoluble Becket question
fields.body:
About nine months ago we carried an obituary of a medieval historian in the course of which the author of the piece, another medieval historian, referred to Thomas Becket. This was changed by the sub-editor to Thomas à Becket, and according to the Guardian style rules, he or she was absolutely right to do so. If our own style guide does not offer any advice, which in this case it does not, then we turn to the millennium edition of Collins English dictionary. This admirable tome has him under the Bs, thus: Becket (n), Saint Thomas à, 1118-70, English prelate; chancellor (1155-62) to Henry II; archbishop of Canterbury (1162-70); murdered following his opposition to Henry's attempts to control the clergy.

The trouble was that this particular style, Thomas à Becket, was a form which the subject of the obituary had spent the better part of a lifetime resisting. The change in the obituary brought a sharp little note from the writer: "Please could you put in a correction... the intrusive à in Thomas Becket's name ought not to be there - and it was a 19th-century invention that [the subject of the obituary] himself found particularly vexatious. His Becket lectures always began with an absolute prohibition."

Let me explain something about the corrections column. The purpose of a correction should be to put right a simple error or to resolve a matter of contention beyond further argument. In the case of Thomas's à, I decided a correction would not do that.

An electronic search of references to him over the past year in newspapers in the UK and Ireland found Thomas Becket outnumbered almost three to one (30 Beckets, 83 à Beckets). Mind you, some impressive forces were discovered lining up behind, let us call him the sans Becket, among them the compilers of the national curriculum in history for the period 1066 to 1500.

If you turn to Encyclopaedia Britannica (or britannica.com) you will find that Saint Thomas Becket is preferred, but then it notes "also called Thomas à Becket or Thomas of London". The Dictionary of National Biography places him firmly in the Ts as Thomas, adding "known as Thomas à Becket". At Canterbury they eschew the à and call him Saint Thomas or Thomas Becket. But you see what I mean, it is not a short correction.

You may wonder why, almost 10 months after the historian's obituary appeared, I am referring to it only now. This week I had a letter from another historian who referred to the obituary and explained that she was trying to establish the origin of the intrusive à. "Footling as the point may seem, tracing the way that historical myths and traditions arise can be quite illuminating. Anyway that is what I am doing..." Was there, she wondered, some reference work in newspaper offices that explained the certainty that Thomas Becket should be Thomas à Becket? Or did we know it was right because it looked so medieval?

Certainly, the à is as persistent as a wasp at a picnic. When I rang my correspondent she told me how, when she had been involved in setting an Oxford University examination paper in medieval history, all references to Becket carefully avoided the à; but when the printed papers came back from Oxford University Press, the printer had inserted it.

She believes that printers and publishers may have a good deal to do with the establishment and perpetuation of the à, for which no one appears to have found any medieval authority. She has dicovered it imposed upon title pages and book covers in the 18th century without any support from the text. "So far I have traced it as far back as the late 17th-century Oxford antiquarian Anthony Wood, who also took to calling himself Anthony à Wood, apparently because he thought it looked more distinguished."

You may feel it is much àdo about nothing. For the sake of consistency we should decide, and my vote goes with the historians. If you have something interesting to say on the subject I shall see that my correspondent gets a copy.

Coincidentally I received a very choleric note from another reader complaining of my failure to correct the erroneous statement that Becket had been killed before the high altar. "Millions of visitors will have known that the actual location was in a side chapel dedicated to St Benedict." He went on, " ...to declare your dedication to accuracy and responsibility is misleading, dissembling and hypocritical, even lying". Oh, dear.

According to Canterbury Cathedral Thomas was murdered in the northwest transept and not in the chapel which in Thomas's day was just to the east of the transept and was indeed dedicated to St Benedict. They quote The Architectural History of Canterbury Cathedral, by Professor R Willis (Longman, 1845), see page 123.

On this note I leave you for a month's sabbatical. Please, don't try to follow me.

fields.headline: Internal affairs
fields.standfirst: Christopher Dodd loses himself in the maze of narrow streets only to find himself in an oasis of cool, tiled courtyards and tapas bars
fields.trailText: Christopher Dodd loses himself in the maze of narrow streets only to find himself in an oasis of cool, tiled courtyards and tapas bars.
fields.body:
Setting off from my hotel, near the old Hospital de las Cinco Llagas, now the Andalucian Parliament, I passed through a portal of the old city wall and headed for the centre of town. It was Sunday morning and the streets were deserted.

The route took me through quiet little plazas, past the churches of Santa Marina and San Luis, San Marcos and Santa Isabel, to the convent of Santa Paula and a walled garden, the Jardines del Valle. Bandsmen were assembling in the plaza near the church of Santa Catalina. Seville grabs any excuse for a f te or festival, and nothing is more haunting than the music that accompanies the parading of icons through the streets during Holy Week.

Neighbourhood bars were now busy dispensing coffee and pastries, and I circumnavigated the 17th-century convent of San Leandro, where the nuns are famous for their egg-yolk sweets, called yemas .

On the far side, I came upon the Casa de Pilatus. Completed in 1540, the palace is a renaissance building in Moorish mudéjar style. Its ground floor is a stunning display of tiled courtyards and a garden, and its first floor a succession of cool, lofty rooms with wonderful beamed and panelled ceilings. This oasis is typical of the old city. Behind massive doors and grilled and shuttered windows in the maze of narrow streets lurk courtyards and patios, ferns and palms, marble anterooms and staircases.

Refreshed, I continued through the maze and emerged rather suddenly at the cathedral. "Let us build a cathedral so immense that every one on beholding it will take us for madmen," they said when they knocked down the mosque to make room for it in 1401. They succeeded madly.

Massive though it is, the cathedral is well hidden until you get close. The former minaret is now the belltower, attached to a building of gargantuan proportions and diverse style, cavernous and all-pervading gloom inside, stuffed with paintings by masters including Murillo, Zurbaran and Goya, copious mudéjar craftsmanship, paid for with looted Latin American silver. There's even a hanging crocodile carcass.

Round another corner is the Alcazar and its gardens. Mostly built in the 14th century by Peter the Cruel, very little of it dates from the pre-Christian period, but the decoration is based on the Alhambra in Granada. There was a long queue for entrance on my Sunday walk, so get there early or choose another time. The Alcazar's Court of the Maidens, royal and admiral's apartments and its exquisite gardens are worth the effort.

I wandered on to the Alphonse XIII hotel, built in Andalucian-Moorish style for the Ibero-American Exhibition of 1929, formal and very grand, with accompanying prices. Behind the hotel is the old tobacco factory completed in 1757, a vast series of courtyards, now the main building of the university (closed on Sundays). Carmen rolled her own here.

This was enough meandering before siesta, and I found a restaurant with a terrace overlooking the river for sherry, bread, beer, shrimps, omelette, beans and capers.

The restaurant was on the edge of Triana, the old Gypsy quarter, quite different in character from the old town but appealing nevertheless. Beyond Triana is the 1992 Expo site, much of it forlorn but with a new Olympic stadium close by, and an Olympic rowing and canoeing centre on the river.

Expo brought fast trains from Madrid - the best way to arrive in Seville, a grand journey through a haunting landscape - and transformed the river into a place of recreation and sport. Its old role as gateway to the New World had long since moved to Cadiz.

My walk also missed out the old Jewish quarter of Santa Cruz, the bullring with its museum, the main shopping street and the Town Hall, besides countless churches, convents, nooks and plazas. I have spent two or three days in Seville several times, and have hardly scratched the surface of its Moorish and Christian culture, its obsession with fighting bulls, its haunting Semana Santa (Holy Week) parades which engulf the whole city, less in religious fervour than in all-day and all-night bar-crawling while following the endless parading of religious images. The culmination of Holy Week in Seville is the first bullfight of the season, so you can judge the attitude. Book early to avoid disappointment.

A further Sevillian mystery is flamenco, a subculture that, aside from its pat tourist bars, is hard to penetrate. For the real stuff, seek local advice.

The best thing about a meander in Seville is that no matter how lost you get, you can always find a bar serving tapas. Eating and drinking little but often is perfectly suited to a hot climate of starkly contrasting light and shade. This has never been easier than here, at a table in the street or a cool interior under the hanging hams and chorizo, aided by golden liquid from Jerez or cold Cruzcampo beer.

Best tapas in town

Sol y Sombra Calle Castilla, Triana Tiny and traditional with outstanding tapas.

Bar Alicantina Plaza del Salvador Outdoor sea food heaven.

Portagayola Santander Tapas with pictures depicting the near-demise of the owner at the horns of a bull.

Rio Granda Calle Betis Riverside restaurant in a street with several bars and night clubs.

Teraza La Primera del Puente Calle Betis Also recommended.

The practicals

The Magic of Spain has city breaks to Seville starting from £309 for 2 nights at the 3 star Hotel Cervantes, a small hotel close to the main shopping area. The price includes scheduled flights. Call 020 8748 4220 for reservations or 0990 462442 for a brochure, and visit www.magictravelgroup.co.uk. The bull-fighting season is from March to October.

fields.headline: Airport departures
fields.standfirst: Ros Taylor offers advice on how to make your visit to the terminus as painless as possible
fields.trailText: Ros Taylor offers advice on how to make your visit to the terminus as painless as possible
fields.body:
There is, of course, no such thing as a pleasant airport experience - with the possible exception of Stansted's coffee bar on a sunny afternoon - but there are ways of making the interminable wait between check-in and take-off more exciting. Perhaps surprisingly, the web is rather a good place to alleviate the tedium.

If you're travelling with children, bear in mind that most big airline sites devote a considerable amount of space to their fleet. Diagrams of a Boeing's seat plan or photos of a gleaming new Airbus may not excite you, but they can help to distract children from fears about flying and provide an opportunity for plane-spotting in the departure lounge.

British Airports Authority
For some, an hour isn't enough to weigh up the merits of Russian and Finnish vodka or discounted French moisturisers. BAA recently launched an online store encouraging customers to buy ahead and collect their tax-free purchases on the spot. It's also possible to pre-order currency and book parking in the same way. The central site has real-time flight arrival details.

Holiday extras
The lugubrious Holiday extras claims to offer up to 55% off car parking and hotel bookings at UK airports. When I visited, the pages downloaded more slowly than luggage on a carousel but, if it speeds up, the site could prove useful.

New York JFK's site is a disappointment, and although Paris Airports and Schipoll are better, navigating them is unlikely to markedly improve your stopover. Hong Kong's new Chek Lap Kok has some impressively detailed maps and photos of the world's largest enclosed public space and the "tranquil" passenger terminal.

Sleeping at Airports
Can an airport double as a hotel? Sleeping at Airports is devoted to this ghastly prospect. Recommended only for the most desperate backpackers who carry a padlock and a thick sleeping-bag with them at all times.
fields.bodyText: There is, of course, no such thing as a pleasant airport experience - with the possible exception of Stansted's coffee bar on a sunny afternoon - but there are ways of making the interminable wait between check-in and take-off more exciting. Perhaps surprisingly, the web is rather a good place to alleviate the tedium. If you're travelling with children, bear in mind that most big airline sites devote a considerable amount of space to their fleet. Diagrams of a Boeing's seat plan or photos of a gleaming new Airbus may not excite you, but they can help to distract children from fears about flying and provide an opportunity for plane-spotting in the departure lounge. British Airports Authority For some, an hour isn't enough to weigh up the merits of Russian and Finnish vodka or discounted French moisturisers. BAA recently launched an online store encouraging customers to buy ahead and collect their tax-free purchases on the spot. It's also possible to pre-order currency and book parking in the same way. The central site has real-time flight arrival details. Holiday extras The lugubrious Holiday extras claims to offer up to 55% off car parking and hotel bookings at UK airports. When I visited, the pages downloaded more slowly than luggage on a carousel but, if it speeds up, the site could prove useful. New York JFK's site is a disappointment, and although Paris Airports and Schipoll are better, navigating them is unlikely to markedly improve your stopover. Hong Kong's new Chek Lap Kok has some impressively detailed maps and photos of the world's largest enclosed public space and the "tranquil" passenger terminal. fields.headline: M&S rejects £37.5m bill
fields.standfirst: Union fights on to get compensation for lost jobs
fields.trailText: The GMB union yesterday pledged to step up its campaign against Marks & Spencer after the retailer turned down a union plea for £5,000 compensation for each of the 7,500 textile workers who lose their jobs as a result of the firm's switch to cheap foreign producers.
fields.body:
The GMB union yesterday pledged to step up its campaign against Marks & Spencer after the retailer turned down a union plea for £5,000 compensation for each of the 7,500 textile workers who lose their jobs as a result of the firm's switch to cheap foreign producers.

The union plans newspaper advertisements, demonstrations outside M&S stores and a campaign of letter-writing to the group's leading shareholders to win support for its claim.

The GMB also hopes to bring political pressure to bear because most of the workers hit by the M&S decision, at facto ries owned by Daks Simpson, William Baird and Coats Viyella, are in Labour heartlands.

The union's claim for compensation, which would total £37.5m, was made by the general secretary, John Edmonds, at a secret meeting last month with Peter Salsbury, Marks' chief executive. The retailer insisted yesterday it was an informal, regular meeting between the two men and the company had no intention of compensating the workers.

The store said: "The first responsibility of Marks & Spencer is to the health of the business, which will remain the largest customer of the UK clothing industry."

A GMB spokesman said the union had received no official reply to its claim and was "amazed and bitterly disappointed" by M&S's refusal to negotiate. He pointed out that the number of workers affected by the move was "about the same as the number which are likely to be affected by BMW's decision to pull out of Longbridge".

The union added: "Marks & Spencer still made more than half a billion pounds profit last year, and £5,000 for loyal workers who have worked for decades on M&S contracts and are now being thrown out on to the streets would be a small price to pay. How much longer is Marks and Spencer prepared to see its name dragged through the mud?"

webTitle: Three more athletes get racist hate mail

fields.headline: Three more athletes get racist hate mail
fields.standfirst: Race issues in the UK: special report
fields.trailText: The racists who last week attacked the British international athlete Ashia Hansen's boyfriend have sent hate mail to three other top track and field internationals, demanding that they withdraw from the Olympic Games this summer because they are black, it emerged yesterday.
fields.body:
The racists who last week attacked the British international athlete Ashia Hansen's boyfriend have sent hate mail to three other top track and field internationals, demanding that they withdraw from the Olympic Games this summer because they are black, it emerged yesterday.

Although police refused to be specific about the contents of the letters, it is known they were similar to one found by Hansen at her home the day after her partner, Chris Cotter, who is white, was stabbed. The letters were signed WANO - possibly an acronym for White Aryan Nazi Organisation.

UK Athletics, the sport's governing body, said yesterday the male athletes, who have not been named, had been upset rather than frightened.

Max Jones, its performance director, said: "It was a shock. They're thinking: 'Why me? Why have I been targeted?' It's distressing for all of them. There are pressures on them when competing but this is a different thing to handle."

The organisation has sent a letter to all the country's top athletes warning of the hate mail and asking that they contact the police immediately if they are targeted.

West Midlands police said yesterday they were sure that the racists who attacked Mr Cotter last week were also behind this campaign. Mr Cotter, 28, was stabbed in the back and slashed across the forehead by a gang of at least four men who approached him outside Ms Hansen's home in Erdington, Birmingham. He lost four pints of blood and needed 17 stitches.

One of the men told Mr Cotter: "We warned you not to mix with niggers."

Mr Cotter believes they were really after his girlfriend, a triple jumper with chances of a gold medal in the Sydney Olympics, and that they intended to maim her.

Hansen found a hate mail letter on her porch the morning after the attack, which police are treating as attempted murder. It read: "You were lucky last time. We won't make the same mistake again."

Det Supt Tony Garbett, who is leading the investigation, said yesterday the letters sent to the other athletes were posted in Birmingham on Wednesday last week, two days before details of the attack were made public. Like the letter to Hansen, it was made up of letters and words cut out from newspapers and magazines.

However, the sender did not know the addresses of the athletes. The letters were posted to the headquarters of UK Athletics, which forwarded them believing they were fan mail.

Two of the letters were opened on Tuesday, and the third was opened on Thursday night. Mr Garbett said: "The letters are not threatening, but are racist in nature."

Another police source added: "The letters are photocopies which say black people should not be representing Britain at the Olympics this year. They were written on the same paper as the letter sent to Ms Hansen."

Mr Garbett said he did not believe that an organised far-right group was operating in the West Midlands.

He said he had never heard of an organisation called WANO. Gerry Gable, publisher of Searchlight, the anti-fascist magazine, said: "This is just a made-up name of convenience. These idiots will emerge again in a few weeks with another name."

The magazine warned, however, that the midlands has a long history of racial tension. "The National Front and Combat 18 have had a presence in the area in the past," said a spokesman.

In February, Michael Johnson, a black Birmingham City footballer, received a racist letter at the club. It was sent from London and is not thought to be connected with the latest hate campaign.

Two years ago a series of death threats were sent to black community leaders on Birmingham council notepaper. Harjinder Singh, of the Birmingham racial attacks monitoring unit, said yesterday there were a number of no-go areas in the city for black people.

"There has been a definite increase in the number of racist incidents in the past year. On one estate, a black family was shot at with a gun," he said.

"The Falcon Lodge estate has been flooded with racist literature and stickers on lamp-posts which are quite horrific. It is important to catch the perpetrators of this racism so it is made clear that this sort of thing will not be tolerated and must be stamped out."

fields.headline: Police rethink over double 'suicide'
fields.standfirst: Race issues in the UK: special report
fields.trailText: Police are treating the deaths of two black men from the same family found hanging in Telford as murder, the Guardian has learned.
fields.body:
Police are treating the deaths of two black men from the same family found hanging in Telford as murder, the Guardian has learned.

The family of Errol and Jason McGowan claimed that two investigations by West Mercia police had dismissed the deaths within six months of each other as suicide. The McGowans said Errol died after a campaign of racial harassment and death threats.

It is increasingly unlikely that Errol's death was suicide and evidence suggests it was suspicious, according to sources with knowledge of the investigation.

The McGowan family believe the decision to treat the deaths as foul play is a vindication for their campaign. The murder investigation is staffed by 47 detectives, analysts and civilians. Errol McGowan, 34, was found dead in July 1999. His nephew Jason, 20, who had been investigating his uncle's death was found on New Year's Day, hanging from railings by a busy road in the Shropshire town.

West Mercia's chief constable, Peter Hampson, agreed to a fresh investigation into both deaths after pressure from the McGowans. In a highly unusual move he agreed to the involvement of deputy assistant commissioner John Grieve, a Scotland Yard officer specialising in tackling racist crime.

The new investigation began on February 1 under Detective Superintendent Mel Shore.

Police are treating the deaths as murder, though detectives are keeping an open mind.

One factor leading police to suspect foul play is the highly unusual manner of Errol's death. The pub bouncer was found in a friend's house hanging from a doorknob barely three feet from the ground.

A source said: "The way he killed himself is so unusual, it's not the thing you'd try unless you knew others who had done it. You'd be likely to fail unless you knew exactly how to do it.

"There are more unanswered questions about Errol but both could be murder. There are a lot of questions that haven't been asked by the first investigation team."

Another source said: "The more that is unearthed, the more it points away from suicide and towards murder."

A spokesman for West Mercia police said: "Since February 1 Detective Superintendent Mel Shore has been pursuing an investigation into the deaths if Errol and Jason McGowan starting from an initial presumption of foul play. The investigation is progressing well." The spokesman would give no other details.

Last week West Mercia's chief constable apologised to the McGowan family.

Mr Hampson wrote: "I am very sorry that the service we have given you in the past has been less than satisfactory and hope that you might be able to accept this apology."

The source said that the first investigation teams had made too many assumptions and had believed a racist killing could not happen in Shropshire.

Errol's brother, Leroy McGowan, said: "If it's treated as murder every avenue will be looked down and maybe we'll get answers from that.

"West Mercia did not take it seriously. The new investigation happened because of the publicity.

"We fear that evidence might have been lost because of the time that's gone."

The McGowan family regard Mr Grieve, head of Scotland Yard's race and violent crimes task force, as the de facto senior investigating officer in the investigation.

They had demanded that West Mercia be stripped of control of the inquiry and that Scotland Yard take over.

webTitle: Council tax rises bode ill for Labour's local poll hopes

fields.headline: Council tax rises bode ill for Labour's local poll hopes
fields.standfirst: New Labour in power: special report
fields.trailText: Labour's local election worries deepened yesterday when it was forced to defend average council tax rises of 6.2% in England this year, almost three times the inflation rate.
fields.body:
Labour's local election worries deepened yesterday when it was forced to defend average council tax rises of 6.2% in England this year, almost three times the inflation rate.

Amid warnings from ministers that the party faces its worst electoral performance in nearly a decade in local elec tions next month, Conservatives accused the government of increasing town hall taxes by stealth by cutting support to local councils.

While Labour claimed that council taxpayers in areas under its control were paying less on average than those served by Tory or Liberal Democrat councils, ministers are clearly embarrassed by the level of the tax in heartland areas and some big cities. They expect a significant fall in the party's performance on May 4, though Tories say Labour is lowering expectations to save face.

Labour sources yesterday claimed that the Conservatives would have to win back more than 500 seats out of 3,337 up for grabs in metropolitan and unitary authorities and district councils to show they were making significant gains.

Labour argues that its showing in 1996 was one of its strongest ever, and says it expects to gain fewer seats than the Tories next month. Strategists say it will be hit by low turnout in Labour areas.

Labour figures showed that the annual average 2000-01 bill per household for Labour authorities was £654.60, whereas for Tory councils it was £756.75 and for Liberal Democrat coun cils £762.55. Tory-controlled Westminster has the lowest band D tax of £350, while Liberal Democrat Liverpool has the highest at £1,171 - frozen for the past year.

Government figures yesterday put the average band D tax at £847, varying from £919 over metropolitan areas, largely Labour controlled, to £778 in London and £843 in the shires.

Archie Norman, shadow environment secretary, said: "In three years the average band D tax has risen by £150, proof that Labour tax more and deliver less."

Don Foster, Liberal Democrat environment spokesman, accused the government of underfunding councils, although this year the government gave English councils £42.8m, an increase of 5.5%.

fields.headline: Boy story
fields.standfirst: One of the most refreshing Oscar winners in years, Hilary Swank can at last put those embarrassing early career moves behind her. Well, almost
fields.trailText: One of the most refreshing Oscar winners in years, Hilary Swank can at last put those embarrassing early career moves behind her. Well, almost
fields.body:
Hilary Swank has definitely come a long way. She uttered the phrase: "That is so five minutes ago!" in the original Buffy The Vampire Slayer movie, and kicked up attention in the box-office bust The Next Karate Kid. Then, after a stint on pretty people parade Beverly Hills 90210 as a single mom, Swank chopped off her lengthy locks for the indie hit Boys Don't Cry, which has earned her a seemingly infinite amount of praise and awards, culminating in this year's Best Actress Oscar. In Boys, Swank embodies the role of real-life character Brandon Teena  really a girl named Teena Brandon who realised early in life that she was born in the wrong body. So despite being a biological woman, Teena lived his life as a man. In her own life, Swank (who ironically was born in Teena's home town of Lincoln, Nebraska) is far less gendered-confused. She has been married to actor Chad Lowe for over two years, and the couple share their Los Angeles home with a menagerie that includes dogs, an African parrot and a rabbit.

Has all of this attention taken you by surprise?

I wouldn't say by surprise, it's something that has been evolving. It's definitely very exciting, and it's really nice when people recognise your work, especially when it's for a movie that you're so proud of.

How has your life changed since the movie came out?

People have been very respectful. I think most people feel like it's an important movie too. I have been sent a lot of scripts, and it's very humbling. Following this movie up is hard; finding something that I respond to and that can stretch me as an artist and as a human being is not easy.

How do you look back on shooting Boys Don't Cry?

It was very emotionally draining and physically exhausting. We worked very, very long hours: 18 hours a day, six days a week. I felt a huge obligation to tell the story honestly in a way that would make Brandon proud.

Did you do a lot of preparation?

I knew if I couldn't pass myself off as a boy, that I would be doing the film a great injustice. So I lived my life for four weeks before filming as a boy, seeing when did I pass, when did I not pass. I read books on transgendered people  lots of literature which let me into the thinking and the emotions that they feel. Because I know that I can go back to being a girl that people can define, but not what it feels to live that, to know from the very beginning that you've been put in the wrong body. And there was the physical transformation  cutting my hair off, losing weight, not necessarily pounds but body fat so that what was masculine about me, like my jaw bones, would protrude. I trained for two hours a day lifting weights.

How does it feel becoming a lesbian icon?

I love it. I've had a lot of gays and lesbians come up to me and say, "We're so glad that you're straight because if you weren't people would think that this was a gay movie, and it's not a gay movie." I found that very interesting.

Do you groan when people mention The Next Karate Kid?

I don't look back at anything that I did and think, "Why did I do that?" because it all made me who I am now. And without all of that, I couldn't have pulled off the performance that I did. Yes, I look at it and groan. I look at my work in it and go, "Ohhhhh." But I learned a lot from that.

What do you do to kick back?

I love having friends over to play games. Scrabble and Celebrity. So much fun. I love to go to movies. They're my passion.

webTitle: Should we ease the law on possessing soft drugs?

fields.headline: Should we ease the law on possessing soft drugs?
fields.standfirst: As a highly respected police charity recommends downgrading the punishments for possession of ecstasy and cannabis, is it finally time for the law to recognise that different drugs should attract different penalties? Or will changes in the law merely encourage dealers while doing nothing to alleviate the sometimes devastating consequences of misuse? In this week's debate, Mike Goodman of the drug users' support service Release tackles the issue with Peter Gammon, president of the Police Superintendents' Association of England and Wales. Read the debate and have your say.
fields.trailText:
Dear Peter,
I see you reject the Police Foundation's proposal this week to downgrade ecstasy and LSD to a class B drug, and cannabis to class C, because "it would send out the wrong message to the young and impressionable in our society". What kind of argument is this?
fields.body:
Dear Peter,
I see you reject the Police Foundation's proposal this week to downgrade ecstasy and LSD to a class B drug, and cannabis to class C, because "it would send out the wrong message to the young and impressionable in our society". What kind of argument is this?

Surely the severity of the penalties society attaches to any given offence must be based on the relative dangers the activity creates? The English legal system is founded on respect for fairness and justice, at the heart of which is the principle of proportionality - that the punishment must fit the crime. Either these drugs deserve this level of sanction because of the dangers they cause, or they do not. The truth is they do not.

We would welcome more research on mood-enhancing drugs, because there is still much to learn. But we are sure of some things: ecstasy and LSD are not in the same danger league as heroin and crack cocaine, and those who bracket them together are irresponsibly fostering public ignorance. The law on cannabis, never in more disrepute, is wrong in principle and unworkable in practice; because most people are well aware how safe cannabis is compared to the real killers, alcohol and tobacco.

This week the government also refused to reduce the limit on drink-driving - which kills almost as many people as all illegal drugs put together. So how can you talk about "sending messages" to young people when you really mean criminalising them? We must raise the debate above this sloganising; the Police Foundation's proposals do this. We have a responsibility to respond in kind.

Yours,
Mike Goodman,
Director,
Release

Dear Mike,
The Police Foundation acknowledges that there is a paucity of research and information about drug use, yet recommends fundamental changes to the way we tackle the issue. You have adopted a similar stance, and that I find worrying. But I wouldn't like you to misrepresent my views, so I'd like to state them accurately.

I said that the "de-penalisation" of cannabis misuse would serve to encourage young and impressionable people to partake of the drug. I think the classification of the drug is an irrelevance to the user or potential user, and I made no claim that changes in classification would have an impact on them. But I do believe the demoting of certain harmful drugs to a lower class does have an effect on those who supply and deal, because the penalties are less severe. The obvious outcome is that dealers see less risk and a growing market.

Very few people are prosecuted or imprisoned simply for possession. The current drug strategy - law enforcement, education, treatment and rehabilitation - reflects that position. I support it, and I believe we are seeing it beginning to work. If we weaken one strand, we weaken the whole of it.

I'm not at odds with you over the harm that alcohol does. You overlook, however, the growing evidence of how many road deaths are associated with drug use. It's unproductive to scream about the effects of alcohol and tobacco if we're not going to translate the lessons learned from those statistics into action with other drugs. Legalisation of alcohol and tobacco has not provided answers. Is the legalisation of other drugs likely to be so different?

Yours,
Peter Gammon,
President,
Police Superintendents' Association of England and Wales

Dear Peter,
It's inadequate to dismiss the proposals about classification as irrelevant to the user because few people are prosecuted or imprisoned for possession. Drugs laws damage lives. In 1998, police and courts dealt with almost 128,000 people for drugs offences, 76% for cannabis.

The vast majority were for possession of small amounts, often by otherwise law-abiding young people who would feel humiliated and intimidated by the process. Over half were cautioned rather than sent to court - but still tainted by a system that has proved ineffective in controlling the demand or supply of drugs.

You misjudge my views on drugs and driving: those who drive under the influence of drugs must be prosecuted and accept the penalties. We are all waiting for a suitable test that proves impairment rather than previous drug use. A law doesn't have to be just, or even logical or rational. But it should meet these requirements to be worthy of a civilised society.

If the classification of a drug is only maintained because the system would be weakened by attention to its most discredited parts, that reveals a need for sensible reform.

Yours,
Mike

Dear Mike,
Please don't try to put your own interpretation on what I say. I did not claim classification is irrelevant because few people are prosecuted or imprisoned for possession.

If someone is considering using cannabis, or even heroin, it doesn't matter to that individual how the law classifies the drug. He or she does not say, "this is a class A drug so I will not use it, but this is a class B drug so I will". The principal factors influencing choice are availability, peer group behaviour and society's standards.

You claim drugs laws are damaging lives. I wonder how you react to drug abuse damaging lives. I have (and I suspect you have) seen the devastating consequences of drugs misuse on the users, families and friends. Youngsters turn to crime, prostitute themselves, damage their health and destroy relationships; many die. Relaxing the control of drugs would do nothing to change that.

You say those with whom the police deal suffer from the ordeal. Let me remind you of the humiliation, intimidation and isolation felt by many drugs users. What you fail to point out is that law enforcement is often the gateway to programmes to help drugs users. If that didn't happen, many would not get the support and expert attention they need.

Yours,
Peter

Dear Peter,
I have no desire to put my own interpretation on what you say - just to follow the logic of your position. You say it does not matter to an individual considering using a drug how the law classifies it - but that this does deter suppliers and so the law must stay unchanged.

But this is based on the curious principle of penalising the user for the crimes of the dealer. The idea that suppliers are deterred by the current classification is not supported by evidence: in the last 10 years, seizures of class A drugs have increased sevenfold - twice the class B rate. Potential users' understanding of comparative health risks does influence their choice of drug; fortunately, they tend to be much more discerning than legislators.

I am only too aware of the damage drugs can cause. Every day since 1967, Release has listened to callers suffering from the terrible consequences drug abuse brings, and we have done our utmost to bring help to users and their loved ones in the face of chronic underfunding. So we are delighted by the long overdue expansion of drug treatment services, and the scope for "gateway programmes" like arrest referral schemes. We're running a national conference on this later in the month; we'd be pleased to welcome you as our guest.

There are no perfect solutions, but the public seems ready for an informed debate on the options for change. On behalf of the people you and I work with, we have a responsibility to accept that challenge.

Yours,
Mike

Dear Mike,
Clearly there are some people who are prepared to deal in the most dangerous drugs and to face the legal consequences. Deterrents do not work for that type of criminal. But they can work for those operating at the lower end of the dealing hierarchy. Statistics on the type of drugs seized do not negate that view. The number of seizures reflects the focus of policing activity rather than indicating the comparative levels of trafficking in different drugs.

That we need to target suppliers, particularly the international criminal organisations, is beyond question. Perhaps that is the less complex part of the strategy - the aims and objectives are clear and there is a consensus of opinion.

The more difficult issues relate to drug use. As you say, there are no perfect solutions. There is a divergence of views, facts get skewed, passions are aroused.

We disagree on a number of things, but I do agree with you that the debate must continue, even in its sometimes ill-informed way. I hear people say the war against drugs is lost. I disagree. It is only lost when we become disinterested or complacent. I'd very much like to join you at your conference; I look forward to continuing our conversation face to face.

Yours,
Peter

fields.headline: Science paperbacks
fields.trailText: The chart of paperback science books is entirely dominated by physics.
fields.body:
Last week, we looked at hardback sales in science books. This week's paperback charts show a very different line-up - the most noticeable feature being that, with the honourable exceptions of Richard Dawkins and Edward O. Wilson, it is entirely dominated by physics.

It seems that we're more fascinated by chaos and quarks than by the vagaries of our own genes or behaviour. Jim Al-Khalali's Black Holes, Wormholes and Time Machines might sound like something that fell off the back of an SF channel, but actually it is the sort of sound, clear science reader that you might need before embarking on Stephen Hawking's ever-popular Brief History of Time or Brian Greene's taxing Elegant Universe.

The most interesting front-runner is The Meaning of it All, a collection of lectures from the 1960s by Richard Feyman, a man who never lived to board the pop-science bandwagon, and probably wouldn't have anyway. Bongo playing is much more fun.

webTitle: Fire kills 74 locked in porn cinema

fields.headline: Fire kills 74 locked in porn cinema
fields.trailText: A fire broke out in the video parlour of the town close to the Henan-Shanxi provincial border, killing 63 men and 11 women. The men were mostly local youths or migrant workers whose families lived in the country.
fields.body:
The owner of the Paradise Cinema in Jiaozuo city locked the main entrance as he did every night, so that his customers could watch pornographic films undisturbed.

But at 3.30am on Wednesday morning a fire broke out in the video parlour of the town close to the Henan-Shanxi provincial border, killing 63 men and 11 women. The men were mostly local youths or migrant workers whose families lived in the country.

Most of the women were reportedly trapped in private boxes where they were "entertaining" customers. But one was the owner's wife and there are conflicting stories as to whether the owner himself fled or was also trapped.

He had sealed the main entrance with a steel grille lowered to the ground to prevent the police intruding. Only a few people inside managed to escape by breaking into the video parlour next door.

Yesterday, a red lantern still hung incongruously above the steel grille, in front of the burnt out shell of the building. Once again China has been shaken by a fire disaster which raises worrying questions about poor public safety and law enforcement.

President Jiang Zemin in Beijing has ordered an urgent investigation into the fire and the governor of Henan province quickly arrived on the scene.

By a grim coincidence, another devastating fire at the other end of the country had also taken young lives a few hours before, prompting another demand from Beijing for a serious investigation.

An explosion on Tuesday afternoon in a cigarette lighter factory in the southern province of Guangdong killed 17 young women workers and injured many more - the youngest victim was 14 years old.

The fire swept through a long workshop with a door at one end and no fire escapes: those caught furthest from the door were asphyxiated by thick smoke.

The factory, owned by an overseas Chinese entrepreneur from Thailand, had recently moved to Huilai county, where labour costs are lower than those near the Hong Kong border. Local officials allowed the factory to start work without a business permit or fire certificate.

The workers, mostly migrant women from at least five provinces, were filling disposable lighters - the kind sold for 35p in Hong Kong. Workers in this industry often complain of being poisoned by the fumes.

On this occasion, fuel seems to have leaked from a container causing a flash fire. "There was a sparking sound," said survivor Wang Zhenkuan - a young migrant from Henan province. "Then a red ball of fire rushed from the west end of the workshop to the other end."

Public anger has been stirred by a series of disasters in the past two years, often linked to poor safety or construction standards which had been ignored by corrupt officials. These have included the collapse of improperly designed bridges and buildings, ferry disasters - including one that cost 280 lives - and numerous fires and explosions.

Revelations about the embezzlement of construction funds and substandard work on the Three Gorges Dam on the Yangtze River have raised safety fears for the massive project. Collapses and explosions in mines - most of them without operating licences or safety equipment - take more than 1,000 lives a year.

In spite of repeated protests, many southern China sweatshops producing cheap goods for western and Asian markets continue to ignore minimum safety standards. A recent investigation of working conditions in Shenzhen, the booming economic zone next to Hong Kong, showed that in 1998 31 workers suffered from industrial injuries daily and one died every four and a half days.

This week's accidents in Henan and Guangdong provinces both involve migrant workers; many of the young girls killed in Huilai were migrants from Henan, one of China's inland provinces where poor rural conditions provide a regular supply of cheap labour.

The Chinese media has become less reticent to publish news of such disasters. Though most newspapers only gave brief details of the Jiaozuo fire, the popular Yangcheng Evening News reported the event fully. But investigative journalists are sometimes beaten or detained when they try to find out who is responsible.

The disasters have heightened public outrage at the corruption and negligence in the Communist party and government. But although the Chinese premier, Zhu Rongji, has urged officials not to turn a blind eye or take bribes, many people believe he is fighting an uphill battle.

webTitle: Hit movie prompts flood of water lawsuits

fields.headline: Hit movie prompts flood of water lawsuits
fields.standfirst: The latest Julia Roberts film, Erin Brockovich, is shaking giant US utility companies
fields.trailText: The success of a film starring Julia Roberts and based on the true story of a glamorous legal worker is causing panic in the boardrooms of big American utility companies
fields.body:
The success of a film starring Julia Roberts and based on the true story of a glamorous legal worker is causing panic in the boardrooms of big American utility companies. Such has been the effect of the film, which reveals how a utility company poisoned a water supply and had to pay millions in compensation, that many other potential plaintiffs are queuing to sue.

In the film, Erin Brockovich, directed by Stephen Soderbergh and also starring Albert Finney, Roberts plays Ms Brockovich, now 39, a single mother of three, who found herself working in 1992 in a small Californian law firm. She was studying a real-estate case when she noticed the large incidence of local residents with mysterious blood problems in the small town of Hinkley, in the Mojave desert.

Showing great persistence, the untrained Ms Brockovich won the confidence of local residents and, with her boss Ed Masry (played by Finney), helped to build a lawsuit against Pacific Gas & Electric. After four years of research and negotiation, the firm paid $333m (£208m) in compensation to the 650 residents. Ms Brockovich was rewarded with a $2m fee, and in July she will be honoured as citizen of the year by the American Trial Lawyers' Association.

The film, which makes much of the fact that Ms Brockovich liked to dress in short skirts and low-cut tops, has been a surprise hit, topping the best-selling film list in America: no mean feat for a movie based on such a potentially complex story. It is being seen as the millennium Silkwood - the film in which Meryl Streep starred as a whistle-blowing nuclear plant worker who was mysteriously killed.

But its effect has gone far beyond the box office. Ms Brockovich is already working on another lawsuit against PG & E. This time it is on behalf of 1,500 employees and their families who lived near another Californian plant, in San Joaquin Valley. They claim that their water supplies were contaminated with chromium in a period stretching from the 1950s to the 70s, and that this has caused cancers. Such has been the impact of the film that another 50 potential plaintiffs have contacted Ms Brockovich. If they succeed, the amounts awarded could dwarf the earlier settlement.

Litigation lawyers know that the more evidence of illness that is accumulated, the better the chance of a settlement being offered by the relevant corporation, so the film is doing a great evidence-gathering job for the lawsuit.

PG & E is aware that the film shows Ms Brockovich as honest, courageous and principled, while the company is portrayed in a far from flattering light. If the suit were to go to trial, the jurors might well identify with the Brockovich/Roberts side of the story and award damages accordingly.

The film will worry other utilities companies accused by local residents of causing environmental harm. Already Ms Brockovich is due to appear at a fundraising event for protesters against a PG & E plant in Salem, Massachusetts.

PG & E is contesting the latest case. A spokesman said a "very spirited and vigorous defence" would be mounted. He said that the movie was seen as an "entertainment vehicle" and was unlikely to influence jurors.

Erin Brockovich follows three Oscar-nominated films based on true stories, all of which attracted some negative response from some of the real-life characters involved.

The Insider celebrated a tobacco industry whistle-blower; the Hurricane was based on the life of a wrongly-convicted boxer, Rubin Carter; and Boys Don't Cry, which won Hilary Swank the best actress Oscar, was about a young woman who passed as a man and was murdered for doing so.

A spokesman said a "very spirited and vigorous defence" would be mounted. He said that the movie was seen as an "entertainment vehicle" and was unlikely to influence jurors. Erin Brockovich follows three Oscar-nominated films based on true stories, all of which attracted some negative response from some of the real-life characters involved. The Insider celebrated a tobacco industry whistle-blower; the Hurricane was based on the life of a wrongly-convicted boxer, Rubin Carter; and Boys Don't Cry, which won Hilary Swank the best actress Oscar, was about a young woman who passed as a man and was murdered for doing so.

webTitle: Mendes strikes beauty of a deal to form dream team with Spielberg

fields.headline: Mendes strikes beauty of a deal to form dream team with Spielberg
fields.trailText: The first-time film director Sam Mendes has struck an unprecedented deal with Steven Spielberg hot on the heels of his five-Oscar triumph with American Beauty.
fields.body:
The first-time film director Sam Mendes has struck an unprecedented deal with Steven Spielberg hot on the heels of his five-Oscar triumph with American Beauty.

So keen are Spielberg's DreamWorks studio to secure his future services that they are pumping £100,000 a year into his theatre, the Donmar Warehouse in London, to keep him sweet.

The unique arrangement also guarantees Mendes, 34, £250,000 a year to develop movies through his new company, Donmar Films. But if a brilliant script does comes along from another studio in the next two to three years, he is free to take it.

There were lots of other big- money offers, Mendes admitted yesterday. But all would have meant foresaking the intimate Covent Garden venue that he has turned into a force in world theatre.

His bottom line was always: "I'll do this deal if you fund the theatre. If I had signed an exclusive deal with DreamWorks I would probably could have got millions. But I am very con scious of allowing myself freedom. Without that freedom I have here at the Donmar, I would not have been able to make American Beauty."

Mendes gleefully confessed that he was now in a position to make "pretty much anything I want I suppose. Now is the time to make my Crusades epic for $120m. It would be quite a dangerous situation to be in actually if I wasn't so clear about what I want to do."

And after two years away from the rehearsal room, what he is "desperate" to do now is theatre. He will direct Twelfth Night at the Donmar in September, and although he has not yet cast it, he hinted that he would be going for a "home team" of English actors rather than importing big-name Americans.

He said Hollywood stars were queuing up "all the time" to work at the Donmar. "They see us as a way of increasingly their artistic validity, which is great. But that is not quite how we work. I'm nervous of star vehicles. As I think Philip Larkin said, the sun destroys the interest of what is going on in the shade. Often there is someone better for a role who is English or a theatre actor."

Mendes denied rumours that he was close to persuading Tom Cruise to tread the London boards soon. "I wish," he said. "It's far more likely that I will be working again with Nicole [Kidman]."

He did, however, concede that he was yearning to tempt Annette Bening, the star of American Beauty, across the Atlantic after she has her baby. "I don't know, it may take 10 years - she has four kids you know - but I would really love to bring her here."

He said he "hasn't a clue" what his next film will be, although it was a "safe bet" it would be one developed by Donmar Films, which he said he wanted to keep "small and light on its feet, a bit like this theatre".

He has has spent six months working on Lookout, written by Scott Frank, who adapted Elmore Leonard's Get Shorty and wrote the thriller Out of Sight, but he doubted that it would get off the ground for some time.

The DreamWorks money would be added to the £350,000 a year that the New York producer Anita Waxman is pumping into the Donmar so that she can bring their new productions to Broadway.

Mendes said it would allow them to be more adventurous and to get more people into the theatre with "lower seat prices and pay-as-you-wish nights. We are doing one next month for the Passion Play. You pay whatever you can afford, be that 10p or whatever."

He said he had enjoyed Los Angeles but wanted to work in England if possible. "Hollywood gets a bad rap here, but I enjoyed very much working with the people I met there.

"Obviously the Oscars was an entirely different experience. You are on a train and it's travelling at 120mph and you can't get off. Like every director, I'm a control freak. But all you can do is just sit there and grit your teeth. Some of the time it's exhilarating, sometimes it's not.

"I was doing publicity for the film for what seemed like a decade. Did I enjoy the Oscars? Well, it's the single most nerve-wracking experience ever.

"It is away out there on its own."

fields.headline: Piggmalion
fields.standfirst: Adrian Mole, aged 32 3/4
fields.trailText: The secret diary of a provincial man: Adrian Mole, aged 32 3/4
fields.body:
Monday, March 20, 2000

Glenn's photograph is on the front of tonight's Ashby Bugle. The headline said, "Glen cross about country run." It was not a flattering portrait: the combination of his new Beckham haircut and the way he was scowling into the sun gave him the look of a youth at a fascist training camp. As I paid for my copy, a pensioner behind me looked at Glenn and said, "I wunt like to meet him down a dark alley."

I longed to tell the mustachioed lard-belly that Glenn was a good boy, but she picked an argument with the newsagent about non-delivery of her People's Friend, so I left without defending my son. When I got home, I read the article with growing disgust; it was littered with inaccuracies.

To the Editor, the Ashby Bugle
Dear Sir, It is not my habit to write to the papers, but I must on this occasion as you have written an ill-informed and inaccurate article about my son, Glenn, and his refusal to wear shorts during cross-country running at his school, Neil Armstrong Comprehensive.

1. Glen is Glenn. You misspelt his name throughout.
2. I am Adrian Mole, not A Drain-Mole.
3. I am 33 years old, not 73.
4. I am not 'unemployed'; I am currently writing a serial-killer-comedy for the BBC called The White Van.
5. Glenn does not wear an earring in his right ear. He wears it in his left lobe.
6. Glenn does not have the support of our MP, Dr Pandora Braithwaite. She refused to back our campaign. I quote from her recent email: "I am too fg busy with the Onion Working Party to faff about with fg school uniform issues."

I remain, Sir, yours, A Mole, father of Glenn

Tuesday, March 21

Glenn came to me tonight as I was ironing and listening to the Archers. He begged me to allow him back to school, and said he would happily wear white shorts on cross-country runs. I reminded him that Midlands Today was interested in covering his campaign on its news spot.

He said, "It's not my campaign any more, Dad. It's yours." As I ironed his white shorts, I reflected on the sacrifices parents make for their children. I'll be a laughing stock at the next parents' evening.

Thursday, March 23

The following letter was in the Bugle tonight.

Dear Editor
The BBC would like to make it clear that Adrian Mole has not been commissioned by us to write a serial-killer-comedy called The White Van.

Yours sincerely, Geoffrey Perkins (Head of Comedy)

So, the BBC now employ spies to read the regional newspapers, does it? Institutional paranoia or what?

Friday, March 24

Pamela Pigg from the homeless unit called round on her way home from work, to tell me there's a vacant maisonette on the Prescott Estate. "It's a new housing complex, purpose-built for tenants aspiring to join the new middle class."

She said that Alan Titchmarsh had been consulted about the design of the patio/wheelie bin area. He had declined, but as Pamela said, "At least he was consulted."

I made her a cup of Kenco and broached the delicate matter of changing her name by deed poll. She got very defensive and said there had been a Pigg in the Domesday Book, a Pigg at Ypres, and recently a Pigg had been awarded an OBE for services to the post office. When I said tentatively, "Yes, but how can a Mole go out with a Pigg?" she said shyly, "Well, we'd be Pamela and Adrian, wouldn't we?"

Saturday, March 25

Pamela and I had our first tryst watching the boat race. I bet her £500 that Cambridge would win, but I don't care. I think I may be in love with a woman called Pigg.

fields.headline: Non-fiction
fields.trailText: Tony Blair likes it but don't let that put you off, plus Class in Britain and Sex in the Future
fields.body:
Living on Thin Air
Charles Leadbeater
Penguin, £6.99
Buy it at BOL

Tony Blair praises it priggishly on the cover but don't let that put you off: this is a genuine analysis of our transitional economic state. Skip Leadbeater's St Albion sermons and stick to his perceptions - defining tacit and explicit knowledge through Delia Smith recipes ("we do not need more information, we need more understanding" - most acute line of the work); explaining past aspirations of incremental betterment through Raymond Briggs's comic book Ethel and Ernest. Pleads for trust and compassion, but bases its future world on branding, celebrity and exploitative manipulation: just as nasty and brutish as Hobbes.

Class in Britain
David Cannadine
Penguin, £7.99
Buy it at BOL

Best we've read on pre-1980 Brit fantasies of structure. From the 19th century come Rev Marmaduke Pritchett's booming pronouncements on the divine order of inequality, and the immediate introduction, upon the invention of the railway, of first, second and third-class carriages; from the mid-20th comes young Peregrine Worsthorne's "the class system looks foolish and tacky when related to a second-class power on the decline"; and the Boys Brigade and Rotary processions in the Grantham of Mrs Thatcher's childhood. Cannadine ignores women, sex and food in relation to class, rather an invalidating omission.

Sex in the Future
Robin Baker
Pan, £6.99
Buy it at BOL

Baker doesn't mean sex, not even the commercial contact sport in every headline and trailer: he means "reproductive technologies". An awkward work of projected scenarios (he's no novelist) alternating with explanations of the probable evolution this century of perfect offspring purchased by the rich, either cloned or fused from expensive components selected for genetic success - not Mendelian breeding, more buying the ultimate in white goods. Baker relishes the possibilities but refuses to concern himself with the reduction of the human to transactions in vanity and DNA: like reading Mary Shelley, only scarier.

fields.headline: Fiction
fields.trailText: A novel that begins with a sharp jolt before gathering characters and setting, plus Killing Me Softly, Making Love and Shouting At The Ship Men
fields.body:
The Museum Guard
Howard Norman
Picador, £6.99
Buy it at BOL

When a novel begins with a sharp jolt and then slows to gather characters and setting, you know that you are embarking on a delicious read. Defoe works with his uncle as a guard at a museum in Halifax, Nova Scotia. He falls in love with Imogen, caretaker at the Jewish cemetery, who has fallen in love with one of the paintings. His obsession with Imogen, and her obsession with Jewess on a Street in Amsterdam, lead the reader to Amsterdam on the eve of the second world war. Norman writes with delicacy about a much-trampled-upon history in this engrossing book.

Killing Me Softly
Nicci French
Penguin, £5.99
Buy it at BOL

I won't be spoiling a secret if I mention that "Nicci French" is the husband-and-wife writing duo Nicci Gerrard and Sean French. This is their third novel written in tandem, and part of the fun is that you get a chapter from each in turn. The method ratchets up the suspense as Alice drops nice, dependable Jake for a handsome stranger she meets on the street. Killing Me Softly is a dependable thriller which will set your spine shivering pleasurably - while making you question just how much you can really know about the person you share your bed with.

Making Love
Lucretia Stewart
Vintage, £6.99
Buy it at BOL

Is this debut novel, subtitled "a romance", more of a fictionalised confession? The death of the 40-plus heroine's father prompts the rekindling of a relationship with Louis in the knowledge that this could be her last chance of love. We see the sexual development of a young woman from drug-happy student couplings in the 70s to the darker, more desperate tangling of middle age. Stewart digresses to fill every cranny in her heroine's past. What would make a sleek novella, brooding with failure and emptiness, expands into a loose, overblown novel.

Shouting At The Ship Men
Tim Geary
Phoenix, £6.99
Buy it at BOL

Mixed-up daddy's girl Portia leaves Toronto for London and the chance to discover her English roots. Her passage to England is made possible by merchant-banker type Luke Bingham. Portia's toying with the romance of being a true Brit has a hysterical edge that Geary tempers with sly comedy. We know that Portia will never make it as Luke's dog-loving, Homes and Gardens girl, but despite Geary's easy style, this story of a self-obsessed young woman wears thin well before her world comes to its crashing end.

fields.headline: Small press corner
fields.trailText: An irresistible guide to the ailments that carried off the kings and queens of England
fields.body:
The Death of Kings
Clifford Brewer
Abson Books, £5.99
Buy it at BOL

We have a penchant on these pages for ghoulish subjects, and we found this book irresistible. It is an attempt by a distinguished retired surgeon to diagnose the ailments that carried off the kings and queens of England. We all know that Edward II died of "perforation of the bowel", but what of poor Queen Anne? A combination of multiple miscarriages and bloating leads him to the conclusion that she suffered from the complications of lupus erythematosus. Helped, of course, by doctors - who have, over the centuries, done more than any regicide to rid us of the monarchy.

fields.headline: Audio
fields.trailText: Stephen Fry, no mean wizard himself, and JK Rowling continue the powerful magic they started in the prototype.
fields.body:
Harry Potter and the Chamber of Secrets
JK Rowling
Cover To Cover, £21.99, 580 mn unabridged
Buy it at BOL

Raptures! Two years after publication, as Harry Potter II finds its voice, bang on cue a Kent headteacher obligingly bans the books from her school. Better publicity even JK herself couldn't buy.

Here Stephen Fry, no mean wizard himself, and Rowling continue the powerful magic they started in the prototype. The prose sounds good: spare, powerful sentences, comfortable for reader and listener, and glistening with wonderful words. Rowling enjoys the rare gift of finding perfect names: Gringotts the magic bank, Dumbledore the headmaster, Draco Malfoy, the school thug... And of course Quidditch, Rowling's inspired aerial-combat game. Fry brings out these choice epithets with relish. He clearly believes what he's reading, and holds you spellbound.

fields.headline: From Entries on Light
fields.trailText:
Dawn paves its own way

  if what we mean by dawn

is sunrise...
fields.body:
Dawn paves its own way

  if what we mean by dawn

is sunrise. The sky's already

  light by the time the sun

comes up, rising on its own

  prediction of the day.
This is how art is made.

  And memory. And love.

First, the halo overhead.

  Next, the body. Last
the roots like the final

  rays of the sun spiralling
as earth pulls free of them
 and they of earth. Then
illumination's width and frame.
 This is how love is made

rising into a desire

  for love, however grey

the outlook, late the hour
 hard for faith and fear
to pave the way. Love

  full-face. Preordained
as sunrise, chasing after

  the ghost of its own grace.
