And memory. And love. First, the halo overhead. Next, the body. Last the roots like the final rays of the sun spiralling as earth pulls free of them and they of earth. Then illumination's width and frame. This is how love is made rising into a desire for love, however grey the outlook, late the hour hard for faith and fear to pave the way. Love full-face. Preordained as sunrise, chasing after the ghost of its own grace.

fields.headline: The real order of Lenin
fields.standfirst: Russia's new ruler cannot avoid the shadow of his great predecessor.  Robert Service on the old revolutionary's true character
fields.trailText: Russia's new ruler cannot avoid the shadow of his great predecessor. Robert Service on the old revolutionary's true character
fields.body:
Vladimir Putin, the first Russian leader of the 21st century, combines the old and the modern in his political style. His presidential campaign was fought with western opinion polls and TV advertising, yet he also acted as both a tsar and a commissar - when Chechnya refused to come to heel, he sent in the army to raze Grozny. Like the communist leaders, he burnishes his image as a man of action without concern for democracy, telling regional politicians to produce a majority for him or face dire consequences, and surrounding himself with friends from his KGB days. And like Lenin in 1917, Putin achieved supremacy while just beginning to learn to make a public speech with confidence.

So the Lenin question has not left the Russian political agenda. Among Putin's few statements in his campaign was the promise to remove Lenin's body from the mausoleum on Red Square and bury it properly. Nine years of de-communisation have lowered Lenin's prestige - he now comes only third, after Jesus Christ and Peter the Great, as the historical figure most admired by Russian people. Yet even many who dislike communism are still in his grasp. Charismatic Lenin founded the Communist party. He created the October Revolution and invented a new state - one party, one ideology - which became the model for states in eastern Europe, China and elsewhere. Lenin's works of Marxist theory were extremely influential. After his death, his ideas were codified as Marxism-Leninism, and his corpse was displayed in the mausoleum, where it is still given a monthly bath in formaldehyde.

His passionate nature made him difficult to live with. His family had to make him promise not to talk about politics on holiday. In his years of power, he threatened to put colleagues "on bread and water in prison" for failing to implement the economic policy. He was probably being rhetorical, but nobody could be quite sure.

Lenin was also a revolutionary romantic. He carried photographs of Karl Marx, and bought a postcard of Emile Zola when the French writer took up the cause of Alfred Dreyfus in 1898. He was desperate to conserve himself for the inevitable great dawn of revolution, and felt meant for a special destiny. His nerves played him up. Around 1900, a Swiss doctor gave him the terrible diagnosis: "It's the brain." Already impatient, Lenin lived the rest of his life as if his personal clock were ticking quickly towards midnight.

He was cunning in playing them off against each other so that they would carry out his errands uncomplainingly. Nadya even put up with his dalliance with the Marxist activist and feminist Inessa Armand, who was captivated by him. When he broke with her before the first world war, she pleaded: "At the moment I could manage without the kisses: just to see you and talk with you sometimes would be a pleasure - and this could do no one any harm."

Marxism was his preferred doctrine and he owned up to being "in love" with Karl Marx. Ideology meant more to him than women. But privately, he drew on other influences. Machiavelli and Darwin had hugely impressed him. So, too, had the ideas of the Orthodox Church priest Father Gapon, who led the procession to the Winter Palace on Bloody Sunday in January 1905. He closeted himself for days with Gapon, and from him developed the idea of expropriating the entire property of the landed gentry. My own position was that neither of these contentions was true, but that Lenin was a man of ideological commitment who nevertheless altered his ideas to suit changing circumstances and new opportunities and threats - and not always for the reasons he gave in public. He had to manage opinion among his associates, his party and society. Sometimes he spoke straight and sometimes he fudged.

He genuinely believed humanity's future lay with communism and the creation of a world without political or economic oppression. But he also thought this required a most ruthless temporary class dic tatorship. He needed to get power before he could explain his strategy to supporters among the workers and even inside his party.

But Lenin's ideas and activity are just two corners of a triangle. The third is his emotional life, and now that the archives are available, we can work out the nature of the triangular relationship. Lenin was not the robotic politician of legend. He was a flesh-and-blood, over-confident, impatient, brilliant, charming and often troubled revolutionary. His story is incomplete until we take the entire triangle into account. Lenin was 47 before he gained power. For most of his adulthood, he had been an émigré. He might easily have given up and become the provincial lawyer he had trained to be in the 1890s, before he turned to revolutionary activism. But he was sustained by internal drives, and although he did not talk about them, they were constant and powerful.

What also emerges from the archives is a sense of the oneness of Lenin. It is sometimes claimed that, as he lay dying, he moderated his dictatorial doctrines. This is supposed to be proved by his call for the removal of Stalin from the party general secretaryship. But the evidence suggests instead that Lenin died a Leninist. Which is to say that he remained an idealist, but this meant to him staying true to the need for revolutionary persecution. Lenin's deathbed disagreements with Stalin were about bureaucratic matters that did not touch on the fundamentals of the one-party state.

We can now also see that Lenin's final illness caused him to behave bizarrely in the two years before his death in 1924. When Lenin spoke to his doctor, Liveri Darkevich, he admitted to thinking that he might be going clinically mad. A series of "obsessions" were unhinging him. Darkevich heard him pour his heart out: "A night doomed to insomnia is a truly terrible thing when you have to be ready in the morning for work, work, work without end." This tiny episode, which happened when Lenin swung between anger and despair, makes it easier to understand why Stalin managed to survive the criticisms made by Lenin. The other central party leaders had reason to think that Lenin's judgment was no longer to be trusted.

Lenin had an enormous impact but he had needed equally enormous luck to make that impact. Without the first world war, Russia would not have plunged into military defeat, economic collapse and administrative disintegration in 1917. Without a radicalised intelligentsia and working class, Lenin would have had few followers and would never have been able to gain power. He made the most of these extraordinary opportunities. Once he had power, he let nothing stand in the way of his keeping it. His successors maintained the basic system of communist rule until Gorbachev dismantled it in the late 80s.

Lenin's influence has declined since the fall of the Soviet Union. Marxism-Leninism is ignored even by the Russian Communist party. But many of the social and institutional arrangements of Lenin's regime have yet to be eliminated; the thinking of the Russian people was not changed overnight by the abolition of the USSR; and in China and Cuba he remains a secular saint. The world still lives in his shadow.

 Robert Service's Lenin: A Political Biography is published by Macmillan (£25).

webTitle: The other boy made me do it, sir

fields.headline: The other boy made me do it, sir
fields.standfirst: Roy Hattersley  hears Jonathan Aitken's side of the story in Pride and Perjury
fields.trailText: Roy Hattersley hears Jonathan Aitken's side of the story in Pride and Perjury
fields.body:
Pride and Perjury
Jonathan Aitken
HarperCollins, £19.99, 392pp,
Buy it at BOL

Some tasks are, by their nature, beyond successful completion. One of them is the attempt to transform a conviction for perjury into an "inspiring message of hope and redemption". Another is the publication (at least in the Guardian) of a review which is generally accepted as an objective assessment of Pride and Perjury, Jonathan Aitken's account of his transition from sinner to saint. For the Guardian is a central character in the drama; indeed, when Aitken allocates blame for his downfall, this paper comes a close second to original sin.

I cannot adjudicate on the dispute between the paper and the perjurer over questions of detail. But two facts are beyond argument. When Aitken accepted Said Ayas's hospitality at the Paris Ritz, he was breaking the rules of conduct for ministers. And when he falsely claimed in court that his wife had paid the bill, he was breaking the law. Whether or not Mohammed al Fayed (often, it seems, brought into the narrative to make readers' flesh creep) was right to say that Said Ayas, Wafic Said and Aitken ate together in the Espadon Restaurant on the weekend of September 17-19 1993 is neither here nor there.

Right or wrong, Aitken's arcane corrections only serve to create the impression that the born-again Christian is not as full of remorse as the second half of his book suggests. Nor is the impression of penitence increased by his complaints about the methods the Guardian used to win the libel case which Aitken so foolishly initiated. The charges of sharp practice are damagingly reminiscent of the drunken driver who claims he should escape conviction because he was caught by an unmarked police car.

I have no wish to see Aitken go through the rest of his life wearing sackcloth and ashes. He has paid a terrible price for conduct which I am not sufficiently censorious to classify as wrong, bad or wicked. Had it been my decision, he would not have been prosecuted for perjury. And I could see no point in sending him to prison: the destruction of his career, marriage and reputation was sufficient punishment. But the account of his moral fall and spiritual regeneration has brought a sudden end to all my sympathy. It reveals virtually nothing to Aitken's credit. Perhaps he wrote it because he was desperate for money; otherwise, he is again the victim of the hubris which brought about his downfall.

No one who reads Pride and Perjury can doubt that Aitken's conscience spoke to him only after he was found out. "In the aftermath of the collapse of the libel case I was often asked the question 'Didn't you realise that the Guardian might produce some evidence which would destroy your case?'" Typically, Aitken was confident that he could avoid such a catastrophe. He had discovered from "a friend who is a senior director of British Airways" that flight records are destroyed after two years, so he thought no one could prove that Mrs Aitken was not in Paris on the day when his hotel bill was paid. The explanation reveals why he thought that he could get away with the fraud. It also confirms that he had weeks to repent the carefully planned deception before he planted the false evidence.

Much of Pride and Perjury is written to prove that he is sorry now - chastened by his own suffering and the pain which he has caused his family. Aitken insists that "After months of prayer and listening, my eyes opened and I recognised that I had accepted Jesus Christ into my heart as my Lord and God."

Even if the saviour of the world was undiscriminating enough to cohabit with so ostentatious a Christian, we must assume that He only agreed to the close relationship when the convert accepted full responsibility for his sins. However, Aitken is careful to point out that it was the ubiquitous Said Ayas who had the fraudulent idea. "If you said that Lolicia paid your bill in cash how the hell can a cashier at the Ritz contradict you six months later?" Poor, naive, easily influenced Jonathan could not resist the temptation.

The only possible excuse for Pride and Perjury is that, after months of suffering, Aitken has lost touch with reality. Perhaps we should have realised that something was wrong when he made his flamboyant "Sword of Truth" speech at the beginning of his doomed campaign against the Guardian. But Aitken shows little sign of realising, even now, how mad that exercise was. He tried the speech out on "an assembled group of civil servants and lawyers". Both "rehearsal audiences gave strong encouragement"; the treasury officials "burst into a round of applause". Their support is described as if it somehow justified at least the strategy. But the people on whom he practised the speech did not recognise that he was lying. The outstanding question is, does Jonathan Aitken recognise it now?

fields.headline: First leach your brawn
fields.standfirst: From the munificent first foodies to the miserly Mrs Beeton:  Vera Rule  feasts on classic English cookery books
fields.trailText: From the munificent first foodies to the miserly Mrs Beeton: Vera Rule feasts on classic English cookery books
fields.body:
The Accomplisht Cook
Robert May
Prospect Books, £20, 495pp
Buy it at BOL

Mrs Beeton's Book of Household Management
Oxford World's Classics, £7.99, 629pp
Buy it at BOL

A New System of Domestic Cookery
Maria Rundell Old Fort Niagara Association, $14.99, 320pp

Across Europe in the century after recipes were first committed to print in 1570, chefs offered culinary instruction in books; whatever their religion, they were Protestant in revealing what might seem a mystery to be physics, chemistry and skill. Among them was Robert May, 72 in 1660 when his Accomplisht Cook was published. The son of a professional cook, he had also been brought up to the craft: sent as an apprentice to France and as a journeyman to the Star Chamber kitchens before a lifetime catering for recusant lordly households.

May wrote like his contemporary William Harvey, discoverer of the circulation of the blood: both communicated exciting knowledge through urgent active verbs and imperative terms - leach that brawn, allay that pheasant, unbrace that mallard. Menu and manners were then in transition: May boiled puddings wrapped in a cloth, a new technique, yet continued to encircle stews with sippets of toast so that, forks being novelties, morsels might be conveyed to the mouth on the dip principle.

May's cuisine was certainly not nouvelle, despite his casual references to New World arrivals such as the potato and the turkey (a bird already ominously obligatory in his Christmas bill of fare). His diners delighted in the simpler produce of their northern land: fresh soft cheeses, salmon marinated in herbs, oil and wine vinegar, collops (chops and steaks broiled on a gridiron and served with mustard). He cooked frogs and snails, too, though it is hard to discern whether he learned those receipts in France, or whether Britain only spat out the frogleg during that 18th-century nationalist bovine fervour against the French, reflected in the current Tate Hogarth exhibition.

But those at his tables also preserved conservative international tastes: May's prologue is nostalgic for pre-Civil War Twelfth Night feasts, with live birds bursting forth from fake "pyes" after a mock battle on the table. Heartily medieval. As were his many meals profligate with ingredients in the old European courtly taste, derived from a Byzantine or Middle Eastern mother cuisine taken across the Mediterranean by Islamic conquest. This style was easy with saffron, almonds, East Indies spices. May prepared fish, fowl and flesh alike with fat-enriched spiced fruits, a combination which now faintly lingers in mince pies and brown sauce on bacon butties. His ubiquitous luxury garnish was molten butter frothed with sharp orange juice.

Who read May when Obadiah Blagrave (he sounds no nibbler of sippets) printed his book? May borrowed expertise from gentlewomen practising fashionable sugar confectionary, so presumably it was bought by such ladies, and by pro cooks. It can't have been an extensive readership, unlike that of Isabella Beeton, whose 1861 volume sold two million copies after being partworked in her husband's Domestic Magazine. Every newbuilt Victorian villa wife must have had a copy, not merely to learn to cook - food was only half of Beeton's "incessant labours" - but also to discover how to engage a footman and purchase an Improved Leamington Kitchener or Stove, to be had at £23.10s. (Our Aga fantasies are not new.)

Beeton's manual told females how to conduct each separate cell of expanding middleclassdom as a household, although not one May would have recognised. In his rural experience, all but imported groceries came slayed and flayed from an estate provident of beasts, cream and eggs: in Beeton's citified life, comestibles were purchased ready-made from manufacturers and meat came jointed from the butcher.

May recorded without commentary his craft processes over 50 years; Beeton, aged 25, imparted outlines of natural history, morality and sanitary practices between economic instructions for the preparation of carrot jam to imitate apricot preserve. Her recipes, few original, were tested in her kitchen to establish exact quantities; she could not specify temperatures (even the Leamington's heat was unquantifiable), but she did offer for the first time recipes as scientific experiments with a known, repeatable outcome.

Although an unappealing one. Her Oxford sausages or jugged hare with port wine and redcurrant jelly, descended from May's plain strand, were handsome enough. But there was no appetite in her writing. Beeton was a style journalist, proposing that her readers conduct their lives to confirm their alliance with gentry and aristocracy;"capital" and "nice" were her favourite adjectives, and she confined garlic, consumed by "continentals", to a footnote as "offensive" and "acrimonious".

Her business was getting things right, aspiring publicly and being uncreatively mean in private. When only the family was at repast, suet and treacle pud were sufficient; the snipe and lobster were set between the épergnes to entertain company. She ordered cabbage boiled into submission with soda as an ineffectual deodorant.

And the poor she abused worse than brassicas: she recommended mock-turtle soup, costed at 3s 6d per quart, across the page from a "useful soup for benevolent purposes" at three halfpence - one ox cheek tinting 10 gallons of water - served with a sermon about pauper ignorance. The nasty taste in the reader's mouth is not only a reaction to Beeton's disdain, but a realisation that her core meat, wheat and cream would dominate British food for 140 years. Snobbery and quasi-science mattered to her more than eating.

So was there ever a golden age of Britfood? Probably not, Hogarth and his roast beef notwithstanding. I appreciate, though, the honest delectation in the work of Maria Rundell, who compiled a manuscript for her daughters in 1804 and was persuaded into publication by family friend John Murray, whose firm printed it, modernised and Frenchified, over the next 60 years. Rundell threw in hints on cleaning wallpaper (rub with stale bread: works, too), but did not waste dreams on establishments staffed complete to under-stableboys. She was rightly concerned about tinning batteries de cuisine so as to avoid poisoning their contents, but not yet seduced by the idea that the Patent Stove would, by itself, produce banquets.

May's ancient musks had leached out of her flavour palette, but she still had an ample hand with ginger, pimentos and mace, supplemented with spices from India, soy and walnut catsups, herbs and garlic. Citrus fruits and peels zested her fish and meat; wine, sherry and brandy were lavished upon her sauces.

She is a most cookworthy historical source: even her unprepossessing titles - hashed calf's head - are followed by cogent instructions promising mouth pleasure: to make that hash add good gravy, truffles, morels, Cayenne pepper, parsley, tarragon, marjoram and lemon to the meat slices sautéed in butter. Where did the tenderness go which Rundell bestowed on spinach, sorel and cabbage, which were to be put to the pan with "no water but what hangs to the leaves from washing"? Buried under the bricky industrial terraces and laid, with a sprig of rosemary, in the graves of the last British peasantry and yeoman farmers.

Even Rundell's hints for charitable assistance were listed as "respecting the poor" - sympathetic that the "laborious poor have not fuel to do justice to what they buy", she recommended that the surplus of every family of income be converted into warm meals to give away. She added frankly that, should the cook think this troublesome, "a gratuity might repay her, if the love of her fellow-creatures failed of doing it a hundredfold". Raise at least a glass of Yarra Valley Pinot Noir to Rundell, as flavourful as the River Cafe's Rose Gray and Ruth Rogers, and unpretentious with it.
fields.bodyText: The Accomplisht Cook Robert May Prospect Books, £20, 495pp Buy it at BOL Mrs Beeton's Book of Household Management Oxford World's Classics, £7.99, 629pp Buy it at BOL A New System of Domestic Cookery Maria Rundell Old Fort Niagara Association, $14.99, 320pp Across Europe in the century after recipes were first committed to print in 1570, chefs offered culinary instruction in books; whatever their religion, they were Protestant in revealing what might seem a mystery to be physics, chemistry and skill. Among them was Robert May, 72 in 1660 when his Accomplisht Cook was published. The son of a professional cook, he had also been brought up to the craft: sent as an apprentice to France and as a journeyman to the Star Chamber kitchens before a lifetime catering for recusant lordly households. May wrote like his contemporary William Harvey, discoverer of the circulation of the blood: both communicated exciting knowledge through urgent active verbs and imperative terms - leach that brawn, allay that pheasant, unbrace that mallard. Menu and manners were then in transition: May boiled puddings wrapped in a cloth, a new technique, yet continued to encircle stews with sippets of toast so that, forks being novelties, morsels might be conveyed to the mouth on the dip principle. May's cuisine was certainly not nouvelle, despite his casual references to New World arrivals such as the potato and the turkey (a bird already ominously obligatory in his Christmas bill of fare). His diners delighted in the simpler produce of their northern land: fresh soft cheeses, salmon marinated in herbs, oil and wine vinegar, collops (chops and steaks broiled on a gridiron and served with mustard). He cooked frogs and snails, too, though it is hard to discern whether he learned those receipts in France, or whether Britain only spat out the frogleg during that 18th-century nationalist bovine fervour against the French, reflected in the current Tate Hogarth exhibition. But those at his tables also preserved conservative international tastes: May's prologue is nostalgic for pre-Civil War Twelfth Night feasts, with live birds bursting forth from fake "pyes" after a mock battle on the table. Heartily medieval. As were his many meals profligate with ingredients in the old European courtly taste, derived from a Byzantine or Middle Eastern mother cuisine taken across the Mediterranean by Islamic conquest. This style was easy with saffron, almonds, East Indies spices. May prepared fish, fowl and flesh alike with fat-enriched spiced fruits, a combination which now faintly lingers in mince pies and brown sauce on bacon butties. His ubiquitous luxury garnish was molten butter frothed with sharp orange juice. Who read May when Obadiah Blagrave (he sounds no nibbler of sippets) printed his book? May borrowed expertise from gentlewomen practising fashionable sugar confectionary, so presumably it was bought by such ladies, and by pro cooks. It can't have been an extensive readership, unlike that of Isabella Beeton, whose 1861 volume sold two million copies after being partworked in her husband's Domestic Magazine. Every newbuilt Victorian villa wife must have had a copy, not merely to learn to cook - food was only half of Beeton's "incessant labours" - but also to discover how to engage a footman and purchase an Improved Leamington Kitchener or Stove, to be had at £23.10s. (Our Aga fantasies are not new.) Beeton's manual told females how to conduct each separate cell of expanding middleclassdom as a household, although not one May would have recognised. In his rural experience, all but imported groceries came slayed and flayed from an estate provident of beasts, cream and eggs: in Beeton's citified life, comestibles were purchased ready-made from manufacturers and meat came jointed from the butcher. May recorded without commentary his craft processes over 50 years; Beeton, aged 25, imparted outlines of natural history, morality and sanitary practices between economic instructions for the preparation of carrot jam to imitate apricot preserve. Her recipes, few original, were tested in her kitchen to establish exact quantities; she could not specify temperatures (even the Leamington's heat was unquantifiable), but she did offer for the first time recipes as scientific experiments with a known, repeatable outcome. Although an unappealing one. Her Oxford sausages or jugged hare with port wine and redcurrant jelly, descended from May's plain strand, were handsome enough. But there was no appetite in her writing. Beeton was a style journalist, proposing that her readers conduct their lives to confirm their alliance with gentry and aristocracy;"capital" and "nice" were her favourite adjectives, and she confined garlic, consumed by "continentals", to a footnote as "offensive" and "acrimonious". Her business was getting things right, aspiring publicly and being uncreatively mean in private. When only the family was at repast, suet and treacle pud were sufficient; the snipe and lobster were set between the épergnes to entertain company. She ordered cabbage boiled into submission with soda as an ineffectual deodorant. And the poor she abused worse than brassicas: she recommended mock-turtle soup, costed at 3s 6d per quart, across the page from a "useful soup for benevolent purposes" at three halfpence - one ox cheek tinting 10 gallons of water - served with a sermon about pauper ignorance. The nasty taste in the reader's mouth is not only a reaction to Beeton's disdain, but a realisation that her core meat, wheat and cream would dominate British food for 140 years. Snobbery and quasi-science mattered to her more than eating. So was there ever a golden age of Britfood? Probably not, Hogarth and his roast beef notwithstanding. I appreciate, though, the honest delectation in the work of Maria Rundell, who compiled a manuscript for her daughters in 1804 and was persuaded into publication by family friend John Murray, whose firm printed it, modernised and Frenchified, over the next 60 years. Rundell threw in hints on cleaning wallpaper (rub with stale bread: works, too), but did not waste dreams on establishments staffed complete to under-stableboys. She was rightly concerned about tinning batteries de cuisine so as to avoid poisoning their contents, but not yet seduced by the idea that the Patent Stove would, by itself, produce banquets. May's ancient musks had leached out of her flavour palette, but she still had an ample hand with ginger, pimentos and mace, supplemented with spices from India, soy and walnut catsups, herbs and garlic. Citrus fruits and peels zested her fish and meat; wine, sherry and brandy were lavished upon her sauces. fields.headline: Egypt through unstarry eyes
fields.standfirst: Ahdaf Soueif tells Polly Pattullo how to avoid the cliches of exotic fiction
fields.trailText: Ahdaf Soueif tells Polly Pattullo how to avoid the cliches of exotic fiction
fields.body:
Like contestants on Blind Date, non-western writers who live and write in the west are still forced to explain who they are and where they come from. And Egyptian-born Ahdaf Soueif, who writes in English, feels doubly scrutinised. "You're open to criticism," she says, "of writing in an exotic way about the Arab world."

She swept to attention last year in Britain when her novel, The Map Of Love, was shortlisted for the Booker Prize. But she has also won over Arab critics, who have praised her for writing through an authentic Egyptian consciousness, and who called her first novel, The Eye of the Sun (1992), an Arabic novel written in English. "That pleases me enormously."

But these debates don't go away. She was recently at a conference of African writers in Washington DC, some of whom felt that they had a duty to dispel the myths about their own cultures. Soueif is "wary" about that position because, as she says, it creates an agenda over and above the craft of writing.

Although Soueif writes in English - always at night, for she has a full-time "day job" in an Islamic cultural centre - she hears the dialogue in her head in Arabic. In this way she hopes that she can accommodate both the Arab experience and language in her work.

Indeed, those complex cultural rituals of greeting, the courtesies, the "inshallahs" - the phrases she calls "comforting" - flow effortlessly in her English dialogue. And perhaps because Soueif has a PhD in linguistics, she can unselfconsciously include a glossary in which tidbits of information about Arabic roots are revealed: that haram, for example, denotes a sacred space, that the haram of a man is his wife, that hareem (from the same root) means women and that the haramlek is the area of a house reserved for women.

All Soueif's work is concerned with women, in their public and private lives, in their struggles to define themselves. The Map of Love, in particular, provides a voice for the haramlek. But not, as Soueif says, as a place where "women are lounging about waiting for men". Instead she is aware how rich, "not amputated", how supportive these women's communities were - and are. Feminism in Egypt began in the 1880s - with the struggle for education, in which Soueif's own paternal grandmother played a part, writing verses on the education of women and taking part in anti-colonial demonstrations.

A century or so on, the discourses about women's identity continue. What is clear to Soueif - and threaded always into her writing - is that the acceptance of the veil doesn't necessarily mean that a woman is "oppressed, an extremist or wants an Islamicist state".

Soueif has been writing for some 20 years now since since turning her back on a university career (her parents, too, were academics, forced at one stage into low-grade jobs by the British). She had lived in the UK as a small child and had returned as a student. After a stint teaching at Cairo University, she moved back to London, married the poet Ian Hamilton and had two sons.

Of her four books, two are collections of short stories - delicate, spare, lyrical. In contrast, the two novels are unashamedly fat and robust, wide-ranging in style and content, ambitiously embracing history, politics, feminism and romance, whether in Cairo, London, Beirut or New York. She started both novels, she says, by writing separate scenes that had "pressed in on" her. From this beginning, there evolved a sense of "uncovering - like a statue from a piece of marble".

The research alone for The Map of Love took two years, with Soueif combing the SOAS library for books, newspapers and pamphlets that would provide the precise chronological details of Egypt's complex history at the turn of the century as Turkish rule weakened, British imperialism deepened and Egyptian nationalism recharged its energies.

The novel, which is to be published in Arabic later this year in a translation by Soueif's mother, turns on the relationship between Egypt and the West - at the beginning and end of the 20th century - through a cross-cultural love affair between Anna, an intrepid Victorian English widow, and Sharif, a dashing (it has to be said) Egyptian nationalist. "I wanted to make a romantic hero who would also be an Egyptian," says Soueif.

In its historical narrative, The Map of Love is unhurried and luxurious. "That is the beauty of the past: there it lies on the table - journals, pictures, a candle-glass, a few books of history," Soueif writes. In contrast, in its tales of contemporary Egypt, written almost as history unfolded, there is an urgency, a sense of rushing events.

In dealing with the massacre of the tourists at Luxor, Soueif focuses on the government's response - the bewilderment and fear as villagers are rounded up by an unaccountable police force. Life in Egypt, she says, is hard now: the impact of globalisation, inflation, privatisation (46,000 workers sacked from public-sector factories - she has just read this in Al Ahram). Emergency laws and the issues around fundamentalism have also had an impact. All will, no doubt, surface in a non-fiction book about Cairo that she is set to write as part of a series for her publishers, Bloomsbury.

"All that desert-and-stars business. You know it won't do," chides an English character in The Map of Love. It won't, and Soueif - from a very different perspective - has been saying why.

fields.headline: Sacrilege!
fields.standfirst: Joyce Carol Oates offers an 'intimate, unsparing vision' of Marilyn Monroe in Blonde - no thanks, says Julie Burchill
fields.trailText: Joyce Carol Oates offers an 'intimate, unsparing vision' of Marilyn Monroe in Blonde - no thanks, says Julie Burchill
fields.body:
Blonde
Joyce Carol Oates
Fourth Estate, £17.99, 752pp
Buy it at BOL

Ironically for a woman who, during her life, was considered something of a crime against morality by certain sperm-brained seat-sniffers, Marilyn Monroe remains after her death the crime scene that certain dubious types cannot help returning to time and time again. Whether it's Elton John indulging the mawkish queen's taste for tragic femmes or Norman Mailer grieving for the time when women were girls and boys were men, this sensitive, intelligent and incomparably beautiful woman has repeatedly been the repository of others' kinks and dreams, while being consistently denied the dignity for which she fought so fiercely, if inconsistently, throughout her life.

Even Arthur Miller (in his book Timebends) outrageously portrayed her as a woman who barely ever read books; this, far more than the numerous sexual slurs she suffered, was the thing that would have hurt her most of all. No wonder she hated him towards the end of her life, considering that he had exploited her far more than the cigar-chomping studio heads just out for a blowjob.

Of all the numerous biographies, TV films and fantasies, only three stand out: Fred Lawrence Guiles's beautiful, careful and definitive Norma Jean, the loving and sad Marilyn, My Friend by Lena Pepitone, her maid for 10 years, and a novel called The Goddess.

As a feverish 12-year-old haunting the grown-up bit of Sandy Park Library I was lucky enough to come across this book, written (or so I thought) by a woman named Alvah Bessie. I was already a Bride Of Marilyn, as morbidly sensitive, semi-smart adolescent girls tended to be, and immediately recognised its stammering, damaged, redheaded sex symbol Wanda Oliver ("The Woo-Woo Girl") as my heroine.

It was a brilliant book, especially considering that Bessie turned out to be not a woman at all but a blacklisted 50s male screenwriter, one of the gorgeously named Unfriendly 10. To this day I recall the part where Wanda, who has never had an orgasm during sex with men, thinks she's about to have one with her adored third husband, an intellectual type. (So obviously not based on Arthur Miller, then.) Her rising excitement and subsequent bitter disappointment still live on in my mind after almost 30 years. Bessie was considered a bit of a pulpmeister, but this scene stays with me as literary giant after literary giant describes women who come off like catherine wheels at the merest poke of a touchpaper.

But enough of incandescent talent; let's talk about Joyce Carol Oates instead. I've never liked her, and in fact believe that she has only ever written one thing of any merit, that being the title (not the story itself) "Where Are You Going, Where Have You Been?" Even after 30 years in the racket, she remains one of those Yanks you should know about rather than actually do know about.

What Oates serves up here is her "intimate, unsparing vision" of poor Marilyn, who you'd think had suffered enough forced intimacies from strangers, let alone unsparing ones. I'm always uncomfortable with "faction", believing it to be the last refuge of the imagined-out scoundrel, and here the boundaries are even more blurred than usual.

Made-up poems purporting to be by "the Blonde" are mixed in with Marilyn's own; some remarks in a chapter called "The Collected Works Of Marilyn Monroe" are taken from interviews, while some are invented. The original writing, such as it is, never gets better than the first chapter, "Special Delivery", which begins "There came Death hurtling along the Boulevard in warning sepia light... Then came Death in a hurry. Death furiously pedaling. Death carrying a package marked SPECIAL DELIVERY HANDLE WITH CARE in a sturdy wire basket behind his seat."

I'm sorry, but it's ham-fisted scribbling such as this (compare it with Terry Pratchett's gorgeous depiction of Death the man in Mort, which saw me through the deaths of both my parents in the space of 18 months) which has turned people away from the Literary Novel and towards the despised genres.

Parts of this book have already appeared in Playboy, the spiritual home of haggard masturbators masquerading as humanitarian men of the world - the very people who made Monroe's life such a burden to her. This is the work of a writer past her prime and out of fashion, desperate to revamp her career; well, it worked for Norman and Elton. But if you've been touched for even a moment by the blithe, fragile spirit of Marilyn Monroe, forego this exercise in exploitation and seek out a copy of The Goddess instead. Tattered, torn and 20 years out of print as it is, it could never be as shabby as this shiny new thing.

fields.headline: Man of mysteries
fields.standfirst: He's a northerner, a poet and playwright famous for reworking Greek and medieval classics. His latest poems, which include a swipe at the poet laureate, have drawn heavy critical fire. Married to an opera star, he also has a long-term relationship with a successful actress.  Nicholas Wroe reports
fields.trailText: He's a northerner, a poet and playwright famous for reworking Greek and medieval classics. His latest poems, which include a swipe at the poet laureate, have drawn heavy critical fire. Married to an opera star, he also has a long-term relationship with a successful actress. Nicholas Wroe reports
fields.body:
It was the culmination of four years' toil for Tony Harrison on his monumental theatre work, The Kaisers of Carnuntum, a play in verse. Specifically written to be set in the remains of Marcus Aurelius's Roman stadium at Carnuntum, 40 kilometres outside Vienna, the piece was to have only two performances, in the summer of 1995. The extravagant logistics of the work - which required real lions, tigers and bears - were so complicated that the first time it could be put together was at the dress rehearsal the evening before the first performance.

Just as the rehearsal was due to start, a massive thunderstorm broke. As the night wore on the set was washed out, and to the background accompaniment of increasingly restless lions, the rehearsal was finally cancelled in the early hours of the morning. No one would know what the show was like until it was staged the following evening. Harrison was drenched and exhausted after climbing around on rigging in an attempt to lash plastic covers over the set. A member of the crew told him the bad news. His response was unequivocal. "I couldn't give a fuck", he said. "I'd rather be here than anywhere else in the world."

Harrison has always relished the struggle to produce art, and this struggle matched the scale of his ambitious expectations. When the play was staged next day it was a triumph. "I think it's probably the best thing I've done in the theatre," he says. It might have had a brief existence, but the play neatly encapsulates much of Harrison's view of life and art. It was set in the classical world and drew on it to expose the brutality of the Romans as opposed to Harrison's beloved Greeks.

It applied the politics of the past to the present and presciently identified - through a line in the play - the then little-known local demagogue Jörg Haider as a man to watch. It mixed vulgarity with great seriousness and placed Yorkshire vowels - as delivered by the definitive Harrison actor Barrie Rutter - among the words of emperors. And, like earlier Harrison works, it caused a bit of a stir. It was Ezra Pound who asserted that literature is news that stays news, and Tony Harrison is living proof. While the journey from arts page to front page has proved a leap too far for most writers, Harrison takes it in his stride.

His habit of breaking out of the literary ghetto is made all the more remarkable in that his varied body of work for the theatre, opera, film, television and print is not only all written in verse but is also steeped in an appreciation of classical literature and culture. The attention of news editors was first sparked by Richard Eyre's 1987 film of his poem v. The potent mix of swearing, Yorkshire accents, football hooliganism and Channel 4 attracted the rabid attentions of rent-a-quote MPs, Mary Whitehouse and the Daily Mail.

His 1989 verse film, Blasphemers' Banquet, prompted by the fatwa placed on Salman Rushdie, led to more headlines and almost a caricature of an establishment reaction when the Archbishop of Canterbury sent a discreet note to the BBC asking that it be withdrawn. To the BBC's credit it was not. Most recently his very public refusal to be considered for the post of poet laureate - he wrote a poem for this newspaper, setting out his objections - and his accompanying sideswipe at Andrew Motion, who subsequently got the job, sparked another minor media frenzy. This has been kept going by publication of his most recent work, the collection Laureate's Block - which includes that eponymous Guardian poem - and which has been pretty well savaged by the critics.

But he has such a great intellect it makes you think that the poems are strategic. I think these things are done out of choice and not senility."

The fact that he is currently on the receiving end of acclaim (The Mysteries), indifference (Prometheus) and hostility (Laureate's Block) doesn't seem to surprise Harrison. But that can become harder. People say, 'you can do anything you want'. So you tell them what you want and they say that's not quite what they had in mind."

Harrison has been confounding expectations of what people had in mind for him all his life. The story of how the baker's son from Leeds went to grammar school and became a classicist, and what that meant for him, for the people he left behind and his take on the world at large, has been the starting point for much of his subsequent work.

He was born in 1937, the first child of Harry and Florrie Harrison. He has one younger sister. Even at primary school he remembers himself "ravenous" for knowledge, and he won a place at Leeds Grammar School and then went on to Leeds University. I only understand this clearly in retrospect, that my ability to study came from a hunger to learn all the resources of articulation."

He remembers his parents being nervous about his academic success. "They felt if you're launched on a path of education, it would take you completely away from them, and it does. I was one of the few people from south Leeds at the school and they were very shy about things like meeting people. Maybe there was some resentment too. They were told I'd be a professor when I was 20-odd and stuff like that."

Harrison has written extensively about his parents - v. was sparked by obscene graffiti on their headstone in a Leeds cemetery - but says that he only found the right voice to address them after they were dead. "The shock of their death made me find that. My mother hated my early poems. I didn't give her The Loiners [his sexually and emotionally explicit collection, published in 1970] because I knew she would find it upsetting. A friend got a copy from the library and said to her 'look what I've found by your Tony'. She was shocked. She didn't really learn to accept that I was going to be a writer until she came to the National and saw my adaptation of The Misanthrope in 1973. Laurence Olivier gave her a big kiss and said 'how proud you must be of your little boy.'"

Although his parents never saw the poems he wrote about them, they are still included in his audience. "I'm a total atheist but I do write things for them. For quite a long time I didn't do justice to my father. He's this rather curmud geonly, hostile presence in some of the earlier pieces. But I have done a poem more recently about him spending days decorating a wedding cake and then it being immediately cut up and eaten. And he had no feeling that that was a tragedy. I think I learned something about how you give your art through that gesture, but I was very late in coming to that realisation."

Harrison's most anthologised poem, "Them & [uz]", comes out of his time at Leeds Grammar where he recalls not being allowed to recite Keats because of his accent. Its bold declaration, "We'll occupy/your lousy leasehold Poetry", and revelation that in Wordsworth "matter/water are full rhymes" set the tone for his future assault on the cultural barriers that divide the classes.

At university he took part in a revue show written by a fellow student, the writer and comedian Barry Cryer. "In one show everyone had to dress up in very smart dinner jackets and all that," recalls Cryer. "We had to forcibly hold Tony down and apply Brylcreem to his hair. It infuriated him." Another university friend and fellow member of Cryer's revue was the Nobel prize-winning writer Wole Soyinka. It was his friendship with Soyinka that contributed to him taking a post in the English department at Ahmadu Bello University in Nigeria in 1962.

Harrison had married his first wife Rosemarie in 1960. Their daughter, Jane, was born the year they moved to Nigeria and their son, Max, the following year. He has three grandchildren. His first collection of poems, Earthworks, was published in 1964, and he and the Irish poet James Simmons, also at the university, worked together on Akin Mahta, a Nigerian version of Aristophanes's comedy Lysistrata, incorporating African music and dance. Works for stage and page have continued in tandem ever since.

After four years, Harrison moved to Prague, partly because his wife's family lived in East Germany - her father had been a communist under Hitler - and Czechoslovakia was one of the few places where the whole family could meet. The city's vibrant theatrical life also fed the development of Harrison's drama. "I went to theatre every day for 18 months. It was fantastic, a really important part of my life. With the official media being censored, in something like Shakespeare you got productions of intense power, and people reading them in terms of news about today from the past. It gave me the sense of the power of what you could unlock from a play from the past."

The other influence on his theatrical ideas was the variety shows he saw as child in Leeds. "Music hall was my diet and I think a lot of my work has been a serious metamorphosis of things I saw as a child. It was quite hard to think about verse drama when I started out. It was Eliot and Fry, which I didn't like. I thought they ruined verse drama. But the verse of musicals and of pantomime was wonderful. I remember men playing women and women playing men speaking in verse, and I think those experiences go quite deep."

Richard Eyre says Harrison has not been yoked to the usual list of great British dramatists because he has chosen to write exclusively in verse. "Which ironically is the great British tradition, with the greatest British dramatist Shakespeare. Tony is saying here is a medium, verse drama, which has incredible vigour, which uses the source of rhythmic language to distil and provide a pulse for dramatic action. It is a conscious choice for him as it was for Shakespeare."

By the time Harrison returned home from Prague in 1967 he was determined not to end up teaching in England and decided "to venture everything on being a poet. It had to be a real job, like my father's." And so began his policy of "it's all verse," as he started to work as much for the stage as for the page. The success of his adaptation of Molière's The Misanthrope was his big break at the National Theatre, followed by his adaptation of The Oresteia and then The Mysteries.

Eyre places his 1990 play, The Trackers Of Oxyrhynchus - in which satyrs with giant phalluses clog dance - among the five most imaginative pieces of drama in the 90s. Jocelyn Herbert, doyenne of British theatre design and a long-time Harrison collaborator, acknowledges that his ideas are intrinsically dramatic. "The idea of satyrs jumping out of boxes in Trackers is wonderful for the stage. Some writers just write and have little idea what it will look like, but Tony always knows exactly what he wants."

He also knows exactly what it should sound like. The Yorkshire actor Barrie Rutter has featured in many Harrison productions. He recalls a time when the accepted wisdom was that "Rutter couldn't play kings, because of my accent. And here was Harrison writing the greatest drama for voices like mine. He showed that high art needn't be appropriated by received pronunciation. His stuff is tremendous material for an actor, and I love to rock'n'roll on his language. He is very actor conscious and his speeches work every faculty."

Harrison's poems began to become increasingly direct and simple when he realised his own parents couldn't understand his work. From the time of v. in 1985 he set out on a new route. "He doesn't distinguish between the lyric, the narrative and the dramatic work," says critic Sandie Byrne. "He illustrates how we shouldn't expect poetry to be homogenous and consistent. It is a wonderfully flexible medium. Sometimes he writes lines of stonking doggerel and that is intentional. The sheer audacity of the bad rhyme is part of the poem. His early works are highly finished and have obviously been through a number of drafts, but things like the Bosnia reportage poems were written at speed. It would almost be an insult to their subject matter for them to be polished in the same way."

The critic Neil Corcoran is more wary. "I'm not entirely negative about Tony Harrison," he says. "In his earlier work there's an enormous amount of energy and exuberance. There are lots of ingenious little anecdotes and historical vignettes which are often the instruments of class antagonism and venom. This exuberance makes many of these lyrics very dramatic, especially in his own readings. But I think there's a danger in that. The poems can seem too much merely a performance, with insufficient inwardness and subtlety to sustain repeated readings. Perhaps that element comes to predominate in some of the more recent work, much of which is conceived in a theatrical or cinematic context."

Corcoran argues that it can be hard to differentiate necessary antagonism to a repressive class system from self-admiration. "That's to say, the poet celebrating his own triumph in adversity. And this is particularly the case when this theme is repeated as often as it is in Harrison. To my mind, some of what he does in this regard is done with greater complexity by poets such as Douglas Dunn or Seamus Heaney - who, it should be said, are nevertheless both admirers."

When his name was trotted out in relation to the poet laureateship after Ted Hughes's death, he thought his refusal to be considered was a statement of the obvious. "Anyone who read my poetry would know that I was the most unlikely person. But people know me as a public poet and thought I was an obvious candidate. I think I was even on the list the time before. People would say we want somebody serious. And I'd say it's not a serious position."

The fall-out from his refusal was as much personal as literary, and included some unwelcome tabloid scrutiny of his own love life. He and Rosemarie had been divorced in the late 70s and Harrison had married the Greek soprano Teresa Stratas in 1984 after meeting her some years earlier when he adapted the libretto to Smetana's opera The Bartered Bride for the Met in New York. In Laureate's Block he referred to both Stratas and his long-term girlfriend, the actress Sian Thomas.

"Anybody who knows me knows I've been with this woman for years," he says. "It's not new. But the papers hounded both Sian and my wife. It was revolting." For all the self-revelatory material in his poetry, particularly in the ongoing sonnet sequence, "From the School of Eloquence", Harrison says he is "not somebody who can easily share personal things with people in conversation. But if I get the poem right there's no embarrassment about sharing it. It's not a simple thing of saying I have this feeling and I've got to get it into this book. You actually discover what the feeling is by writing the poem. Things like rhyme and meter are instruments of discovery. It's like water is used by a potter to keep the clay malleable."

But he acknowledges that while he can articulate his feelings in verse, that in itself doesn't change the source of pain. These lines were written to his son:

I never pray; I scorn religious quacks

but do things I despise, for my son, Max,

out of unbearable panic at his pain:

like light a candle in a church in Spain.

"These poems, like the ones I wrote for my friend Jonathan Silver who was dying, do raise the question as to what does poetry help. It doesn't stop the person from dying. The poems become a kind of looking for fullness and celebration in the darkest situations."

Harrison has been able to utilise his own periodic descents into darkness - into depression - as another instrument of discovery. "It's part of my nature to be dark and I bask in it. I absorb it and I use it. And then I have sort of manic weeks and I finish everything.

"Death gives us all our appetite. Eros and Thanatos. The idea of death gives us our sexual impulse. It's not a canceller of appetite, it's an enhancer. If you really are aware of it, then it gives you an immense capacity for living in the here and now. Feeling your sorrows to the full, as well as your joy. And most people have more sorrows than joys."

Richard Eyre recalls Harrison treating his actors backstage to a sip of champagne from a 2,000-year-old Greek cup before they went on. "He's the only writer I know who would do something like that. He does have a terrific appetite for the taste of life. And that includes the taste of melancholy; he is a melancholic, not a depressive. He did once say to me that if he couldn't write he would go mad. He has a sense of a soul within him that is fighting for expression and if it didn't legitimise its expression through art would dissolve into madness."

Over the past decade or so Harrison's art has been increasingly visual, and he is the first poet since Betjeman to establish a regular niche with his verse films. They started in 1987 when he wrote In Loving Memory, four television films about cemeteries. Next was Blasphemers' Banquet in which he placed himself at the table with Voltaire, Omar Khayyám, Byron, Molière and Salman Rushdie. Black Daisies For The Bride was his study of Alzheimer's sufferers. He started to direct with his film about economic migrants from Kazakhstan selling tatty Soviet memorabilia in a street market in Athens, and followed it with The Shadow Of Hiroshima, which marked the 50th anniversary of VJ Day.

With Prometheus, the story of the titan who stole fire and made the gods' world ours, he follows Shelley in seeing it as an example of class warfare, with Zeus and his henchman Hermes agents of capitalism, and Prometheus a reminder of socialist idealism. His anger at Zeus is deeply personal. On some level he inhabits the classical world as part of his daily life.

His contempt for Roman theatre is visceral. "I loathed the way the Romans adapted almost every ancient Greek theatre into a killing place. Even the great theatre of Dionysus in Athens has marble slabs which are clearly blood-guards so that people in the front row didn't get splashed. For the Greeks, when something terrible happens a messenger would come on and tell you about it in spellbinding language. The ear goes much closer than the eye would ever accept. Their masks always had the eyes and mouth open.

"But the Romans used to get prisoners out of the prison, dress them up as Hercules and literally burn them. It was snuff theatre. It was an expression of power to kill 100 rare ostriches in a morning, but after the Greek theatre, it was such a failure of the imagination."

Harrison's work has been a lifelong struggle to respect the powers of imagination and make them accessible. Simon Armitage acknowledges that he has blazed a trail for many poets. "He has allowed my generation to do our own thing without having to worry too much about where we come from and what accents we've got. Trying to write in a way that's representative of our voices was a pitched battle for him."

And what of Harrison's own perception of his legacy? "Well, like anyone, I hope the people who knew me will talk about me over a bottle of wine after I've gone. But what I'm proud of is that I can read poems about my parents in Leeds or Bradford, and men especially are suddenly sobbing in the audience. That a short poem has touched them that deeply and brings that kind of response is better than a rave review.

"But I always feel, especially in my fallow periods, that I don't recognise this monster who finishes my work with such intensity. It's like Rumplestiltskin coming in and turning all the straw into gold and then going away again. I've done poems for the page, the stage, the opera house, television, film and newspapers. It's all one work. You know, maybe the life is really about dodging about to achieve moments where the work can happen. And often you fuck up your life in order to get that moment. But that's the way it can be when the muses have your telephone number."

Life at a glance: Tony Harrison

Born: Leeds, April 30 1937.

Education: Cross Flatts county primary school; Leeds grammar school; Leeds University.

Family: Married Rosemarie Crossfield 1960 (one son, one daughter), marriage dissolved; married Teresa Stratas 1984.

Teaching: English lecturer, Ahmadu Bello University, Nigeria 1962-66; Charles University, Prague 1966-67.

Some poetry: Earthworks 1964; Newcastle Is Peru 1969; The Loiners 1970; Palladas 1975; From the School of Eloquence 1978; v.1985; Selected Poems 1987; A Cold Coming 1991; Laureate's Block 2000.

Theatre: Akin Mahta 1966; The Misanthrope 1973; Phaedra Britannica 1975; Bow Down 1977; The Oresteia 1981; Yan Tan Tethera1983; The Mysteries 1985; The Trackers of Oxyrhynchus 1990; The Kaisers of Carnuntum 1995; The Prince's Play 1996.

Some film: Blasphemers' Banquet 1989;Prometheus 1999.

Its bold declaration, "We'll occupy/your lousy leasehold Poetry", and revelation that in Wordsworth "matter/water are full rhymes" set the tone for his future assault on the cultural barriers that divide the classes. At university he took part in a revue show written by a fellow student, the writer and comedian Barry Cryer. "In one show everyone had to dress up in very smart dinner jackets and all that," recalls Cryer. "We had to forcibly hold Tony down and apply Brylcreem to his hair. It infuriated him." Another university friend and fellow member of Cryer's revue was the Nobel prize-winning writer Wole Soyinka. It was his friendship with Soyinka that contributed to him taking a post in the English department at Ahmadu Bello University in Nigeria in 1962. Harrison had married his first wife Rosemarie in 1960. Their daughter, Jane, was born the year they moved to Nigeria and their son, Max, the following year. He has three grandchildren. His first collection of poems, Earthworks, was published in 1964, and he and the Irish poet James Simmons, also at the university, worked together on Akin Mahta, a Nigerian version of Aristophanes's comedy Lysistrata, incorporating African music and dance. Works for stage and page have continued in tandem ever since. After four years, Harrison moved to Prague, partly because his wife's family lived in East Germany - her father had been a communist under Hitler - and Czechoslovakia was one of the few places where the whole family could meet. The city's vibrant theatrical life also fed the development of Harrison's drama. "I went to theatre every day for 18 months. It was fantastic, a really important part of my life. With the official media being censored, in something like Shakespeare you got productions of intense power, and people reading them in terms of news about today from the past. It gave me the sense of the power of what you could unlock from a play from the past." The other influence on his theatrical ideas was the variety shows he saw as child in Leeds. "Music hall was my diet and I think a lot of my work has been a serious metamorphosis of things I saw as a child. It was quite hard to think about verse drama when I started out. It was Eliot and Fry, which I didn't like. I thought they ruined verse drama. But the verse of musicals and of pantomime was wonderful. I remember men playing women and women playing men speaking in verse, and I think those experiences go quite deep." Richard Eyre says Harrison has not been yoked to the usual list of great British dramatists because he has chosen to write exclusively in verse. "Which ironically is the great British tradition, with the greatest British dramatist Shakespeare. Tony is saying here is a medium, verse drama, which has incredible vigour, which uses the source of rhythmic language to distil and provide a pulse for dramatic action. It is a conscious choice for him as it was for Shakespeare." By the time Harrison returned home from Prague in 1967 he was determined not to end up teaching in England and decided "to venture everything on being a poet. It had to be a real job, like my father's." And so began his policy of "it's all verse," as he started to work as much for the stage as for the page. The success of his adaptation of Molière's The Misanthrope was his big break at the National Theatre, followed by his adaptation of The Oresteia and then The Mysteries. Eyre places his 1990 play, The Trackers Of Oxyrhynchus - in which satyrs with giant phalluses clog dance - among the five most imaginative pieces of drama in the 90s. Jocelyn Herbert, doyenne of British theatre design and a long-time Harrison collaborator, acknowledges that his ideas are intrinsically dramatic. "The idea of satyrs jumping out of boxes in Trackers is wonderful for the stage. Some writers just write and have little idea what it will look like, but Tony always knows exactly what he wants." He also knows exactly what it should sound like. The Yorkshire actor Barrie Rutter has featured in many Harrison productions. He recalls a time when the accepted wisdom was that "Rutter couldn't play kings, because of my accent. And here was Harrison writing the greatest drama for voices like mine. He showed that high art needn't be appropriated by received pronunciation. His stuff is tremendous material for an actor, and I love to rock'n'roll on his language. He is very actor conscious and his speeches work every faculty." Harrison's poems began to become increasingly direct and simple when he realised his own parents couldn't understand his work. From the time of v. in 1985 he set out on a new route. "He doesn't distinguish between the lyric, the narrative and the dramatic work," says critic Sandie Byrne. "He illustrates how we shouldn't expect poetry to be homogenous and consistent. It is a wonderfully flexible medium. Sometimes he writes lines of stonking doggerel and that is intentional. The sheer audacity of the bad rhyme is part of the poem. His early works are highly finished and have obviously been through a number of drafts, but things like the Bosnia reportage poems were written at speed. It would almost be an insult to their subject matter for them to be polished in the same way." The critic Neil Corcoran is more wary. "I'm not entirely negative about Tony Harrison," he says. "In his earlier work there's an enormous amount of energy and exuberance. There are lots of ingenious little anecdotes and historical vignettes which are often the instruments of class antagonism and venom. This exuberance makes many of these lyrics very dramatic, especially in his own readings. But I think there's a danger in that. The poems can seem too much merely a performance, with insufficient inwardness and subtlety to sustain repeated readings. Perhaps that element comes to predominate in some of the more recent work, much of which is conceived in a theatrical or cinematic context." Corcoran argues that it can be hard to differentiate necessary antagonism to a repressive class system from self-admiration. "That's to say, the poet celebrating his own triumph in adversity. And this is particularly the case when this theme is repeated as often as it is in Harrison. To my mind, some of what he does in this regard is done with greater complexity by poets such as Douglas Dunn or Seamus Heaney - who, it should be said, are nevertheless both admirers." When his name was trotted out in relation to the poet laureateship after Ted Hughes's death, he thought his refusal to be considered was a statement of the obvious. "Anyone who read my poetry would know that I was the most unlikely person. But people know me as a public poet and thought I was an obvious candidate. I think I was even on the list the time before. People would say we want somebody serious. And I'd say it's not a serious position." The fall-out from his refusal was as much personal as literary, and included some unwelcome tabloid scrutiny of his own love life. He and Rosemarie had been divorced in the late 70s and Harrison had married the Greek soprano Teresa Stratas in 1984 after meeting her some years earlier when he adapted the libretto to Smetana's opera The Bartered Bride for the Met in New York. In Laureate's Block he referred to both Stratas and his long-term girlfriend, the actress Sian Thomas. "Anybody who knows me knows I've been with this woman for years," he says. "It's not new. But the papers hounded both Sian and my wife. It was revolting." For all the self-revelatory material in his poetry, particularly in the ongoing sonnet sequence, "From the School of Eloquence", Harrison says he is "not somebody who can easily share personal things with people in conversation. But if I get the poem right there's no embarrassment about sharing it. It's not a simple thing of saying I have this feeling and I've got to get it into this book. You actually discover what the feeling is by writing the poem. Things like rhyme and meter are instruments of discovery. It's like water is used by a potter to keep the clay malleable." But he acknowledges that while he can articulate his feelings in verse, that in itself doesn't change the source of pain. These lines were written to his son: I never pray; I scorn religious quacks but do things I despise, for my son, Max, out of unbearable panic at his pain: like light a candle in a church in Spain. "These poems, like the ones I wrote for my friend Jonathan Silver who was dying, do raise the question as to what does poetry help. It doesn't stop the person from dying. The poems become a kind of looking for fullness and celebration in the darkest situations." Harrison has been able to utilise his own periodic descents into darkness - into depression - as another instrument of discovery. "It's part of my nature to be dark and I bask in it. I absorb it and I use it. And then I have sort of manic weeks and I finish everything. "Death gives us all our appetite. Eros and Thanatos. The idea of death gives us our sexual impulse. It's not a canceller of appetite, it's an enhancer. If you really are aware of it, then it gives you an immense capacity for living in the here and now. Feeling your sorrows to the full, as well as your joy. And most people have more sorrows than joys." Richard Eyre recalls Harrison treating his actors backstage to a sip of champagne from a 2,000-year-old Greek cup before they went on. "He's the only writer I know who would do something like that. He does have a terrific appetite for the taste of life. And that includes the taste of melancholy; he is a melancholic, not a depressive. He did once say to me that if he couldn't write he would go mad. He has a sense of a soul within him that is fighting for expression and if it didn't legitimise its expression through art would dissolve into madness." Over the past decade or so Harrison's art has been increasingly visual, and he is the first poet since Betjeman to establish a regular niche with his verse films. They started in 1987 when he wrote In Loving Memory, four television films about cemeteries. Next was Blasphemers' Banquet in which he placed himself at the table with Voltaire, Omar Khayyám, Byron, Molière and Salman Rushdie. Black Daisies For The Bride was his study of Alzheimer's sufferers. He started to direct with his film about economic migrants from Kazakhstan selling tatty Soviet memorabilia in a street market in Athens, and followed it with The Shadow Of Hiroshima, which marked the 50th anniversary of VJ Day. With Prometheus, the story of the titan who stole fire and made the gods' world ours, he follows Shelley in seeing it as an example of class warfare, with Zeus and his henchman Hermes agents of capitalism, and Prometheus a reminder of socialist idealism. His anger at Zeus is deeply personal. On some level he inhabits the classical world as part of his daily life. His contempt for Roman theatre is visceral. "I loathed the way the Romans adapted almost every ancient Greek theatre into a killing place. Even the great theatre of Dionysus in Athens has marble slabs which are clearly blood-guards so that people in the front row didn't get splashed. For the Greeks, when something terrible happens a messenger would come on and tell you about it in spellbinding language. The ear goes much closer than the eye would ever accept. Their masks always had the eyes and mouth open. "But the Romans used to get prisoners out of the prison, dress them up as Hercules and literally burn them. It was snuff theatre. It was an expression of power to kill 100 rare ostriches in a morning, but after the Greek theatre, it was such a failure of the imagination." Harrison's work has been a lifelong struggle to respect the powers of imagination and make them accessible. Simon Armitage acknowledges that he has blazed a trail for many poets. "He has allowed my generation to do our own thing without having to worry too much about where we come from and what accents we've got. Trying to write in a way that's representative of our voices was a pitched battle for him." And what of Harrison's own perception of his legacy? "Well, like anyone, I hope the people who knew me will talk about me over a bottle of wine after I've gone. But what I'm proud of is that I can read poems about my parents in Leeds or Bradford, and men especially are suddenly sobbing in the audience. That a short poem has touched them that deeply and brings that kind of response is better than a rave review. "But I always feel, especially in my fallow periods, that I don't recognise this monster who finishes my work with such intensity. It's like Rumplestiltskin coming in and turning all the straw into gold and then going away again. I've done poems for the page, the stage, the opera house, television, film and newspapers. It's all one work. You know, maybe the life is really about dodging about to achieve moments where the work can happen. And often you fuck up your life in order to get that moment. But that's the way it can be when the muses have your telephone number." Life at a glance: Tony Harrison Born: Leeds, April 30 1937. Education: Cross Flatts county primary school; Leeds grammar school; Leeds University. Family: Married Rosemarie Crossfield 1960 (one son, one daughter), marriage dissolved; married Teresa Stratas 1984. Teaching: English lecturer, Ahmadu Bello University, Nigeria 1962-66; Charles University, Prague 1966-67. Some poetry: Earthworks 1964; Newcastle Is Peru 1969; The Loiners 1970; Palladas 1975; From the School of Eloquence 1978; v.1985; Selected Poems 1987; A Cold Coming 1991; Laureate's Block 2000. Theatre: Akin Mahta 1966; The Misanthrope 1973; Phaedra Britannica 1975; Bow Down 1977; The Oresteia 1981; Yan Tan Tethera1983; The Mysteries 1985; The Trackers of Oxyrhynchus 1990; The Kaisers of Carnuntum 1995; The Prince's Play 1996. Some film: Blasphemers' Banquet 1989;Prometheus 1999.  Laureate's Block is published by Penguin (£7.99). The Mysteries are at the National Theatre until May 15.

fields.headline: Not to be sniffed at
fields.standfirst: DJ Taylor  enjoys JJ Connolly's linguistically lively crime caper Layer Cake
fields.trailText: DJ Taylor enjoys JJ Connolly's linguistically lively crime caper Layer Cake
fields.body:
Layer Cake
JJ Connolly
Duck Editions, £9.99, 309pp
Buy it at BOL

Given the current glut of crime'n'caper novels, I approached JJ Connolly's debut with faint enthusiasm. Happily, Layer Cake (referring to the complex series of constituencies that make up modern London gangsterland) is a storming piece of work: funny and serious by turns, with an abiding sense of conviction. I may be wrong, and Connolly turn out to be a prize fellow of All Souls, but on the strength of this it doesn't look like it.

Or, indeed, sound like it. Set in a teeming north-east London world of seriously criminal business types, the novel has a grasp of street argot unparalleled since Kinky Friedman first sashayed out of his front door and nailed a checker straight out of the bat. "Three-piece whistles with 24-inch lionels" I take to mean extravagantly flared suits, but even case-hardened East End slang fanciers will probably feel the need of a glossary.

For all its linguistic liveliness, Layer Cake manages to ransack every cupboard of what has become a highly stylised genre. Connolly's nameless narrator ("If I told you [my name] you'd be as clever as me") is a 29-year-old veteran of the metropolitan coke trade who aims to make one last hit before a far-flung retirement. Unfortunately, the gnarled Mr Big to whom our hero's firm owes its profits and reputation has other ideas: he wants the narrator to track down the wildcat daughter of an old chum of his. Polite refusal is not an option.

Meanwhile, other business awaits, notably the disposal of two million top-grade MDMA tablets robbed from an Amsterdam factory by one of the firm's less respectable offshoots. Matters are further complicated by the discovery that the pills' rightful owners - European neo-Nazis, naturally - are in vengeful pursuit, and that all paths lead back to Mr Big, also revealed as a police informer. Furious at the set-up, our hero overcomes an ingrained aversion to violence and heads up to Totteridge to do something very nasty indeed.

Publishing lead times being what they are, I doubt if the author got a sight of Lock, Stock and Two Smoking Barrels before he finished this novel, and yet the resemblance is uncanny: cross and double cross, glorious bits of effrontery (a gang of carefully kitted-out fake policemen who cover their tracks by pretending to be corrupt real policemen), archetypal ordinary-decent-criminal moralising, the box switch at the end which sees the pills go back to Amsterdam. No female characters above the level of a walk-on, either.

Amid much larkiness, gallows humour and wayside mayhem, Connolly never glosses over the fact that pain hurts and bullets kill: while there are odd dollops of gratuitousness, the final effect is never callow. And though one can envisage Layer Cake transferring triumphantly to the screen, the chances of anyone being up to translating it are pretty remote.
