fields.headline: Heinous envy
fields.standfirst: Ted Heller puts office life on the anatomist's table in Slab Rat
fields.trailText: Ted Heller puts office life on the anatomist's table in Slab Rat
fields.body:
Slab Rat
Ted Heller
Abacus, £10.99, 332pp
Buy it at BOL

The hero of this novel at one point receives a dressing-down from his bosses for an opinionated piece of work. Enraged, he spits out exactly what he thinks of their tiny-minded objections. Wow: awesome cojones, we breathe. Then he confesses laconically: "I don't say this but think it very loudly." Ha. He's like the rest of us after all.

Though Slab Rat has been widely hyped as an exposé of the New York magazine world, its major virtue is as a virulently comic anatomy of office life. The story, after all, is pretty universal: skin-creepingly irritating newcomer with solipsistic void where his talent should be enjoys obscenely rapid promotion and induces seething, possibly murderous envy among his colleagues.

The golden boy is Mark Larkin, a tweedy fraud who arrives at It magazine and soon proves to be a virtuoso of the brown nose. His enemies are two associate editors: Zachary Post, the narrator, and his old friend Willie. When Larkin is promoted over their heads, their irreverent emails turn darkly to the subject of disposal. Larkin, they decide, must die.

Meanwhile, Post is torn between two women. Ivy Kooper is a sweet office intern; Leslie Usher-Soames is a fabulous stereotype of the posh English female, with a family that knew Churchill and "small perky breasts that point up like faces looking at a man about to jump off a building". Usher-Soames doesn't eat properly, and when Post kisses her she feels "like an ironing board". But class matters: Post got the job at It by inventing a famous architect father and a sunny Gatsbyan childhood, and he covets Usher-Soames's distinguishing hyphen.

Heller's style belongs to that zippy American school - slangy and light on figuration, apparently more interested in the texture of things than of minds, and composed largely of short, denotative sentences - that so cleverly conceals the work going on underneath. It's a refreshing draught of cool lager after the heavy, cloudy bitter of much British prose.

The novel rejoices in mercilessly detailing the linguistic abuses of the glossy media. "'Kafkaesque' is one of those second-tier magazine-speak words and phrases: 'Grand guignol', 'cause célèbre', and, well, 'and, well' are some others," Post explains. One of Larkin's meretricious book reviews is a beautiful parody of see-saw puffery: "Ethan Cawley at once de-mythifies and re-mythifies, deconstructs and reconstructs... turning American literature on its head, then standing it back up again..."

And what had Post done to provoke the ire of his superiors? "I had said a book was bad and everybody else had said it was good because they thought that everybody else would say it was good." Reading dangerous fantasies like this, I fear, could erode the touching faith British readers place in their own newspapers.

Slab Rat's metropolitan smarts are reminiscent of Jay McInerney's Bright Lights, Big City or a less misanthropic Bret Easton Ellis, but Heller also seems to have inherited a strain of dad Joseph's absurdism. The book's funniest episode is a dazed, surreal trip to London, where Post visits Usher-Soames's parents and walks into the plate-glass window of a Jermyn Street gentleman's outfitters. (A newspaper reports that the window should be fixed "within the next few months".)

Heller's plot devices can creak: Post infiltrates an email account that, incredibly, isn't password-protected; Larkin should not be revealed so quickly as the bogus and malevolent buffoon he really is. Post's romantic difficulties, too, are a sugary distraction; but the tart twists of the revenge drama ensure the novel remains a very classy slab of literary entertainment.

Yeah, right. That's what everyone else has said too. How do you know I'm not just covering my ass?

fields.headline: Bottom feeders
fields.standfirst: Andrew Pulver  on Peter Farrelly's authentic tale of Hollywood angst, The Comedy Writer
fields.trailText: Andrew Pulver on Peter Farrelly's authentic tale of Hollywood angst, The Comedy Writer
fields.body:
The Comedy Writer
Peter Farrelly
Faber, £9.99, 366pp
Buy it at BOL

Novelists write screenplays all the time, so why shouldn't film directors write fiction? Recent examples include Ethan Coen (a short-story collection, Gates of Eden), Gus van Sant (a novel, Pink), and Harmony Korine (a scrappy prose collage, A Crack-Up at the Race Riots).

But Peter Farrelly (celebrated for virtually inventing, along with his brother Bobby, the modern gross-out movie: Dumb and Dumber, Kingpin, There's Something About Mary), is actually on his second novel - the first, Outside Providence, was completed a decade ago when Farrelly's Hollywood career was only just getting off the ground.

Unlike his book-writing peers, Farrelly has steered conspicuously clear of the brainy end of the film-making spectrum - the brothers' debut, Dumb and Dumber, was roundly accused of precipitating the intellectual decline of the entire western hemisphere. Here Farrelly shows that you have to be truly smart to appear that dumb. In stark contrast to his primary-colour, elbow-in-the-ribs, head-down-the-toilet film-making, Farrelly writes a low-key, melancholic prose, wandering from vignette to vignette with an oblique but assured narrative drive.

He has certainly taken to heart the dictum that you should write about what you know. Outside Providence fed directly from his experiences as a teenager in Rhode Island; The Comedy Writer details the uncertainties of an aspiring scriptwriter in Los Angeles. Chronicles of the Hollywood underbelly - both true and fictional - are meat and drink to the reading public these days, and Farrelly's contribution to the genre comes over like a cross between Rob Long's Conversations with My Agent and Bruce Wagner's sorely overlooked Force Majeure; a mix of couldn't-make-it-up powerplays and the wretchedness to which industry bottom-feeders inevitably succumb.

There is the genuine tang of authenticity in Farrelly's account of his protagonist, Henry Halloran, attempting to negotiate the prickly worlds of agency representation, production deals and TV pitch sessions. In real life, the Farrelly brothers offered a storyline for Seinfeld that later became the celebrated episode "The Virgin" (the one in which Jerry's girlfriend won't have sex with him). The whole sorry incident is reproduced here in all its ambiguous humiliations - with Larry David and Jerry Seinfeld mentioned by name.

Farrelly also recounts a particularly piquant incident which, whether true or not, perfectly distills the Faustian pact Hollywood demands of its inmates - Halloran is required, by a powerful producer with whom he has just lunched, to perjure himself in regard to a road-traffic accident in which his benefactor is clearly culpable. Morality, as ever, is the victim of showbiz aspirations.

Farrelly's novel is, however, considerably more than another unspooling of life in the Hollywood shark-tank. Lacing together the anecdotes about celebrity spotting and development meetings is a subtly observed, genuinely funny and cheerfully obscene study of a 33-year-old man in emotional crisis.

Halloran heads out west in the throes of a relationship breakdown (his "spec" script is called How I Won Her Back); once in LA, he has to contend with a stream of rejections from one cantilevered Hollywood woman after another, a rapidly burgeoning hypochondria ("I haven't had many men ask for mammograms recently") and, most significantly, an unwelcome entanglement with the sister of a woman he watches commit suicide three days after he arrives.

Halloran's reaction to this suicide - another item, apparently, from the Farrelly scrapbook - is the reader's way into his convoluted inner life. His is an uneasy participation in the Hollywood treadmill: he observes the unreflecting hedonism around him with an eager but appalled eye. And his scriptwriting, it seems, is his method of filtering his experience, of mediating his own web of human relationships.

There's also a gallery of hilarious modern grotesques - from the wannabe player who adopts a Jewish name ("Herb Silverman") to gain studio-executive credibility to the near-demented movie-maker who is hooked by Halloran's serial-killer pitch "The Ice Cream Man" (tagline: No More Mr Softee). The Comedy Writer is a comic achievement of considerable proportions; frighteningly confessional in places, but run through with remorselessly self-deprecating humour. In his unabashed recycling of his most intimate experiences, Farrelly offers himself as something of a West Coast Philip Roth.

Here Farrelly shows that you have to be truly smart to appear that dumb. In stark contrast to his primary-colour, elbow-in-the-ribs, head-down-the-toilet film-making, Farrelly writes a low-key, melancholic prose, wandering from vignette to vignette with an oblique but assured narrative drive. He has certainly taken to heart the dictum that you should write about what you know. Outside Providence fed directly from his experiences as a teenager in Rhode Island; The Comedy Writer details the uncertainties of an aspiring scriptwriter in Los Angeles. Chronicles of the Hollywood underbelly - both true and fictional - are meat and drink to the reading public these days, and Farrelly's contribution to the genre comes over like a cross between Rob Long's Conversations with My Agent and Bruce Wagner's sorely overlooked Force Majeure; a mix of couldn't-make-it-up powerplays and the wretchedness to which industry bottom-feeders inevitably succumb. There is the genuine tang of authenticity in Farrelly's account of his protagonist, Henry Halloran, attempting to negotiate the prickly worlds of agency representation, production deals and TV pitch sessions. In real life, the Farrelly brothers offered a storyline for Seinfeld that later became the celebrated episode "The Virgin" (the one in which Jerry's girlfriend won't have sex with him). The whole sorry incident is reproduced here in all its ambiguous humiliations - with Larry David and Jerry Seinfeld mentioned by name. Farrelly also recounts a particularly piquant incident which, whether true or not, perfectly distills the Faustian pact Hollywood demands of its inmates - Halloran is required, by a powerful producer with whom he has just lunched, to perjure himself in regard to a road-traffic accident in which his benefactor is clearly culpable. Morality, as ever, is the victim of showbiz aspirations. Farrelly's novel is, however, considerably more than another unspooling of life in the Hollywood shark-tank. Lacing together the anecdotes about celebrity spotting and development meetings is a subtly observed, genuinely funny and cheerfully obscene study of a 33-year-old man in emotional crisis. Halloran heads out west in the throes of a relationship breakdown (his "spec" script is called How I Won Her Back); once in LA, he has to contend with a stream of rejections from one cantilevered Hollywood woman after another, a rapidly burgeoning hypochondria ("I haven't had many men ask for mammograms recently") and, most significantly, an unwelcome entanglement with the sister of a woman he watches commit suicide three days after he arrives. Halloran's reaction to this suicide - another item, apparently, from the Farrelly scrapbook - is the reader's way into his convoluted inner life. His is an uneasy participation in the Hollywood treadmill: he observes the unreflecting hedonism around him with an eager but appalled eye. And his scriptwriting, it seems, is his method of filtering his experience, of mediating his own web of human relationships. There's also a gallery of hilarious modern grotesques - from the wannabe player who adopts a Jewish name ("Herb Silverman") to gain studio-executive credibility to the near-demented movie-maker who is hooked by Halloran's serial-killer pitch "The Ice Cream Man" (tagline: No More Mr Softee). The Comedy Writer is a comic achievement of considerable proportions; frighteningly confessional in places, but run through with remorselessly self-deprecating humour. In his unabashed recycling of his most intimate experiences, Farrelly offers himself as something of a West Coast Philip Roth.

webTitle: Under The Skin by Michel Faber review – flesh-creeping

fields.headline: Under The Skin by Michel Faber review – flesh-creeping
fields.standfirst: It is better to travel than to arrive in Michael Faber’s Under The Skin
fields.trailText: It is better to travel than to arrive in Michael Faber’s Under The Skin
fields.body:
Under The Skin
Michel Faber
Canongate, £9.99, 296pp
Buy it at BOL

Like the sun in the Highlands, Michel Faber has been threatening for so long now that I had begun to think of him as a myth - a sly fabulist way up there in the heather invented by Edinburgh’s smart-alec hypesters to add spice to the Scottish literary renaissance.

On the jacket of his one collection of short stories, Some Rain Must Fall, we were asked to believe that he was a Dutch pickle-packer who studied Anglo-Saxon in Australia before giving it all up to become a cleaner somewhere near Inverness. This air of mystery thickened with the tantalising glimpses of something big beneath the bushel in such perfectly turned stories as “Sheep”, “The Red Cement Truck” and “The Perfect W”.

You don’t often see satire stirred with so humane a hand, or tragedy handled with so light a touch. Here was a ventriloquist with a whole Babel of voices to throw: artists making nothing out of something, cosmetic surgery junkies obsessed with the unseen and dead people coolly assessing their killers. Was Faber really who he said he was, you wondered, or was he the Dr Jekyll to Irvine Welsh’s Mr Hyde, or some sleeker incarnation of Alasdair Gray?

So when Faber finally sat down to write a novel, it is not surprising that he adopted the guise of someone not of this world, nor even of this galaxy. Like her creator, we are never quite sure where his Isserley, a small, bespectacled being with a perfect nose and curiously buoyant breasts, comes from. Driving all day at funereal pace along the empty roads of northern Scotland, she is after one thing: well-muscled men. What she does with the hitchhikers picked up in lonely glens we learn only slowly, by which time our fascination with Isserley and her own victimhood easily eclipses the gruesome fate that awaits them. (Human bresaola, if you must know.)

With each male specimen who steps into the passenger seat of her little overheated car, Faber adds another piece to the puzzle of this alien kerb-crawler. There is something strange about her legs; her grasp of the world around her is patchy, yet occasionally her insights into the banal are so beautiful that they bring up you short. Notwithstanding the clever characterisation, the real triumph is Faber’s restrained, almost opaque prose. This is a man who could give Conrad a run at writing the perfect sentence.

Under The Skin has already been sold in eight countries, a boon for the small publisher Canongate. But finally, having utterly convinced us of his alien narrator and persuaded us to go along for the ride for nearly 300 pages, Faber doesn’t quite know where to go: the miniaturist aims at a big metaphysical moment. Metaphysics are fine, but you can’t feed a family on them. Still, the journey alone is worthwhile. Room will now have to be made for Faber alongside Alasdair Gray, James Kelman, Irvine Welsh and AL Kennedy.

fields.headline: My new found land
fields.standfirst: Peter Ho Davies is refreshed by America's open spaces in Equal Love
fields.trailText: Peter Ho Davies is refreshed by America's open spaces in Equal Love
fields.body:
Equal Love
Peter Ho Davies
Granta, £9.99, 180pp
Buy it at BOL

At the heart of this collection of a dozen terse, melancholy stories is one that does not really work, but that lets you see how many of the others do. Called "How To Be An Expatriate", it is a kind of satire that traces the Americanising of an English postgraduate student. In 10 pages it covers six years and the changing yet constantly absurd ways that someone might trade on being English in America. It does not work because its shrewd little observations are all too "typical", unresolved into the exactness of character and situation that is this writer's strength. Yet its interest in expatriation and in America is behind much of what comes to life in Equal Love.

In his first short-story collection, The Ugliest House in the World, Ho Davies ranged restively in time (the 40s to the 19th century) and place (Malaysia, South Africa, Patagonia), as if straining to get beyond his own horizon. Now this writer, who was born to Welsh and Chinese parents and grew up in Coventry, has discovered America (he is currently teaching creative writing at the University of Michigan). America is his way out of himself - the setting for many of his stories, a space in which to rove.

America can make the peculiar probable. Ho Davies's opening piece is a precise and cleverly restrained example of this. Somewhere in New Hampshire in the 60s, a husband listens to his wife reporting her abduction by a UFO to a professionally respectful airforce officer, detailed to collect such accounts. It could only happen in the US. Yet there is absolutely nothing comic about it: it is a scene from a marriage - weirdly normal from the inside. What a lesser writer would have made of the "real" subject of the story - the way the relationship is shaped by the fact that he is black and she is white - emerges almost accidentally, as if it were rooted too deeply to be described directly.

The short story has, in the past, been a peculiarly American genre, naturally fitted to a society so hard to see as a whole. It clearly gives Ho Davies new ranges of experiment, though expatriation also has its uncertainties. Significantly, a story told in the voice of a single mother, detailing her efforts to keep her child from being taken into care, was set in Oregon when it was first published in Granta. As if not trusting his grasp of idiom, Ho Davies has transposed it to Manchester; the realities of class and colloquialism are grasped at, but the fragment's vivid strangeness is gone.

Usually Ho Davies is good at making strange the ordinary bonds of love. Most of his tales are vignettes of the unsymmetrical affection between parents and children. In one of the saddest and best, a married man tracks down an old girlfriend for a one-night stand, but rediscovers only the part he once played in the falling-out of her parents. In the title story, a mid-life academic's awkward seduction of his best friend's wife is abandoned when he and she glimpse from the bedroom window his son and her daughter beginning their own mutual seduction. They are outdone and chastened by their "glowing, lying children".

In each story Ho Davies sets himself the test of imagining a coherent "Small World", as one of his titles has it. Sometimes in Equal Love there is the sense of the creative-writing exercise, as he runs through every kind of narrator and tries out protagonists of every age and ethnicity. Yet this is the work of a writer really challenging himself, and treating the short story as a specially intriguing and demanding form.

fields.headline: To turn the tables
fields.standfirst: Nicholas Lezard  bats away his doubts and learns to love ping-pong in Howard Jacobson's The Mighty Walzer
fields.trailText: Nicholas Lezard bats away his doubts and learns to love ping-pong in Howard Jacobson's The Mighty Walzer
fields.body:
The Mighty Walzer
Howard Jacobson
388pp, Vintage, £6.99
Buy it at BOL

I had heard that this was a duff novel. It goes off in the second half, I'd heard. It's lopsided. The review in this paper said as much and could even be called harsh in its assessment; but not, perhaps, inaccurate - "Roth's fumbling understudy" being one memorable phrase to describe Jacobson's descriptions of, well, fumbling self-study. And its subject matter? Ping-pong. Excuse me, but can you write a novel about ping-pong?

So if this was a duff novel, then, why did I keep coming back to it when the alternatives palled? Why did the alternatives pall in the first place? Why did I laugh so much during it? (Although not as loud and long as I had during his previous, No More Mister Nice Guy, admittedly.) And why, most pertinently of all, did I find Jacobson's cadences, rhythms and vocabulary (a particularly rich broth of Mancunian Yiddish) implanted in my brain for what seemed like weeks afterwards? Is this what duff novels do? Give me another one, then.

Part of the problem, I suspect, is that as Jacobson continues to mine the story of his life for his novels, he perhaps finds himself running ahead of us, himself even, and using a kind of shorthand for characterisation, forgetful of the fact that not everyone is going to be as up to speed on the matter as himself, or indeed his fans. The Mighty Walzer is about Oliver Walzer, a shy and bookish Jewish boy from Manchester. We have been here before, but this time, the narrator discovers that he is absolutely brilliant at ping-pong. Is the information that Jacobson was, too, relevant?

Well, yes and no. It certainly means that he can write about the game with not only style but authority. And if he also chooses to write about his hour-long masturbation sessions in the family khazi, when he presumably realises that he is not the first writer to cross such territory, then we can assume that maybe he is writing about that with authority, too. Although perhaps this is not an avenue we should pursue.

No, if the story has a fault, it is that at times it seems as if Jacobson has something else on his mind. Another story altogether, perhaps (the next one?); or just maintaining the flick and vigour of his prose, and if the price of this means that we find it hard to distinguish between a few of his ping-pong pals, or note that the brief Cambridge section seems almost contemptuously scanty, then so be it. If it also means that we get passages like the following, in which the young Walzer imagines chewing out his headmaster for not hymning his talent and success to the rest of the school, then I don't think we really have much to complain about.

"Is it too much for you to bear, you yiddenfeit, you anti-Semitic piece of crap, that we should be good at a game and win scholarships to Oxford and Cambridge? Is that more than an erstwhile fucking Church of England grammar school can swallow? Well, prepare to swallow more, shithead. Meet the master race. You're looking at a double starred first and the next World Ping-Pong Champion. Won't that be something for you to ignore in favour of how Albert Shaygets came last in the All Radcliffe fishing gala with an already dead mackerel measuring a quarter of an inch - we're all proud of you Albert, you dim-witted freckled little snub nose petseleh, you!"

webTitle: The consolations of the coffee house

fields.headline: The consolations of the coffee house
fields.trailText: The Loafer moves from 'simple opinions' to 'ideas' over a hot cup of the Java, plus WH Smith Literary Award shortlis and it smells like teen hype
fields.body:
 To Alain de Botton's launch party at the state-of-the-art restaurant in the swanky Channel 4 building. Our Renaissance Man is, as we know, branching out into TV with a series to accompany his philosophical pensées.

In a less well-documented move, however, he's also taking his message to the streets, or at least the tea-room. The Institut Français will host a "café philo", apparently a laid-back kind of group encounter in which "the participants listen attentively to each other and are encouraged by the moderator to pass from simple opinions to ideas" - although we are warned that "while the café philo is the antithesis of an academic lecture, it is not an occasion for mere 'coffee-shop chat' ". AdeB will preside over the affair, held, with unwavering confidence, on today of all days.

 The shortlist for this year's WH Smith Literary Award has been announced, with the notable omission of longlist contenders JK Rowling and Seamus Heaney. Good news, though, for JM Coetzee, Joanna Bourke, Ann Wroe, Howard Jacobson and Melvyn Bragg. Congratulations too, to our colleague Francis Wheen, whose biography of Karl Marx is also up for the prize. Francis would have commented, but he was too busy swigging champagne outside the MI6 building to celebrate the publication of Stephen Dorril's account of 50 years of the outfit's most special operations. His publisher, however, noted that Marx himself would most probably have been delighted at the opportunity to promote vigorous public debate of his work.

 Two 12-year-old schoolchildren from Hampshire have been at the centre of a frenzied bidding war this week, after submitting a proposal for a book that, according to a leading agent, "will blow the lid off the epidemic of underage sex, drug-taking and alcohol abuse in our schools". Publishers' interest, it seems, has been excited by the pair's claims that a prominent MP's children will feature, and the current floor stands at well over £250,000.

In a separate development, HarperCollins have retained the services of Jeffrey Archer, buying worldwide rights to his next three books and the copyright term in his entire backlist. This at a time when his latest short story collection is "breaking records for the genre in the UK", according to HC. Well, one of these stories is true, anyway.

fields.headline: Cool companies
fields.standfirst: No. 30 PSD Associates
fields.trailText: No. 30 PSD Associates
fields.body:
Since its formation in 1988, Richmond-based PSD Associates has created a set of design competencies which help companies develop new brands and services. It can point to enviable performance in product design 2D/3D packaging, brand development, digital media and graphic communication and has a client list to die for. British Airways, Virgin, Mitsubishi, Philips and.. ahem... Rover are just a few of the high profile companies who have benefited from the PSD touch.

An integrated approach to projects enables the firm to express the values of a product or service through design, packaging, environment graphics or new media applications.

PSD's philosophy is that design can deliver the decisive competitive edge - from form to function and from innovation to realisation. Take the example of Van den Bergh Foods' Chicken Tonight Sizzle and Stir sauces. The challenge was how to keep the spicy sizzle and rich pour over sauces separate. PSD designed a distinctive pack shape, formed by two jars kept in place by an over-all shrink sleeve. Ingenius!

PSD's hierarchical approach to design also gives companies a firm foundation on which to build their branding strategy and conceptual thinking, adding value in new markets or re-positioning established products or services.

Here's another example: as part of its strategy to become a top five global writing instruments company, Caran d'Arche appointed PSD to develop a new corporate identity for its luxury brand and to re-design the Geneva product range. PSD's analysis, helped by a bit of brand "mapping" suggested the need to move toward a classic modern positioning while retaining top Caran d'Ache associations. The resulting definition of Caran d'Ache and its portfolio of sub-brands created a platform to relaunch into the marketplace.

PSD's product design team has also been to work on Swatch which was looking to launch into the telecomms market. Swatch wanted to PSD's help in designing a Swatch cordless phone and packaging.

PSD has also got its feet firmly in the new economy thanks to its new media operations, which have clocked up design work on a number of internet sites including the award winning web site for Flymo, the powered garden equipment manufacturer.

And if all that wasn't enough, PSD designs whole environments - next time you fly across the pond, have a look at Virgin Airline's drive-through check-in facility for its first class passengers.

PSD says it recruits graduates with degrees that are complementary to any of the design disciplines. Send speculative applications to PSD Associates Limited, 18, Petersham Road, Richmond, Surrey, TW 10 6UW.

PSD says it recruits graduates with degrees that are complementary to any of the design disciplines. webTitle: Quit clowning around: show some personality

fields.headline: Quit clowning around: show some personality
fields.standfirst: It's no joke being in a role that doesn't fit you
fields.trailText: It's no joke being in a role that doesn't fit you
fields.body:
When I embarked on my career as a journalist some years ago I realised quite quickly that working a 8-12 hour day in a busy newsroom was not for me. I loathed the office politics, floundered under the pressure of tight deadlines and resented the lack of autonomy. Petrified about the future, I used to sit at my desk and worry about how I would cope with early morning starts and late nights if I had a baby whose crying kept me up half the night.

I resolved to find a solution and concluded that instead of abandoning my dream career I would freelance. Just over two years ago I was forced into this situation when my dad had a stroke and I became his main carer.

Now I work from home and also in an office as a sub-editor for a media company several days a month. I love my current situation because it gives me the autonomy and flexibility I crave and an opportunity to write about subjects I enjoy.

Why am I telling you all this? Because if your dream job has turned into a nightmare like mine did, you mustn't make a hasty decision and quit. The problem could be that you are simply working in the wrong environment.

One way to discover if this is true is to take a personality test such as the Myers-Briggs Type Indicator (MBTI) which will give you an insight into your preferred way of interacting with people as well as your preferred way of working.

The MBTI programme features 16 personality types who widely differ in the way they view the world. Participants must answer 88 questions, each offering a choice of two answers. They include questions like:

Would you rather work for someone who is:

a) Always kind?

b) Always fair?

"There are no right or wrong answers," says Kavita Sharma, an MBTI facilitator and manager of graduate careers consultant C2. "There are some tests where, as you're filling them in, you know what the right answer is. Realising that even though you've chosen answer a), other people have chosen b) and you're both right is very enlightening."

I took the test in the comfort of my own home, then posted my answers to C2. The results revealed that my personality type was Extroverted, Sensing, Thinking and Judging. I'm an ESTJ!

And ESTJ's are "practical with a natural head for business", qualities which can lead to a great career as a sales manager, and administrator. I was pleased with this assessment because you need business skills to survive as a freelancer as well as an ability to sell ideas.

Interestingly, my near polar opposite personality type, INFJ (Introvert, Intuitive, Feeling and Judging) make good writers and editors. But does that mean I'm in the wrong profession?

Reassuringly no, confirms careers consultant Kay Pearson, who is an INFJ. "Knowledge of your type should never stop you from finding a job that appeals to you. "People of all types can find success in all fields. What matters most is finding the best job for you within each field and the working environment that suits you."

The MBTI explains the four personality types as follows. Extroverts tend to focus on the outer world of people and things, while Introverts tend to focus on the inner world of ideas and impressions.

Sensing types are prone to focus on the present and concrete information gained from their senses, while Intuitive types, their polar opposites, enjoy anticipating the future and like to focus on the big picture.

Thinking types are naturally quite analytical, tend to base their decisions on logic and aim to be fair when dealing with people. Feeling types are able to empathise and base their decisions on values and people's feelings.

People who are Judging types dislike working under time pressure, preferring a planned and organised approach to life. Perception types get energised by last minute time pressures and enjoy a flexible and spontaneous approach to life.

The test may reveal that a career change could be your best move but before making that change it is important to understand yourself, something the MBTI programme aims to help you achieve.

"Understanding yourself means that you won't jump out of the frying pan and into the fire," says Kavita, who is an ESTJ. "You will make a more informed decision next time and understand why your current job doesn't fit."

 For more information about MBTI contact your local careers service or C2 on 0207 554 4555

fields.headline: Tip of the week
fields.standfirst: Work that body
fields.trailText: Work that body
fields.body: Didn't get the job? Maybe it was something you said - or maybe it was something you didn't say. "Non-verbal communication - your body language, facial expression, tone of voice, your rate of speech - is 93% of your communication," says career coach Joan Smith. "Employers look for people who are energetic and command power. Sit up straight. Don't cross your arms, put your head down or slump your shoulders. Look relaxed." Eye contact is also extremely important. Self-confidence is a key quality communicated by non-verbal communication. "Look directly at the interviewer," she says. "It shows you're not intimidated and that you're trustworthy."

webTitle: How to... moonlight your way to the top

fields.headline: How to... moonlight your way to the top
fields.standfirst: Are you condemned to a life behind bars?
fields.trailText: Are you condemned to a life behind bars?
fields.body:
What does the word 'moonlighting' mean to you? If you were around in the eighties, it's probably the title of a stylised American TV comedy starring Bruce Willis and Cybill Sheppard. If not - and if you're a recent graduate, it was on way past your bedtime - you'll know it as a rather romantic name for 'doing two paid jobs'.

The word may have lost some of its descriptive power since the invention of electric lighting, but moonlighting is still viewed as a rather shady occupation. Moonlighters are cheats, playing the system for their own financial gain. They're not to be trusted.

But with graduate debts at record levels - an average of over £5,000 at the last estimate - a whole new generation of moonlighters has sprung into being. One job, with a graduate starting salary of around £15,000, may simply not be enough to pay the rent and bills and pay back overdrafts and student loans.

Many people need to supplement their income with evening shifts in a pub or restaurant, a Saturday job in a supermarket, or a bit of tutoring or freelancing on the side.

According to Nick Isles, a spokesman for the Instiute of Personnel and Development, "having more than one job isn't actually illegal. Where people fall foul of the law is if they don't declare their second income". He advises that if you have a second job, you declare your earnings to the Inland Revenue for tax purposes.

It's also a good idea to tell your employer that you're doing work outside your job. Just look at the trouble MPs get into for failing to mention their business interests outside the House. Lawrence Wilson, director of careers and student development at Canterbury Christchurch University College, says you should check your contract before taking on another job:

"Some contracts will specify that you can't enter into another activity without permission and you can't take on work which would be detrimental to your full-time job."

What's considered detrimental may be a matter of subjective interpretation. Your employer might think a second job - however menial - will affect your concentration and performance at work.

And let's face it, how many of us work nine-to-five these days? If you've got to shoot off at 5pm on the dot to go to a second job, you might not be seen to be pulling your weight or fulfilling your contract. You won't be able to join your colleagues in the pub after work and you'll miss out on client functions.

You could scupper your chances of promotion, or worse, find yourself without a main income.

You also need to be wary of work which could cause a conflict of interests: "Let's say you're working for an organisation which has Whitbread as its client," Lawrence suggests. "Your employer might not take too kindly to the fact that you spend your evenings behind the bar of a pub owned by Bass Brewers."

Not all employers frown on moonlighting. When I started my career as a journalist on trade magazines, my editor encouraged me to sell news stories and features to national newspapers - so long as I did it in my lunch hours and after work.

Why? It was good for the profile of the magazine. Sometimes, when you want to change direction or move into a new industry, moonlighting is the only option. Rachel, who is a PA, is desperate to break into the film industry: "I couldn't afford to give up my job, so I decided to use my five weeks annual leave to get experience and make contacts. I've taken courses and worked as a runner, so that when a suitable job comes up, I'll be in a good position to apply."

While he doesn't condone moonlighting per se, Carl Gilleard, chief executive of the Association of Graduate Recruiters, says it can be a useful experience. "We're seeing an increase in the number of portfolio workers," he explains. "Having lots of skills and being able to juggle your workload are important qualities in today's workplace. But if you're going to moonlight, you need good self-discipline, excellent time-management skills and the ability to prioritise."

If you don't remember anything else, remember this...

The government is cracking down on moonlighters and encouraging whistle-blowing. Last week, Chancellor Gordon Brown announced that magistrates will be able to try a new offence of fraudulently evading income tax.

It will also be changing data protection laws so cheats can be caught out via the phone system. Lawrence Wilson says: "Failing to declare a second income is a bit like lying about your qualifications. Don't do it. You'll always be looking over your shoulder."

webTitle: Help:  What have I got myself into?

fields.headline: Help:  What have I got myself into?
fields.trailText: How can you be sure that you'll enjoy working with a prospective employer? Irene Krechowiecka offers tips on testing the water
fields.body:
I seem to have a real talent for picking bad bosses and dreadful companies to work for. How can I find out what I'm letting myself in for before I accept the next job?
Fiona P, investment analyst, Bristol

Just as you concentrate on your strengths and gloss over weaknesses in an interview, so employers make a supreme effort to impress candidates. The more desperate they are for staff the harder they'll try. To discover what they may prefer to hide, you need to ask searching questions.

Decide what's important if you're to make a long term commitment and interrogate them on

policies such as professional development, promotion, overseas assignments,

flexible working or sabbaticals. Check details of staff turnover, find out how long the person they're replacing stayed and why they left. Ask how people who work for them would describe the best and worst aspects of the organisation.

But don't begin the cross examination until confident you've wowed them. Although interviews are a two way process, the balance of power lies with the employer. Reasonable interviewers will appreciate you making the effort to ensure a lasting match. Most companies are keen to get staff that will stay - recruitment is costly and time consuming.

Different occupations attract different types. Enjoying the company of those you share your day with can make the difference between work being a place

you want to go to or somewhere you're desperate to leave. If you can't find

the right environment perhaps you're in the wrong occupation.

 Email Irene Krechowiecka with your comments and questions

webTitle: Moving on up: An ABC guide to navigating organisational charts

fields.headline: Moving on up: An ABC guide to navigating organisational charts
fields.trailText: A three point guide to knowing your place
fields.body:
A. Know your place

Like family trees, organisational charts can explain relationships between the jumble of people that have a significant effect on who you are and what you can do. Diagrammatic representations of a company structure can be sobering. It's one thing to suspect you're unimportant but quite chilling to see it in print. Slightly more depressing than being represented as an

insignificant speck is not seeing yourself at all - a technique used by less than subtle employers to broach the subject of redundancy.

B. Flat landscapes

You can learn a lot about a company from the look of its organisation chart. If it needs to be printed as landscape, it's a flat organisation with few promotion prospects. It might be heartening to know you're just two layers below the chairman, but if those layers are heavy they can squash the life out of you. Charts that look better in portrait format mean a hierarchical organisation. Use them to map your route to the top, or depress yourself with the impossibility of it all.

C. Paper tigers

Apart from putting you in your place, charts show who can legitimately tell you what to do and who's pulling your manager's strings. With any luck they'll provide irrefutable evidence that clerical staff should treat your requests seriously. If you've got a boss who enjoys frightening staff by doodling around with the possibilities, beat him at his own game. Make amendments to his position in the chief exec's handwriting and leave it on the copier.

fields.trailText: American dream: IT graduates and professionals interested in a career in the US should check out the
fields.body:
American dream: IT graduates and professionals interested in a career in the US should check out the

EMDS invitation-only event being held in Boston on May 22-24. You'll have to pay your own travel and accommodation costs, but discount fares are available through a deal EMDS has struck with American Airlines. See

www.emdsnet.com/usa for more info.

Welcome home: Returning male Irish migrants, who are college graduates, earn some 10% more on average than men who graduated at the same time but remained at home, according to new research. For those who left specifically for labour market reasons as opposed to men who emigrated in search of adventure, the wage premium is even higher at 15%.

Sorry...who am I again? Do you keep forgetting meetings and appointments? Could be stress. Researchers at the University of Zurich asked volunteers to memorise a list of 60 nouns. Only the group that was stressed had problems when trying to recall the words the next day.

Oi, you! Log off! You can film me going to the loo, but don't read my email. More workers say it is unethical for employers to monitor their email than it is to watch them with video cameras, according to a US survey by the Society of Financial Services. And just as many workers find voicemail monitoring as unethical as searching desks and lockers.

Pulling in opposite directions: Be careful which team members you choose on adventure training events. Research at the University of Ulm in Germany has concluded that men and women use different parts of the brain when they try to find their way around, suggesting that the strategies they use might also be completely different.

Have a nice day: Women were once kept beneath the glass ceiling because they were 'too nice'. Now they're being held back because they aren't nice enough, says Peter Glick, psychology professor at Lawrence University, Wisconsin. The 'feminisation' of companies may be working against women lacking the soft skills now expected from them.

fields.headline: Top rung/Bottom rung
fields.trailText: Two employees from either end of the career ladder share their experiences of working at Scottish & Newcastle
fields.body:
Jim Stephenson
Aged 51
Head of group review and audit Scottish & Newcastle

Jim Stephenson is proud of the graduate training scheme at Scottish & Newcastle. "We employ a vigorous selection process which sees just two taken on each year from around 150 applicants. We need to bring in the right people and it's a very successful scheme."

CV to date: Trained as an accountant with British Steel, moved to BOC and to S&N in 1979 where he has held senior finance director posts within the group, moving to his current post four years ago.

Stats and facts: Largest UK brewer; owner of Center Parcs & Pontins and more than 2,500 pubs.

"My job is to ensure the continuous improvement of controls and procedures in the group," says Jim. "In addition, I have to cover all the corporate governance requirements, and provide high quality finance staff for the group."

Job buzz? "Trying to add value to the process and bringing in the right people who can contribute to the future of the business."

Must-have qualities: "Graduate trainees in audit must not only be good accountants but also have good inter-personal skills in dealing with board members in group companies. We look for those who can stand on their feet and present information."

Lyndsey Strachan
Aged 23
Chartered accountancy trainee Scottish & Newcastle

Lyndsey Strachan did law and French at Glasgow University, but was keen on a a commercial career . "I didn't know precisely what I wanted to do," she says, " but I was certainly interested in the financial side."

She applied to join the S&N accountancy trainee scheme. "The selection process involved psychometric testing and an assessment day which included a presentation and interviews," she recalls.

Entries to date: She joined the three-year scheme in 1998 and the first 12 months were spent studying accountancy. Over the past year she has been working on various group audits and secondments.

Training is a mix of block release study and homework for accountancy exams - the finals of which Lyndsey sits in June 2001. During this time she is allocated a counsellor - a senior chartered accountant - and her work is subject to regular appraisals.

She believes S&N is a good place for graduates - and the six who are on the scheme at any one time get together regularly during the year.

Next move? "When I qualify there are a variety of options for a financial role within the group."

 For more details visit the website www.scottish-newcastle.com

Training is a mix of block release study and homework for accountancy exams - the finals of which Lyndsey sits in June 2001. During this time she is allocated a counsellor - a senior chartered accountant - and her work is subject to regular appraisals. She believes S&N is a good place for graduates - and the six who are on the scheme at any one time get together regularly during the year. Next move? "When I qualify there are a variety of options for a financial role within the group."  For more details visit the website www.scottish-newcastle.com

webTitle: Hey kid! You're quite a catch

fields.headline: Hey kid! You're quite a catch
fields.standfirst: How is your firm doing in the talent contest?
fields.trailText: How is your firm doing in the talent contest?
fields.body:
How hard is your company working to keep you? Life used to be so uncomplicated for the big graduate recruiters. Because they were big - as the Barclays TV ad would put it - they didn't have to try too hard to attract and retain the cream of the campus crop. Through the eighties and nineties they treated graduates mean to keep them keen. Long hours and uncomfortable shirts were the price to pay for promotion and perks at a later date.

Then, boom! Someone invented the new economy and all of a sudden the blue chips had a war on their hands. A war for talent.

Over the last 24 months or so, it's been dawning on some of the smarter employers that the team with the most talent wins. Unfortunately, there are simply not enough truly talented people to go around. The result: a scramble for talent.

Young workers, and even fresh graduates are looking for the best place for them to express and expand their talent. On the other side of the table, the companies that have tumbled to this new reality are asking themselves, Why would the most talented people coming out of university want to work for us?

A couple of years ago a team from McKinsey & Co conducted a a study involving 77 companies and almost 6,000 managers and executives. The research concluded that the most important corporate resource over the next 20 years would be talent: smart people who are technologically literate, globally astute, and operationally agile. It predicted that the demand for talent would go up, but supply of it would go down.

The cruel irony is that it's the big consulting firms like McKinsey and investment banks such as Goldman Sachs which are bearing the brunt of this change. As a report in last week's Economist magazine explains, many of the larger firms got used to the assumption that they could simply pick from the cream of business-school graduates every year. Now these firms are having to pull out all the stops to persuade any MBAs to choose them. Last year, only 39% of Harvard business school graduate went to investment banks or consultancies, compared with more than half in 1994. Even business schools themselves are struggling in the battle for talent, as a growing number of students are not bothering to complete their studies before leaving to start a dot.com.

The battle for talented young people is jusn't a struggle between new and old economies. Even the 'new blue chips' like Microsoft, Oracle or Excite are finding it harder to stop the exodus of their brightest staff to internet start-ups or smaller, faster growing firms.

The consulting industry, however is the best case study, where the big firms are watching some of their best employees join the internet ventures they were employed to advise, or defect to up-and-coming management consultancies.

These newcomers specialise in e-business, devising and implementing digital strategies, but they are capturing increasing volumes of work. Razorfish - a firm that calls its staff 'fish' - already boasts a client list which includes AT&T, Nokia and CBS. Viant, another of the new firms, can reel off American Express, Charles Schwab and General Motors as its customers.

But the new consultancies, which also include names like Scient, Sapient and Lante, are not only taking clients away from the big firms - they are stealing some of their best people, too.

Why? Partly because they are small and exciting. Razorfish has 1,300 consultants; Andersen Consulting has 53,500. The small firms are also less formal, with little hierarchy. There is no agonising wait to 'make partner' - simply because there are no partners.

Above all, the new consultancies can offer young employees a share of the spoils in the form of stock options. The big firms can offer large salaries and cash bonuses, but not the paper wealth that comes from the sudden rise in the share price of a small start-up.

Some of the more progressive employers are improving their offer. For ideas, companies need only look across the Atlantic where Texas Instruments' concierge team will repair an employee's car, Sun Microsystems provides an in-house laundry, Netscape has its own dentist, and Intuit has a masseur.

Back in the UK, the shortage of talented electronics engineers in the UK has persuaded GEC to appoint 'e-mentors' from within the company to guide talented prospective employees through the course of their university careers.

And as part of Andersen Consulting's declared "War for Talent", it has launched an initiative to reward high-performing staff. Promising to invest around £150 million in e-commerce companies on behalf of the employees, Andersen says the wealth created by these investments will be distributed to staff as 'eUnits'.

Yet maybe the answer to attracting and keeping talented people needn't be so complicated - perhaps they just need some space to live and work.

Research published this week by consultant Ceridian reveals that while 38% of under-30s admit they're not giving of their best at work, 45% say issues outside the office affect their concentration.

"If employers want to compete in the market for young, talented people they must start listening to what they want," says Penny de Valk, Ceridian's managing director.

"Recent surveys, including one by PricewaterhouseCoopers, have repeatedly shown that young workers want flexible working - more control over when and where they work. They also want the freedom to be able to take a couple of months unpaid leave, without it being interepreted as lack of commitment."

She points to Xerox's willingness to tailor a career around triple jumper Tosi Fasinro's plans to compete in the Olympics - Tosi joined Xerox as a graduate four years ago.

Perhaps a better deal for other talented workers is no more than a hop, skip and jump away.

fields.headline: Trading up
fields.trailText: Elizabeth West, senior trader at Chase Manhattan
fields.body:
Name: Elizabeth West

Status: Senior trader at Chase Manhattan Bank

Past: Read economics and commerce with maths at Melbourne University, then worked as a chartered accountant at KPMG and the National Australia Bank, before coming to London.

Present: Elizabeth's role is to "exploit profit-making opportunities trading a range of financial products focusing on emerging market derivatives".

Future: "I anticipate staying in the industry because of the challenge and the dynamic pace of work. Ultimately, I want to be a chief dealer managing other traders."

Strengths: "I have the dedication and resilience to persist and overcome obstacles to achieve my goals. I'm always looking to venture outside my comfort zone."

Weaknesses: "I don't recognise that relaxing doesn't mean embracing the next challenge."

Wisdom: "Hard work is not always enough. You need a real belief in yourself,and a willingness to back that up with action."

References: www.uk.chase.com

fields.headline: The ideal drop scones
fields.trailText: I don't think it's possible to make too many drop scones (or Scotch pancakes as they're also known). I once ate 54 at a sitting. It had to be a sitting: I couldn't stand afterwards. Makes 24 scones
fields.body:
I don't think it's possible to make too many drop scones (or Scotch pancakes as they're also known). I once ate 54 at a sitting. It had to be a sitting: I couldn't stand afterwards. Makes 24 scones.

200g self-raising flour

Pinch of salt

2 eggs

300ml milk

50g butter

Sift the flour and salt into a bowl. Add the eggs and milk, and beat until the mixture is smooth. Melt the butter in a small pan, add that to the batter and beat some more.

Grease a frying pan, then heat until almost smoking. Drop a tablespoonful of the batter into the pan. When holes begin to appear (about two minutes), flip it over and cook for another two minutes or so. Keep re-greasing the pan and griddling the scones until all the batter is used up. Oh, and eat as soon as possible.

webTitle: What's your name? Off message infant quizzes Queen

fields.headline: What's your name? Off message infant quizzes Queen
fields.standfirst: Australia and the monarchy: special report
fields.trailText: Whatever they may think in private, republicans down under have displayed due deference to the Queen in public. But Sol Masters, age three, dispensed with decorum when she toured his school in Western Australia yesterday.
fields.byline: Christopher Zinn  in Canberra and Matt Wells
fields.body:
Whatever they may think in private, republicans down under have displayed due deference to the Queen in public. But Sol Masters, age three, dispensed with decorum when she toured his school in Western Australia yesterday.

After taking a well-aimed hit at a classmate, Sol (second left, above) looked up and demanded of the monarch: "What's your name?"

Sol's target, Jacinta Haywood, four (in centre), was meanwhile in floods of tears. The Queen, though looking a little startled, said nothing as the teacher, Sue Merry, abandoned her royal charge to go and comfort Jacinta as she sobbed: "Sol's just cracked me one".

Sol was the only one at Vasse school in Busselton who had no idea what was expected of him, the others having had a crash course in royal protocol. "He's only been here for two days," said Mrs Merry. "We've been telling the kids about the Queen, but he's missed it all."

As the Queen's 16-day tour drew to a close - she returns to Britain today -she thanked royalists and republicans alike. She told a reception: "Prince Philip and I have been given the warmest of welcomes from everybody, whatever views and aspirations they might have for the future of this country. This has been true of every background, age or walk of life."

Indeed, the visit has been relatively trouble-free. There was the odd rebel flag, but a reception at Canberra's parliament on Monday was full of bowing politicians, who, only weeks before, had been fighting tooth and nail. Both sides claim victory: monarchists believe the Queen has projected a modern image of her constitutional role; republicans argue she herself has made the case for change.

In carefully-worded but direct speeches, the Queen has acknowledged the political climate. Whatever Australians decided, she declared at the tour's start, she would retain a deep and lasting affection: "That is what I have come to say; that is why I am pleased to be back."

fields.headline: A political plaything
fields.standfirst:
No one comes well out of the Elian case

More about the Elian Gonzalez case
fields.trailText: US federal court case 11424-D, Elian Gonzalez v Janet Reno, lies at the heart of a national American disgrace. For four months, Ms Reno, the attorney-general, has been trying to apply some common sense (and established law) to what should have been a straightforward immigrant custody case: that of Elian, the six-year-old whose mother was drowned while they were trying to reach Florida last November and whose father wants him back in Cuba. And for four months, with growing intensity, America's politicians, lawyers, pressure groups and media have conspired with Cuba to turn the process into an ugly, shameful farce.
fields.body:
US federal court case 11424-D, Elian Gonzalez v Janet Reno, lies at the heart of a national American disgrace. For four months, Ms Reno, the attorney-general, has been trying to apply some common sense (and established law) to what should have been a straightforward immigrant custody case: that of Elian, the six-year-old whose mother was drowned while they were trying to reach Florida last November and whose father wants him back in Cuba. And for four months, with growing intensity, America's politicians, lawyers, pressure groups and media have conspired with Cuba to turn the process into an ugly, shameful farce.

Crowds of Cuban-Americans keep a vigil outside the Miami home of Elian's relatives, turning it into a kind of shrine-cum-peepshow. The hapless Elian is paraded for the cameras, cute as can be. George W Bush and Florida's senators trample on statutes to try to win Elian permanent residency. Local judges dependent on Hispanic votes for re-election turn the law on its head. Miami officials warn that Washington will be held to blame, should civil unrest erupt (thereby indirectly encouraging that very thing). While rival attorneys issue suit and counter-suit, administration "insiders" snipe at Ms Reno's handling of the case. Al Gore, with a rather too obvious eye on the presidential election and 800,000 Cuban votes, breaks ranks, calling for an exception to be made. Fidel Castro wades in again, saying the boy's father can, after all, travel to the US to reclaim his son. And all the while, nationwide, the media make of the affair a live, prime time, downmarket soap.

If Americans were seriously re-evaluating immigration policy; if the plight of the unknown thousands of Cubans, Haitians and others who each year risk their lives trying to reach America's shores were under scrutiny; if the confrontational, 41-year-old US attitude towards Cuba, the root cause of this and much other suffering, were being reconsidered, then some good might result. But that is not the case. The debate is narrowly focused and puerile, with Mr Gore, for example, attaching sole blame to "the oppressive regime" in Havana which forced Elian "to choose between freedom and his father". He says he only wants what is "best for the boy". What pusillanimous hypocrisy! A swift, firm decision is what would be best for Elian, and an end to this political exploitation. Let Ms Reno get on with her job.

fields.headline: Cuba's showman plans Elian circus
fields.standfirst:
The veteran propagandist's latest move to embarrass the US may recoil

More about the Elian Gonzalez case
fields.trailText: "One should not abandon propaganda for one moment," Fidel Castro wrote as a jailed revolutionary 46 years ago. "It is the soul of all struggles."
fields.body:
"One should not abandon propaganda for one moment," Fidel Castro wrote as a jailed revolutionary 46 years ago. "It is the soul of all struggles."

Since November the veteran Cuban president has been putting his maxim into practice, with the biggest propaganda exercise Cubans can remember, to demand the return of six-year-old Elian Gonzalez from Miami.

From midday to evening the state television shows a continuous stream of rallies, speeches and round table discussions with experts - all expressing the same point of view and declaring that 11m Cubans support them.

When the dispute started the state printed more than 3m "Save Elian" T-shirts and many more posters. Since January bulldozers have been busy around the clock building a permanent site in front of the US interests section in Havana, called the "park of national dignity", from which to harangue the American diplomats inside.

As the Cuban president has frequently said, even if the US sends Elian back, the Helms- Burton law, the Torricelli law, the Cuban Adjustment Act and many other anti-Cuban laws remain.

Fidel Castro has always been an expert propagandist. After almost being wiped out at the start of his struggle against the Cuban dictator Batista in 1957, his priority was to send for a journalist.

The New York Times veteran Herbert Matthews came to interview him as Fidel's brother, Raul, led their column of only 14 men backwards and forwards. Someone came running in with a message from a fictitious second column. The legend of the revolutionary hero with an army in the mountains was born.

The latest propaganda barrage has principally been aimed at Cuba's youth. A trip to the weekend disco at Lenin park on Havana's outskirts makes it obvious why. All the latest US fashions, along with a smattering of stars and stripes T-shirts, are obtained from relatives in Florida.

What does this generation want? "To emigrate!" comes a collective response from a group of 19-year-olds.

At the last opportunity more than 500,000 Cubans applied for immigrant visas to the US - a sizable chunk of the population. So the youth have been put at the forefront in the "battle for Elian", which some officials are calling the island's "cultural revolution".

Children from four up go on to the stage to sing songs and shout slogans against the imperialists. They denounce how Elian has been kidnapped in a country that is dominated by drugs, violence, school shootings and homelessness.

Now 73, the Cuban leader's traits of obsession and control are becoming more and more pronounced. His speeches are often punctuated with long pauses as he searches through piles of papers for a tiny detail that has escaped his grasp. But few deny that he has been one step ahead of his enemies all along - as demonstrated by his latest proposal for Elian's father to travel to Washington to collect his son.

From the start the president has been under pressure to let Juan Miguel Gonzalez travel to Miami, which US officials say would make it much easier to wrest the boy from his Florida relatives. So now the father has been told he can go - as long as the show can travel with him. Twelve of Elian's classmates, all veteran stars of the Elian rallies, are to be unleashed on the US capital in the middle of an election campaign. They plan to take Elian's desk and set up a classroom in a Cuban diplomatic residence in Washington.

The children would also go sightseeing, the president said. "There are very interesting places in Washington: the Capitol - from a distance of course; the Lincoln memorial."

Cuba has emphasised that the proposal is all or nothing. President Castro wants temporary custody of Elian given to the father while the case goes through the US courts. And the whole entourage must be given US visas.

The only risk is if the father decided to stay in the US. That would be a monumental propaganda disaster. But it is far more likely that Washington will balk at the whole idea. Elian and his 12 classmates going around Washington preaching that the US should lift the embargo and love its smallest neighbour might just be enough to bring 40 years of US policy towards the communist island tumbling down.

fields.headline: E-shopping is a minefield
fields.standfirst: Shopping Unlimited
fields.trailText: We hear and read virtually every day about the joys of e-shopping. But while, for many, this form of armchair shopping has proved a real boost, lawyers - perhaps with reprehensible glee - tend to see it as a potential minefield for consumers.
fields.body:
We hear and read virtually every day about the joys of e-shopping. But while, for many, this form of armchair shopping has proved a real boost, lawyers - perhaps with reprehensible glee - tend to see it as a potential minefield for consumers.

The report by Consumers International last year highlighted many pitfalls of this area. And the European Media Forum has just issued a report urging credit card companies to provide protection for all transactions of more than £25, rather than the £100 currently specified by the Consumer Credit Act 1974.

That legislation gives consumers the same rights against card issuers as they have against the retailer when defective or incorrectly described goods are supplied in breach of contract. It is debatable whether this protection extends to debit cards, like Switch, or charge cards, like American Express.

One very important protection most reputable shopping sites give is an express assurance that money will not be taken from an account until goods are dispatched. A retailer who provides that assurance, but takes the money without dispatching the goods, then has done so without the customer's agreement. As there is not even a contract, there is no obligation to reimburse the card company.

The old chestnut about card details being stolen is still causing a great deal of worry. However many times people are told that they cannot possibly be liable if their card number is used fraudulently, the myth persists that by shopping on the web one runs this risk. But no bank has ever sought to argue that in those circumstances the consumer could be forced to pay up.

When there is a dispute, it is easier to obtain redress if there is a "real world" address or telephone number for the retailer published on the site. If a company refuses to respond to complaining e-mail, the consumer is left powerless. Legal action is not possible if there is no address to which the proceedings can be directed.

Consumers International also highlighted the problems that can arise where consumers use foreign web sites. Most will specify that their own national law should apply. In Europe consumer protection law is becoming increasingly uniform, but accepting American law may substantially reduce the customer's rights.

Whether or not the credit card company remains bound either by British law in this situation or to accept the jurisdiction of the British courts is debatable.

The last thing the credit card industry would want is for their liability to be increased by a reduction in the £100 limit. But with around half of internet transactions being for less than that sum, the European Media Forum identified an important gap in consumer protection.

A reduction in that limit, coupled with the setting up of a simple and binding online arbitration service, would be a spur to the growth of web shopping, from which the banks will unashamedly be taking a healthy and profitable cut through credit card fees.

 Richard Colbey is a barrister

fields.headline: Teachers fight rule to encourage 'snooping'
fields.standfirst: Education Unlimited
fields.trailText: Doug McAvoy, leader of the largest teaching union, yesterday threatened strike action against a government regulation that he said would force teachers to become "informers", passing evidence about their colleagues to managers and external assessors.
fields.body:
Doug McAvoy, leader of the largest teaching union, yesterday threatened strike action against a government regulation that he said would force teachers to become "informers", passing evidence about their colleagues to managers and external assessors.

Mr McAvoy, general secretary of the National Union of Teachers, applied to the high court for judicial review of a government order that comes into effect today to implement plans for performance-related pay.

David Blunkett, the education and employment secretary, introduced the new rules to allow headteachers to assess staff to establish who should qualify for a higher salary scale, with an immediate cash bonus of £2,000.

But Mr McAvoy said the order gave heads the power to tell teachers to snoop on other members of staff. "Teachers will find it offensive that they should be asked to inform on a colleague ... This is the most deceitful act against teachers sought by a government for at least 30 years.

"Nothing as devious, deceitful and manipulative as this was ever done by the Tories. This government has sunk to new lows in the staff rooms," he said.

The union's legal action will centre on an allegation that the regulation is based on the wrong statute. Ministers used a 1991 act about teachers' pay and conditions of service instead of legislation in 1986 covering appraisal of teachers.

Mr McAvoy said the government failed to consult teachers about the change, as it should have done under the 1991 act.

He accused ministers of rushing the procedure through to avoid embarrassment in the Welsh assembly where there is a majority against assessing teachers against their pupils' test and exam results. Decisions under the 1986 act would have been devolved to the assembly, but regulations under the 1991 law could be imposed from Westminster. "They know the Welsh assembly won't like it and they want to deny them the chance to vote on it," Mr McAvoy said.

The union hopes the courts will decide the matter before its annual conference in Harrogate over Easter. "If this fails, we will take strike action in schools, subject to the necessary balloting, to protect teachers from being asked to inform on each other," the general secretary said.

When teachers were refused a performance bonus they would not know whether to blame the external assessor or the colleague who might have said something bad about their performance.

"It's a form of snooping ... It will destroy professional teamwork. Teachers will be constantly suspicious of each other," he said.

A senior education department source said the union was indulging in a mistaken conspiracy theory. "We used the most recent legislation to set up a system for line managers to provide an assessment about teachers under their command.

"It would be bizarre if heads did not take the the views of line managers into account when assessing whether teachers should get a £2,000 pay rise."

He said the government never intended to ask rank and file teachers to "snoop" on their colleagues. The assessments would be made by department heads.

"This is not about colleagues assessing each other. It is about heads of department giving their views as part of the process of saying whether staff should get the pay increase."

 Estelle Morris, the school standards minister, said children should be entitled to after-school facilities, including sports, arts, computer and homework clubs. A report by the Schools Plus policy team on improving educational chances in disadvantaged areas said pupils should have at least three hours of out of school hours activities a week.
