fields.headline: Longbridge - the inside story
fields.standfirst:
As the West Midlands prepares for Britain's biggest industrial protest in years, angry and demoralised staff talk of their despair and fears for the future
Rover in crisis: special report
fields.trailText: As the West Midlands prepares for Britain's biggest industrial protest in years, angry and demoralised staff talk of their despair and fears for the future.
fields.body:
For Rover, and British manufacturing as a whole, the innovation was state-of-the-art. Screens cut off a section of the canteen at Longbridge this week, and behind them officials from the government's employment service were setting up the car industry's first in-house job centre.

It was not an instant success. Sullen workers at the canteen's formica-top tables munched away with their backs to the unwelcome intruder, trying to pretend that this well-meant gesture of help and the little white index cards of job vacancies stuck on to boards were not really there.

"We've had a few inquiries but people are mainly asking 'what if?' questions. They're still waiting for the uncertainty to be resolved," said Jon Dews, an employment adviser.

In the forecourt outside, a worker in grey overalls passed a group of managers standing on the front steps. "Heard anything yet?" he called out without waiting for an answer. In this brutal disaster, where decisions are taken in global boardrooms far away, local executives are as out of touch as everyone else.

The first shock of BMW's decision to sell Rover to the venture capitalists Alchemy has faded, but anger and a powerful sense of betrayal hang over the plant. There is also fear. The word has gone out from BMW to restrict press access to the site, and workers have been warned not to speak to reporters. So everyone insists you disguise their name and job description for fear that their redundancy terms might be affected.

The only exceptions are full-time union officials. "I don't think anyone here wants to work in the car industry again," snaps Adrian Ross, a shop steward for the Transport and General Workers' Union. "Rover was two years away from being a very profitable business. On that basis you would tell youngsters to work here, but not now."

A man from Rover's public relations team hurries over like a prison officer and urges me out. Visiting time is up. I am only in the building because Tessa Jowell, the employment minister, is talking to staff upstairs.

Trapped

To add to their anger, workers are furious that on the same day it announced it was selling Rover BMW stopped its voluntary redundancy scheme. When BMW slimmed the workforce two years ago, it offered packages that were considered generous. "Now people are trapped here like prisoners," Kumar, who works as a process engineer, tells me later. "If they try to find a new job today and give notice, they will lose their redundancy. If they stay on, there's no guarantee they will get any more than the minimum one week for every year of service."

Neither BMW nor Alchemy has made it clear who is responsible for redundancy and what they will pay. Long-serving workers are afraid they may be taken on by Alchemy and a year later be sacked and told they qualify for only one year's compensation.

Kumar, 41, is one of many British Asians at Longbridge. After 14 years in the plant, he has imbibed local pride as much as anyone else. "This is the birthplace of the Mini. The Rover marque is our heritage. This is what hurts people," he says.

"Only five weeks ago we were looking at an exhibition of new models and their future plans. They invited us to bring the wife and children to see it. Then they do this. The government should intervene. It's unacceptable, this mass redundancy. It's an utter mightmare. We all thought the plant was secure."

Longbridge is a deceptive place. It was built as a greenfield site, but the suburbs of south Birmingham now lap close to its sprawling red-brick buildings. This is no dark satanic mill; it looks more like an affluent technical college with its hundreds of cars parked on every inch of pavement around the factory. Workers drive in from all over the West Midlands.

Today thousands of them will take part in Britain's biggest industrial march for at least a decade. Backed by several local MPs and church leaders it will rumble through the streets of Birmingham, culminating in a rally in Cannon Hill Park, not far from the Edgbaston cricket ground. It is not only many of the 10,000 Rover workers and their families who will turn out, but hundreds of others in the supply chain. Up to 50,000 other jobs could go if Rover were to close completely.

The unions expect workers from apparently successful car plants such as Jaguar and Peugeot to take part, since the Rover crisis has shown that under the pressures of globalisation car companies across the world are merging production and cutting staff.

They are even hoping for support from the IG Metall trade union in Germany, as German workers realise that they are in an international struggle. Contrary to the stereotypes portrayed by newspapers such as the Sun, anti-German feeling at Longbridge is remarkably low. Workers blame BMW, not Germany as a whole, and take heart from the fact that influential news magazines such as Der Spiegel and much of the German press reporting of the crisis have focused on BMW's mismanagement and its loss of image.

Suspicious

Mike, an assembly line worker, says: "Saturday's march is not a rebellious thing. In the 1970s they would have walked out and put pickets round the factory. Here we're still building cars. Considering the severity of the circumstances, it's been very quiet, almost unnervingly so."

Albert Bore, leader of Birmingham city council, who will be on today's march, complains: "Longbridge has been cut off without having a chance to prove itself. The view round here is that the sales of the Rover 75 were artificially depressed when BMW announced on the launch day that Rover was facing losses. They almost set in train a strategy to undermine the 75."

His opinion is widely shared. "They decided to finish production of the Metro before starting to make its replacement, the new Mini. That left a gap in the market of up to three years. Why didn't they wait?" says Tim Parker, regional organiser for the MSF union. "At the time we put it down to incompetence. Now we're suspicious."

He believes BMW's secret purpose in buying Rover six years ago was to give itself "critical mass" by getting a high-volume production line in addition to its own top-of-the range cars. "It wanted to stop itself being eaten by a predator because the word was that in five years there would only be a few car companies left in the world: GM, Ford, one in the far east and one or two in Europe. They picked it up and ran off with it but now they've smashed it to the ground. It's an act of pure vandalism."

For many workers it is the waste that seems so unfathomable. Sleek new models stand in the Longbridge yard, apparently facing being scrapped. Giant transporters, stacked high with precision-made vehicles, lumber through the gates and head for dealerships that have suddenly become ashamed of the brand.

Colin and Mike, two 20-year-olds in the final months of a five-year apprenticeship at Rover, are bitter. It was partly the romanticism of the production process that attracted them.

"I found it amazing. You've got a bare shell at one end and a finished car at the other. I felt proud of it," says Colin. "But on Friday it was like a morgue. Some halls have been closed. They were just empty. It was so quiet with no engines running, no music, no banter, no shouting."

Now they are waiting as anxiously as everyone else. "We want to stay and finish our qualifications in August, but we don't know if they'll sack us. We may be seen as long-term assets, or told to go because we lack experience," says Mike.

Sympathetic and fast-talking, Ms Jowell sits in a small conference room in the management wing at Longbridge explaining the government's plans for early action to help people faced with redundancy. She is anxious to show that the government cares, after all the charges that it ignored the warning signs before BMW's announcement. No doubt she is also aware that 23 of the 27 Westminster seats within a 15-mile radius of Longbridge are held by Labour.

A group of senior Rover staff have just told her they are as much out of the loop as the workers. Now it is the shop stewards' turn. Amazingly, Ms Jowell had not scheduled a meeting with the trade unions, but when a newspaper reporter queried the omission she hastily asked the works' convenors to come up.

It soon becomes clear that the two sides have different priorities. The minister reports that the government has allocated £10m to strengthen the employment service so that officials can devote more time to Rover workers facing redundancy. She mentions the advance party in the canteen downstairs, who can give advice on retraining, benefits, and cash-flow problems for people on mortgages.

"I'm going to be honest," says Alwyn Thomas of the engineering union, the AEEU, bluntly sidestepping the offer. "The only way forward is to keep this plant open. We've got no alternative but to fight for this place. I've been here 37 years and it's never been so bad." He asks why the government does not consider helping a rival bid for Rover led by John Hemming, a local millionaire.

"These are commercial decisions. Our job is to see the infrastructure is there," Ms Jowell tells him before setting off to meet the taskforce set up by the Department of Trade and Industry. It will estimate job losses, produce plans for keeping skilled workers in the industry, and develop ideas for new uses for Longbridge site.

Union officials say these measures are only useful as Plan B. Plan A must be to save Longbridge as a car factory. The government has offered £129m to cover some of the costs of the crisis. BMW is offering Alchemy 1bn marks (£330m) to take over the plant. Union officials wonder why this could not be added together to offer to an alternative bidder who could keep the plant open as a high-volume producer rather than the niche market Alchemy is planning. They claim most of Rover's deficit is due to German accounting rules that require new investments to be depreciated in the first five years rather than, as in Britain, spread out over a longer period.

"The government should do some strategic thinking," argues Tim Parker of the MSF. "If it's going to cast £500m in jobseekers' allowances and other benefits, why not say we'll join you in helping save this company? Let's not talk about nationalisation - that's dead and buried -but what's wrong with private-public partnership?"

At the city council and the chamber of commerce, which have been working hard to develop the West Midlands' im age, the closure of Rover is seen as a fearful blow. The region had managed to climb out of the recession of the mid-1980s by lessening its dependence on car manufacture. It has built up a successful financial services sector thanks to the attraction of huge infrastructure projects, from the National Exhibition Centre on the edge of the city to the Convention Centre and National Indoor Arena down-town. "In the first half of the 80s we lost more jobs than in the whole of Scotland and Wales," says Mr Bore. "Losing Longbridge, if that is what happens, will be a shock to the West Midlands but we are in a better position to overcome it now."

Even before the Rover crisis, employers were finding it hard to attract school-leavers into engineering. Studies have shown that parents' views are the main factor behind young people's career choices, and after the unemployment crisis of the 1980s engineering got a bad name. It had a poor image of dirty jobs, low pay, bad conditions and uncertainty. At university level an increasing number of students insured themselves by combining engineering courses with business studies or marketing. That trend is likely to accelerate. In all the gloom, one voice stands out for its defiance of the conventional wisdom. Geoff Edge was one of Labour's youngest MPs until he lost his seat in 1979. Now he heads West Midlands Enterprise, an investment consultancy.

Although he criticises BMW's over-confidence in taking over a company it could not run and for its "pathetic and dishonest exit", he says the West Midlands' self-image is wrong. "People don't seem to understand that while employment is falling in manufacturing, output is up. The notion that manufacturing is dead is nonsense," he says as he produces the latest forecasts from Cambridge Econometrics.

They show that while jobs in the motor vehicles sector in the West Midlands declined from 110,000 in 1980 to 61,000 last year, gross value added nearly doubled in the same period (in inflation-adjusted terms) from £1.4bn to £2.7bn. By 2010 it was expected to go up to £4.1bn. "We have one of the strongest motor industries in Europe. It's all based on inward investment from abroad," he says.

Mr Edge also debunks the new enthusiasm for the service sector, at least as a generator of stimulating jobs. Online shopping, telephone banking, and all the other forms of e-commerce are bound to grow but the work they involve is dull key-board tapping, which itself will increasingly be mechanised, he argues.

Flexible

The labour-intensive sectors with interesting potential are education and health. Manufacturing will still offer jobs, but for a limited number of highly skilled, highly flexible people doing consumer-aided design and production engineering. "World best practice in manufacturing is to use human beings as human beings, with small teams producing sophisticated components and intelligent people being used in an intelligent way," he says.

His idealistic vision seems a far cry from BMW's failure to inform Rover's workers or management what was coming. A year ago the European commission drafted a directive that would require companies with at least 50 employees to inform and consult their staff on business and employment issues.

It is hardly revolutionary stuff, with its get-out clauses on commercial confidentiality, its exclusion of public sector workers and its non-mention of trade unions. Employee representatives are described as "social partners".

The British government has been one of the fiercest opponents of the directive. Ms Jowell was visibly shocked this week by the level of uncertainty crippling managers and workers at Longbridge as they ask each other "Heard anything yet?" So I asked her at the end of her trip if she now favoured the EU draft directive.

"Well, that's an issue that the DTI is leading with," she said. "It's not really appropriate for me as employment minister to comment on that, beyond saying that of course consultation is important and all the evidence from successful British companies is that they realise the benefits of involving the workforce, consulting with the workforce, keeping the workforce well-informed and the demotivating impact of that not happening. What we don't want is to impose a regulatory burden on business that becomes a constraint on its competitiveness."

Cold comfort there for Kumar, Adrian, and the apprentices who still hope for a future in industry. Since the regulations on prior consultation would apply to every business in Europe, how does that affect competition?

She is anxious to show that the government cares, after all the charges that it ignored the warning signs before BMW's announcement. No doubt she is also aware that 23 of the 27 Westminster seats within a 15-mile radius of Longbridge are held by Labour. A group of senior Rover staff have just told her they are as much out of the loop as the workers. Now it is the shop stewards' turn. Amazingly, Ms Jowell had not scheduled a meeting with the trade unions, but when a newspaper reporter queried the omission she hastily asked the works' convenors to come up. It soon becomes clear that the two sides have different priorities. The minister reports that the government has allocated £10m to strengthen the employment service so that officials can devote more time to Rover workers facing redundancy. She mentions the advance party in the canteen downstairs, who can give advice on retraining, benefits, and cash-flow problems for people on mortgages. "I'm going to be honest," says Alwyn Thomas of the engineering union, the AEEU, bluntly sidestepping the offer. "The only way forward is to keep this plant open. We've got no alternative but to fight for this place. I've been here 37 years and it's never been so bad." He asks why the government does not consider helping a rival bid for Rover led by John Hemming, a local millionaire. "These are commercial decisions. Our job is to see the infrastructure is there," Ms Jowell tells him before setting off to meet the taskforce set up by the Department of Trade and Industry. It will estimate job losses, produce plans for keeping skilled workers in the industry, and develop ideas for new uses for Longbridge site. Union officials say these measures are only useful as Plan B. Plan A must be to save Longbridge as a car factory. The government has offered £129m to cover some of the costs of the crisis. BMW is offering Alchemy 1bn marks (£330m) to take over the plant. Union officials wonder why this could not be added together to offer to an alternative bidder who could keep the plant open as a high-volume producer rather than the niche market Alchemy is planning. They claim most of Rover's deficit is due to German accounting rules that require new investments to be depreciated in the first five years rather than, as in Britain, spread out over a longer period. "The government should do some strategic thinking," argues Tim Parker of the MSF. "If it's going to cast £500m in jobseekers' allowances and other benefits, why not say we'll join you in helping save this company? Let's not talk about nationalisation - that's dead and buried -but what's wrong with private-public partnership?" At the city council and the chamber of commerce, which have been working hard to develop the West Midlands' im age, the closure of Rover is seen as a fearful blow. The region had managed to climb out of the recession of the mid-1980s by lessening its dependence on car manufacture. It has built up a successful financial services sector thanks to the attraction of huge infrastructure projects, from the National Exhibition Centre on the edge of the city to the Convention Centre and National Indoor Arena down-town. "In the first half of the 80s we lost more jobs than in the whole of Scotland and Wales," says Mr Bore. "Losing Longbridge, if that is what happens, will be a shock to the West Midlands but we are in a better position to overcome it now." Even before the Rover crisis, employers were finding it hard to attract school-leavers into engineering. Studies have shown that parents' views are the main factor behind young people's career choices, and after the unemployment crisis of the 1980s engineering got a bad name. It had a poor image of dirty jobs, low pay, bad conditions and uncertainty. At university level an increasing number of students insured themselves by combining engineering courses with business studies or marketing. That trend is likely to accelerate. In all the gloom, one voice stands out for its defiance of the conventional wisdom. Geoff Edge was one of Labour's youngest MPs until he lost his seat in 1979. Now he heads West Midlands Enterprise, an investment consultancy. Although he criticises BMW's over-confidence in taking over a company it could not run and for its "pathetic and dishonest exit", he says the West Midlands' self-image is wrong. "People don't seem to understand that while employment is falling in manufacturing, output is up. The notion that manufacturing is dead is nonsense," he says as he produces the latest forecasts from Cambridge Econometrics. They show that while jobs in the motor vehicles sector in the West Midlands declined from 110,000 in 1980 to 61,000 last year, gross value added nearly doubled in the same period (in inflation-adjusted terms) from £1.4bn to £2.7bn. By 2010 it was expected to go up to £4.1bn. "We have one of the strongest motor industries in Europe. It's all based on inward investment from abroad," he says. Mr Edge also debunks the new enthusiasm for the service sector, at least as a generator of stimulating jobs. Online shopping, telephone banking, and all the other forms of e-commerce are bound to grow but the work they involve is dull key-board tapping, which itself will increasingly be mechanised, he argues. Flexible The labour-intensive sectors with interesting potential are education and health. Manufacturing will still offer jobs, but for a limited number of highly skilled, highly flexible people doing consumer-aided design and production engineering. "World best practice in manufacturing is to use human beings as human beings, with small teams producing sophisticated components and intelligent people being used in an intelligent way," he says. His idealistic vision seems a far cry from BMW's failure to inform Rover's workers or management what was coming. A year ago the European commission drafted a directive that would require companies with at least 50 employees to inform and consult their staff on business and employment issues. It is hardly revolutionary stuff, with its get-out clauses on commercial confidentiality, its exclusion of public sector workers and its non-mention of trade unions. Employee representatives are described as "social partners". The British government has been one of the fiercest opponents of the directive. Ms Jowell was visibly shocked this week by the level of uncertainty crippling managers and workers at Longbridge as they ask each other "Heard anything yet?" So I asked her at the end of her trip if she now favoured the EU draft directive. "Well, that's an issue that the DTI is leading with," she said. "It's not really appropriate for me as employment minister to comment on that, beyond saying that of course consultation is important and all the evidence from successful British companies is that they realise the benefits of involving the workforce, consulting with the workforce, keeping the workforce well-informed and the demotivating impact of that not happening. What we don't want is to impose a regulatory burden on business that becomes a constraint on its competitiveness." Cold comfort there for Kumar, Adrian, and the apprentices who still hope for a future in industry. Since the regulations on prior consultation would apply to every business in Europe, how does that affect competition?

webTitle: Nuclear flasks fail safety test in new blow for BNFL

fields.headline: Nuclear flasks fail safety test in new blow for BNFL
fields.standfirst: Britain's nuclear industry: special report
fields.trailText: Flasks used by British Nuclear Fuels to transport dangerous radioactive material can resist fire for less than three minutes, newly released research reveals.
fields.body:
Flasks used by British Nuclear Fuels to transport dangerous radioactive material can resist fire for less than three minutes, newly released research reveals.

The revelation will provide fresh headaches for the crisis-ridden BNFL, which runs a major business using the flasks. New safety regulations demanded by the United Nations mean that all the flasks will now have to be replaced.

The tests by France's nuclear safety agency showed that the flasks would rupture within 175 seconds in a fire.

The flasks are used to transport 20,000 tonnes of uranium hexafluoride or "hex" - the raw material to make fuel for nuclear power stations - around the world every year, much of it for BNFL. Hex is particularly dangerous because as well as being radioactive it reacts with air to produce hydrofluoric acid, a gas which destroys the lungs.

Using the suspect flasks BNFL exports hex to Russia, US and Europe from its Springfields fuel fabrication plant in Preston. Internationally, the nuclear industry makes 2,300 shipments of hex every year by road, rail and sea.

The study was by the Institut de Protection et de Sreté Nucléaire (IPSN) in Paris, which advises the French government on nuclear safety. IPSN scientists led by Gilles Sert baked flasks in an oven and ran computer simulations to see if the hex container most widely used, a type 48Y, would survive the kind of fire that could erupt after an accident.

"Rupture of the 48Y container in a fire seems likely and its resistance to fire should be improved to guarantee safety," they said.

Their study is published in the latest issue of the International Journal of Radioactive Materials Transport. From next year hex flasks will be required by the UN International Atomic Energy Agency to resist fire for 30 minutes at 800C. IPSN's experiments suggest current flasks would explode after 175 seconds "in the most favourable case".

But defects found by x-raying welds on the flasks, of which there are 100,000 worldwide, mean that the explosion could come even sooner. "Large quantities of uranium hexafluoride might be released in a transport accident involving a fire," the scientists said.

The IPSN study was launched in the wake of the sinking of the French cargo ship, Mont Louis, on August 25 1984 after a collision with a ferry in the English Channel. It went down off Ostend, Belgium, with 350 tonnes of hex destined for Russia on board. There was considerable alarm about the danger and all of it was salvaged from the seabed.

There have been several other accidents involving hex, including a train derailment in the US and a seven-tonne leak from a French nuclear facility at Pierrelatte, both in 1977.

Edwin Lyman, scientific director of the Nuclear Control Institute in Washington, said: "This [report] raises disturbing questions about the credibility of industry safety assurances, not only for hex flasks but for all the radioactive material transport flasks in service today."

BNFL confirmed yesterday that it used 48Y containers for shipping hex in Britain and abroad. It was transported from Springfields to Capenhurst near Chester for enrichment, as well as to enrichment plants in Russia, the US, France, Germany and Holland.

"Under the new proposed transport regulations there are some additional requirements, one of which is the fire test," said a BNFL spokesman.

"The industry has done extensive research on the cylinders and there is no conclusive evidence that the current mode of shipping natural hex will not meet the new regulations."

Although there had been thousands of shipments of hex, there had never been an incident involving a release of hex nor any danger to the public, he said.

"BNFL will continue to transport to a high standard in line with the regulations for the safe transport of radioactive material."

BNFL has been under attack from the Nuclear Installation Inspectorate over its safety regime and from its major customers for falsifying quality control data on plutonium fuel. This week the government postponed part-privatisation of the company and demanded management improvements.

fields.headline: 30,000 Rovers going cheap
fields.standfirst:
Rover in crisis: special report

E-finance: special report
fields.trailText: BMW is cutting the price of Rover's main models in an attempt to shift the 30,000 unsold vehicles parked in storage areas beside the Longbridge and Cowley plants.
fields.body:
BMW is cutting the price of Rover's main models in an attempt to shift the 30,000 unsold vehicles parked in storage areas beside the Longbridge and Cowley plants.

It is offering cashbacks between £1,000 and £2,000 on its 25, 45 and 75 models together with three years' free servicing.

A company spokesman said the deal, which will run throughout April, was aimed at reassuring customers during the period of uncertainty about the British car company's ownership.

BMW is expecting to complete the sale of the bulk of Rover to Alchemy Partners, the London venture capitalists headed by Jon Moulton, within the next six weeks. On Wednesday, Mr Moulton told a Commons select committee that there would not be a "bargain sale" of Rover cars because it would ruin the brand.

BMW will bear the cost of the price cuts. Rover's German chief executive, Werner Saemann, told the same committee that BMW was losing £2,000 on every Rover sold in the UK.

Under the new package, buyers will get a £1,000 cashback on a Rover 25 costing between £9,395 and £15,495, £1,500 on a Rover 45 costing between £11,995 and £18,995, and £2,000 on a Rover 75 costing between £18,280 and £27,875.

A new advertising campaign is due to start today, when thousands of Rover workers and sympathisers are due to take part in a march in Birm ingham to protest against BMW's planned dismemberment of the company.

Stephen Byers, the trade and industry secretary who has been blamed for not realising that BMW was planning to abandon Rover, is fighting to save his political reputation. He has promised to publish further details of meetings and phone calls between himself, his departmental officials, and executives of the German company.

Downing Street sought to play down the war of words between Mr Byers and BMW, which flared up again on Thursday over whether BMW managers had told the minister that the whole Longbridge plant was in danger or whether it was just the plan to build a new small car which was at risk.

fields.headline: Britain unveils plan to evacuate
fields.standfirst: The British government has a three-point contingency plan in place should relations in Zimbabwe deteriorate to the point that British nationals are threatened. Ewen MacAskill reports Zimbabwe: special report
fields.trailText: The final stage would be an emergency airlift of all those holding British passports, similar to the one organised to evacuate British nationals from Sierre Leone in 1998. But the foreign office was yesterday playing down the likelihood of such drastic action having to be taken.
fields.body:
The final stage would be an emergency airlift of all those holding British passports, similar to the one organised to evacuate British nationals from Sierre Leone in 1998. But the foreign office was yesterday playing down the likelihood of such drastic action having to be taken.

The Foreign Office minister, Peter Hain, last week raised the prospect of evacuation after protesting about president Robert Mugabe's endorsement of the forced occupation of white-owned farms.

A foreign office source said yesterday: "There is a civil contingency plan meant to cover many eventualities."

The first step would be for the Foreign Office to warn against travel to Zimbabwe, and the second would be to advise British nationals to leave the country using commercial transport.

The third step would involve an emergency airlift.

The Foreign Office emphasised that the numbers involved would be a lot less than the 20,000 people who hold British passports in the country.

The bulk have dual passports and, under international law, are the responsibility of the Zimbabwean, rather than the British, government.

"But we would not turn our backs on them," a Foreign Office source said.

Most of the 20,000 British nationals residing in Zimbabwe live in urban rather than rural areas and are not involved in the land crisis.

webTitle: Panic shows as Mugabe vents spleen on Britain

fields.headline: Panic shows as Mugabe vents spleen on Britain
fields.standfirst: Zimbabwe: special report
fields.trailText: On a remote farmstead 50 miles outside the southern town of Bulawayo, President Robert Mugabe set the tone yesterday for what looks like being a eccentric and rather desperate election campaign.
fields.body:
On a remote farmstead 50 miles outside the southern town of Bulawayo, President Robert Mugabe set the tone yesterday for what looks like being a eccentric and rather desperate election campaign.

Zimbabwe's leader launched a 45-minute assault on the government of Britain, a country of which much of his audience seemed only dimly aware.

Asked later if he was declaring war on Britain - which is increasingly critical of Harare's record on human rights, corruption, and the current campaign to disrupt white-owned farms - he said: "They have declared war on us."

Mr Mugabe hinted that the harassment being directed at white farmers could expand to British-owned industry. He drew cheers from veterans of the 1970s guerrilla war against white rule who had taken time out from their occupations of the white farms to come and listen. But most of the 1,200-strong crowd did not applaud.

The president made no attempt to lower the temperature surrounding the occupations. "Keep it as peaceful as you can," he told the veterans. "But this does not mean when you are attacked you must not hit back."

Britain, he said, was threatening Zimbabwe with sanctions, was keen to foment fighting in rural areas and was carrying on as if it were still the colonial power. And he could not resist his favourite subject.

"There is no rationality, logic or even morality from a government of this nature. But of course we know that the government has a lot of psychiatric cases, a lot of homosexuals, men who want to be women. Everything appears to be the opposite in Britain."

Zimbabwe, he went on, "cannot continue to exist as though we were an extension of the British empire, we get our instructions not from London, not from Downing Street, but from our people."

Sanctions, he claimed, would hurt Britain more than Zimbabwe. "Every month we remit $10m to Britain. Our economy is servicing the British economy. Our only grievance now is over land but if they raise this issue, we can sanction them better than they can sanction us."

The speech was another sign of the panic apparently afflicting the Harare government, with the economy in crisis and yet another devaluation of the Zimbabwean dollar imminent. Parliamentary elections are expected in May or June and there is increasing speculation that the opposition Movement for Democratic Change - a black front for white interests, according to Mr Mugabe - can get close to victory. Though the president is in office until 2002, his position could become untenable.

This rally was in Matabeleland, a place harbouring long-standing bitterness towards the regime. The president's speech had to be translated from English into Ndebele.

Many of the Mugabe allegations and threats will be familiar to Mr Blair but the sustained nature of the assault, and the setting, came as a shock. Officially, the occasion was to open a new and uncontroversial resettlement scheme at Dromoland Farm, a 60,000-acre ranch formerly owned by Lonrho and now to be shared by 200 families, it was said.

The handful of white farmers at the rally were relieved that the attack on Labour - not a party to which they owe much allegiance - took the heat off them. But despite all the rhetoric, the atmosphere was entirely amiable.

It was also engagingly shambolic. President Mugabe, now 76, slumped lower and lower in his chair through three hours of tribal dancing and warm up speeches. As his vice-president finally wound up, the rain started pelting down with rumbles of thunder and the crowd rushed for cover. There was a delay before the president began his speech.

As the rain eased off, the speech soon became too powerful to ignore, but it will be scrutinised more carefully in London than in Dromoland. "It's just electioneering," shrugged one of the whites.

webTitle: Internet bank launches first personal ATM

fields.headline: Internet bank launches first personal ATM
fields.trailText: An internet bank is promising to make overcharging at high-street cash machines a thing of the past when it launches the world's first personal ATM onto the UK market at the start of next month.
fields.body:
An internet bank is promising to make overcharging at high-street cash machines a thing of the past when it launches the world's first personal ATM onto the UK market at the start of next month.

Using tracking technology developed by Soviet scientists at the end of the cold war, Yourbackpocket.com says it can install a cash dispenser in the space beneath a CD-rom or DVD drive on a desktop PC for under £250 at cost.

As part of a profile-raising exercise before its planned Techmark flotation, the Easdaq-listed company has announced plans to offer the personal ATM free to customers with over £2,500 in their current account in a bid to catch the cash-rich, time-poor market sought eagerly by the entrepreneurs of the new economy.

Chief executive Chris Taylor, a former management consultant with a paper fortune estimated at over £13m, insists that the bank can succeed if it secures an early place in the market.

"We've got the staff, we've got the technology, now we've got to give the product the push it needs. But it's not sink or swim - we've got powerful backers, so I see no reason why we can't be the Amazon.com of the desk-top cash dispenser," he says.

A satellite tracking system will notify the bank if one of its personal cash machines is moved out of a designated five-metre zone. And as a final precaution against theft, a security device is primed to incinerate the cash if anyone attempts to open the dispenser without the correct authorisation codes.

The entrepeneur responds to accusations that the company is literally burning money by pointing out that many dot.coms write five-year losses into their business plans. He says few hope to ever make the profits suggested by their stock-market value.

In addition, the bank has taken out corporate insurance against theft and fire, and expects to make enough revenue from a range of personal finance partnerships and onsite advertising to cover their losses.

But the promise of a life free from cash-machine charges will no doubt be Yourbackpocket.com's greatest asset. A report last week into UK banking revealed that customers were being overcharged by up to £5bn a year. The inquiry team, headed by former telecommunications regulator Don Cruickshank, called for a radical shake up of the sector.

"Other banks want to get your money, cream off a handsome profit for themselves and then charge you to get your hands on your money. We don't do that. We just want to put it in Yourbackpocket.com," Mr Taylor remarked.

The UK online banking sector has to date been hampered by high-street cash-machine charges. Few internet banks have a physical presence, and their customers are forced to pay up to £1.50 per transaction when they withdraw money from the Link network.

A report last week into UK banking revealed that customers were being overcharged by up to £5bn a year. "Other banks want to get your money, cream off a handsome profit for themselves and then charge you to get your hands on your money. We don't do that. We just want to put it in Yourbackpocket.com," Mr Taylor remarked. The UK online banking sector has to date been hampered by high-street cash-machine charges. Few internet banks have a physical presence, and their customers are forced to pay up to £1.50 per transaction when they withdraw money from the Link network. webTitle: WTO entry for China put on ice

fields.headline: WTO entry for China put on ice
fields.standfirst:
EU insists on tougher concessions from Beijing
World Trade Organisation: special report
fields.trailText: China's hopes of entering the World Trade Organisation later this year suffered a blow yesterday when talks with the European Union over the terms of its accession collapsed without agreement.
fields.body:
China's hopes of entering the World Trade Organisation later this year suffered a blow yesterday when talks with the European Union over the terms of its accession collapsed without agreement.

After four days of negotiations, the European trade commissioner Pascal Lamy left Beijing last night declaring that an agreement was not possible at this time. No date was given for the resumption of talks.

China has made joining the WTO this year a priority, after it concluded a market access agreement with the United States last November.

But while Chinese negotiators hoped they could offer the same deal to Brussels, the EU is believed to have demanded tougher concessions from Beijing over sensitive issues like foreign ownership of finance and insurance companies.

The talks collapsed despite a meeting between Mr Lamy and premier Zhu Rongji on Wednesday which raised hopes of a replay of the China-US talks when Mr Zhu's eleventh-hour intervention helped seal a deal after protracted negotiations.

Yesterday, neither side was divulging the exact issues still dividing Beijing and Brussels. The previous round of talks in February faltered after the EU insisted on 51% foreign ownership of Chinese mobile telecoms networks.

Mr Lamy said in a statement that the talks "were held in a constructive spirit with positive movement on both sides resulting in a certain narrowing of differences on the outstanding issues under negotiation".

But he added that "conclusion of a bilateral agreement was not possible at this stage".

China, which still says it expects to join the WTO this year, put a similar gloss on the failure. A trade ministry statement described the talks as "positive, constructive and fruitful".

Last week, WTO members set a mid-May date for a major push on finalising China's bid to enter the Geneva-based organisation which polices global trade rules.

But the EU's failure to nail down a deal with China adds to the uncertainty facing Beijing's 14-year-old WTO accession drive.

Adding to China's problems, new polls suggest Bill Clinton will have difficulty securing an agreement from Congress to grant permanent normal trade relations with Beijing, a vital condition for WTO membership. Republican congressional leaders have said approval is in peril due to opposition from Democrats. Opponents of the pact have demanded that China improve human rights and labour standards before joining the WTO.

A Reuters poll showed Mr Clinton was 78 votes short of getting the deal through the House of Representatives, although it is virtually assured of Senate approval.

Mr Lamy said the EU had been ready to compromise to get an agreement this week, but his spokesman, Anthony Gooch, declined to discuss the areas of disagreement.

"The EU has shown flexibility," Mr Gooch said.

Mr Lamy's statement said: "A final package should be balanced taking due account of the specificity of the important trading relationship between the EU and China."

webTitle: Putin seeks small, better nuclear force

fields.headline: Putin seeks small, better nuclear force
fields.standfirst: Russia: special report
fields.trailText: President-elect Vladimir Putin called yesterday for cuts in strategic nuclear arsenals and urged the Russian parliament to ratify a stalled arms control treaty which would halve US and Russian nuclear missiles.
fields.body:
President-elect Vladimir Putin called yesterday for cuts in strategic nuclear arsenals and urged the Russian parliament to ratify a stalled arms control treaty which would halve US and Russian nuclear missiles.

Sending a strong signal of rapprochement to the Americans and the west in general after a year of frosty relations, Mr Putin used his first speech since being elected last weekend to announce that his administration would focus on market reforms, that Russian strength did not mean repression, and that he wanted bigger and deeper arms cuts to make the world a safer place.

But he also signalled a tough approach to international trade and issued a calculated snub to the Americans by suggesting that he would act in Russia's commercial interest by pursuing nuclear cooperation with Iran.

Mr Putin went to Snezhinsk, the home of the Russian nuclear arms industry 900 miles east of Moscow, to deliver his first message of intent and to shed some light on his policy plans.

"Russia is conducting and will continue to conduct talks on reducing strategic offensive weapons further," he said.

"We are tackling the task of freeing the world from excessive weapons stockpiles. Our aim is to make our nuclear weapons complex safer and more effective. We will preserve and strengthen the Russian nuclear weapons complex, even though there is no question of building it up."

He called on the Duma, the Russian lower house, to quickly ratify the stalled 1993 Start-II treaty, which aims to halve Russian and US nuclear warheads to around 3,500.

He said his foreign and defence ministers had been told to lobby the MPs for quick ratification. The previous Duma, dominated by communists and nationalists, refused to accept the arms deal, which was ratified by the US Senate in 1996.

Russian ratification of Start-II is a key foreign policy aim of President Bill Clinton in his last year in the White House, and Mr Putin drove home his pro-American message by sending a birthday greeting to the vice-president, Al Gore, stressing that he wanted to "further the development of Russian-American relations".

In his first hints about his government team, Mr Putin said the new government, to be unveiled in May, would be made up of professionals committed to the free market.

On Thursday he appointed a working group of four key officials to draft his first budget and prepare his economic policy blueprint. Three of the officials, all reform-minded economists, are seen as the nucleus of the new cabinet, while the fourth, Alexander Voloshin, is the powerful Kremlin chief of staff.

"Strengthening the state and continuing market reforms are the principles on which the work of the government will be based," Mr Putin said.

Restoring Russian greatness and building a strong state are his main slogans, causing apprehension that the former KGB career officer may ride roughshod over democracy in his determined pursuit of greatness.

Mr Putin denied that strengthening the Russian state would entail an increased resort to force and strengthening the armed forces and special services.

A strong state, he said, meant enforcing the rule of law, anti-corruption measures and state guarantees of property rights.

But while the policy directions outlined yesterday are likely to enamour Mr Putin further to western governments, there was also a sting in his remarks about exporting Russian nuclear technology.

With comments liable to alarm Washington, he promised a robust defence of Russian interests in world markets.

In the city that produces and assembles 60% of Russian nuclear warheads, and was closed to outsiders during the Soviet era, he was asked about nuclear power contracts with Iran. He made it plain that he wanted to market Russian nuclear expertise internationally.

"We will definitely fight for Russia's interests in world markets and won't allow anyone to exploit phony values to drive Russia from international markets," he said.

Russia is already helping Iran to build a nuclear reactor at Bushehr, and the atomic energy minister, Yevgeny Adamov, said Iran was ready to order a further three reactors from Russia, while contracts were to be signed with India later this year for five Russian reactors.

fields.headline: Creating radio activity
fields.standfirst:
Marconi

E-finance: special report
fields.trailText: In the summer of 1937, the world's radio stations fell silent for two minutes. It was a mark of respect for Guglielmo Marconi, the man who laid the foundations for the broadcasting industry.
fields.body:
In the summer of 1937, the world's radio stations fell silent for two minutes. It was a mark of respect for Guglielmo Marconi, the man who laid the foundations for the broadcasting industry.

Marconi died in the early hours of July 20, 1937 and is buried in the grounds of his family home, Villa Griffone, at Pontecchio, Bologna. The villa had been the site of his early experiments which overturned the accepted scientific wisdom that radio waves travelled in straight lines. He showed they were not affected by physical obstacles.

But when the 21-year-old tried to get Italy's post and telecommunications ministry interested in using his idea to send messages he was rebuffed.

His mother, a well-off member of the Jameson Irish whiskey family who had eloped with Marconi's father, had other ideas. She took him to England, where overzealous customs officers damaged his equipment, thinking the luggage contained a bomb. He used family connections to secure a meeting with William Preece, chief engineer of the Post Office, who gave his support to the young investor.

Marconi patented his system of using radio waves for telegraphy. In 1897 he formed the Wireless Telegraph and Signal Company, although a demonstration on Salisbury Plain that year managed to send a signal just seven miles.

He set up the world's first wireless factory in a disused silk factory in Chelmsford and the equipment quickly made its name after a series of dramatic sea rescues.

In 1899, the Goodwin light ship off the Kent coast successfully radioed for a lifeboat after it was hit by a steamship in thick fog. In 1909, more than 1,700 people were rescued after two ships, the Republic and the Florida, collided in fog off the US east coast. The Marconi radio operator aboard the Florida sent out 200 messages over two days to guide rescue ships.

Three years later, distress signals from the stricken Titanic were picked by by a German ship which helped to save 705 lives. Marconi had arrived in New York two days earlier. The survivors presented him with a solid gold medal.

By this time Marconi had proved that wireless signals could travel across the Atlantic.

In 1910, the infamous Dr Crippen and his mistress were arrested following a ship-to-shore radio message sent on Marconi equipment.

The entertainment value of radio was demonstrated in 1920 when a song recital by Dame Nellie Melba was broadcast from Marconi's Chelms ford works. Two years later, Marconi was in at the founding of the BBC.

His company set up the first microwave telephone link between the Vatican City and the Pope's summer retreat, Castel Gandolfo. In 1937 it began building Britain's first air defence radar network.

Marconi's portrait appeared on everything from meat extract to bank notes.

In the consumer world, the Marconi name was linked to radio sets and valves. After the second world war, his compa nies were swallowed up first by English Electric and eventually by General Electric Company which used the Marconi name for its electronic defence business. When GEC sold the defence business to BAe for £1bn last year, to concentrate on communications and IT, it retained the name Marconi as the group's title.

This week the company invested £40m in a new communications research centre at Cambridge University. Guglielmo Marconi never qualified to go to university.

fields.headline: Underside
fields.standfirst:
E-finance: special report
BMW
fields.trailText: Times may be tough at Longbridge, but BMW still knows how to put on a good show in Munich. For its annual results bash this week, the company laid on a fleet of top-of-the-range BMW 7-series cars to ferry hacks to and from the airport.
fields.body:
 Times may be tough at Longbridge, but BMW still knows how to put on a good show in Munich. For its annual results bash this week, the company laid on a fleet of top-of-the-range BMW 7-series cars to ferry hacks to and from the airport. There was strictly no sharing - it was one man, one car - so energy efficiency clearly isn't on the agenda for Joachim Milberg et al . There are lessons to be learned in terms of job creation, however. One driver admitted to being an off-duty policeman, saying he was paid so little that he had to chauffeur in his spare time. Perhaps some shifts could be found for the group's cruelly abandoned Birmingham workforce?

 That much loved German car company cropped up again at the House of Commons, where the trade and industry select committee applied its razor-sharp analysis to Longbridge on Wednesday. In the witness chair was Bob Morgan, who runs the car parts manufacturer Trelleborg Automotive Europe. The committee's chairman, Martin O'Neill, prefaced a question by referring to "those vultures crawling round" the Birmingham factory. "Actually, those are my customers," retorted Morgan.

 These are strange times at Walker Greenbank, the furnishings company best known for supplying £300-a-roll wallpaper for the Lord Chancellor's opulent apartments. Former chief executive Charles Wightman this week declared he was plotting a £30m bid for the business. His backers, we hear, include the PizzaExpress millionaire Luke Johnson. Wightman's interest comes a few weeks after a series of defamatory remarks about Walker Greenbank were posted under the name of "Blaker" on the internet bulletin board Hemscott.net. The wallpaper firm threatened to sue Hemscott, which made a courageous stand for free speech by banning "Blaker" from its website. Wightman reluctantly admits: "I do know Blaker, although I didn't know what he was doing at the time. Everything he posted was true, though." Even the stuff about chief executive Aidan Connolly facing the chop? He was still there last time we looked. Speaking of Luke Johnson, he deserves congratulations for winning the 1999 Belgian Mercurius Award. His Belgo restaurants have provided a big boost to the little country's exports. Johnson will receive the honour at Belgo's Ladbroke Road restautant from Prince Philippe and Princess Mathilde. Perhaps "Cool Hand Luke" can tempt them with some overpriced wallpaper.

 Sir Alan Sugar was on good form at the launch of Amstrad's new email telephone. Never much of a sucker for the internet economy, he demanded: "HTML - what's that? Stands for 'hard to make a living,' doesn't it?" Not everyone shares his view - Amstrad's shares have plunged 40% in three days.

 Anyone with a strong stomach and a light wallet should get on the phone to Peptide Therapeutics. The Cambridge-based biotech firm is looking for up to 50 volunteers to test its new vaccine for travellers' diarrhoea. The trial involves taking the vaccine, then being injected with a "virulent" strain of Etec, one of the most common causes of Delhi belly. The lucky ones will get a fee of "several hundred pounds". Finance director Gordon Cameron says: "It's only diarrhoea - it's not life threatening, it's just unpleasant. We wouldn't use this approach with, say, hepatitis."

 Running a glorified phone directory no doubt gets boring for Scoot.com's chief executive, Robert Bonnier, so he tries to spice up his conversation with ever-more exotic examples of the services to be found on his company's database. In the old old days, he would explain that customers called up for a "taxidermist in Torquay" or an "plumber in Penzance". Giving a presentation in Cannes this week, he volunteered the example of a "chicken sexer". Scoot's man later assured us that the company does have two such businesses on its files but he was unable to say whether anyone had ever called to request such a service. "It's obviously quite a rare business category," he intoned.

 Pearson's Marjorie Scardino has displaced the queen of fund management, Carol Galley, as Britain's most powerful woman, according to Management Today. The Texan has had a good year - already the country's highest paid company executive, she has sold Lazards merchant bank and attracted praise for Pearson's internet strategy. Martha Lane Fox has entered the list at number five - but who would bet on her remaining in the top 10 this time next year?

fields.headline: ICL sells Finnish stake
fields.standfirst: E-finance: special report
fields.trailText: Information technology group ICL is raising £141m by selling a 16.8% stake in its Finnish subsidiary ICL Data to a group of investors led by Enskilda Securities, a Swedish investment bank.
fields.body:
Information technology group ICL is raising £141m by selling a 16.8% stake in its Finnish subsidiary ICL Data to a group of investors led by Enskilda Securities, a Swedish investment bank.

The British company said yesterday that it was also looking at a stock market listing for the subsidiary later this year. It will use the cash from the placing to help finance its e-business services strategy.

ICL said that the move was part of a wider restructuring of its Nordic operation which will see it merge its Swedish, Danish and Norwegian players.

The British group is keen to establish a strong position in e-business in the region because its believes the Scandinavian countries' lead in the use of mobile telephones means they will be at the cutting edge of new developments in internet technology.

The market for internet services in the Scandinavian region is estimated by IDC to be growing in excess of 50% a year and Nordic companies are looking at ways of allowing mobile telephone users to send instructions to domestic appliances via the internet.

ICL's chief executive Keith Todd said: "ICL has consistently acknowledged the Nordic region's leadership position, which is reinforced by the high penetration of new mobile internet technologies.

"If you don't occupy the e-business high ground in the Nordic region you cannot lead this sector in Europe."

Henry Ehrstedt, the head of ICL Data who will run the combined Nordic operation, said: "The market outlook for e-business is strong both in Finland and in the Nordic countries so - the growth outlook is good."

ICL has developed a strong presence in the Nordic region where it had revenues for the 12 months to March 31 last year of approximately £480m and employs 3,450 people.

webTitle: Chechnya still awaits human rights monitors

fields.headline: Chechnya still awaits human rights monitors
fields.standfirst: Crisis in Chechnya: special report
fields.trailText: A month after the Kremlin bowed to western pressure to let international human rights experts work in Chechnya, the officials have yet to be named at the Council of Europe in Strasbourg and there is little sign of their arriving in the war-ravaged republic.
fields.body:
A month after the Kremlin bowed to western pressure to let international human rights experts work in Chechnya, the officials have yet to be named at the Council of Europe in Strasbourg and there is little sign of their arriving in the war-ravaged republic.

The UN human rights commissioner, Mary Robinson, arrived in Moscow yesterday on her way to a long-delayed visit to Chechnya to examine reports of atrocities and human rights abuses by Russian troops.

But the Kremlin's new special representative for human rights in Chechnya, Vladimir Kalamanov, said he could not understand why the council had not yet sent two experts to work in his office in Chechnya.

"It's very surprising. I don't know what they're waiting for," he said.

"There's no problem at this end."

After weeks of squabbling about £200,000 funding for the international involvement, it was only on Thursday that the council's committee of ministers approved the project.

"I can't give a time frame," said Dmitry Marchenkov, its spokesman. "Nothing's been announced officially."

"These people could have been here weeks ago," said a senior western diplomat familiar with the negotiations. "But European bureaucracy can be as slow as in Russia.

webTitle: Sharif family alone against the military

fields.headline: Sharif family alone against the military
fields.standfirst:
Deposed prime minister's wife vows to seek justice on the streets

Pakistan coup: special report
fields.trailText: The wife of the deposed Pakistani prime minister, Nawaz Sharif, yesterday threatened to defy the military regime and bring protesters out on to the streets if her husband is convicted in his hijacking trial next week.
fields.byline: Rory McCarthy in Raiwind, near Lahore
fields.body:
The wife of the deposed Pakistani prime minister, Nawaz Sharif, yesterday threatened to defy the military regime and bring protesters out on to the streets if her husband is convicted in his hijacking trial next week.

Kulsoom Sharif already faces a charge of treason after making an angry speech to hundreds of workers from her husband's Pakistan Muslim League last month.

"If the decision is not positive then we will go and demonstrate," Mrs Sharif, 45, said from her family's sprawling Raiwind estate, on the outskirts of Lahore.

Next Thursday an anti-terrorism court judge in Karachi will deliver his verdict on Mr Sharif and may sentence him to death. The former prime minister, his brother Shahbaz and five former senior government officials are charged with hijacking, attempted murder, kidnapping and terrorism. They have all pleaded not guilty.

Prosecutors say that on October 12 Mr Sharif sacked his army chief, General Pervez Musharraf, and then tried to stop a commercial aircraft carrying the general landing in Pakistan, risking the lives of the 198 people on board.

The general landed after the army took control of Karachi airport and within hours he staged a coup. Last month Gen Musharraf announced a ban on political rallies.

"Let them ban all these things," said Mrs Sharif, who sat dressed in a flowing pink shalwar kameez trouser suit and clutching a mobile telephone. She has spent the past five months travelling from the green lawns and golden wheat fields of Raiwind, in her husband's political heartland, across the country in a desperate attempt to raise support for his cause.

"They have banned them but the rallies are still there in Faisalabad, in Multan, in Hyderabad. We have demonstrated and they cannot do anything," she said. "Every Pakistani is with me and everybody in the army is with me, except the generals."

But few Pakistanis took to the streets to resist army rule in the days immediately after the coup, nor have they marched in the five months since. Their reluctance is a sign of the resentment that many felt towards Mr Sharif, one of the country's wealthiest businessmen whose family stands accused of widespread corruption.

Senior leaders in Mr Sharif's party have also been slow to lead protests, perhaps worried about their careers. "They are not complaining," Mrs Sharif said. "Sometimes it does disappoint me."

Already lawyers are preparing to appeal against a guilty verdict. "They have not found a single piece of evidence that he was guilty of hijacking. It was all a pre-planned story," she said. "[Musharraf] is a vindictive general."

Diplomats say Mr Sharif can expect a guilty verdict, although even if the court sentences him to death, the military will probably commute the sentence on appeal; Pakistan's sickly economy still needs loans and the new regime is unlikely to risk scaring international lenders.

Yet in the background of Pakistan's brief and troubled political history remains the disturbing precedent of Zulfikar Ali Bhutto, the prime minister hanged on April 4 1979, after he was overthrown by another general, Zia ul-Haq.

Reports have suggested that the Sharif family has reached an out-of-court agreement to pay the regime in order to avoid the death penalty or a lengthy jail sentence.

But Mrs Sharif denied these and ruled out the possibility of going into exile. "There is no agreement. Nobody came to him, nobody came to me," she said. "This is our country. Where can we go?"

With Mr Sharif in jail there are no heavyweight political figures left in Pakistan to challenge the military. His arch-rival, Benazir Bhutto, a former prime minister, is in London and faces a five-year jail term and a heavy fine for corruption if she returns to Pakistan.

Even after the hijacking trial, the Sharif family will find itself under pressure from a string of corruption investigations into huge sugar, steel, textile and paper interests.

Two cases against the family have already been registered and another 16 will follow, in vestigators say. Mrs Sharif insists that the Raiwind estate and four Park Lane apartments are the fruit of business profits, not political kickbacks.

"Having property is not illegal," she said. "The Sharif family is not at all corrupt and, insh'allah [God willing], we will prove it one day."

fields.headline: Buswoman's holiday
fields.standfirst: "Female narcissism is the feminism of the stupid. And it would be better if it was the only self-regard we were interested in, apparently"
fields.trailText: Julie Burchill: "Female narcissism is the feminism of the stupid. And it would be better if it was the only self-regard we were interested in, apparently"
fields.body:
Though sometimes a brutal and careless lover, I worship and adore the English language. And because I feel so strongly about it, because I want it to be every brilliant thing it can be, I feel violent when it doesn't live up to its vast potential. For instance, the words "spasm," "crust" and "gusset" make me feel ill; if anyone asked me after sex whether I had had a "climax", I would be tempted to gouge out their eyes; and if someone wants me to bang their head against a wall, they need only say "Enjoy!" before giving me a plate of food.

Another word that people say at their own risk in front of me is "pamper". According to the dictionary, to pamper is "to indulge too much, to feed to the full". Really? That's not what it means now. What it means now is having your hands, feet, thighs and upper body pulled, poked and pummelled, oiled, anointed and scented, so your disgusting female body won't seem quite so disgusting to your unlucky husband/ boyfriend when he makes a deposit. Hey, the poor guy's already had to reconcile himself to the fact that he's not having regular penetrative sex with Angelina Jolie; the least you can do is get your cuticles knocked into decent shape!

The sad transformation of the word "pamper" goes to show how much pleasure, especially for women, has been pathologised in recent years. Pampering would once have indicated a lost weekend of champagne, lobster and sodomy; it now means, when used in the context of women, "having a wash" or, perhaps, "keeping the equipment in order". It has become, in short, a Buswoman's Holiday. The consolation is that, as with most dubious words, it says a lot more about those who use it (just as people who use "Enjoy!" before eating are generally neurotic, wound-tight potential bulimics who couldn't enjoy food with a clear conscience if it jumped off the plate yelling "Eat me quick!") than that which it purports to describe. If anyone uses the p-word, without irony, to describe the process of getting clean, they identify themselves as being a non-orgasmic, puritanical little mule who wouldn't recognise real pleasure if it love-bit them.

For, surely, "pampering" is a sad, shop-bought imitation of the way good sex is supposed to make you feel: relaxed, treasured, confident. You have to hand it to the ingenuity of the marketplace - it knows it can sell sex to men purely as sex, but to women, being the delicate flowers they are, it has to sell it as being clean. In my bleak, dystopian moments, I imagine the twentysomethings of 2020, the men all shut up in their bedrooms downloading hardcore porn and the women taking long baths in ready-mixed aromatherapy oils called Sensual and Erotic. For many women, titivating themselves has become not a prelude to sex but an end in itself. After all, the last thing you want when you've spent hours honing yourself to perfection is some smelly man putting his greasy mitts on the goods. The New Narcissists may kid themselves that they're ultra-femme females but, as surely as any cloistered nun, they are dedicated to something far beyond romantic love. Female narcissism is the feminism of the stupid - and it would be better for everyone if it was the only kind of self-regard we were interested in, apparently. Earlier this month, one half of the Daily Mail's front page screamed Pamper Yourself, offering £30 of moisturiser, aromatherapy oils, bath foam and scented candles to readers ("The perfect antidote to today's stressful lifestyle"), while the other laboured under the headline Anger Over Astonishing New Right To Abortion. Obviously no one at the paper saw the funny side of this - a stressful lifestyle will obviously not be much improved by the addition of an unwanted child. And you try spending a bit of decent me-time in the tub with a brat screaming next door.

At the risk of cruising for a Pseud's Corner bruising, I'd say that the scented "aromatherapy" candle is one of the foremost weapons in middlebrow England's dirty little war against feminism - its message being, "Calm down, you hysterical cow, and stop complaining. You stink! And you're so ugly, don't let any man see you with the light on, he'll run a mile!" Scented candles make Blanche DuBoises of us all: never quite smelling, looking or "being" good enough to be looked upon without the intervention of all kinds of merciful middle men. And the fashion and beauty industries being what they are, nine times out of 10 those middle-men are gay; and while gay men have many excellent qualities, their appreciation of the sight, smell and taste of the unadorned female body is not one of them.

As women have, on average, 15 hours a week less than men to devote to leisure, it's rather sad that the little spare time they do have is consumed by the business of maintaining their market value. Every girl grows up with the mindless mantra "cleanse, tone, moisturise", but these days this is only the beginning of any decent skin "regime". The word invariably used to make vacuous primping seem like an outward bound course; now you need to masque, exfoliate, polish, too. Twenty years ago, a jar of Nivea Cream would cover a multitude of skins, but now there are distinct lotions and potions for every single bit of the body - eyes, thighs, insteps. I'm sure that somewhere in a laboratory in Switzerland a clever scientist is this very moment dreaming up a cream to be used on some newly- discovered essential zone; the two big toes, perhaps, or the inside of the elbow. And this time next year, we'll wonder how we ever lived without it.

Even weirder is the growing popularity of the spa holiday, where the usual two weeks of sea, sun and sangria are sacrificed in favour of seaweed wraps and protein shakes. On a recent holiday to an all- inclusive resort in Jamaica, the hotel presented me with a coupon to have whatever I wanted done at its state-of-the-art spa. From speaking to the other broads, I understood that they were queuing up to have mud slapped all over them. I, on the other hand, didn't get there until the last day, when the girls who worked there expressed real astonishment that I should have preferred to spend the previous six days lying in the sun with my boyfriend, drinking free cocktails and generally living it up.

They were lovely to look at, but there was something inert about them (as there often is about people who are in great physical shape), something fatally unimaginative that regarded beauty as far superior to, and completely separate from, fun in general and sex in particular. They reminded me of those fashionistas currently getting worked up about an eagerly-awaited new François Nars blusher called Orgasm. Bless 'em - it's the nearest they'll get to one this year.

fields.headline: Final frontier
fields.standfirst:
Gypsies are challenging the most fundamental of Europe's ideals and principles

Refugees in Britain: special report
fields.trailText: Why should the arrival of a small number of Gypsies in Britain be greeted with a burst of xenophobia out of proportion to their numbers? Why should a few Romanian women in brightly coloured shawls, begging with their babies, have suddenly provoked a national phobia? It is important to recognise that Gypsies have always provided the most difficult test of tolerance of human rights; and that they are a forewarning of the problems Britain will inevitably face in an enlarged European Union. They have to be faced before they provide a rallying-point for the forces of intolerance.
fields.body:
Why should the arrival of a small number of Gypsies in Britain be greeted with a burst of xenophobia out of proportion to their numbers? Why should a few Romanian women in brightly coloured shawls, begging with their babies, have suddenly provoked a national phobia? It is important to recognise that Gypsies have always provided the most difficult test of tolerance of human rights; and that they are a forewarning of the problems Britain will inevitably face in an enlarged European Union. They have to be faced before they provide a rallying-point for the forces of intolerance.

Journalists and politicians have made racial attacks on Gypsies which they would not dare to make against other peoples. "All the racism that the national press feels too ashamed to express against black people," said the black newspaper, the Voice, "it felt free to aim at the Gypsies". But in central and eastern Europe, they provoke much fiercer reactions. When I talked to the distinguished Czech scientist-poet Miroslav Holub before he died last year, our conversation came to a painful end when I asked about Czech Gypsies: "There are some rights," he said frostily, "which a young democracy cannot concede."

There has always been a difficult duality in European attitudes to Gypsies, as I learned through my grand- father John Sampson, who compiled the first Romani dictionary. He acquired a passion for their culture which left him with many Gypsy friends; but the romantic interest of intellectuals in Gypsies was very detached from the fears and resentments of ordinary people, which are now again being exploited.

It is crucial to understand the historical background. Gypsies have always provoked strong reactions, ever since they first migrated to Europe from India in the late middle ages, bringing their nomadic habits, their proud and separate communities and their tradition of begging. At first they were protected by Catholic rulers, and seen as penitents entitled to alms and succour. But the Reformation produced a more intolerant attitude to outsiders who would not accept protestant disciplines; and for centuries they suffered persecution as vagrants and petty thieves.

The industrial revolution and the motor car provided a still greater threat to their lifestyles, depriving them of livelihoods based on horses, and extending the cities and suburbs which encroached on the open countryside, their favoured habitat.

There were always two sides to the Europeans' attitude. Many romantic artists and intellectuals were enchanted by their wild songs, exotic clothes, their closeness to nature and their unique language, developed from Sanskrit. But government bureaucrats were determined to educate them, tame them and fence them in, and the romantic interest was not much help.

Each new government had its own reasons to hate them. The Nazis saw them, like the Jews, as a threat to racial purity: they murdered about half a million Gypsies - who remain shamefully neglected in memorials to the Holocaust. The post-war communist regimes saw them as a threat to their elaborate state planning and controls: while they did not massacre them, they hemmed them into minimal housing and restricted their movements.

But many post-communist governments in eastern Europe have in some ways treated them worse, seeing them as a threat to law and order and economic prospects in a capitalist world. In Romania, as Britain's Refugee Council reported last year, "the post- Ceausescu period has been marked by horrific mob violence against Roma, with hundreds of deaths".

The Gypsies provided a fundamental challenge to the principles and idealism of a united Europe. Gypsies were true Europeans, in terms of their mobility and ignoring of national frontiers; and their alternative lifestyle, defying the constraints of cities and capitalism, provided a test of individual freedom and human rights. The European Union cannot now ignore the test, at a time when the countries with the biggest Gypsy populations are clamouring to join it.

The most prosperous and western countries are not necessarily the most tolerant, and the Balkans are not always the worst. When I visited Serbia five years ago, I talked to the leader of the Gypsies in Belgrade who reckoned that the most intolerant were the Czechs - who are now closest to joining the European Union. But the 4m Gypsies in eastern Europe present a much bigger long-term problem, of which Britain is now having its first taste. The first British response to the small inflow of Gypsies across the Channel has been essentially nationalist; but we cannot make sense of the problem except in the context of Europe.

If the "second tier" of eastern Europeans, including Romania (with 2m Gypsies) and Hungary (with 600,000) - are eventually to become members of the European Union, the British and the other richer western countries cannot realistically be expected to provide open frontiers for refugees from countries which maltreat them. But they have an obligation to insist on their freedom from persecution within an enlarged Europe.

The European Union will have to link more firmly the applications to join the union with the acceptance of human rights, for which their treatment of Gypsies would act as a yardstick. The Council of Europe in Strasbourg, which embraces eastern Europeans, has shown much greater interest in Gypsies than the Brussels bureaucrats; but Strasbourg will have to play a more positive role in monitoring and publicising their persecutions.

The Gypsies are certainly awkward victims - as if they were determined to test tolerance to its limits. Their tradition of begging with their children and assuming an obligation to charity is now out of keeping with the western spirit of self-reliance and commercial competition. Their attitudes to the law and the police are more defiant and less obedient than those of the bourgeois citizens of the west; while their nomadic habits cut across all the neat assumptions of national and local planning.

But their contrariness still has some resonance among the more adventurous young British, beyond mere romanticism and sentimentality, as shown by the travellers and caravan dwellers who cannot stand circumscribed city life. And any political system which provides no escape-valve from the pressures of conformity carries the danger of eventual explosion.

 Anthony Sampson is the author of The Scholar Gypsy, published by John Murray.
