But the Reformation produced a more intolerant attitude to outsiders who would not accept protestant disciplines; and for centuries they suffered persecution as vagrants and petty thieves. The industrial revolution and the motor car provided a still greater threat to their lifestyles, depriving them of livelihoods based on horses, and extending the cities and suburbs which encroached on the open countryside, their favoured habitat. There were always two sides to the Europeans' attitude. Many romantic artists and intellectuals were enchanted by their wild songs, exotic clothes, their closeness to nature and their unique language, developed from Sanskrit. But government bureaucrats were determined to educate them, tame them and fence them in, and the romantic interest was not much help. Each new government had its own reasons to hate them. The Nazis saw them, like the Jews, as a threat to racial purity: they murdered about half a million Gypsies - who remain shamefully neglected in memorials to the Holocaust. The post-war communist regimes saw them as a threat to their elaborate state planning and controls: while they did not massacre them, they hemmed them into minimal housing and restricted their movements. But many post-communist governments in eastern Europe have in some ways treated them worse, seeing them as a threat to law and order and economic prospects in a capitalist world. In Romania, as Britain's Refugee Council reported last year, "the post- Ceausescu period has been marked by horrific mob violence against Roma, with hundreds of deaths". The Gypsies provided a fundamental challenge to the principles and idealism of a united Europe. Gypsies were true Europeans, in terms of their mobility and ignoring of national frontiers; and their alternative lifestyle, defying the constraints of cities and capitalism, provided a test of individual freedom and human rights. The European Union cannot now ignore the test, at a time when the countries with the biggest Gypsy populations are clamouring to join it. The most prosperous and western countries are not necessarily the most tolerant, and the Balkans are not always the worst. When I visited Serbia five years ago, I talked to the leader of the Gypsies in Belgrade who reckoned that the most intolerant were the Czechs - who are now closest to joining the European Union. But the 4m Gypsies in eastern Europe present a much bigger long-term problem, of which Britain is now having its first taste. The first British response to the small inflow of Gypsies across the Channel has been essentially nationalist; but we cannot make sense of the problem except in the context of Europe. If the "second tier" of eastern Europeans, including Romania (with 2m Gypsies) and Hungary (with 600,000) - are eventually to become members of the European Union, the British and the other richer western countries cannot realistically be expected to provide open frontiers for refugees from countries which maltreat them. But they have an obligation to insist on their freedom from persecution within an enlarged Europe. The European Union will have to link more firmly the applications to join the union with the acceptance of human rights, for which their treatment of Gypsies would act as a yardstick. The Council of Europe in Strasbourg, which embraces eastern Europeans, has shown much greater interest in Gypsies than the Brussels bureaucrats; but Strasbourg will have to play a more positive role in monitoring and publicising their persecutions. The Gypsies are certainly awkward victims - as if they were determined to test tolerance to its limits. Their tradition of begging with their children and assuming an obligation to charity is now out of keeping with the western spirit of self-reliance and commercial competition. Their attitudes to the law and the police are more defiant and less obedient than those of the bourgeois citizens of the west; while their nomadic habits cut across all the neat assumptions of national and local planning. But their contrariness still has some resonance among the more adventurous young British, beyond mere romanticism and sentimentality, as shown by the travellers and caravan dwellers who cannot stand circumscribed city life. And any political system which provides no escape-valve from the pressures of conformity carries the danger of eventual explosion.  Anthony Sampson is the author of The Scholar Gypsy, published by John Murray.

fields.headline: Time to fight the bigots
fields.standfirst:
Too few dare stand up for asylum seekers

The issue explained: How to claim asylum
Refugees in Britain: special report
fields.trailText: One bright event in an extremely bleak scene occurred a week ago - confirmation that for the first time in 24 months, the number of decisions on asylum seekers exceeded the number of new applicants.
fields.body:
One bright event in an extremely bleak scene occurred a week ago - confirmation that for the first time in 24 months, the number of decisions on asylum seekers exceeded the number of new applicants. The massive - and shameful - backlog of 104,000 cases has finally begun to decline, but will be years before it is totally eliminated. This figure represents the number of "applications", and becomes even bigger when children and wives are added. Then consider the enfeebling sense of insecurity which waiting for a decision creates. Some of the misery which these debilitating delays generate was dramatically portrayed in our asylum series this week in special reports from Dover and Glasgow. So was the deep hostility and prejudice which many refugees have to face. Our foreign correspondents traced the long torturous road that many applicants - from Yugoslavia, Afghanistan, Iraq and Sri Lanka - had to take to get here. And our home affairs editor quashed the myth that the vast majority are bogus: even under the ever-tighter screening process, over half are granted asylum or given exceptional leave to remain.

Next week a new system begins. Like almost everything associated with asylum, its launch will be inauspicious. The government's "tough new rules" are being delayed for 60% of new arrivals. Belatedly, even the Home Office has been forced to concede its alternative asylum welfare state cannot deal with all applicants. Only the 40% who apply for asylum at the air or sea port at which they arrive will be subjected to the new system of dispersal and vouchers. The other 60%, who apply "in country" after they have arrived, will be able to claim a mixture of cash, social security and housing benefit and live in London or the south east. Ministers should make good use of this delay to ensure dispersal is as humane as possible.

There are three crucial fronts which require attention. First, housing. Local authorities were asked to nominate 40,000 places outside the south east but produced only 4,000. The temptation will be to place refugees on sink estates. This must be avoided, as should bed and breakfast accommodation, given the length of time applicants have to wait. There are plenty of good empty houses without resorting to the use of condemned property. Care should be taken to avoid leaving individual families isolated on an alien estate: they need community support, access to legal help and interpreters. Secondly education: about 2,500 children of asylum seekers are not in school. This is a denial of a basic legal right. Many schools, fearful of losing their place in local league tables, are refusing to accept refugee children. But this is only storing up long-term problems. And then there is unemployment. Some refugee communities, despite a third having degrees or professional qualifications, have unemployment rates touching 90%. All three issues would benefit from a review by the social exclusion unit.

Finally, there is a front which does not require cash but is proving even more difficult to find commitment: rallying public support - locally as well as nationally - for the refugee community. Far too few people have stood up and championed their cause. We need to see more MPs joining the brave band who have spoken up: Simon Hughes, Neil Gerrard, Jeremy Corbyn; more peers supporting Shirley Williams, Avebury and Russell in the Lords; more bishops backing Southwark and Oxford in their fight against prejudice. Resisting racism means people fighting at every level.

fields.headline: Wallowing in victimhood
fields.standfirst: "As recent events have shown, you don't even have to possess a gun, let alone draw one, to get shot dead by a New York policeman"
fields.trailText: Alexander Chancellor: "As recent events have shown, you don't even have to possess a gun, let alone draw one, to get shot dead by a New York policeman"
fields.body:
During the last week of my month in New York, I have been up to Columbia University to take part in a students' writing class. I was invited there by a friend, Tom Beller, a high-flying writer in the magazine world, who is conducting an evening course on writing and journalism. I arrived in the middle of a discussion of "personal" journalism. There wasn't much of a contribution for me to make, since I hadn't read the two pieces that were being talked about - one was about a girl's loss of her virginity, the other was by another girl about her fraught relationship with her father. About 10 young people were seated around a long table engaging in what is called "upspeak", the practice of speaking every sentence as if it were a question. "I quite enjoyed it, right? But it was like, okay, that the writer was holding stuff back? I was feeling like, right, she wasn't being completely honest?" Upspeak is widespread among American college students, especially among women, and seems to reflect insecurity and a craving for reassurance.

According to Tom, most of his students were pretty bright, and some of them wrote well. But he said that the course had been a draining experience because of a fierce undercurrent of emotion beneath the surface of the debate. I saw no sign of this until about halfway through the class, when the true agenda of a couple of the students was exposed - they were there not so much to talk about writing for its own sake as to seek advice on how to break into the world of magazine journalism and get pieces published. My own advice was to steer clear initially of "personal" journalism, unless they had some truly unusual and interesting personal experience to report.

One of the students said that there had recently been a very good article in the New York Times Magazine by someone who had drawn a gun on a policeman. This was clearly a good example of what I meant, but not a practice to be encouraged in Mayor Giuliani's New York. As recent events have shown, you don't even have to possess a gun, let alone draw one, to get shot dead by a policeman. At the funeral in Brooklyn last Saturday of one such victim, a ceremony marred by clashes with the police, the presiding reverend called on God for protection from the New York Police Department. "We are defenceless, we are without weapons," he said. "Instead of protecting us, they [the police] are assassinating us. Keep your eyes on us, Lord. Protect us. We ask for justice."

Anyway, it quickly became clear that some of the students believed that all advice was worthless, even though they were claiming to want it. They felt themselves up against an invisible wall that would stop them ever getting anything published, however good it was. They were convinced that, without friends or connections in the journalistic world, nobody could ever break in to it. Tom then pointed out that to say there was nepotism at work was as obvious as stating that the sky was blue, but he insisted that any writer with ability and persistence would get published in the end. However, a couple of his students just could not accept this. They appeared to be attending his classes purely to demonstrate their futility. They wanted to convince him that he was wasting his time, because nothing he said could possibly help them.

Their attitude starkly illustrated the sense of exclusion felt by many people in New York, especially among black residents. It is a depressing phenomenon, widely blamed on Mayor Giuliani for his unquestioning support of the New York police, who have killed three unarmed black men in little more than a year. But even if Giuliani is a bit of a monster and a divisive influence on the city, young people must somehow be prevented from wallowing in their victimhood. It is unhealthy and destructive. I tried to persuade the unpersuadable ones that, although things are much harder for some than for others, talent is almost always recognised in the end, that there are always editors with open minds, and that the way to get published was to write, not to talk.

I can't remember which editor it was who said that the most important quality in any article was "doneness", but I repeated this to them. Tom was even brave enough to say that there were other ways of getting on in the world than writing articles for magazines; and that for people with genuine writing talent, the key to success was writing about things that really interested them, instead of arguing theoretically about what might or might not interest an editor. As we left, he said that I should have attended the start of his course, when I would have found the surliness much greater. He believed he was making good progress.

fields.headline: Just clone, Tone
fields.standfirst: Blair wouldn't have to bypass councils if he recreated them in his own image
fields.trailText: As Labour lumbers towards electoral humiliation, may we discuss whether the general election result really was a masterstroke of strategy?
fields.body:
As Labour lumbers towards electoral humiliation, may we discuss whether the general election result really was a masterstroke of strategy?

The way the story is told by people who analyse Westminster for us, a landslide victory was in fact a cunning ruse culminating in millions of people all turning up at polling stations on the same day, and having no idea why they were there. If you are ever passing Downing Street of a morning, wait a while and you will see those simpering hacks being ushered past the hopeful petitioners and bemused back-packers pressed up against the huge, black iron gates. It would never occur to the prime minister's briefees that the welcome extended to them makes them more or less redundant as anything other than digitised town criers.

Anyway, bitter rambling aside, my point is that, with varying amounts of scepticism about the alternative, we, the public, joyously threw the Tories from our backs. We did it. Lots of us. In fact, Blair was clearly baffled and disturbed that we did so in such numbers

Now, it is widely accepted by all but his tiny inner circle that there is very great disappointment with Blair. Mainstream comment agrees that he should listen to Peter Kilfoyle and other "loyalists". That is foolish advice; it can only have been by listening to such unstintingly craven hatchet-men that Blair became such a vain and demented controller in the first place. It is a bit late for pleas from the heartlands.

With all the weaknesses and contradictions of a social democratic party, Labour was one. It is now something else. I'm not even sure what. All I know is we must stay awake because they get you when you sleep. I'm convinced that lorry loads of strange-looking pods are dispatched from Millbank to local authorities every night. I give Ken Livingstone six months before he tells us, with glazed serenity: "Nothing's wrong. I feel fine now."

And yet somehow the human spirit is surviving. Because Livingstone is seen as his own man - not because he has adopted the Liberal ruse of raising finance for the tube by selling raffle tickets - he will deliver a humiliating blow to the Blair project. Other local election results will further embarrass the leader. How can the people who won that spectacular victory three years ago be so stupid now? Possi bly because they didn't win it - it was handed to them on a plate. Most of us who are handed plates have the good grace to acknowledge that whatever is on it was made by someone else. We say: "Ooh, thanks, that looks moist." Blair would say: "Look, as long as I'm holding this, never again will I let it return to the bad old days of sogginess at the one extreme and dryness on the other."

The Blairites just don't get it. We often hear that the left and the anti-nuclear movement were out of touch with popular opinion in the 80s, even though about half the population was against Cruise and Trident. But this government is incapable of grasping the public mood about anything. It tries to reassure us about British Nuclear Fuels by giving BNFL Aldermaston to play with, as though our concern was not that BNFL is a dangerous incompetent but that it doesn't have deterrent capability.

And when well-meaning worthies produce a mild report saying that lying to young people about drugs might undermine the government's credibility, the reaction is: "Don't listen kids! One puff on a pot-hash butt and you'll be hooked on loco weed!" The police are saying: "Look, Mr Straw, we love nicking people, but even we get bored with dope-smokers and refugees." But Straw will not rest until half the country is in detention. And his response to calls for open government is: "Trust me - you don't want to know."

The government tries to appeal to us in consumer language -"cutting out the middle man". That would be elected councillors, juries, trade unions, all those people with a duty to uphold our rights, getting in the way when all we want is to be ruled, sentenced and managed. In fact, wouldn't it be better if pay bargaining was replaced with decisions taken by local magistrates?

Having its finger firmly on the pulse, the government realises people would like improvement in local services and so proposes "cabinet style" (closed) local government. Then perhaps Whitehall won't have to bypass councils because it will have recreated them in its own image. Then councils could have upper chambers with locally ennobled Blairite members, an appointed gentry. I'm brainstorming here, but the appointees could be local media types, magistrates, business-people and those mysterious, rootless people who become school governors, but don't appear to have any connection with schools. Just a suggestion.

The trouble is Labour will probably have lost a load of councils by the time the Local Government Act is implemented. That must not have occurred to Labour.

webTitle: Cyberspace faces up to its Demon

fields.headline: Cyberspace faces up to its Demon
fields.standfirst:
The illusion of internet unaccountability has been blown

More about privacy on the net
fields.trailText: The award of damages and costs of around £500,000 against the internet service provider Demon - for failing to remove libellous remarks about a physicist posted on a website - coincided with a case in which a student was fined for accidentally emailing a pornographic picture to users other than the recipient he intended. In both cases, representations in cyberspace were treated to the same limitations as printed or spoken material.
fields.body:
The posters for the current identity-swap movie, Being John Malkovich, ask: "Ever wanted to be someone else?" But this dream is now available - at the level of names - for anyone with a PC and a modem.

There is a dizzying moment when creating an email identity for yourself through one of the numerous free internet access CDs handed out these days, when you realise that you could become anyone you want. Tony Blair, Zoë Ball, JD Salinger: turn yourself into any of these people, send messages around the world as them and the technology will do nothing to stop you. The only limit is the credulity of your correspondents.

The ease of impersonation which email allows has always seemed to me a symbol of the moral irresponsibility inherent in the internet. But this week the hands-free stance has been challenged by some key legal cases. The award of damages and costs of around £500,000 against the internet service provider Demon - for failing to remove libellous remarks about a physicist posted on a website - coincided with a case in which a student was fined for accidentally emailing a pornographic picture to users other than the recipient he intended. In both cases, representations in cyberspace were treated to the same limitations as printed or spoken material.

The internet has often been sold as circumventing the usual rules. Beyond the mad, but already receding, period when the City seemed to believe that dot.com companies were exempted from the usual laws of economics, the worldwide web was seen as a liberating force. Artists would be freed from the tyranny of selection by professional corporations. Write a novel, record a song or shoot a film and - if the artistic establishment won't produce it - put it on the net. But electronic distribution was also seen as a challenge to the dictatorship of taste. Pornography no mainstream shop would stock is widely open to downloading.

A nd the laws of libel - which so tormented writers and speakers in the world of paper and airwaves - were somehow believed to be suspended. Some local councils, sick of cleaning off graffiti, designated walls where it was tolerated. Many advocates of cyberspace saw the web as such a wall. Service providers like Demon held to the view that they merely provided the bricks. They could not be responsible for what was written on them.

Some net-heads genuinely believed in freedom of speech and information. But there was also a practical aspect to this enthusiasm. Abuse someone in a newspaper and - even if the remark slips past the editors and in-house lawyers - the culprit's cutting will be on the victim's desk within hours. Launch a hostile comment into cyberspace and you could cynically assume it would never be traced. The internet was the perfect haystack in which to needle your enemies.

But this view that the web placed a parallel universe for anarchists alongside the familiar policed and lawyered world found no support in court this week. Media lawyers disagree on the implications of the libel judgment against Demon. If the company was being punished merely for failing to remove the material (the physicist had asked several times for remarks to be cut), then the result will merely be a tamer cyberspace in which powerful figures will be able to delete comments they dislike. But if Demon was censured for having allowed the libel to be displayed at all, then shares in internet service providers are about to become an even riskier investment.

One inevitable outcome, however, will be cyberspace ambulance-chasers: insult-trufflers who will surf the world's websites and bring hostile comments to the attention of those who may wish to sue and split the proceeds.

It was never clear to me, though, why anyone believed that writing words in elec tronic limbo would not constitute publication. After all, one of the most famous recent libel cases - Lord Aldington v Tolstoy - resulted from words printed in a pamphlet. And the internet is merely a very large and hi-tech leaflet.

You also don't need to be a luddite (I write and send thousands of words in cyberspace each week) to feel that the internet needs some controlling. This week, the novelist Jeanette Winterson revealed that she is taking legal action in a test case against a Cambridge academic, Mark Howarth, who has registered the web addresses of writers (including jeanette.winterson.com) and now tries to sell them back their electronic identities. As with the email registrations mentioned above, you don't need to have a name to use it on a computer site. Ever wanted to be someone else? Mark Howarth wished to be 130 noted authors.

While there is a practical problem of baptismal duplication - some unknown Jeanette Winterson in, say, New Zealand has as much right to start a website as the author of Oranges Are Not The Only Fruit - it cannot morally or legally be right for a man to rob people's identities in bulk for profit. A name is a basic human right: a point made by prisoners who refuse to answer to numbers. Jeanette Winterson should be cheered to the door of the court. A victory for her would - like this week's internet libel case - challenge the silly and dangerous fairytale that computers are beyond rules. Why should people lose their right to name and reputation when they step through a computer portal?

But this dream is now available - at the level of names - for anyone with a PC and a modem. There is a dizzying moment when creating an email identity for yourself through one of the numerous free internet access CDs handed out these days, when you realise that you could become anyone you want. Tony Blair, Zoë Ball, JD Salinger: turn yourself into any of these people, send messages around the world as them and the technology will do nothing to stop you. The only limit is the credulity of your correspondents. The ease of impersonation which email allows has always seemed to me a symbol of the moral irresponsibility inherent in the internet. fields.headline: Chillin' with rehash Ali
fields.trailText: Easy now! Wat a gwan wid Ali G? Mi feelin dat da hincreased fascination across da nation wit dis comic stereotype is no bad ting. Fi once da British lion an da Lion of Judah, dem beast lie down together, hear me bwoy? Im increase da comprehension which reduce da tension. Easy now! Wat a gwan wid Ali G? Mi feelin dat da hincreased fascination across da nation wit dis comic stereotype is no bad ting. Fi once da British lion an da Lion of Judah, dem beast lie down together, hear me bwoy? Im increase da comprehension which reduce da tension. Owever, is chrue im mek me vex big style when im speak fi de sexualism ina offensive way and when im speak disrespectfully of da batty bwaays. An what is dis punani ting of which him speak? Mi tink im talk as if him tek a toke on some baksha superskank that im haccidentally have pon im person, officer. Man an Man never speak like dat inna Trenchtown! Ali G, im put im ead an da block when im happropriate Jamaican patois ina Berkshire stylee, innit? For real. Nuff respect!

By which I mean to suggest that, while the Ali G phenomenon may be of limited duration, it may also at the same time reflect, in a profoundly satirical manner, some of the multi-cultural conflicts blithely overlooked by Tony Blair in his recent speech on the nature of Britishness. This, after all, is a Jewish comedian posing as an Asian wannabe rapper who plunders and mangles not only Caribbean speech patterns and hip-hop culture, but also embraces the homophobic and sexist attitudes as well as the drugs purportedly beloved of gangsta rappers. It's an intriguing comic persona. No matter that vast tranches of white Britain doesn't get Ali G's schtick. No matter at all.

The most pressing question, though, was whether there was enough in Sacha Baron Cohen's persona to make the 40 minute Da Ali G Show (Channel 4) work. After all, his sterotype surely has too little substance to flesh out more than the odd sketch. What's more, the supply of interview patsies must be poised to dry up. If all the old duffers who lined up ("Respect, Sir Boyson-in-the-house!" "Booya! Booya! Booyakasha, Sir Teddy Taylor!") so obligingly to be lampooned last year have got with the programme and realised this Ali G is a satirical interviewer ina Dennis Pennis-stylee, then how was Ali going to fill his show? Surely now only the most worthless, the most shameless, the most discredited publicity hounds would deign to expose themselves to the interviewing skills of the doyen of the West Staines Massive? And so it proved.

Enter Neil Hamilton. There's something about Hamilton and his wife that makes me want to take bong hit after bong hit rather in the manner of Bridget Fonda in the Tarantino film Jackie Brown. Cho Rastafari! Me feelin' dat sinsimella upside mi head now fi sure. Christine, yo one fine lookin ladygirl! Neil, yo give me da food for da beast now, bwoy! Westside!

Unfortunately, though, Ali G used the presence of Neil Hamilton not to further trample the former member for Tatton's reputation into the dust as he should have done, but rather to make mock of himself. Thus, his ignorance of the news: "Let's get this right. You is da geezer who went to Clapham common and shagged a rasta?". Thus too, Ali G's perversely personal take on the Ritz hotel scandal: "Is it true they have likkle bokkles in there with shampoo and conditioner? Did you wear towels that goes all over your body like a suit?"

Thankfully, Hamilton is a seasoned professional at making himself into a bigger arse than anyone would have thought humanly possible. Thus, he replied to the towel question: "I don't think I did. I walked around in the nude most of the time." "Tanks for tellin me dat," said Ali G grimly.

But Ali G did conclude this interview on an upbeat note: "You musta got lots of respect in the House of Commons or whatever for being the baddest gangsta! Respect to you!" He then handed Hamilton a putative spliff, which the Shameless One inhaled before coughing stupidly in a failed stab at humour. A Channel 4 press officer told me there were no illicit narcotics in the spliff. Which makes Hamilton's attempted satirical coughing fit even more stupid.

Ali G also pitched a movie idea before some gullible American producers at Cannes. This film was called Booka, after the sound a bullet makes when it hits the human body. The execs promised to read his script. But I believe they will not fulfil that pledge. There was also a parody of Who Wants To Be a Millionaire called Who Wants To Win an Ounce which, fairly tiresomely rehashed some of Ali G's old hash gags.

Admittedly, Channel 4 would not allow me to see the whole show before transmission (thus I had not seen and so cannot judge the merits of his new character, the spoof reporter from the Kazakhstan Broadcasting Corporation), but of what I saw the show suggests Sacha Baron Cohen had no new moves for his comic creation. Drugs, homophobia, the singular world view of a Thames Valley gangsta living off the social - we've been here before.

Thus, he did his increase the peace rantette: "We all know there is a lot of killing and blood out in the ghetto. I seen it on the streets of Chertsey, I seen it on the streets of Eton Wick, and if we don't start changing the way we think, Langley Village will be next." Funny stuff, but substantially the same as the West Staines massive versus East Staines massive conflict that he outlined in minute detail for the benefit of the 11 O'clock Show audience last year.

Mi feelin' dat da show have two series worth a material tops. Fi now tis a Irie likkle show fi chillin' on a Friday night. Big up, then, Ali G! Wi some well crucial caveats.

fields.headline: Ribtickling whitesmiths, quote, unquote
fields.trailText: Tony Blair made a speech on Tuesday about being British, a big Labour theme as the next election looms - yet there was very little about it in Wednesday's papers. This was because they had all reported the speech already. A curious form of stately dance has now been invented which reverses the grand old order of things in which a statesman opined on a Tuesday and reports of his speech duly appeared on a Wednesday. Now the reports appear before he has even opened his mouth. At first this practice was subject to coy little rules. "In a speech in Theddlethorpe today," a reporter would cautiously write: "Mr Votewheedler is expected to say..." But now it is naked and unashamed. Now we get: "Today Mr Votewheedler will tell a meeting at Theddlethorpe 'the state of the matting industry in this fine old country of ours is nothing short of a total disgrace'." By the time the words are actually spoken, no one is interested.
fields.body:
Tony Blair made a speech on Tuesday about being British, a big Labour theme as the next election looms - yet there was very little about it in Wednesday's papers. This was because they had all reported the speech already. A curious form of stately dance has now been invented which reverses the grand old order of things in which a statesman opined on a Tuesday and reports of his speech duly appeared on a Wednesday. Now the reports appear before he has even opened his mouth. At first this practice was subject to coy little rules. "In a speech in Theddlethorpe today," a reporter would cautiously write: "Mr Votewheedler is expected to say..." But now it is naked and unashamed. Now we get: "Today Mr Votewheedler will tell a meeting at Theddlethorpe 'the state of the matting industry in this fine old country of ours is nothing short of a total disgrace'." By the time the words are actually spoken, no one is interested.

Of course, it's the purpose of newspapers to break stories before they happen. Even so, this trend seems to Smallweed somewhat unhealthy. Mr Votewheedler's leak is designed to ensure that the bit of his speech he wants reported is the one that gets into the papers, not some other element which reporters may judge more appropriate. In other words, it is yet another manifestation of news management, and therefore to be suspected.

 A cross letter from Wales berates me for printing football results of matches in Wales contested by sides with names like Ystradmynach and Cefn Cribwr. "Oh, my splitting sides!" my correspondent adds with what I take to be sarcasm. I do not aim to quote John Betjeman every week, but I would draw my castigator's attention to a poem called Dorset, each verse of which ends with a list of people allegedly buried in Mellstock churchyard, including TS Eliot, HG Wells, Edith Sitwell, Mary Borden and Thomas Hardy, none of whose graves you are likely to find there. In a footnote the poet explains: "The names are put in not out of malice or satire but merely for their euphony." Such too was my purpose in printing these Welsh results. I aimed to tickle, not ribs, but sensibilities.

 Still, at least I can quote John Betjeman without my superiors getting the nasty phone calls which tend to arrive if you dare to reprint the words of a popular song. For that you are required to ask permission, which you will not necessarily get. David Lodge wished to call one of his novels after a line in a much loved song about London, which asserts (I take care to paraphrase) that because of weather conditions restrictive of visibilility, the charm of the British Museum is reduced to a lesser level than is habitual. The copyright holders denied him that right, which is why he was reduced to calling the novel The British Museum Is Falling Down. This legislation has oppressed us too long. I hope the new Human Rights Act due to come into force in October (which is so upsetting the Daily Mail) will sweep it away and assert our right to quote as we wish, within reason.

 The new salary which Peter Middleton has awarded himself (with the connivance of colleagues) for running Barclays seems to me quite obscene. I will, however, refrain from condemning it now, on one condition. Sir Peter, as I happen to know from seeing him on the terraces when they played at Plough Lane, is a faithful supporter of Wimbledon football club. His offence would be instantly purged if he now used his money to buy out all these Norwegians who seem to have taken the fight out of our team and, if present trends continue, may even propel it into the Nationwide League first division. I shall need to be consulted, however, on who shall be manager.

 In the sweetly written account of his Liverpool childhood which opens his memoirs, Fourth Among Equals, published this week by Politico's, the Labour/ SDP/ Lib Dem politician Bill Rodgers says that one of his forebears worked as a whitesmith. I had to look that up. A blacksmith, yes: a big beefy figure who worked in a forge and put shoes on passing horses; but till now I do not remember, in a long and obstreperous life, ever encountering whitesmiths. I now know they are either workers in white iron, or tinsmiths; or those who polish or finish metal goods, as distinct from those who forge them; or more generally, workers in metals. "He was a white-smith," says a reference dating from 1826, "and published various lucubrations under the title of the Tinclarian Doctor." Alternatively, a whitesmith can mean a variety of gooseberry with white fruit, its name deriving from Sir William Sidney Smith (1764-1840) and, of course, the word white; but I doubt if that is relevant here.

 Somewhere or other this week I saw a tale of the great turn of the century premier, Lord Salisbury, asking a young man he vaguely recognised "Who are you?" and getting the answer "Your son". This is troubling. Some time ago I recounted a story, told by the Labour MP Frank Field about the Victorian hymnodist Sabine Baring-Gould, who, on coming upon a pleasing young girl at a party, asked: "And whose child are you?" "Yours, papa," the poor waif is said to have sobbed. These tales are so hauntingly similar that I don't believe either. This was probably one of those stories which tended, then as now, to travel around with their details progressively curdling and the names of their characters changing. Other forgetful fathers named in it, I dare say, included the Duke of Cambridge, Archbishop Benson, Sir Edward Elgar, Anthony Trollope, Harley Granville-Barker, Oscar Wilde and WG Grace.

webTitle: Odd job of a spook spotter

fields.headline: Odd job of a spook spotter
fields.trailText: I worked many years ago in recruiting for MI6 and other hush-hush civil service jobs, when working for a university (My brief encounter, March 30). It was an odd business.
fields.body:
I worked many years ago in recruiting for MI6 and other hush-hush civil service jobs, when working for a university (My brief encounter, March 30). It was an odd business. As Leanda de Lisle says, there was no job description, so how was anyone to know in advance what the duties were likely to be?

It was hard to explain them to the candidates, and for them to take me seriously, if I couldn't say in detail what was involved. I finally built up my own person specification: they had to have liked living abroad, to like and be good at foreign languages and needed to understand what I was getting at if I suggested talking further to someone in Whitehall.

There also had to be an unusual, even contradictory, mixture of qualities: to be unconventional enough to enjoy and flourish in working at a secret job, yet to be totally trustworthy; please, please, under that safe exterior, don't turn out to be another Kim Philby. One of the problems MI6 must have is that there often is a knife edge between the brilliant and the fatally unsuitable candidate; selection is a high-risk activity.

One problem MI6 had was that too many successful candidates came from Oxford and Cambridge, a narrower recruitment base than would have been desirable. You may be able to trust them because you know their background, but if they are donkeys they are not doing you much good. I haven't the faintest idea whether the possession of too much bodily hair would be a bar to successful recruitment.

Ian Kerr
Hove, E Sussex

fields.headline: No shirking HIV debate
fields.trailText: Following the allegations you report (Royal Society accused in row over origins of HIV, March 30) that the proposed Royal Society discussion on the origins of HIV has been postponed "after pressure from opponents of the vaccine theory", I write to clarify the matter.
fields.body:
Following the allegations you report (Royal Society accused in row over origins of HIV, March 30) that the proposed Royal Society discussion on the origins of HIV has been postponed "after pressure from opponents of the vaccine theory", I write to clarify the matter.

The Royal Society holds 14 discussion meetings a year, on frontier topics proposed by fellows and others. The HIV meeting was proposed by the late Bill Hamilton to discuss the controversial hypothesis that HIV entered the human population through trials of an oral polio vaccine (OPV). It was agreed that this would be done in a wider context, such as cross species transmission (from animals to man), virus evolution and public health.

Owing to a misunderstanding of the purpose of the meeting, and because of the dissension aroused by the hypothesis, we found it impossible to arrive at a well-balanced set of speakers in time for the meeting in May. We learned that additional data would become available in the next few months, highly relevant to the OPV controversy, including the re sults of independent blindtesting of remaining oral polio vaccine stocks, evidence on the prevalence of a related virus in chimpanzees, and major publications on evolution and rate of change of HIV. So we have postponed the meeting until September.

I refute the assertion that the postponement is "an attempt to load the dice" in favour of one of the parties to the debate. The Royal Society does not shirk from tackling important scientific issues, but we have always tried to ensure that the protagonists be fairly represented.

Sir Aaron Klug
President, The Royal Society

 It is most certainly not members of the Royal Society who should be criticised, but those who have backtracked about appearing at the conference, or worked to undermine it. Two leading opponents of the "cut hunter" theory of origin, doctors Beatrice Hahn and Bette Korber, both readily agreed to speak when invited in January, but withdrew some weeks later after learning of those scheduled to speak in opposition. Doctors Stanley Plotkin and Hilary Koprowski, who helped produce the polio vaccine at the heart of this controversy in the late 50s, also floated the possibility of withdrawal, even though Plotkin had agreed to speak, and Koprowski to attend. The organisers were receiving correspondence from America, some of it from senior scientists, questioning - among other things - the balance of the meeting. At this point, they decided to postpone the event to the autumn, an unprecedented move for a Royal Society meeting.

The conference was never intended to be about my book, The River, but intended as a multi-disciplinary debate about how HIV and Aids began, based on a comparison between the only two really viable theories of origin: viral transfer from butchered chimp to hunter; or transfer via contaminated polio vaccine. This is still the schedule: all those invited to speak at the May meeting will be reinvited in the autumn. One hopes that some at least of the withdrawals will decide, after all, to participate in this open debate.

Edward Hooper
Bridgewater, Somerset

fields.headline: New lords for old
fields.trailText: As one of the new Liberal Democrat nominees to what Hugo Young calls the "fixed-up" House of Lords (A House of corrupted legitimacy, March 30), I cannot claim to be an ex-MP - just an ex-candidate, failed; nor a "retired party hack" - still going strong.
fields.body:
As one of the new Liberal Democrat nominees to what Hugo Young calls the "fixed-up" House of Lords (A House of corrupted legitimacy, March 30), I cannot claim to be an ex-MP - just an ex-candidate, failed; nor a "retired party hack" - still going strong.

But Young is quite right; I pledge to vote on every opportunity to abolish myself and all other appointed and hereditary peers, in favour of an upper house elected by proportional representation on a different electoral system from the Commons.

I will find this easy, since it is my party's policy. The Liberal Democrats experienced an outbreak of democracy last summer, when the party conference elected a panel of people from which our new leader, Charles Kennedy, has been required to pick most of our new peers. This is small stuff. Nothing less than full election by the people will do in a democracy. Where we lead, who will follow?

Tony Greaves
Colne, Lancs

 As he considers his political prospects, William Hague might wonder how the SDP, a political party which ceased to exist almost a decade ago, has received more peerages in today's working peers list than the Conservative party (Blair balances Lords, March 31). Lindsay Granshaw, Richard Layard, Parry Mitchell, Matthew Oakeshott and John Roper were SDP parliamentary candidates. Lord Chandos sat in the Lords for the SDP. In politics, at least, there is life after death.
Ian Wright
Whissendine, Rutland

 New lords for old, tax exiles and personal trainers. Come on, tell me this was the Guardian having April Fool fun one day early. Please.

Gerald McMullan
London

webTitle: Gadafy set to come in from the cold

fields.headline: Gadafy set to come in from the cold
fields.standfirst: Lockerbie: special report The European Commission: special report
fields.trailText: Muammar Gadafy will achieve a historic breakthrough in Libya's relations with the west when he meets European Union leaders at the first EU-Africa summit in Cairo on Monday.
fields.body:
Muammar Gadafy will achieve a historic breakthrough in Libya's relations with the west when he meets European Union leaders at the first EU-Africa summit in Cairo on Monday.

Working hard to shed his pariah status, Colonel Gadafy appears to be close to signing a declaration recognising Israel and accepting respect for democracy and human rights, diplomats said last night.

Having finally handed over the two Lockerbie bombing suspects for trial, his subscribing to the principles of the 27-member Euro-Mediterranean forum - the so-called Barcelona process - is now all that stands between him and international respectability.

Romano Prodi, the European Commission president, provoked a furious row in January when he agreed to meet the maverick Libyan leader, but was then forced into an embarrassing climbdown.

No meeting between the two is scheduled, although Col Gadafy arrived in Egypt yesterday, so it would be extraordinary if an encounter did not take place during the two-day event.

"Something is moving on the Libyan side," Mr Prodi's spokesman said. "There are encouraging signs of the Libyan government adopting a more open attitude to the Euro-Med dialogue."

Europeans feel emboldened to bring Col Gadafy in from the cold because he has turned a new leaf on terrorism, and because of the importance of Libya's oil industry, but also because the US is now less hostile: this week it is sending its first official delegation to Tripoli for 20 years.

The Cairo summit is designed to show that the EU has not forgotten Africa - ravaged by conflict and threatened by Aids, famine and marginalisation - after a decade of post-cold-war focus on eastern and central Europe.

It is the brainchild of Portugal, current holder of the union's rotating presidency, which fought the continent's most bitter colonial wars in Guinea-Bissau, Angola and Mozambique but now has the best relations with its former colonies.

Only a month ago the event seemed destined for disaster or oblivion, because Morocco refused point blank to attend if the Western Saharans were there.

The EU is still Africa's biggest single source of emergency assistance and development aid through a variety of programmes, including the aid-and-trade pact concluded in February with 71 former colonies.

African critics point out, however, that too much money has disappeared into the pockets of corrupt government officials, and accuse the European Commission of failing to keep tabs on its largesse.

Social, economic and development issues are high on the Cairo agenda, as are debt relief and the fight against Aids, though the EU side has made it clear that it does not want a pledging conference.

Oxfam is urging EU governments to agree a Compact for Africa, to mobilise $1.6bn a year, in advance of the forthcoming World Education Forum in Senegal.

Suspicions remain strong. Abdelaziz Bouteflika, the Algerian president, warned that Africans would benefit only if they prevented Europeans from "trying to sell more and more of their goods".

Only last month the EU and South Africa settled an acrimonious dispute that hinged largely on trivial questions about product names like grappa and ouzo, displaying a rich and self-satisfied trading bloc at its most selfish.

Britain, represented in Cairo by Robin Cook, the foreign secretary, wants a sharp focus on conflict prevention - vital in a continent which still accounts for more than half the world's wars, draining resources from development projects and pouring them into refugee camps.

Oxfam points to a sharp contrast between the EU's commitment to stopping violence in Kosovo and East Timor and the largely forgotten wars of Angola, Sudan and the Democratic Republic of Congo.

The EU puts a far greater emphasis on fostering relations with the continent's giants, such as South Africa, Nigeria and the Maghreb countries.

fields.headline: More pricks than kicks
fields.trailText: Now that Sean McPhilemy has won his libel case, over his allegations of a conspiracy between high-ranking RUC officers, unionist politicians, business figures and loyalist terrorists to murder Catholics (Loyalist murder committee was 'no hoax', March 31), the case for an independent international inquiry is surely undeniable.
fields.body:
Now that Sean McPhilemy has won his libel case, over his allegations of a conspiracy between high-ranking RUC officers, unionist politicians, business figures and loyalist terrorists to murder Catholics (Loyalist murder committee was 'no hoax', March 31), the case for an independent international inquiry is surely undeniable.

M Brennan
Belfast
m.b@freenet.co.uk

 Shoot to kill, I thought, was the longstanding policy of the IRA/UDA. What of their victims, and their civil freedoms and right to life?

Dave Cousins
Southwell, Notts
david.cousins4@virgin.net

 Re "Labour panic over poll meltdown" (March 31): do you think pensioners will take this opportunity to thank the chancellor for their 75p increase? I know I will.

William Munn
Hamilton
Bill@munnw.freeserve.co.uk

 In 1963, my class of 15-year-old boys was interested to learn the penis, when it stood up, was not filled with air or water or cheese or the holy spirit, but with blood (Letters, March 31). No one had told them. It is gratifying this information can be printed in a national newspaper in 2000.

Maurice Hill
Alicante, Spain

 So just where is a cow's clitoris (Banned from the radio, March 29)?
Brian Carr
St Helens, Merseyside

 Re Hugh Gibson's letter (March 31): how about the site www.wwwdotcom.com?

Giles Wilson
London
gillis@beeb.net

 The laureate of tedium, Samuel Beckett, evinced remarkable prescience when, in 1953, his waiting for go. astounded the world.

Eamon Gran
Birmingham

fields.headline: Austen brought to book
fields.trailText: What appears to John Mullan (Fanny's novel predicament, March 28) as disastrous for Eng Lit students might be their salvation. To write their essays about Mansfield Park, they will be compelled to read Jane Austen's novel, since studying a text is the only way to connect with an author's mind.
fields.body:
What appears to John Mullan (Fanny's novel predicament, March 28) as disastrous for Eng Lit students might be their salvation. To write their essays about Mansfield Park, they will be compelled to read Jane Austen's novel, since studying a text is the only way to connect with an author's mind. All screen adaptations, by definition, depict stories at second hand, sieved through someone else's consciousness.

Patricia Rozema knows her Austen, but has chosen to create a gifted, confident Fanny Price, perhaps because the original character would be beyond the experience of today's audiences: the genre of poor nieces adopted into wealthy aunts' families no longer exist. But it exists historically, and will always form part of the academic syllabus.

Susan McCarton
Secretary, Jane Austen Society
janeaustensoc@freouk.com

 In your review (March 31), Mansfield Park is described as: "perversely experimentalist and frankly preposterous, very silly and PC", yet on the following page an ad for the film carries the endorsement: "Audacious, handsome and finely acted with excellent performances - the Guardian." So is it any good or not? I think we should be told.

Christopher Ellicott
Bristol

fields.headline: Two fingers
fields.trailText: Like Becky Gardiner, I am short of index and long of ring finger (Slight of hand, March 31). Perhaps this explains why I swear like a trooper, can drink male friends under the table, and am frequently dubbed a "ladette".
fields.body:
Like Becky Gardiner, I am short of index and long of ring finger (Slight of hand, March 31). Perhaps this explains why I swear like a trooper, can drink male friends under the table, and am frequently dubbed a "ladette".

Unfortunately for Professor Breedlove's theory, I also have a bosom to rival the best, favour short skirts and ridiculously high heels, and find men devastatingly attractive. I therefore join Becky in her (uneven) two-fingered salute to such futile research, and can only hope that these "masculine" traits of mine will manifest themselves usefully in the form of a whopping great salary before too long.

Georgina Barnes
London
georgina_barnes@hotmail.com

 Nice to hear the scientists now saying the gay boys are as masculine as the straight. I've discovered that my right hand is gay while my left hand is straight, making me, what? Ambisexual?

Clare Whatling
University of Manchester
cyerex@hotmail.com

 I checked the lengths of my fingers. Nothing unusual. I am also the elder brother, although I am gay; but my younger brother is definitely heterosexual. Perhaps scientists should give up this tosh and research into winning the argument for equal treatment for all regardless of sexuality?

Dr Peter Purton
Southall, Midd

fields.headline: Bare cheek
fields.trailText: The other day I had a call asking for my comments, as an actress, about Kathleen Turner taking her clothes off in The Graduate (Bare market, March 30), and was identified as the actress "whose coupling in the ferns in Dennis Potter's Pennies from Heaven has been voted the most erotic moment on television". Sadly, I did not give this performance.
fields.body:
The other day I had a call asking for my comments, as an actress, about Kathleen Turner taking her clothes off in The Graduate (Bare market, March 30). I made some remarks about actors doing what is right for the play etc, and was identified as the actress "whose coupling in the ferns in Dennis Potter's Pennies from Heaven has been voted the most erotic moment on television". Sadly, I did not give this performance. My admired friend Alison Steadman did: actually it was in The Singing Detective. Another example of exposed flesh remembered, rather than the actress?

Maggie Steed
London maglecheval@hotmail.com

fields.headline: Lords on probation
fields.standfirst:
New Labour invents the provisional peer

Lords reform: special report
New Labour in power: special report
fields.trailText: Dear Mr Dubious: I am happy to be able to write on behalf of the government's public honours scrutiny committee to confirm that you have been approved for one of our new conditional peerages. The committee is happy to accept the case made for your ennoblement, but only if the following requirements are met.
fields.body:
Dear Mr Dubious: I am happy to be able to write on behalf of the government's public honours scrutiny committee to confirm that you have been approved for one of our new conditional peerages. The committee is happy to accept the case made for your ennoblement, but only if the following requirements are met.

1. It will be necessary to reduce your dealings with several past associates, especially Mr Jimmy ("Fingers") Gonzalez. We need a written assurance that should Mr Gonzalez visit you in the House of Lords, he will not be wearing his gun.

2. Though in the present liberal climate no objections are raised to your continuing friendships with the women described as Amber, Sharon, Sukie, Samantha B, Samantha C, Gorgeous Gloria and Peaches, or the person who styles himself Madame Fifi, lines still have to be drawn, and, given her provenance, we have to insist that the line in this case is drawn at the woman called Trixie. You are therefore required to undertake not to appear in public with this female, nor to visit her in her quarters near Kings Cross station, nor to bring her into the parliamentary precincts, especially at times when Her Majesty may be present.

3. Your plans, reported in the News of the World on February 6, to publish an autobiography entitled Stoned Out, Stotious and Stonking should be urgently reconsidered, and the episode with the tuning fork and the blancmange deleted entirely. Any such volume will need to be studiedly uncontroversial, with a title to match. May we suggest: My Path to the Ermine: A Retrospect?

We have to warn that, should any of these conditions be broken once you have been introduced in the House of Lords, this committee will have no alternative but to ... that is to say, it will feel itself bound to... in other words, we shall not for a moment hesitate to invoke the condign powers vested in us by statute to take appropriate action, such as...

Or perhaps we'll just send in the boys.

fields.headline: The eaves dropper
fields.standfirst: Our weekly probe into the companies that are hot gossip in the internet chat rooms
fields.trailText: Our weekly probe into the companies that are hot gossip in the internet chat rooms
fields.body:
Retail Decisions?

A provider of anti-credit card fraud services formed out of the demerger of Card Clear three months ago. When you buy petrol at an Esso, BP or Shell station or groceries at Sainsbury's and Tesco's and they swipe your card, Retail Decisions provides the software which checks that it's not fake. Last year it verified 1.1bn card transactions, a third of the UK total. It has a database of 5m lost, stolen or delinquent "hot cards" against which your card is checked every time you use it.

Petrol forecourts aren't exactly "new economy" are they?

The big new thing in anti credit card fraud is checking that cards used to buy things over the internet are not fake. In the industry lingo, internet transactions are "card not present' (CNP) and are especially risky to the e-tailers, who bear the cost of a CNP fraud. Last year Retail Decisions checked 55m CNP transactions, small beer compared to its mainstream business, but widely considered to have huge growth potential.

Does it catch many fraudsters?

It reckons it saved UK retailers and card issuers £50m last year by detecting 210,000 potentially fraudulent transactions.

Lots of internet potential but no profits yet?

Unlike most other internet plays, Retail Decisions' position in the existing anti-fraud market (it's been going since 1991) makes it "cash generating" rather than "cash burning." Last year, on sales of £11.9m, it made profits of £2.4m. Its broker, Teather and Greenwood, gushes that the company is far from being an internet "blue sky" company, and that if and when the dot.coms hit the fan, Retail Decisions will survive. "If sentiment turns against the dot.coms, this company can ride out the storm," says technology analyst Alex Davies.

At last: an internet business that's going to make money.

Don't start counting the cash yet. T&G is pencilling in a fall in profits to only £0.2m this year as the company gears up its investment in e-commerce verification. But it expects profits to be £4m-plus in 2002. That doesn't make the shares cheap - even at 207p, below its peak of 350p, the company is valued at more than £350m. This means it is trading at 145 times its 1999 profits, or 1,750 times this year's expected profits. Compare that to the 30-40 times common in FTSE 100 stocks.

Its share price shot up, then shot down. Must have been some bad news?

Don't believe all you read in the press. In a bizarre episode, a story appeared in the Daily Telegraph on Thursday this week that Retail Decisions had signed a deal with Royal Bank of Scotland worth £36-£45m. The internet bulletin boards where traders swap gossip went into a frenzy.

So why didn't the share price enter the stratosphere?

Because the story was nonsense. RBoS declared that it was "completely false." The bulletin boards got wind of the fact by late morning. Instead of rising, the share price nosedived, falling 20% at one point. This was probably more to do with a continued dot.com shake-out on Nasdaq.

So was the story an attempt to ramp the share?

Certainly not by the newspaper. Perhaps someone tried to "sell" the story to the newspaper in the hope that the price would soar, and then offload their shares, but it didn't work because the share price fell. But it's a warning bell about the dangers of investing in small companies where incorrect 'newsflow', can have a dramatic impact on thinly-traded shares.

So what do the bulletin boards say?

Some think the recent fall is only the beginning. "Price below 200p. Next stop 100p," said "NotanotherIPO" at iii.co.uk. "If this stock is to recover then a miracle is required," warns "Jack Daniels" at iii. "The majority of postings seem to be nervous. If nervous then sell," claims "shedful" at fool.co.uk. But others think its recent setback is overdone. "Small investors are panicking because they think this is a dot.com and may crash. This company is already making money so there is nothing to worry about," said Robert Glenn on iii. "Hold tight and ride the rollercoaster. I've seen my holdings in RTD fall by 50% in eight days. Am I worried? No! I'm an investor that can see the true potential of this company," posted by Sarbjit Dhillon at iii.

webTitle: Agents try to charge for not selling flat

fields.headline: Agents try to charge for not selling flat
fields.standfirst: A couple are being pursued for nearly £9,500 in fees although the sale of their home fell through
fields.trailText: If there is one thing worse than forking out absurdly large sums to estate agents who have sold a property, it must be forking out to agents who haven't even done that. That prospect faces London couple Neil and Eleanor Cameron.
fields.body:
If there is one thing worse than forking out absurdly large sums to estate agents who have sold a property, it must be forking out to agents who haven't even done that.

That prospect faces London couple Neil and Eleanor Cameron who instructed local agents, FPD Savills to sell their three bedroom flat in Hampstead for £645,000. They agreed to pay Savills' standard rate of 2.5% plus VAT, though with a bit of haggling most agents would have accepted 1.5% or even 1%.

Had the agents sold the flat for the asking price, the bill would have been £18,947. On an hourly or weekly basis this sum would probably be equivalent to several times that charged by a top QC or private surgeon.

However, there was no sale. The buyers found by Savills tried to renegotiate the price downwards by £30,000 at the last minute. Although the buyers later reverted to their original offer, the Camerons did not feel this was acceptable behaviour and pulled out.

In a sense one might have sympathy for estate agents in this position who have put in the work but lost the fee through no fault of their own. On the other hand the only conceivable justification for the rates they charge for work that is by and large no more difficult than any other form of selling, is that they run this risk.

However, many other agents insert a clause in their standard contracts saying that they can charge - half the usual rate in Savills' case - if they find someone "ready willing and able to exchange contracts and terms are agreed". Savills has relied upon this clause to seek nearly £9,500 from the Camerons and has threatened county court proceedings if it is not paid.

The fact that their clause only applies if terms are agreed could scupper the claim. Many estate agents have conditions that provide for commission merely upon the prospective purchaser being ready, willing and able to pay the asking price.

A few even provide for some payment if the sellers take the house off the market before any buyer is found. Regulations introduced in 1991 require estate agents to provide clear information about these terms in their contractual documents. Even though the vast majority do comply with this, many purchasers like the Camerons do not read the terms closely.

This may give them an argument that the term was caught by the Unfair Terms in Consumer Contract Regulations, as the term wasn't drawn to their attention when they signed the agreement. It could be said that the clause was a penalty which required "a consumer who fails to fulfil his obligation to pay a disproportionately high sum in compensation", and hence potentially unenforceable.

A spokesman for Savills was adamant that it would proceed with the case. If the firm doesn't change its mind, and the Camerons remain equally set on defending, it could well lead to a precedent that clarifies the extent to which these regulations affect estate agents' charges.

When the use of the "ready willing and able purchaser" in agents' contracts became common place after the second world war, there were dozens of reported cases on their meaning, but they have led to very little recent litigation - meaning that clarification of the law would be welcome for consumers and the industry.

When the Camerons come to offer their flat for sale again, they will doubtless be tempted to follow the increasingly popular course of using an internet service, such as the one Elizabeth Langton featured in her column a couple of weeks ago. This will not only save them up to £20,000 in fees but also avoid the possibility of litigation.

Other vendors who still want to use traditional estate agents should remember the growth of these websites is making agents much more willing to negotiate on both their fees and terms.

A condition that requires payment if there is no sale can be regarded as little more than a try-on, which most agents will delete as soon as they are asked.

 Richard Colbey is a barrister

fields.headline: Preserving English values
fields.standfirst: Buying a house in a conservation area brings kudos - and cash. But it can also entai a host of stifling restrictions. Elizabeth Langer reports
fields.trailText: Buying a house in a conservation area brings kudos - and cash. But it can also entaila host of stifling restrictions.
fields.body:
However humble the house, if it's standing in a conservation area then it must be desirable. Estate agents leap on this status as a unique selling point and, in a slowing housing market, experts say the conservation area tag can add as much as £20,000 to the value of a property.

There are more than 8,000 conservation areas in England alone and the number is going up all the time, but there are downsides to enjoying the coveted status. Buyers could be in for a shock if they believe only the owners of listed buildings can be forced to take down porches and rip out replacement windows.

Homeowners who want to move could find the tag attracts buyers in droves, while those who want to stay put and improve or extend their home may find their plans severely restricted.

The planning battlefield is littered with casualties and, with this in mind, the government has commissioned English Heritage to draw up proposals to overhaul the system and speed up the decision-making process.

Under planning laws local authorities can protect areas of "special architectural or historic interest, the character or appearance of which it is desirable to preserve or enhance".

In designated areas, councils have extra powers to control the demolition of buildings, minor developments and protection of trees. In practice this means that householders in conservation areas have to apply for planning permission to carry out tasks that other homeowners can do without reference to the council such as applying cladding, installing dormer windows and putting up satellite dishes visible from the street.

Removing slate tiles from a roof and replacing them with concrete, changing the type of windows or demolishing a front wall to make way for an off-street parking space could all alter the unique character of an area, says Charles Wagner, English Heritage's adviser for London.

Laws introduced in 1995 gave councils far-reaching powers to protest about even the smallest details. Subject to local consultation, planning officials can prevent householders erecting porches, painting their house a different colour, or changing their doors or windows - although they must have good reasons for making the restrictions.

This applies even in some more modest areas: "Quite often homeowners aren't aware that they're living in a conservation areas unless the previous owner has passed the information on," says Mr Wagner. "Very often local authorities designate conservation areas if local opinion calls for it."

Occasionally, areas are designated when the character of an area is threatened by an unsuitable development.

Critics believe that councils are designating too many conservation areas and are devaluing the term in the process. There has to be sound architectural or historical reason behind the status. But over time our ideas change about what is and is not worth preserving for posterity.

The announcement that Erno Goldfinger's concrete Trellick Tower in north Kensington, London was a conservation area was greeted with horror by traditionalists. Most people would appreciate why Georgian terraces might be classed as a conservation area, but less obvious gems include garden estates built after the war, or high streets.

Local authorities have a duty to review conservation area boundaries from time to time and remove the status from areas that are no longer of special interest.

Some see conservation area status as blocking progress and preventing environmental improvements. In Hounslow, west London, the council is digging its heels in over awarding the status to the centre of Brentford near the Grand Union Canal.

The council wants developers to breathe new life into the area. English Heritage believes the regeneration should include protecting the locks, walls and bridges tucked away behind the high street and the organisation wants to designate the length of the Grand Union Canal that runs through Brentford as a conservation area.

The council, for its part, says the move would be inappropriate, as much of the area includes buildings of little interest constructed in the 60s. Hounslow says it has employed consultants to review the impact of all the development schemes in Brentford and hopes to reach a compromise.

If the situation becomes a stand-off, English Heritage could use its powers to override the council and go ahead with the designation anyway.

For Mr Wagner, conserving the built environment is about "balancing personal freedoms with protecting what people regard as local heritage".

Peter Studdert, vice-chair of the English Historic Towns Forum, says too many homeowners are in the dark about how living in a conservation area will affect them. Even dramatic makeovers aren't automatically ruled out, he says.

But buyers with plans to turn a humble cottage into a glass and steel palace worthy of Norman Foster should check with their local authority before carrying out home improvements that would be visible from the street.

webTitle: Drink a toast to the worm that turned

fields.headline: Drink a toast to the worm that turned
fields.standfirst: Early corkscrews are in demand among collectors, pushing prices far beyond some estimates, reports Stewart Dalby
fields.trailText: Early corkscrews are in demand among collectors, pushing prices far beyond some estimates.
fields.body:
Corkscrews are an area of collecting which can really surprise. In May 1997, Christie's South Kensington held a mould-breaking sale of 450 items belonging to the late Dr Bernard Watney. Until then it had been a little-known field; Dr Watney had put his collection together largely from rummaging around markets.

One piece was an early to middle 18th-century silver pocket corkscrew initialled EH 1743. It came in a case initialled AR Alexandra Regina and dated 1910. It was estimated to fetch £5,000 to £6,000; in fact, it made £16,350.

In one bound, corkscrews leapt from the junk shop to the auction room. There was a realisation that there was an infinite variety of corkscrews and, as there was clearly a dedicated band of collectors, they could realise serious sums.

Christie's holds at least two auctions a year and its next one is on May 3. Denis Cox, the expert in charge, says demand remains strong.

An early literary reference to corkscrews is thought to be in 1676 in A Treatise on Cider by J Worlidge. By the 17th century bottles were increasingly being used not just for wine but also for beers, spirits, medicines and cider.

The first corkscrew patent is ascribed to the Rev Samuel Henshall in 1795. He lived in Oxford and his invention, like so many great technical innovations, was brilliantly simple. He placed a fixed disc or button between the worm (twisty bit) and the shank. His design meant the worm would be prevented from advancing any further once the button reached the top of the bottle.

When the worm was halted it could only do one thing and that was to turn the cork in the neck of the bottle and so reduce friction and make the cork easier to extract. Until then corks had been removed by brute force, often resulting in wet servants.

Henshall's patent was the first of some 300 registered in England alone over the following 100 years. The next major development came in 1802 when a young engineer, Edward Thomason, who was later knighted, made pulling corks easier still. He devised a metal frame that sat on top of the bottle and positioned the worm above the centre of the cork so it would go in parallel to the neck. By using a hermaphrodite screw Thomason could insert the worm into the cork by screwing it one way then eject the cork by turning the other.

Many other inventions followed, including levers, pegs, bows and champagne taps. There are thought to be more than 3,000 patents around the world, all slightly different; some with brushes to dust the bottle, some with wire cutters, and so on. There is a large body of literature on the subject and a number of collectors' clubs.

Dr Watney was a founder member of the International Correspon dence of Corkscrew Addicts. This limits its members to 50 and there is a long waiting list to join. The main function of this group of very serious collectors is to correspond with one another and keep up to date on what is available.

The Canadian Corkscrew Collectors Club has an open membership and a branch in Britain.

Denis Cox says among dedicated collectors the interest is very much in looking for unusual or rare patents. Old Thomasons usually fetch from £200 to £300 upwards at auctions, although it is possible to pick them up in markets and shops for less.

The Christie's auction on May 3 is not as large as some sales. There are 150 lots and prices begin at £100. A 19th-century English, 11-tool, folding bow corkscrew with leather pouch, button hook, carriage key and corkscrew carries an estimate of £350.

The most expensive item is an 1852 Belgian patent belonging to Levaux Lemaitre. This is a lever corkscrew with a little brush for dusting the bottle. This is estimated to realise £5,000 to £6,000.

But you never can tell. If two addicts decide this is a piece they absolutely must have the estimates could mean little.

 For further information phone Christie's, 020-7581-7611
