"Maybe people will come for me now." Brooks agrees that he has changed, been politicised. He recently went to Northern Ireland and shared a platform with a family campaigning about sectarian killing and RUC neglect. Another day, another court case. This time, we're in one of the most salubrious parts of London, Regent's Park, as the Metropolitan Police argue that Brooks's racism case should be struck out. Outside, a little scene is being played out. A posh elderly woman shouts, "We're living in a police state, and I'm willing to go to prison for saying so." The rasta who has been at every one of Brooks's court appearances quietly ticks her off. "You not been there, lady, have you? Prison is the worst possible place, you know. They break you in prison." The barrister for the Police Federation starts proceedings by saying that whatever points he is going to make, they do not detract from the sympathy he offers to Mr Brooks for all that he has been through. He then launches into the most cynical, legalistic argument for why Brooks is not owed an apology from the police. Brooks sits there with his hands on his chin, stroking the beginnings of a goatee. What's he thinking about? The attack on Stephen and himself has defined his life - in many ways destroyed it, in some ways made it. As he reminds me when he's feeling most chipper: "Duwayne Brooks's evidence rocked the inquiry, it opened up everybody's eyes. If Duwayne Brooks had decided not to give evidence, not to give police statements, there would have been no investigation into the murder. If Duwayne Brooks had not decided to follow his friend that way, there would have been no suspects." The Old Bailey, March. Darren White says that he is going to try and have the sexual assault case thrown out as an abuse of process. He warns me to be prepared for an intense legalistic debate. A month after the defence asked for the updated notes of one of the officers, WPC Chapman, they have still not received them. Eventually, the notes arrive in court and confirm that, when the complainant suggested not going ahead, WPC Chapman met her and told her that, as a fully-bound witness, she could be arrested. We return the next day for more legal argument. Even the prosecutor agrees that there have been "disastrous" errors by the police. Brooks says that he is not worried about going to jail because, in the end, he knows the truth will come out. His friend tells me that the previous night he couldn't sleep. Soon after noon, the judge says he will retire to consider whether there has been an abuse of process. Over lunch, Brooks is quiet, reflective. Out of nowhere he starts talking about a docu-drama concerning the killing of Stephen that was on television a few years ago."They por-trayed us as rude boys, ragamuffins. I was so annoyed about that, boy, was I annoyed. They used the word ragamuffin. Ragamuffin ! He picks up my Guardian and reads a piece about the racist killing of Michael Menson. "'Police initially thought he had set fire to himself, but later decided that he had been the victim of a racially motivated attack.' That is wrong, they didn't decide. It should say they were forced to, after persistence of family and friends." It's 2pm, and we're called back into court. The judge says that the use of the mediator has been disastrous, that the police failed to brief her as to her role, and that then, when she did make her statement, they waited six weeks before asking her to sign it. "This delay is even more baffling . . . or worrying," he says. The prosecution, he says, has caused this situation with "a series of errors and misjudgments. Bearing in mind the conflicts and inconsistencies, it would be unfair to try Mr Brooks, therefore I will stay the proceedings." Outside the Old Bailey, Duwayne Brooks is wearing a huge smile. He makes a brief statement and dances down the street for the camera, arm in arm with his sister, Millie. "My little brother. You've got your life back again brother," she says as she buries her face in his chest. "We've only just begun," says Brooks. His friends are ecstatic, looking forward to tomorrow's headlines. In the event, Brooks is knocked off the front pages. Actually, many papers don't even report the case. It's not surprising that the Budget took precedence, but amazingly, on the very day Brooks is acquitted, the police announce that they have arrested three new suspects in the Stephen Lawrence case. The next day Brooks rings me. I ask whether he's been celebrating, and he mumbles an answer. He sounds upset. "You know the girl I've been staying with. Last night, her car was set on fire."

fields.headline: The guy can't help it
fields.standfirst: Bryan Ferry has always been an innovative, even daring musician, but it is the look, the sophistication, the Gatsby style, that fascinate. As much as ever in his new, torchy incarnation, he admits to Lindsay Baker
fields.trailText: Bryan Ferry has always been an innovative, even daring musician, but it is the look, the sophistication, the Gatsby style, that fascinate. As much as ever in his new, torchy incarnation, he admits to Lindsay Baker
fields.body:
We don't really like our rock stars to age. Should they be allowed, at 56 years of age, to wear leather trousers and persist in performing? As a rule, we prefer to think of them as they were in those early moments, when they first started to seep into our psyches. When Roxy Music appeared on Top Of The Pops in 1972, they seemed freakishly exciting and grown-up, with their futuristic rockabilly look. As the poised Bryan Ferry launched into the trilling, peculiarly hypnotic strains of their first single, Virginia Plain, it felt as if they had crashlanded into a landscape previously populated by lumpen Osmond brothers and over-sequined glam rockers.

Roxy Music were pure, distilled glamour. Through the 70s and early 80s, they reigned supreme, with hit after glorious hit, and, with the blonde and glossy Jerry Hall on his arm, Ferry became an icon of urbane cool and affluent sophistication. Roxy revamped the idioms and attitudes of popular music with their weird concoctions of oboe and synthesiser, their arrogant bravado, their visual flair, and their singer's half-drawled snarls and warbles.

So it comes as no great surprise that Ferry is such a picture of impeccable composure this evening in Amsterdam. It's only to be expected that he should saunter, unruffled, out of his dressing room, and - flanked by two staff - stride coolly down the backstage corridor that will take him to the stage and his expectant audience. Ferry doesn't do flustered. He is known, after all, as the master lounge lizard. Although he has written and produced some of the most innovative and exciting music of his time, the popular perception of Ferry is still invariably linked with one or other of his languorously elegant images.

On the afternoon before the Amsterdam concert, the floppy-haired, slightly craggy Ferry sits sipping sparkling water, and speaks quietly in a voice that wavers between plummy English gent and lilting Geordie. He is as you would imagine he would be - tall, handsome, elegant in his tweed jacket ("Savile Row") and cords.

Ferry has attained heights of sophistication so at odds with his upbringing as to seem improbable. Home was in a tiny, impoverished pit-village called Washington, near Durham; his father was a farmer and sometime pit-worker. Bryan was listening to music at five years old, and "obsessive" by the age of 10 or 11, ever since his Aunt Enid and her husband had met some GIs in Gibraltar, and returned home with a suitcase full of jazz records. As a boy, Bryan had a newspaper round, and he would read the music papers as he walked down the street.

He knew early on that he wanted to escape, that he didn't quite fit in. "I'm not sure if cuckoo's the right word," he muses, gazing absently out of the window, "but I remember feeling like I wanted to expand, go to New York, or go to London initially, which is pretty normal . . . for people to gravitate towards their capital city if they're ambitious." As a teenager, he travelled every Saturday to Newcastle, where he had a job in a tailor's shop. He used to love it when the teddy boys strolled into the shop. He would look on admiringly as they strutted like peacocks in their velvet-collared jackets. He saved his wages to buy winklepickers and Italian suits - and jazz music.

He admits freely that, for the purposes of the most recent album, As Time Goes By - a collection of 30s standards, many of which feature on the current tour - he borrowed from the style and phrasing of Billie Holiday in her 30s period, and her arranger Teddy Wilson. One of the first records he remembers buying was an EP by the Charlie Parker Quintet with Miles Davis. On As Time Goes By, he returns to the likes of Cole Porter's You Do Something To Me and Miss Otis Regrets, and Kahn and Donaldson's Love Me Or Leave Me. It is not the first time that Ferry has revisited the songs of his youth and long before - they also featured on earlier albums such as These Foolish Things, Another Time, Another Place and Taxi. The songs on this latest album are not all melancholic, but many are, and most are love songs. It seems appropriate Ferry territory. The sweeping anguish and grand romanticism of earlier songs such as Carrickfergus, Dance Away and Over You have always suggested something of the doomed romantic about Ferry. "Most of the great songs are love songs, it's as simple as that. Whether I'm that romantic, I don't know - as much as a northern boy can be," he laughs.

His childhood wasn't hard, he insists. "It depends how spoilt you are now. We didn't have a car or a telephone or a fridge, we lived in a Coronation Street-type terraced house, and went to the local school. I worked in all the holidays to make money. We always felt poor, I guess, but I was never deprived of anything. I just had to go out and work for the extra things." He loved Newcastle. He remembers a mod clothing shop called City Stylish, one of his favourites. "Newcastle was a mod stronghold, really." When he goes there now, all of these memories come back to him, he says. He still feels a closeness to the north. "The light you get up there is quite clear and hard and crisp," he says, gazing into the distance. Would he move back? "I wouldn't mind living on the Borders. I don't know if I ever will, but when I go up there I do think, 'God's own country'."

After jazz, Hendrix was his next love, and then, when studying fine art at Newcastle University, he favoured the "more esoteric art music" of John Cage and his ilk, "but only up to a point". The look of things was always crucial. Ferry was taught by Pop artist Richard Hamilton at art college, and it was his influence that spawned the "cover girl" look of the Roxy album sleeves. "To go that route seemed the only option," he says. "I mean, we could've had a picture of the band, looking rather glum, which was normal, standing on a cobbled street or something. But I didn't fancy that. The pin-up was a great way to sell things traditionally, whether it was a Cadillac or a Coke bottle or a packet of cigarettes."

It's easy to forget that rock was a rather austere domain in the early 70s. Roxy's album sleeves were in a league of their own, and there was always an element of pastiche about the aesthetic: from the Betty Grable-style shot that adorned their first, eponymous album onwards, they introduced a new, semi-ironic glossiness to rock music. Designer Antony Price helped with the styling, and every element, from the photography to the typeface, was planned in meticulous detail. The style was much imitated in ensuing years, and the covers still possess an iconic quality. "I'm quite proud of that, really," says Ferry, "because I never got a chance to do anything else, visually. I chose not to paint any more after I started to do records."

The look hovered somewhere between sophisticated lingerie advertising and softcore pornography, and the album Country Life - which featured on its cover models in their knickers, posing as socialites caught in the headlights of a car, as if in the midst of some wild country-house party - was banned in the US. Ferry took any objections to the cover-girl sleeves in his stride. "It wasn't a case of putting anyone down," he says evenly. "They were kind of tributes. A celebration of female glamour, if you like. They weren't done with any bad feeling at all."

The mermaid with the killer fingernails and the come-hither expression on the cover of the 1975 album Siren was Jerry Hall, hired by Ferry. She soon moved into his Los Angeles mansion - she was 18 and he was 30 - and for two years they were a most dazzling item. She even performed the memorable, high-pitched yelps on the classic Let's Stick Together of 1976. It was Ferry, so the story goes, who introduced her to his friend Mick Jagger. Nothing happened until Ferry went on tour to Japan and Australia, declaring - Hall later claimed - that he would not be calling her because it was too expensive. She was furious ("I mean, he was a rock star!" she later commented), and went to New York where she came across both Jagger and Warren Beatty at a dinner party. Both men were interested in the statuesque Texan blonde, but it was Jagger who took her home. "That was it," she said later. "I behaved very badly. No excuse."

What with Roxy's growing success in the States allowing for an increasingly glossy lifestyle, fantasy and reality began to blur for Ferry, not least during the Jerry Hall phase - he, the dashing, white- tuxedoed lounge lizard; she, the goddess-like übermodel. By the end of the 70s, with the release of Roxy album number six, Manifesto, the intended irony of the Roxy sensibility was beginning to fade. The New Musical Express took to calling him Byron Ferrari.

He already owned a country pile in picturesque West Sussex, and when he married society gel Lucy Helmore in 1982, it was all too much for some commentators, who branded him a fake country gent and an arriviste. Much was made of the difference in backgrounds of the couple, but, he points out, she wasn't the first person he'd met from a different class. There are differences, of course, he says. North, south. She went to boarding school, he didn't. He went to university, she didn't. She is 14 years his junior. "But she's not an heiress, as was often claimed, with a stately home," he says. "Not a sausage," he adds with a laugh.

The couple have four boys, and the eldest, Otis, now lives in Ireland where he works for a horse dealer. "Which is funny, because that's what my dad always liked. He grew up on a farm, and during the depression the farm failed and he had to go and look after the horses underground in the pit. He worked with horses all his life, and then last year, with Otis, horses have taken over." Lucy also loves riding. And she "takes very good photographs, which people don't know". He likes the countryside, and "wearing tweed jackets", but he's fond of the city too, which is just as well, he says, since he's there five out of every seven days.

His wife doesn't much like being written about, he tells me, which is not so surprising. He has, in the past, referred to the marriage as "turbulent", and in interviews described her as "a Virgo . . . not easy", and as "Garbo-esque". In 1993, she revealed that she had been admitted to a rehab clinic to be treated for drink and drug dependency, and Ferry admitted at the time that he was prone to depression. An obsessive career in music has its drawbacks: "The other side of your life suffers, that's for sure, but I'm not crying about it." His marriage has survived. "We've managed to keep it together all this time," he says with a smile.

The Ferry aesthetic is rather more subdued these days than at its height of febrile Roxy sensuality, and has been for a number of years. He chose an image of a horse for the sleeve of his 1994 album Mamouna. "That went down like a lead balloon," he laughs. It must, after all, have been rather wearing, being so mercilessly cutting-edge in the 70s and early 80s; that high-octane, highly-sexed sensibility, you would imagine, might wear thin in middle age. Is this new, nostalgic preoccupation a kind of backlash, I wonder, against the unrelenting edginess and modernity of the Roxy days. "Yes," he agrees. "Or a backwater . . . a salmon pool," he chuckles. He's particularly pleased with his orchestra, which includes a classically-trained brass section as well as the strings. "As soon as you start having strings, you stop calling it a band. They're not used to this kind of rock'n'roll touring, which means they're not jaded old session players, so it feels very fresh. There are no guitars thrashing about or anything like that - it's more subdued, more intimate." There are three tour buses, and Ferry, I'm told, prefers to travel on the bus with the all-female string quartet (along with his wardrobe master and the sound director, Ferry's old friend and Avalon producer, Rhett Davies). It's the no-smoking bus. All very civilised.

Ferry also seems rather to relish the freedom from fashion that comes with the old standards territory, though he is still a fan of some contemporary music - Beck, Radiohead, Missy Eliot, Macy Gray, Massive Attack, Tricky. "But I don't hear much that blows me away. This record is different from all that, and that's why I'm pleased that it's done well, because it's not for MTV. There isn't even a video. It just exists like an old gramophone record." He draws a comparison with the recent, hugely successful Buena Vista Social Club album. "It's very refreshing that a record that's against the time can do so well."

All in all, he seems to be rather enjoying this more mellow phase of his career. Making the album was "really angst-free, which was a real change for me with record making. I put a lot into it, and as a rule it can be quite traumatic, but with this it was as if I'd been waiting to do it for many years and suddenly it all came rushing out." In the past, his voice has been buried in the mix, but now the approach is different: "The songs are so strong that just to sing them like a conventional singer felt very new to me." The record has done pretty well, considering the low-key approach, selling 500,000 copies worldwide, and although stadium gigs are a thing of the past the new European tour has been a sell-out.

He spends his money, he says, on "decorating" his life - "having things around you that you like to look at", and collects art from the first half of the last century, particularly the Bloomsbury artists. "Not really great art, but decorative, cosy to live with." He has no plans to leave England, though the idea of a warm climate does appeal, he says, citing Noël Coward and Ian Fleming and their elegant, Caribbean idylls.

The self-made glamour of Ferry's persona and the romantic despair that undertows much of his music have led to comparisons with that well-known figure of fatal elegance, Gatsby, a victim of his own aspiration who kept others at a distance with his affluence. "I've been compared to Dracula as well," he responds, with a loud, throaty laugh. He doesn't seem too averse to the Gatsby notion, though; he is a fan of Fitzgerald, along with Waugh, "very stylish writers". "He's a romantic figure, old Gatsby, isn't he - a sad, lost, lonely figure. . ." he smiles. "I always identified with the blues and sad songs that seemed to be deep and mean something, you know, rather than a jingle on a Cornflakes ad. But there's lots of jolly music, too: Do The Strand - that's a lark, one of my best songs. But the bulk of them do tend to be introverted and introspective and doom and gloom." He pauses and gazes out of the window. "My mother was a very emotional person. So am I." Not exactly prone to melancholy, he says, but "soft-hearted, she always cried at things that upset her, any kind of cruelty. Tender hearted. She wasn't a hard woman. The opposite."

From 1976, his parents lived until the end of their lives in a cottage on the grounds of his estate in Sussex; his father died in 1984, his mother in 1991. Their deaths shook Ferry, and his sons felt their absence, too. He says that he has "tried to make a normal life" in order to balance his obsession with music, and doesn't think that fame and success have changed him fundamentally. "You tend to feel the same as when you were a teenager - you don't really change that much. You have different concerns, different worries. You have a family, and that multiplies all the things you have to think about. Certainly since 1982, when I started having a family, I've tried to have a sense of normality in my life, because the rest of it can be a bit bizarre. My children are very important to me, very high on my priority list - but then, so is my work. I've always put so much into my work. It's great that I still have an audience who appreciates it." Is he happy? "Well, it's not a word I bandy around so much . . ." he says, and stares into the distance, looking neither quite happy nor quite unhappy. Later this year there will be a "rock album", which he has been working on with Rhett Davies and Roxy Music founder member Brian Eno. It's not quite a Roxy reunion, but a tour is not out of the question.

On stage that evening at the elegant, classical venue Concert Gebouw, Ferry sweeps through the old standards with aplomb. The show is polished and beautifully crafted; his voice is mesmerising. A mirrorball rotates, casting luminous snowflakes around the auditorium as he launches, light and whimsical, into Just One Of Those Things; his version of the Dietrich classic Falling in Love Again is peculiarly intense and plaintive. It is a perfect set for the rock star growing old gracefully.

Which is, presumably, the whole idea. Ferry, the art-school graduate, has always known how to put together a persona. He and his fantasy world have always been on intimate terms, so it must come easily to him now - to construct an image (the mature, sophisticated crooner beyond fashion) and then to inhabit it with great assurance and equanimity. So, at 54, he still gets to wear the leather trousers, but with a dinner jacket - a combination that he carries off with a languorous, long-legged charm. If there was a time when he felt trapped in his own Gatsbyesque world, his private life the victim of his aspirations, then it seems that time has passed. For all his self-mythologising, Ferry has a rather appealing self-awareness about him. The cover of As Time Goes By is adorned with elegant, demure fashion illustrations from the 1930s. He dislikes using images of himself these days, he says, "because you can never find enough glamorous photographs of yourself. And that's worrying if you're vain," he adds, laughing. "As the years go by, you feel the same inside but you look slightly different."

 Bryan Ferry plays the Royal Albert Hall, London, on April 11. As Time Goes By is out on Virgin Records.

Not exactly prone to melancholy, he says, but "soft-hearted, she always cried at things that upset her, any kind of cruelty. Tender hearted. She wasn't a hard woman. The opposite." From 1976, his parents lived until the end of their lives in a cottage on the grounds of his estate in Sussex; his father died in 1984, his mother in 1991. Their deaths shook Ferry, and his sons felt their absence, too. He says that he has "tried to make a normal life" in order to balance his obsession with music, and doesn't think that fame and success have changed him fundamentally. "You tend to feel the same as when you were a teenager - you don't really change that much. You have different concerns, different worries. You have a family, and that multiplies all the things you have to think about. Certainly since 1982, when I started having a family, I've tried to have a sense of normality in my life, because the rest of it can be a bit bizarre. My children are very important to me, very high on my priority list - but then, so is my work. I've always put so much into my work. It's great that I still have an audience who appreciates it." Is he happy? "Well, it's not a word I bandy around so much . . ." he says, and stares into the distance, looking neither quite happy nor quite unhappy. Later this year there will be a "rock album", which he has been working on with Rhett Davies and Roxy Music founder member Brian Eno. It's not quite a Roxy reunion, but a tour is not out of the question. On stage that evening at the elegant, classical venue Concert Gebouw, Ferry sweeps through the old standards with aplomb. The show is polished and beautifully crafted; his voice is mesmerising. A mirrorball rotates, casting luminous snowflakes around the auditorium as he launches, light and whimsical, into Just One Of Those Things; his version of the Dietrich classic Falling in Love Again is peculiarly intense and plaintive. It is a perfect set for the rock star growing old gracefully. Which is, presumably, the whole idea. Ferry, the art-school graduate, has always known how to put together a persona. He and his fantasy world have always been on intimate terms, so it must come easily to him now - to construct an image (the mature, sophisticated crooner beyond fashion) and then to inhabit it with great assurance and equanimity. For all his self-mythologising, Ferry has a rather appealing self-awareness about him. The cover of As Time Goes By is adorned with elegant, demure fashion illustrations from the 1930s. He dislikes using images of himself these days, he says, "because you can never find enough glamorous photographs of yourself. And that's worrying if you're vain," he adds, laughing. "As the years go by, you feel the same inside but you look slightly different."  Bryan Ferry plays the Royal Albert Hall, London, on April 11. As Time Goes By is out on Virgin Records.

fields.headline: All for one
fields.standfirst: There they were - three sisters, living continents apart, and suddenly each was expecting a child. Were there rivalries? Maybe a few, Tania Unsworth confides, but she wonders whether they will ever know such togetherness again
fields.trailText: There they were - three sisters, living continents apart, and suddenly each was expecting a child. Were there rivalries? Maybe a few, Tania Unsworth confides, but she wonders whether they will ever know such togetherness again
fields.body:
At the time, I thought it was just coincidence, but now I see that we must have set each other off. What else but dormant sibling rivalry - the desire not to be outdone, or simply left behind - could have prompted this collective impulse towards parenthood? When giving the news of my pregnancy to friends, I tried to be nonchalant about the fact that both my sisters were in the same situation. That the three of us - all in our 30s, living in different cities and, in my case, in a different continent - had taken it into our heads to have babies within the same year. But it was impossible. In the end, I resorted to a single statement. "The Unsworths," I took to announcing, rather grandly, "are spawning."

Up until this point, our reproductive tally had been meagre in the extreme. Ten years before, my older sister, Madeleine, had given birth to Felix, who for a whole decade had enjoyed the kind of status afforded to an endangered baby panda in London Zoo. His every movement was tracked and marvelled over by a gaggle of grandparents, aunts and uncles. One Easter Sunday in the early 90s, no fewer than eight adults trailed his unsteady progress during an egg hunt, watching as he filled his basket with more chocolate than half-a-dozen children could possibly eat in a week. Now, in the space of a few months, his long reign was about to come to an abrupt end.

Our mother was in a daze. She seemed to oscillate between pleasure and a piercing fear for our collective health. As though the sudden wealth of grandchildren to come had become muddled in her mind. Not three daughters having separate babies, but one child having three at once. After her fervent wish that we would all make it through labour alive, she wanted at least one of us to have a girl. I was certain it would be me.

We all became pregnant in ways that now seem typical of our characters. My big sister first, of course. She had always done everything first. And, true to form, it was difficult. There was more than a year of trying to conceive, during which time she suffered the frightening indignities of a lost IUD, an emergency operation to remove a polyp and her GP casually (or so it seemed) telling her that it might be too late since she was probably going through early menopause.

At some stage during this process, I decided that I, too, was ready for motherhood. I was perfectly sure that all it would take was for me to throw away my pills and have sex a couple of times. Mentally, I rehearsed what I would say to my older sister when I gave her the news. I would have to be very gentle, since she would still be struggling to get pregnant. I thought that perhaps I could offer - sometime down the line - to be a surrogate mother for her. I was quite taken with the nobleness of this gesture.

During the first few months of trying to conceive my own child, I would imagine what it would like to be pregnant with my sister's. I had got to the part where I, with a tearful - but ineffably brave - smile, was on the point of handing the newborn into her arms when she gave me the startling news that she had become pregnant all by herself.

I was overjoyed, and then I was overcome by panic. If she could do it, why couldn't I? For the next five months, I tormented anyone who would listen with my fears that there was something wrong with me. Each time I called my family from my home in Boston, US, there would be a short expectant pause before I gave the news that nothing had happened yet, and that no, they shouldn't worry, because I felt all right about it. Really all right. I went to the UK for a visit, and my big sister took me to Boots to buy an ovulation predictor kit. As we walked back, I frantically ripped open the wrapper to read the instructions. "I know lots of people who've used them," she said. "They do work, I promise." I could tell that she felt bad for me. I didn't want her to feel guilty, but I knew she did.

And then, when she was seven months pregnant, it happened. With the test still in my hand, I dialled both my sisters to give them the news. Three days later, Maddy called me back. "I don't know how to tell you this," she said, "you must think it's funny coming from me . . ." My little sister, Thomasina, was pregnant, too. She had conceived two weeks earlier than me. Quickly and quietly, keeping the news a secret, not wanting to upset me, and then, when she heard I was pregnant, not wanting to steal my thunder. She was always kind. The sweet sister. I know she disliked this label and felt typecast by it, but it was true.

"How long were you going to keep it from me?" I asked her.

"I just don't know," she said helplessly. "For as long as possible, I suppose."

"I didn't even know you were trying." It struck me how very secretive she was. How there had always been things I didn't know about her. "It would have been spoiled if you hadn't got pregnant, too," she said. "What do you think you're having?"

"Probably a boy," I said, feeling convinced I was carrying a girl. I put my hands on my stomach in the way that newly pregnant women do. With a kind of hesitant, fearful wonder. Each time I did it, it seemed I was touching my sisters' unborn children along with my own. It made me think of Christmas Eve. Of the three of us as children, hanging up our stockings, waiting for a transformation no less miraculous for all its inevitability. The same sense then, as now, of all being in it together, our excitement feeding off each other, our hopes inseparable.

"Are you frightened?" my little sister asked. I told her I was going to ask for painkillers as soon as labour began. Before it began. She said she was going to try yoga and breathing techniques. Maddy and I were sceptical about this approach. It was not that we thought natural childbirth was sure to fail. Just the opposite. If Tom was going to be able to get through labour armed with nothing more than a zen-like attitude and a couple of visualisation exercises, it would make the pair of us look like whining junkies, shrieking for our gas and air and lovely - oh how lovely - epidurals.

But, by this stage, Maddy was beyond caring how much labour might hurt. She just wanted the baby out. Every day, she said, she would waddle down to the bakery around the corner from her house. Sticky buns had become her only joy in life. Between ourselves, Thomasina and I tutted at the weight she must be putting on. Still svelte from throwing up every other day, we decided we would not gain more than one pound a week throughout our pregnancies. As soon as our babies were born, we would start a strict regimen of exercise to get rid of what small amount of flab we might have accumulated.

A few weeks later, after a short but fierce labour, Jack was born. Maddy sent me a photograph taken minutes after the birth. The picture was slightly out of focus. I thought it captured how she must have felt at that moment. Bleary with relief and pride, unsure around her edges. "Jack has the most peculiar face," Maddy told me over the phone. "He's not exactly a looker." It was always her style to downplay momentous events. Self-denigrating quips were a speciality of hers.

Thomasina, on the other hand, seemed to be revelling in the drama of pregnancy. On a trip back home for a friend's wedding, I noticed that she could barely go five minutes without stroking her stomach. Maddy and I watched her on the dancefloor, spinning dreamily, one hand resting on her bulge. "Why does she have to keep drawing attention to it?" I asked. I tried to dance as though being pregnant was a complete irrelevance, swinging my arms briskly, blithely ignoring the fact that I couldn't quite see what my feet were doing. I must have looked completely ridiculous.

Thomasina had decided she wouldn't find out her baby's gender before it was born, but I needed to know as early as possible. I had started fingering tiny dresses in shops and wanted to decide on a name for my girl. I could already see her in my mind's eye. Brown eyes, blonde curly hair, an ethereal air to her.

The ultrasound technician had an unfeasibly loud voice. "You're having a boy!" he bellowed as he swept the paddle across my stomach. He laughed heartily. "Look at him kick. A real football player!" On the way home in the car, I wept from confusion and defeated expectation. "He'll be lovely," my little sister told me over the phone.

"But he's going to be a jock," I protested.

"You'll love him. I know you will."

She came to visit me in Boston when we were both six months pregnant. It was late summer and we sat on the beach in our maternity swimsuits, stomachs pointing towards the ocean. We talked about our older sister, still submerged in the semi-purdah of early motherhood. Jack was colicky, and Maddy had struggled through a bout of mastitis. She seemed to be teetering on the verge of bad post-natal depression. But in the sunshine, half-hypnotised by the sound of the surf, these problems seemed far away. We would have calm babies, we told each other, because we would be calm mothers. We would carry our babies around in slings everywhere we went. Maddy was always so tense about everything, we agreed. She had never learned how to relax.

The truth was that we didn't want to think about the realities of parenthood. We wanted, I think, for that one day, to be contained forever in our pregnancy. In that small, still place between the revolutions of conception and birth. Sitting there, Thomasina said, with both of us pregnant, made her think of our childhood. "Do you think the cousins will play on the beach together like we did?" she asked. I thought they would. At that moment it seemed easy to think that our lives would continue endlessly parallel, that there was a pattern that would keep us always together. But underneath I knew that this was perhaps the last time I would think like this. Birth had drawn us together, and soon it would scatter us. Changing us all in ways we couldn't yet imagine, giving us new patterns of allegiance.

We went and ate hamburgers at a restaurant on the beach. The plan to keep our weight under control had been completely abandoned. "I have cellulite on my ankles," my little sister said as she crammed onion rings into her mouth. "I mean, is that even possible?"

Back at the house, we called Maddy. She sounded busy and very cross. She knew we had been talking about her. Later, she told me it had been difficult for her to think of us together with our stomachs still round while hers was empty and saggy. She felt out of the club. She wondered whether, after all, we'd find birth and early motherhood easier than she had done, and that this would be proof that she really was no good at it. We would not understand what she had been complaining about. We'd be better organised, better mothers. Over the phone, we told her about the trendy boot-cut leggings that we had bought at Guess. "I hope they've got strong elastic in the waistband," she said rather bitterly.

Thomasina went home and we called each other almost every day to compare notes and discuss what a Braxton Hicks contraction might feel like and whether Body Shop cocoa butter was really any good for stretch marks. I had started to feel heavy and uncomfortable and wretched with back ache, but during the conversations with my sister it was still possible to imagine that the whole thing was something of a lark. A kind of game that could end whenever we decided to stop playing.

Thomasina went past her due date and we continued to talk as though we might be pregnant forever. Then she called me to tell me she was in labour. She was in hospital, in bed, talking to me from the telephone on the ward. It was really happening. "What's it like?" I said. "Tell me everything."

"It doesn't hurt. Honestly. It doesn't. It's fine." She gave a little gasp as she said this and put the phone down shortly after. Poor Thomasina. She was still being kind. She couldn't bring herself to tell me the truth. That the yoga had failed, her epidural hadn't taken, her cervix had refused to dilate and doctors were muttering about doing a caesarean. Much later, she confessed that on a pain scale of one to 10, with one being a mild headache and 10 being tortured by the Gestapo all night, it scored an easy 15. Isobel was born in the early hours of the morning and suddenly, I was all alone. The last egg left in the box. Down the phone I heard the thin cries of the newborn.

"Trust you to get the girl," I said.

"We're all waiting on you now," she said.

My labour, 10 days later, was almost as easy as it gets. My doctor told me it was a textbook case. A swift dilation, a timely epidural. I was watching CHiPs on the television and marvelling how I ever fancied Erik Estrada when the doctor told me I could start to push. My husband, geared up for fear and torment, stood about feeling redundant, a paper cup of unwanted ice-chips in his hand. I called Thomasina from the phone by the bed, listening to it ring thousands of miles away and wondering at the strangeness of the world.

"I'm doing it!" I said. "I'm watching CHiPs and having a baby."

"You don't have to be brave," she said. "If it's bad, you don't have to be brave with me. Just hang in there. We're all thinking of you."

"It isn't bad! Was it like this for you?"

She muttered something I couldn't hear.

"I'll call you again when he's born," I said merrily. "It shouldn't be long now."

We will never all be pregnant at the same time again. Maddy is not having any more children. Thomasina and I have not made up our minds when, or if, we'll add to our families. But I like to think that the babies the three of us produced in a single year will be closer than mere cousins. Jack, Isobel and Oscar. The names go well together. Last month, during a trip back home, we sat in a room and watched our children with a feeling close to astonishment. We three had become six.

It seemed a kind of miracle.

None of the babies looks like each other. You wouldn't be able to tell they are related. Jack is big and bold and naughty looking, Isobel blonde and smiley, Oscar is small with dark hair and skin. But we can see similarities. One has Maddy's dimple, another has my eyes, a third the long line of Thomasina's cheek. When we look at our children, we see our sisters there.

fields.headline: Superplonk
fields.trailText: Malcolm Gluck runs out of ammo
fields.body:
I have been manning this outpost for 11 years, and for the first time, in spite of being fortified at my elbow by a bottle of Robert Mondavi Coastal Merlot 1997 (16 points, out of 20, £9.99 at Tesco), my ammunition seems to have run out. That is to say, I have no idea how to shape this week s column, let alone begin it. I have, at least, achieved some measure of success with the latter objective, but as for what follows, I do not have a clue how to proceed.

Writer's block, is it called? Or is that the name of a particularly inky South Australian shiraz? Mondavi s merlot, from California, is not remotely this colour, being a rather light shade of red (which belies its 13.5% alcohol), but it is teasingly cheroot-scented and is, for want of a fancier description, bloody delicious.

But still the words, unlike the wine, won t flow. My wine notes are before me, as usual, but I struggle for context. My apologies, but I can only plunge in and hope for the best. The wine has a certain coyness, a studied lack of flamboyance, so perhaps I ve caught it.

Safeway. Shall we go there? I have tasted recently three interesting reds from this maddening retailer (maddening, as readers often find disparity in pricing, despite my thorough checking before this column goes to press) and these are Acacias Estate Merlot 1998 (16 points, £4.99), from Chile, Landskroon Shiraz 1998 (16 points, £6.49), from South Africa, and Domaine des Lauriers Faugeres 1997 (17 points, £5.59), from France.

The Chilean is magnificently dry and tannin-edged, making it superb with challenging dishes and concentrated authors (Ivy Compton-Burnett, for example). The Cape wine is juicy yet very dry, with a charcoal-richness and a hint of tobacco on the finish. The French wine, just coming into store, parades hedgerows and herbs, earth and orchards - it's got the lot - plus the antioxidental magic of tannins and a very low price ticket (for such well-knitted complexity). Anyone looking for an affordable wine to lay down - for no more than a couple of years, mind - could do a great deal worse than this virile specimen.

At Somerfield, there is Bright Brothers Negroamaro Cabernet Conti Zecca 1998 (15.5 points, £4.49), from Italy, which is delightfully soft and vibrant. It has an insouciance that is unsuppressible, and it is pleasing that Mr Peter Bright, the Aussie who was the wine s midwife, has not tried to polish it overmuch. Somerfield s Cabernet/Merlot Vina La Rosa 1998 (15.5 points, £3.99) is from Chile, and hugely gluggable and cockle-warming it is, too. It has depth and sunniness, and, more impressively - despite a price considered vulgar, not to say gutter-low, by the snob - has great texture and presence on the palate.

At Waitrose, a retailer that is beginning to innovate on various fronts with a degree of wit and precision, there is the richly engaging Sicilian Nero d'Avola/ Syrah 1998 (15.5 points, £3.95) and, frankly, it is a drop-dead fruitily gorgeous bargain. It pertinently fills a number of roles: quaffer, booker, TV-er, music accompanist and, being Italian, is an excellent partner to a range of dishes, from pasta to polenta to pizza.

Two excellent 16-point reds at Waitrose are Chapel Hill Barrique-Aged Cabernet Sauvignon 1997 (£4.99), from Hungary, and Savanha Merlot 1998 (£5.99), from South Africa. The Magyar offers handsomely woody fruit, which is developing marvellously in bottle, and has an elegance beyond its price ticket. The South African has a lovely throaty richness and an impactful leathery texture.

At Sainsbury, until April 8, there is a trio of reduced-price Chileans: Santa Carolina Chardonnay 1999 (16 points, £3.49), Valdivieso Cabernet Sauvignon 1998 (16 points, £3.79) and the own-label Cabernet Sauvignon (15.5 points, £3.49). All decisively fruity; each daftly priced. The Coastal merlot, I see, has sunk considerably in bottle since I opened it. Indeed, it is the end for both of us. Time, I think, for a nap.

fields.headline: The flour of my secret
fields.standfirst: A single mother and her daughter yearn to bake well. Piece of cake, says Robin Stummer, looking on as Kitchen Doctor Rosie Sykes rises to the occasion
fields.trailText: A single mother and her daughter yearn to bake well. Piece of cake, says Robin Stummer, looking on as Kitchen Doctor Rosie Sykes rises to the occasion
fields.body:
Transfixed she was; gooseberry-eyed through a window in south London. Willow may well be the first cat in history to learn the secrets of making a fine, fault-less, no-fuss florentine. Willow's co-habitants, Joan Byrne and daughter Carlotta, 11, were rather fascinated, too, as the Kitchen Doctor, or KD, rustled up a crash-course in how to bake cakes with minimal cash yet maximum panache. While young Carlotta is no novice baker, she had come to sense a certain floppiness in her skills, while, at least in these matters, mum Joan saw her role as supervisory. Yet Joan did harbour one burning desire: to learn the secrets of cake-making without flour.

And so it was that Rosie Sykes, our KD, found herself bound for Peckham. Within minutes of arriving at Schloss Byrne, she had thrown herself and her latest protégée-cum-patient, Carlotta, deep into the lemony mix of the school cake. Since school is one of Carlotta's key preoccupations at the moment, KD had created this cake to be broadly in the spirit of school days. Accordingly, it is heavily dependent on semolina, which takes the place of flour. It is also heavily dependent on a thorough whisking. So, before you could say core curriculum, Carlotta was steering a robust electric whisk around the mixing bowl.

After closely watching the blender perform dozens of figures-of-eight around the bowl, Willow was thoroughly hypnotised and Joan had beaten a retreat to the living room, but the bowl's contents resembled a light, lemony cloud and were, as Rosie declared, "Ready".

Next, KD revealed the extent of that morning's shop in downtown Peckham: organic currants, something called crystallised citron, huge muscatel berries from Australia, chocolate and chocolate and more chocolate. After half-an-hour or so, the school cake was placed in the oven and work began on the next project: moussey chocolate cake. Again, Carlotta's skills in the whisking department were called on until the desired moussey peak-and-trough moonscape was achieved.

By now, the kitchen microclimate had progressed from south London temperate to Amazon Basin tropical. The effect of half-a-dozen bodies in a relatively confined space, combined with an oven at full blast, began to take its toll on the KD, whose face was turning crimson. Even Willow began to wilt.

Luckily, help was at hand. On this call-out, KD had brought along Invaluable Imogen, whose lot it was to peel, scrape, wash and chop, and this she did with good cheer, apparently oblivious to the heat that was threatening to bake cakes outside the oven. Every cook should have an Invaluable Imogen.

Despite the pace slowing due to heat exhaustion, Rosie remained mindful that she was in these strangers' kitchen not to expire on the floor but to educate. So she seized a pair of knives, fixed Carlotta with an intense gaze, and said, "And now, we're going to learn the very exciting rubbing-in method." Pretty basic stuff, she confessed, but still something that all would-be bakers should get to grips with.

Carlotta watched as Rosie made merry with butter and flour, then took over herself. The key, it was explained, was to rub-in gently but methodically (in this case, extremely methodically), but the ends certainly justified the means.

By now, it was time to investigate the school cake. Taken out of the oven, it appeared fully baked and golden-brown, but a well-aimed, firm prod didn't give that firm, spongy feel, and instead caused ripples like a pebble in a pond. Back into the oven: which just shows that baking times serve as a rough guide, since ovens vary so much in character that, ultimately, the firm prod remains the most reliable test to sort baked from unbaked.

But what of the florentines? The first batch was retrieved from the oven, where they had been baking for just a few minutes. In that time, they'd expanded from two-inch-high dollops to four-inch-across dollops, and looked exquisite. Everyone made that mmooaggh farmyard-type noise of approval, but Rosie was having none of it. "In the bin!" she commanded. "We'll do them again!" The florentines had, it appeared, lingered a minute or two too long in the oven. With no one daring to voice dissent, the next batch was hastily prepared.

Meanwhile, the hokey-pokey biscuit mix was assailed with a fork, and then the second batch of florentines emerged - this time with no trace of sunburn. By now, Rosie was decelerating from her normal cruising speed, the kitchen was transformed into a hothouse of sweet, exotic smells, Imogen had mastered the washing-up, Willow was loitering in the wings and the Byrnes had learned a thing or three about baking. All that was left to do was eat.

All recipes serve six.

Important points to remember about baking:

 Accuracy in measuring, temperature and cooking time is all-important.

 Always preheat the oven.

 Bake on the middle shelf of the oven.

 Air is one of the mose important ingredients in cakes.

 Use eggs that are at room temperature.

Moussey chocolate cake

5 eggs, separated

125g caster sugar

125g butter, cut into cubes

250g plain chocolate

Pinch of salt

1 tbsp brandy (or anything from Cointreau to Tia Maria), optional

Preheat the oven to 175C/350F/gas mark 4. Break the chocolate into smallish pieces, place in a bowl with the butter (and the alcohol, if using) and cover. Put the bowl over a pan of hot water, and stir every now and then, until the chocolate has melted.

Line the base of a cake tin with greaseproof paper, then grease the paper and sides with butter. Whisk the egg yolks with the sugar until very thick. Wash the whisk, make sure it is dry, then whisk the whites, together with a pinch of salt, until they form soft peaks. By now, the chocolate should be melted, so give it a stir and carefully amalgamate with the yolk mix. Add a good spoonful of whites and stir throughly, then fold in the rest.

Pour carefully into the prepared cake tin, and bake on a tray for about 30 minutes, until the cake is set - a good sign is that it may have cracked a little on top. Leave to cool for five minutes, then turn out on to a cooling rack. Once cool, if you want, top with a little more dark chocolate melted with butter, or dust with icing sugar and cocoa, or put lots of berries and whipped double cream on top. For a more refined version, add some prunes soaked in brandy to the mix, 75-100g ground almonds to the melted chocolate, and top with some crème frache mixed with cinnamon and shavings of really dark chocolate or flaked almonds.

School cake

So called as it's made with semolina, though this cake is light as a cloud.

5 eggs, separated

Grated lemon rind

250g caster sugar

125g semolina

125g ground almonds

tsp baking powder

150ml water or milk

Pinch of salt

Preheat the oven to 175C/350F/gas mark 4. Lightly grease a deep cake tin. Whisk the egg yolks with the zest and sugar until moussey and light. Stir in the baking powder, semolina, almonds and the liquid, and blend until smooth. Whisk the whites with the salt until they form soft peaks. Loosen the yolk mix with a big spoonful of whites, then fold in the rest. Pour into the tin and bake for 40 minutes, until firm.

While the cake is still warm, you could drizzle a citrus sugar syrup over it, to make a sticky, moist cake; or, once cool, cut it in half across the middle, fill with lemon curd (or jam and cream) and dust with icing sugar. Joan and Carlotta went for a caramelised banana and mascarpone filling.

Loch Katrine Cake

A fave from my childhood, this is a good basic sponge, albeit used differently.

For the base

150g plain flour

50g butter

1 tsp baking powder

3-4 tbsp milk

Raspberry jam

Large handful of currants

For the sponge

50g softened butter

100g sugar

150g flour

1 tsp baking powder

2 eggs

4-6 tbsp milk

Preheat the oven to 175C/350F/gas mark 4. First, make the base: rub the butter into the flour and baking powder until it resembles coarse crumbs, then add enough milk to bind the mix: you want a stiffish dough. Leave to rest and make the sponge: cream the butter and sugar until light. Sift the flour and baking powder, and beat the eggs. Add half the flour and the eggs to the creamed mix, then stir in the remaining flour.

Roll out the dough to fit a rectangular baking tin. Spread a layer of jam on top, sprinkle with currants and cover with sponge mix. Bake for 30 minutes, until the sponge springs back. Leave to cool. (I like to top this with lemon icing: sift icing sugar, add butter and enough lemon juice and water to make a spreadable, but not too runny, mix, then add lemon zest. Spread over the cake and, once set, cut into squares.)

Hokey Pokey Biscuits

Another childhood memory.

125g butter

125g sugar

1 tbsp Golden Syrup

1 tbsp milk

225g plain flour

1 tsp bicarbonate of soda

Preheat the oven to 175C/350F/gas mark 4. Combine the butter, sugar, syrup and milk in a pan, heat until the butter is melted and the mixture is set to boil, then put aside to cool a little. Sift in the flour and bicarb, and stir to form a stiff dough. Break off pieces of dough, roll into balls and place on baking trays. Flatten into circles with a floured fork, and bake for 15-20 minutes until golden.

Biscuits

A simple, all-purpose dough that can be flavoured as desired.

125g softened butter

150g sugar

tsp vanilla essence

1 egg

300g plain flour

1 tsp baking powder (optional)

Preheat the oven to 190C/375F/gas mark 5. Cream the butter, sugar and vanilla until light and fluffy. Stir in the egg, then sift in the flour and baking powder. Mix to a stiff dough, break off pieces and roll into balls. Place on a tray and flatten with a floured fork (for a neater finish, leave the dough to rest for 20 minutes in the fridge, then roll out to around cm thick and cut into shapes). Bake for 12 minutes, until golden.

Add cocoa or grated chocolate for chocolate biscuits; or nuts, orange or lemon zest, dried fruit or crystallised ginger (orange zest and cardamom make good grown-up biscuits).

Florentines

A dead-easy recipe from an aunt in New Zealand.

110g butter

2 tbsp Golden Syrup

100g brown sugar

50g flaked almonds

50g chopped hazelnuts

75g sultanas

75g candied mixed peel

75g flour

150g dark chocolate

Preheat the oven to 200C/400F/gas mark 6. Heat the butter, sugar and syrup until the butter is melted, then add everything else bar the chocolate and stir. Drop small spoonfuls on to baking parchment, and bake until bubbling, golden and toffee-like. Remove from the oven and leave on the tray for about five minutes - they will crisp up as they cool - then spread one side with melted chocolate and leave to set.

Scones

A basic recipe from which stems endless sweet and savoury possibilities.

450g plain flour

6 tsp baking powder

tsp salt

75g butter, cut into cubes

250-375ml milk

Extra milk to glaze

Preheat the oven to 225C/425F/gas mark 7. Sift the flour, baking powder and salt into a bowl, add the butter, then rub it in until the mix is the texture of fine breadcrumbs. Add 250ml milk, and mix to a soft dough, adding up to 125ml more milk to achieve this. Turn out of the bowl and knead a little. Roll out the dough to 3cm thick, then cut into circles or squares. Glaze with milk. Place on an oven tray and bake for 10 minutes until golden-brown. Eat while warm with lashings of butter, jam, etc. (For savoury scones, add 75g grated cheese, cayenne pepper, mustard, chopped herbs, olives, sun-dried tomatoes or finely chopped red onion: whatever takes your fancy. For sweeter scones, add 1 tbsp sugar, honey or maple syrup, and a handful of dried fruit and cinnamon.)

 Do you have a culinary dilemma? Always overcooking fish, say, or fed up with beans on toast for tea? If you would like the Kitchen Doctor's expert treatment, please write with details of your problem and domestic set-up, including a daytime phone number, to Guardian Weekend, 119 Farringdon Road, London EC1R 3ER; email: weekend@theguardian.com

Eat while warm with lashings of butter, jam, etc. (For savoury scones, add 75g grated cheese, cayenne pepper, mustard, chopped herbs, olives, sun-dried tomatoes or finely chopped red onion: whatever takes your fancy. For sweeter scones, add 1 tbsp sugar, honey or maple syrup, and a handful of dried fruit and cinnamon.)  Do you have a culinary dilemma? Always overcooking fish, say, or fed up with beans on toast for tea? If you would like the Kitchen Doctor's expert treatment, please write with details of your problem and domestic set-up, including a daytime phone number, to Guardian Weekend, 119 Farringdon Road, London EC1R 3ER; email: weekend@theguardian.com

fields.headline: School meal deals
fields.standfirst: School vouchers on food aimed at our kids are just token offerings, says Joanna Blythman
fields.trailText: School vouchers on food aimed at our kids are just token offerings, says Joanna Blythman
fields.body:
What do primary school children have to do these days to please the headteacher? Get their homework in on time? Go to bed earlier on weekdays? No - the answer is to consume as many packets of crisps, biscuits and fizzy drinks as possible.

Yes, you read right: schools up and down the land are at risk of being tempted by heavy commercial pressure to encourage their pupils to eat junk food, and in the process collect vouchers on wrappers that the school can cash in for educational resources. Last year, if you collected foil tops from packets of Pringles, say, you got some sports equipment, while greasy tokens cut off any bag of Walkers crisps (including Doritos, Monster Munch and Quavers) earned you free books. This year, McVitie's has joined in: its biscuits, Skips, Mini Cheddars and Hula Hoops now bear tokens that can be exchanged for maths equipment.

This is the latest scheme dreamed up by food manufacturers, and it's working a treat. Corporate public-relations departments refer to it as "in-school marketing", and it's proven a better tool for generating junk food sales among children and their parents than any advertising campaign. With this strategy, the crisp, biscuit and fizzy drink manufacturers can then present their products as having a useful contribution to make to children's physical or mental well-being. And, by linking them to some moral high ground - literacy, sport, education - they can have a real field day. It's what's known in the marketing business as a "paradox concept" - which, in a nutshell, means you link two disparate and contradictory concepts and use them to entice the gullible.

The particularly audacious nerve of the "tokens for junk food" approach is that cash-strapped headteachers get sucked into endorsing the products and lending them their seal of approval. So, while children are being taught about healthy eating in the classroom, they may also be asked to deposit tokens from junk food in the school office. Talk about mixed messages.

The food manufacturers are not the only ones at it, either. Tesco is now offering Computers For Schools vouchers at the check-out - the vouchers are emblazoned with the brand logos of its charitable sponsors, which happen to include sugary fizzy drinks Pepsi, Tango and 7-Up, and Dairylea, the makers of Dunkers and other such delightful, sodium-and fat-laden snacks that have been targeted at the juvenile lunchbox market. That's not to say that children don't eat such junk foods, anyway, but where is the encouragement for them to eat more healthily? Tesco responds to criticisms of its scheme with a less-than-convincing prepared Questions And Answers leaflet. "Q: Does Tesco have any concerns regarding the health issue of these products? A: All products are clearly labelled and if any shopper should have any health concerns they should directly contact the product concerned."

Tesco also insists that its sponsors' branding is "very subtle" and that shoppers collect vouchers even if they don't choose their products. Perhaps some of McVitie's maths packages might come in handy here for a little mental arithmetic - spend £10 on anything in Tesco, and you collect one voucher; spend 89p in Tesco on a two-litre bottle of Tango, and you collect one voucher. So, hands up children, which purchase should the voucher- maximising customer choose?

Tesco would do well to look over its shoulder at its main rival, Sainsbury's, which also operates a "school points" scheme, but which has ditched the sponsors. "We found that both parents and schools did not favour having extra points on certain products, and that parents preferred to carry on their normal shop and still help the school without being pressurised into buying particular brands," says a Sainsbury's spokesman.

In Sainsbury's, then, customers can automatically build up school points on their reward card, which are electronically credited to a nominated school's account. It's an effortless and streamlined scheme that must appeal to the school staff members whose unfortunate and time-consuming job it has been of late to count and bag thousands of spent wrappers and vouchers. But, laudable though the store's own scheme may be, Sainsbury's still sells plenty of branded junk food that has school vouchers on its packaging.

Tesco, however, is adamant that its Computers For Schools scheme has benefited both schools and consumers. "It is a good example of cause-related marketing, where companies and causes come together to benefit the community," says Tesco's community affairs manager, Fiona Archer. Last year alone, Tesco delivered some £10.5 million-worth of computing equipment to more than 20,000 schools, a perfect example of the Business In The Community initiatives so favoured by Tony Blair. But many schools already have two iMacs in each classroom yet no specialist art or music teacher. Such initiatives simply cannot address the chronic funding shortages that hamper schools.

And what happened to the concept of the promoting healthier eating in schools? Our genial sponsors want their pound of flesh, after all. A packet of Doritos tangy cheese flavour 3Ds may deliver one token towards a free book, but to get it the kids have to eat a maize-and-oil snack that is processed with cheese powder, flavour enhancers monosodium glutamate, disodium inosinate and disodium guanylate, further flavouring, added caramel and sunset yellow colours, all tastily rounded off with salt and sugar.

fields.headline: The questionnaire
fields.standfirst: Wendy Holden
fields.trailText: Wendy Holden
fields.body:
Wendy Holden, 34, grew up in Yorkshire. Educated at a comprehensive, she read English Literature at Cambridge University. She went on to become deputy editor of Tatler, and worked on Harpers & Queen and The Sunday Times. Her first novel, Simply Divine, was published in 1999 and became a bestseller. Her new book is Bad Heir Day. She is married and lives in London.

What is your idea of perfect happiness?
Getting into a freshly-made bed with a wonderful book.

What is your greatest fear?
Something happening to harm my husband.

What is the trait you most deplore in yourself?
I worry about absolutely everything.

What is the trait you most deplore in others?
Noisy eaters with tumble-drier mouths.

What is your greatest extravagance?
A cottage in Derbyshire, where I write at weekends.

What do you most dislike about your appearance?
My large, square kneecaps.

What is your most unappealing habit?
Always sitting down next to mad or smelly people on the tube.

What is your favourite journey?
Flying to Nice each summer for our holiday. Last year, a little boy sat behind us on the plane and when it went through the clouds he shouted, 'Where's God?'

Should the Royal Family be scrapped?
Definitely not - they're the best soap opera going.

Do you believe in monogamy?
Yes. If you're lucky and it works, I can't imagine anything better.

What or who is the greatest love of your life?
My husband.

What do you consider the most overrated virtue?
Speaking as you find.

What is your greatest regret?
That my father had a stroke the day before Simply Divine was published. He would have loved the excitement, but was too ill to know about any of it.

How often do you have sex?
Often enough. But no one has as much sex as everyone else imagines they do.

What single thing would improve the quality of your life?
Someone to do the ironing.

How would you like to die?
Awake, standing up and resisting it all the way, like Elizabeth I.

How would you like to be remembered?
With a smile.

What is the most important lesson life has taught you?
Keep trying. If you're determined enough, you'll get there in the end.

fields.headline: Eating out
fields.standfirst: Matthew Fort takes the plunge and heads for Bath's most lauded restaurant
fields.trailText: Matthew Fort takes the plunge and heads for Bath's most lauded restaurant
fields.body:
It's a long time since I was in Bath. As a small boy, I had a bit of an aversion to it and, World Heritage site or not, I've never quite lost my dread of the place. I had a brace of aunts who lived there, Aunts Avis and Ellie, who were tall, dark, angular, austere bags of bones, and they disapproved of me. In reality, they were probably sweet old dears, but that is not how they struck me.

Yet back in Bath the other day it was hard to cling on to those dark memories. The place had sparkled in the afternoon light of a genial spring day, and in the evening its lights sparkled up at me and Fosdyke through the floor-to- ceiling windows of Lettonie, set on the hill above the town.

Every now and then, I am moved to go and visit a top-drawer restaurant. You may think that I spend my time in them, but I like to think that I'm quite conscientious, opting for variety in terms of price, culinary culture and location. Anyway, I had been meaning to go to Lettonie for an age - it is a restaurant that has figured in the upper echelons of guide ratings and critical comments for some time, and every now and then you have to go and see what all the fuss is about.

The creation of the Blunos family - Martin the chef and Sin front-of-house - it moved to an unmistakably grand building in Bath a couple of years back. Indeed, it is grander than any other restaurant I can think of. Grand though the Oak Room, say, or the dining room at the Ritz may be, they don't have a sequence of rooms of such Palladian spaciousness - the happy combination of scale, high ceilings, huge windows, generous mouldings and tasteful decoration. What prevents Lettonie from toppling over into Sense And Sensibility overkill is that most of the walls in the reception room, itself larger than a good many restaurants, are hung with photographs of the Blunos family. The same is true of the bar, or whatever you want to call the stately room in which Fosdyke and I ruminated over the menu. The pictures add a domestic note to the place, an air reinforced by the service, which managed to find that rare balance of friendliness and easy professionalism.

There is an equally cheering cast to the food. There was a commendable shortage of what you might call luxury ingredients, and several that you don't see on many menus of restaurants of whatever pedigree, let alone those twinkling with Michelin stars - brawn, oxtail, shepherd's pie, belly pork and haggis, to name but a few. I think we must thank Martin Blunos's Latvian ancestry for this elevation of the humble.

Fosdyke wanted a lightish affair, so opted for cod, ham and scallop chowder with a tomato tartlet, followed by a dish of lamb cutlets with the shepherds' pie. As there was both a light nibble before the first course and another before the pudding, and as he wallopped the bread pretty heavily, too, perhaps it wasn't surprising that he fell at the pudding hurdle. I, however, am in training, so managed a hot rhubarb soufflé with cardamom and rhubarb sauce and vanilla ice, having already demolished a terrine of brawn, and roast zander with salsify, crayfish and wild mushrooms, potato and salsify cake and a crayfish sabayon.

The brawn would have brought a tear of pleasure to my mother's eye (it is a particular favourite of hers). It was as beautiful as it was unexpected, delicately flavoured and precisely textured, with a little spoonful of seed mustard and a class-A salad to cut the richness. Fosdyke's chowder was a similarly accomplished dish, the cod, ham and scallop each retaining their taste and texture in spite of being cut to polite-eating size, and the richness of the cream in the soup brought to heel by a fine fish stock.

The zander, too, was a fine dish, though perhaps not of quite the same exalted standard, in spite of a gold-medal-winning sauce. The lamb cutlets were impeccable, very fine pieces of meat with a cheerful sweetness; the shepherds' pie with them looked like a mini circus tent, its frivolous exterior covering serious flavour; and the gravy, jus or sauce (call it what you will) carried a liquor-rich weight that dramatically increased the overall impact of a fairly standard dish. The soufflé brought my dinner to a resounding conclusion: it was an astoundingly potent piece of pudding-making.

I wouldn't say that this is food that astounds or exalts. It's not of the gob-smacking, how-did-he-do-that? variety, all pyrotechnics and power-cooking. Instead, it is lovingly-crafted, and the details have been worked at until they take on a lapidary gleam. They are perfectly and precisely what they are supposed to be. Having said that, there were some details that distracted from a sense of perfection: I couldn't make out what the tomato tart was doing with the chowder, the texture of the brioche was at odds with the brawn, and the mushrooms with the fish seemed to have been baked in stale-tasting oil. These may be a matter of taste, but they weren't to mine.

Okay, now for the hard part. Dinner costs £47.50 for a nominal three courses, though in reality it's five (or even six, if you count the plentiful choccie things that come with the coffee). Our bill came to £146.55, and included a half-bottle of decent Sancerre at £18.65 and half a bottle of brilliant Savigny-les-Beaune at £25.25 from a curiously muted list, a bottle of mineral water, a glass of champagne and another of sherry. However, they had also, with great thoughtfulness, deducted the cost of a pudding from the set menu, which I think generous. And, on reflection, generous is the word that best describes Lettonie all round.

fields.headline: How to... be political
fields.trailText: Everyone knows that you shouldn't discuss politics at a dinner party because you'll only upset people. People who choose to go into politics full time are therefore determined to upset people day in day out.
fields.body:
Everyone knows that you shouldn't discuss politics at a dinner party because you'll only upset people. People who choose to go into politics full time are therefore determined to upset people day in day out. In a two-party state, plumping for one party or another means voluntarily discarding one half of your brain. No surprise, therefore, that politicians often come across as halfwits.

You have to start really young if you want to get anywhere in politics, which means that you miss the shift in life that for some reason always swings you from left to right or right to left as you get older. Often, people become political because they want something better for their children; the reward for this is to have children who emerge on the opposite end of the political spectrum from yourself.

Budding politicians start at local level, which gives rise to odd things, such as parish council expenditure on a park bench being debated on party lines with great passion, heat and venom. This is one of the main reasons we don't have any park benches.

At election time, political people put signs outside their house. The intended effect is instantly to change the political persuasion of anyone walking past on the street. What really happens is that you suddenly get crossed off the dinner-party list of people walking past on the street.

To be political, you need to be able to talk with great passion, conviction and sincerity about everything, except the answer to the question. You also need to show complete and unswerving loyalty to the party leader, whoever it happens to be at the time. Finally, you need to have the common touch with the people, which doesn't mean sleeping with as many of them as possible.

Local politicians knock on people's doors. There are only three kinds of people who knock on British doors: plumbers, religious nutters and politicians, and they all promise to fix one thing or another. Unless you're very, very lonely or have a problem with your washing machine, don't let any of them in. Remember: if politicians were really that useful, they'd be in Yellow Pages.

If you really want to change the world, you can take media-friendly direct action, or you can forget the direct action and own the media. The other route is to be very big in business and then buy up politicians wholesale. Of course, you don't give them money directly, but you do what no one else would do - invite them to dinner.

fields.headline: Dulcie Domum: simply red
fields.standfirst: This anti-Ken stuff is blowing the embers of my socialism back into a flicker
fields.trailText: This anti-Ken stuff is blowing the embers of my socialism back into a flicker
fields.body:
'Aunt Elspeth keeps asking me what's wrong with Henry," I hiss to ex-Spouse, seizing rare confidential moment in kitchen. "There's nothing wrong with him!" snaps his devoted Papa. "If she wants to worry about something, what about my chest pains?" He winces ostentatiously. "You should take your Omega-3 fish oil pills, Gordon." "Stuff that! I'd rather die than dose myself up with something politically-correct."

Harriet slouches in looking Gormenghastly in black and white. "Mum? Can I have a fiver? I've run out of sanitary towels." At least we are politically correct on the menstrual front. No bloody tampons - literally. "A fiver? For a packet of panty liners?" Harriet assures me she will give me back the change.

"Dulcie? Have you thought of glandularrrr feverrr ?" Aunt approaches with furtive hiss. Assure her that Henry is only hung over, and excuse myself on the grounds of gardening. "Ah! I wish I could join you dearrr , but wheneverrr I bend overrr , I go all woozy. They say it's a sign of a neglected neck."

Determined to neglect her neck like nobody's ever managed before, I run out into the front garden. It is full of debris: drink cans, cigarette packs, etc. But the weeds are making a comeback. Recall that, when a young, tender-hearted socialist, I used to feel sorry for weeds. No more! I am running a Selective Garden and I don't care! Mind you, this anti-Livingstone business is blowing the cold embers of my socialism back into a flicker. While clearing debris thrown in by drunken louts, I still feel a scintilla of affection for the proletariat. Lift a brick, and find a toad. For an instant did not recognise it as an animal: looked geological. A living stone! Perhaps that's why Ken likes salamanders.

Step in cat shit, lose gardening impulse and go back indoors - leaving shoes on doorstep. Find ex-Spouse by kettle. "My thumb has gone numb," he complains. "Well, have you taken your evening primrose for the nervous system?" "Have I buggery!" he retorts, and returns to his armchair.

Aunt appears, but before she can utter a word I grab purse and drive off at speed to garden centre. Snapdragons, flower of my childhood, in white 'n' claret! Select whole tray. And white foxgloves! So elegant. Must have! Pinks - somehow heraldic. Load up trolley and roll on towards the lupins: must buy seven, since I read somewhere that you should always buy in odd numbers. Political correctness nowhere more rampant than in gardening. Remember Jilly Cooper said red geraniums were considered vulgar and one must only have pale pink. Perhaps New Labour's rejection of the red flag is a sign that they are socially upwardly mobile. "The People's Flag is Face-Powder Pink." Help myself to lots of deep red things just to irritate Blair and show my solidarity with the proletariat.

Advance on check-out like Birnam Forest coming to Dunsinane, and while queuing gaze in complacent rapture at my white and red plants. Then remember old adage, one of Great-Aunt Elspeth's favourites: " Neverrr have rrred and white togetherrr , dearrr - its a wound and a winding sheet!" Hope the bad karma will be more than cancelled out by a bit of blue, so grab extra delphiniums and keep fingers crossed.

Drive home determined to revel in new persona. We Are A Gardener. Would prefer to prune roses than attempt to cut off short Aunt's agitated monologues. Would much rather dig deep, stiff loam than try to get to the root of Henry's anomie. Will bestow muck on my grateful plants rather than try to force Omega-3 fish oils down ungrateful ex-Spouse's gullet.

Front door is thrown open by Harriet, looking frantic. "Mum! We can't wake Dad up! Come quick! I think there's something wrong! Oh God! Is he dead?"

Race to sitting room and shake ex-Spouse, who is slumped in posture suggestive of profound seizure. Oh God! The wound and the winding sheet! Grab phone to summon ambulance when ex-Spouse jerks upright and everybody choruses "April Fool!" Most diverting.

Later, ask Harriet for change from the fiver for the sanitary towels. "I spent it on lip gloss," she smiles. "I knew you wouldn't mind cos it's Factor 15."

Oh well. Find some comfort in the thought that at least menstruation is a simply red experience which New Labour can't do anything about.
