fields.headline: The knowledge
fields.standfirst: Spear of destiny: asparagus
fields.trailText: Spear of destiny: asparagus
fields.body:
The subject
Asparagus officinalis . Officinalis means 'storeroom for medicines'. Our forebears used the wild version for medicinal purposes, before they realised it was the greatest of vegetal delicacies.

The basics
Asparagus grows someplace all year round, but it is worth buying here only in spring. The first Spanish imports, which appeared a few weeks ago, are an entirely luscious prelude to the English season (roll on May 1). Thin spears are good. Thick spears are good. White asparagus is denied colour by earth lumped over the growing spears. Our continental cousins love it. Don't ask me why. Do ask why asparagus is so expensive. Answer: it's expensive to grow.

The details
Much nonsense is talked about cooking asparagus. You do not have to keep the tips above water in an expensive steamer - boiling is fine. You do not have to peel them - unless you work in a restaurant. If boiling, start testing after five minutes. Personal view: roasting is best, in a roasting tin with a little olive oil and some coarse salt. Figure on 200C/400F/gas mark 6 for 10-15 minutes. Hot or cold, this is asparagus ecstasy. Nutritional note: asparagus is embarrassingly good for you, rich in vitamins A and C, and with so few calories (around 250 per 500g) you need a magnifying glass to find them. Shamed-confession note: the Knowledge once ate a whole pound single-handed. Touristic note: the Stockton Asparagus Festival in California takes place from April 28-30 - nine tons of the stuff will be cooked, so you can eat your fill of deep-fried asparagus and asparagus burritos while exploring the AsparaZone and listening to groovy sounds from the Spear-Its Of The Valley.

Where to buy
Wherever they get fresh supplies daily. Eschew wrinkled skin, dryness, brownish points.

The easy way out
Tins and jars are delicious. (April Fool, nyah nyah!)

fields.headline: Uncontrolled delights
fields.standfirst: Christopher Lloyd finds joy twixt rock and hard place
fields.trailText: Christopher Lloyd finds joy twixt rock and hard place
fields.body:
When plants do unusual things in your garden, they often deserve to be encouraged. Walls, especially dry walls but any walls in which the rendering is crumbling a little, can be a great source of excitement.

We usually grow the 2m-high Campanula pyramidalis as a pot plant for indoor display in its August season, but in a public garden, which is where you least expect to see anything uncontrolled, I was once delighted to see one or two self-sown plants of this campanula in the cracks of a wall at Hampton Court.

Then, near Philadelphia city a couple of years ago, there was the sloping roof of a bit tacked on to the main dwelling, with an opuntia established on it. It looked so happy, despite the winters there having far colder spells than we expect in Britain. Opuntias are cacti of the prickly pear persuasion, which make flattened pads covered in tufts of prickles (to be treated with respect); some of them, as evidenced there, are amazingly hardy. I can't wait to do something of this kind on my own premises, but am somewhat lost to know how an opuntia is to get a toe-hold on any of my roofs, and also how then to provide it with enough sustenance to live. (I have not been very successful with house-leeks).

There is a long, wooden bench-seat in our garden, which is sheltered from wind and catches the midday sun. It is ideal, in late autumn and early spring - even in winter, if the weather is right, for enjoying a pre-lunch drink with friends. (The best time for champagne, Sir David Scott, then in his 90s, told me, is at 11am on a Sunday, when everyone else is in church.) Between the paving in front of this seat and the lawns either side, little strips of scented white violets, Viola odorata , established themselves years ago, without seeking anyone's permission; drinks time, mid-March is when I most enjoy them.

There are so many examples; you will have your own. The shrubby Paeonia delavayi , is a pretty ungainly piece of goods, with thick stems to 2m and a short spring flowering season. But the flowers are deep maroon and, although not large, they are rather nice and attract comment, so there must be something about them. Yet I scarcely feel this to be a plant deserving to take up border space. However, it has, in two places, established itself in the dry-stone walling surrounding our sunken garden and there it seems ideal, doing no harm to anyone.

Nearby, a red-hot poker seeded itself in the same way. Who would be so crazy as to suggest kniphofias for dry-wall planting? But it was the plant's own choice and it has survived for many years.

Then there is the variegated Arum italicum 'Pictum' that a bird sowed in the crutch of an old wall-fig tree. Quite absurd, but charming, too.

My mother loved this relaxed kind of gardening. She was always planting snowdrops in odd places, and one of those has seeded itself into a crack in a dry wall. She also planted cyclamen seedlings - the autumn-flowering Cyclamen hederifolium - into wall cracks. They survive for years and their tubers look, when dormant, like toads. Eventually, they tend to lose support from behind and drop out.

My father liked everything to be just so and in its right place. So if a Daphne mezereum , for instance, sowed itself in a step riser, I would, as a child, say to my mother "we must protect it from Daddy and the gardeners". On our sitting-out terrace, a seedling Daphne tangutica appeared some 20 years ago. There wasn't room for it to develop a stem between the paving cracks, so we chipped a corner of stone away for it and it still thrives.

Even more surprising, on the same terrace, was the appearance of a seedling Azara microphylla . This large shrub grows up a wall from the terrace below, and it is flowering as I write, wafting a delicious scent of hot chocolate. Till the seedling appeared, I never even knew that the parent made seeds, but I have since seen a few of them, looking like small white pebbles.

I don't want to be stupid by allowing no bar on self-sowns; any garden that did would quickly become an uncontrollable mess. But this seemed a special case, and the seedling, for which we again made space by chipping some stone away, is now some 5m high and I have allowed a travelling Wisteria sinensis to twine itself into the azara's branches.

It is easy to be gimmicky in your garden and to earn a reputation for being a character, because of the startling etceras that you fit in, but they are non-living additions and, in the end, I find they pall. The plants themselves are what count for me, and when they have done some strange antic, I'm on the watch; they make me laugh, sometimes persuaded to indulge.

Whether you do indulge or say "enough" is for you to decide. It's your garden, isn't it? That's the whole point of having one. However, I'm glad to say that Fergus Garrett, who runs the garden for me, is generally of the same opinion as I am. It was he who suggested I write on this topic.

fields.headline: Cache points
fields.standfirst: Storage unitsare temporary accomodation for our belongings, right? Not at all. Some people these days just can't imagine life without their own repository, says Sophie Radice
fields.trailText: Storage unitsare temporary accomodation for our belongings, right? Not at all. Some people these days just can't imagine life without their own repository, says Sophie Radice
fields.body:
Theresa from New York gets quite misty-eyed when she talks about her self-storage unit in Manhattan. She is a high-powered film executive now working in London, but put her personal effects into a tiny hired room in a battered but fine old warehouse long before she had to move across the Atlantic. "There is so little room in Manhattan's apartments that it is common for people to store stuff that they can't fit into their lives but just can't bear to throw away," she says. "I would pretend that I was going to pick something very important up and actually spend an entire day rummaging around, looking through photos or letters, getting lost in my past. It is all still there waiting for me."

Although space is not as tight in Britain as it is in Manhattan, we are still a "nation of hoarders", according to Adam Ealand, manager of Squirrel storage. Personal storage used to be the preserve of officers and gentlemen posted abroad, who would use the impressive Harrods Depository by the river Thames at Barnes, west London (which, in 1981, was turned into luxury apartments), as safe houses for their personal effects.

Now, however, we use self-storage to put off having to throw out our past. The steel units of varying size and price keep our memories safe from damp, and in some cases (particularly the husband who keeps his pornography collection in a steel-bound unit in Wells, Somerset) from disapproving or acquisitive relatives.

"Most people tell themselves they are storing things of worth, but if you work out the weekly rental against the cost of the old bed, a couple of chairs, some paintings and piles of old books, then you can quickly see that it is of emotional rather then financial value," says Ealand. "Retired couples who move into smaller homes can't bear to part with the bits and bobs they consider to be their heritage, and so they lovingly store it and leave the contents in their will to their heirs. Then, the problem about what to do with the stuff is simply passed on."

My own encounter with self- storage is a perfect illustration of that - in flight from a failed marriage in France with a lorry-load of furniture and boxes that I was not in a fit state to sift through, I packed it into a metal container and didn't pick it up until I moved into my own house a year later. When I opened it up, I was surprised to find that the stuff I had fought so hard to keep and had paid a weekly rental for filled me with the worst and most stifling kind of nostalgia.

With a hired van, I drove to the dump (which is right near the storage place) and got rid of the bed, sofa and all the old clothes. I couldn't help thinking of the time and money I would have saved if I'd visited the recycling centre first.

Divorce also brought David King to self-storage. When he split up with his wife, he found a beautiful longboat on the Thames at Pitstone. "Obviously, I have a lot of things that wouldn't fit into the longboat," he says, "so I found a storage place relatively nearby, where I can come and go as I please, using it rather like someone else might use the spare room or garage. It is quite convenient, and means that my day-to-day life is relatively uncluttered."

Susan Methan-Ford, who stores with the upmarket Big Yellow, is also a regular visitor to her unit. Many of the Big Yellow centres have swanky foyers, drinks machines and smiling, helpful staff - contrasting with the grim, no-questions-asked atmosphere of some of the self- storage units in, say, King's Cross, London. She wants her new flat in Notting Hill to be sparse and modern, and so has an excess not only of the Victoriana and glitzy, glam stuff that used to fill her large home in Richmond, but also with an awful lot of personal baggage.

"I have kept things belonging to my children and odd things like my wedding dress and a white mink jacket that is so tiny I can't believe I used to fit into it. I am a great accumulator of stuff, and yet want to live in a minimal, fashionable way, so storage is my answer.

"Sometimes, I think it might give me bad karma to be such a collector of what to most people is junk. Then I persuade myself that is people like me who preserve things for the future. If we all did what these lifestyle gurus said and threw everything out, then we would have nothing left now, would we?"

Denise Moorcroft-Hogan, who has worked at the reception of the Big Yellow storage centre in Staples Corner, north London, for more than 10 years, says that "it is a fascinating job that requires a certain amount of understanding and discretion. For every straightforward house move, there are clients who have had their houses repossessed, relatives die, or have split up from their partners. One woman had her late aunt's stuff in here for years - she visited almost as often as someone else would go and visit their relatives who are alive and well."

Self-storage can be a liberation, a means to a freer, more nomadic existence. For the charity worker, the international high-flyer or the perpetual traveller, say, it enables some roots to be kept somewhere, even if it is only in a storage unit near the North Circular road. In Alan Bennett's story, The Clothes They Stood Up In, a rather staid couple have every scrap of their existence mistakenly removed and put into storage. Once she has got over the shock, Mrs Ransome feels that to be "parted from all her worldly goods might bring with it benefits she would have hesitated to call spiritual but which might, more briskly, be put under the heading of 'improving the character'."

For Patricia du Pont-de Bis, on the other hand, self-storage is an efficient way to help with her work. She buys properties, does them up with style, and sells them on. For that, she needs a reserve of furniture and household effects, and so has a number of storage units with "mini-homes" inside them. Her daughter, Natascha, however, slips in some of her own stuff alongside her mother's for the more usual reasons: lack of space, an inability to decide what to throw out and, perhaps, the belief that one day she'll one day have a bigger place to live.

Optimism about having a bigger place or a house in the country is a theme that seems to run through many a tale of self-storage. For some of us, that dream will never come true, of course, but one friend, who had been living in Russia and was in the process of reclaiming her stuff from storage to move back into her flat, said that she witnessed a scene of "pure poetry".

"A group of unusually handsome boys were clearing their stuff out and whooping with happiness and excitement," she recalled. "The caretaker told me that they were a boy band who had a top 10 hit and so had managed to buy some roomy bachelor pads with their royalty money. He then spoilt it a bit by asking if I had heard their record, and when I said no, he smiled, tutted, shook his head and said, 'They will be back. You mark my words. Within a couple of years at the most, they will be knocking at our door again.'"

It is quite convenient, and means that my day-to-day life is relatively uncluttered." Susan Methan-Ford, who stores with the upmarket Big Yellow, is also a regular visitor to her unit. Many of the Big Yellow centres have swanky foyers, drinks machines and smiling, helpful staff - contrasting with the grim, no-questions-asked atmosphere of some of the self- storage units in, say, King's Cross, London. She wants her new flat in Notting Hill to be sparse and modern, and so has an excess not only of the Victoriana and glitzy, glam stuff that used to fill her large home in Richmond, but also with an awful lot of personal baggage. "I have kept things belonging to my children and odd things like my wedding dress and a white mink jacket that is so tiny I can't believe I used to fit into it. I am a great accumulator of stuff, and yet want to live in a minimal, fashionable way, so storage is my answer. "Sometimes, I think it might give me bad karma to be such a collector of what to most people is junk. Then I persuade myself that is people like me who preserve things for the future. If we all did what these lifestyle gurus said and threw everything out, then we would have nothing left now, would we?" Denise Moorcroft-Hogan, who has worked at the reception of the Big Yellow storage centre in Staples Corner, north London, for more than 10 years, says that "it is a fascinating job that requires a certain amount of understanding and discretion. For every straightforward house move, there are clients who have had their houses repossessed, relatives die, or have split up from their partners. One woman had her late aunt's stuff in here for years - she visited almost as often as someone else would go and visit their relatives who are alive and well." Self-storage can be a liberation, a means to a freer, more nomadic existence. For the charity worker, the international high-flyer or the perpetual traveller, say, it enables some roots to be kept somewhere, even if it is only in a storage unit near the North Circular road. In Alan Bennett's story, The Clothes They Stood Up In, a rather staid couple have every scrap of their existence mistakenly removed and put into storage. Once she has got over the shock, Mrs Ransome feels that to be "parted from all her worldly goods might bring with it benefits she would have hesitated to call spiritual but which might, more briskly, be put under the heading of 'improving the character'." For Patricia du Pont-de Bis, on the other hand, self-storage is an efficient way to help with her work. She buys properties, does them up with style, and sells them on. For that, she needs a reserve of furniture and household effects, and so has a number of storage units with "mini-homes" inside them. Her daughter, Natascha, however, slips in some of her own stuff alongside her mother's for the more usual reasons: lack of space, an inability to decide what to throw out and, perhaps, the belief that one day she'll one day have a bigger place to live. Optimism about having a bigger place or a house in the country is a theme that seems to run through many a tale of self-storage. For some of us, that dream will never come true, of course, but one friend, who had been living in Russia and was in the process of reclaiming her stuff from storage to move back into her flat, said that she witnessed a scene of "pure poetry". "A group of unusually handsome boys were clearing their stuff out and whooping with happiness and excitement," she recalled. "The caretaker told me that they were a boy band who had a top 10 hit and so had managed to buy some roomy bachelor pads with their royalty money. He then spoilt it a bit by asking if I had heard their record, and when I said no, he smiled, tutted, shook his head and said, 'They will be back. You mark my words. Within a couple of years at the most, they will be knocking at our door again.'"

fields.headline: The net addict
fields.trailText: www.insomnia.com
fields.body:
Mum came back from her her honeymoon with Mike. He was in a vile mood - not helped when I told him that Lamont, his parakeet, had died. The ghastly bird screeched so much that finally Redwood, the doberman I gave Mum for her wedding present (I was looking after him, too), leaped up and swallowed him whole.

The silence was blissful, but still I couldn't sleep, because by then I was getting used to the noise. Luckily, I found www.insomnia.com; you learn about many things, including natural sleep aids. To keep the conversation with Mum and Mike going, I mentioned that snoring may increase heart risk. 'I must be about to have a coronary, then,' growled Mark, 'after two weeks sleeping next to your mother,' and she was off: 'If you had been doing your duty, like Tony, I wouldn't have been asleep!' Her screech reminded me of the parakeet.

It turns out she wants a baby (Mum has been 45 for several years now, so Cherie was inspirational for her). 'Help me!' she pleaded. I switched on the laptop. Lo and behold, www.Sheffield-Fertility.co.uk offers a treatment, called Assisted Hatching, aimed at over-35s. The long and short of it is that they've gone up north.

Peace was short-lived because then I found in www.bibledecoded.com that Armaggedon is imminent; in that case, I thought I'd better check how things stand with Migraine Alan. He was very friendly on the phone, so I suggested a weekend in Paris. He agreed! I booked through www.lastminute.com. There are many sites offering the same deals, but I adore Martha Lane Fox. She reminds me of Mum when I was a child, going round with her Walkman on, chorusing, 'Sis-ters are doing it for themselves'. Martha's shareholders are incredibly lucky: they're all going to be fabulously rich. Not.

webTitle: Social campaigner takes drug debate in her stride

fields.headline: Social campaigner takes drug debate in her stride
fields.standfirst:
Dame Ruth Runciman: Background of liberalism fires fight for justice

Drugs in Britain: special report
fields.trailText: Dame Ruth Runciman this week produced a report on drugs which managed to place Jack Straw firmly to the right of the Daily Telegraph.
fields.body:
Dame Ruth Runciman this week produced a report on drugs which managed to place Jack Straw firmly to the right of the Daily Telegraph. The report of the Police Foundation's inquiry into the drug laws, which she chaired, did not call for the legalisation of cannabis; but it provoked the Daily Telegraph into doing so. She is not bashful about the merits of her report. "Its time will indubitably come. It is an impressive document of quality. It will have a longer shelf life than any government."

She comes from a liberal South African background. "My mother was a social anthropologist who did the first anthropological work on urban South Africa. She was one of the founding members of the progressive party and chaired Helen Suzman's constituency party for some years. I was brought up in a family where black people came to dinner, where my friends were blacks and Asians, and this gave me a very strong sense of what it meant to be socially excluded."

She came to Cambridge to study history and married in Britain. After the birth of her children she started to work part-time. "What one would call my day job, the ballast of my life, is that I am a Citizens Advice Bureau worker and have been for the last 30 years; for the last 15 I have been involved in Wormwood Scrubs, though I no longer go into the prison.

"I set it up that there should be an advice worker on a weekly basis. It is now the most successful such scheme in the country. This is something in which I feel great pride - together with my colleagues. There ought to be one in every prison in the country."

She has sat on the statutory Advisory Council on the Misuse of Drugs since the early 1970s, when Roy Jenkins appointed her. "I knew him, but not well. I chaired the criminal justice working group and the Aids and drugs working group.

"Those two committees produced six reports. The most influential was the Aids and drugs report which really changed this country's strategy. We said: 'Aids is a greater threat to individual and public health than drug misuse.' This was for the time - 1988-89 - a morally ambiguous statement. The government found it hard to accept; but it gradually adopted the policy with immense and commendable rigour.

"One respect in which Britain stands head and shoulders above other European countries is in our rate of HIV infection among injecting drug abusers.

"That report was the point when harm reduction became an acceptable policy and our current report is also about harm reduction."

Not all her campaigns have been successful; in 1981 she was one of the founders of the Prison Reform Trust. "We thought we were in the three-year final push when William Whitelaw was home secretary."

The subsequent course of the prison service is not something she wants to talk about on the record. She is keenly aware of the political impact of what she might say, and anxious to keep as many people on side as possible.

Perhaps the most remarkable feature of her commission's report was that one of the two senior police officers on the commission signed up to all of it, and the other entered only one note of reservation about the operational consequences.

"One said: 'This will take some doing.' It wasn't dissent. And the Cleveland police, the home of zero tolerance, have just come out with an amazing statement. I have got it here.

"I keep it close to my heart: what they said was that there is little evidence that conventional conviction and punishment has any effect on offending levels and growing evidence that treatment and rehabilitation do."

webTitle: E-envoy has sundry strings to his mandolin

fields.headline: E-envoy has sundry strings to his mandolin
fields.standfirst:
Alex Allan: Website pioneer with brief to lure civil service on to the net

New Labour in power: special report
fields.trailText: On Alex Allan's website there is a picture of him going to work at the Treasury. He is wearing a dark suit and a bowler hat, but the hand that clutches his briefcase is also holding the mast of his windsurfer as he tries to cross the Thames, and the sail is decorated with the Grateful Dead's skull and lightning bolt logo.
fields.body:
On Alex Allan's website there is a picture of him going to work at the Treasury. He is wearing a dark suit and a bowler hat, but the hand that clutches his briefcase is also holding the mast of his windsurfer as he tries to cross the Thames, and the sail is decorated with the Grateful Dead's skull and lightning bolt logo.

What does him even more credit is that he goes on to print the next three photographs in the sequence, ending with one where only the briefcase and the bowler hat are still afloat. He was, when the picture was taken, a very senior civil servant indeed: principal private secretary to Nigel Lawson, who was chancellor of the exchequer.

He later served as principal private secretary to John Major and Tony Blair; and now, after a period as high commissioner in Australia, he is the government's e-envoy, a silly title for an important job. He is the man who has to persuade the civil service to get on the net and to encourage, or at least not to hinder, other people from doing the same.

As high commissioner he pioneered a website which told people quickly and simply whether they were eligible for a British passport; but at the same time he worked on a more popular site which allowed visitors to find any song the Grateful Dead ever played, and its lyrics. When we talked, he had just had an email from the woman who runs the band's official website to thank him for his efforts.

He showed real enthusiasm about this, yet he talked with the fluent caution of a born civil servant. "I did a post-graduate degree in statistics, though my thesis was actually on dice games; then I sort of drifted into the civil service. When you have done all the exams and they offer you a job you think, gosh, well, I'll give it a go. I was originally posted to customs and excise. I worked on the very early days of VAT, and that was actually interesting work."

He made it sound entirely self-evident that VAT should be interesting. But in his gentle and self-deprecating way he is obviously extremely ambitious.

Halfway through his stint at the Treasury he went off to work in the Australian software industry for a few years, partly, he said, because there was an age bar then in place, and he could not see the point of treading water for a few years; and partly because his wife, Katie Clempson, is an Australian artist.

So he wrote software that analysed the readings from an America's Cup yacht to help it go faster.

It is easy to see, when he talks about controversial policies, what made him so attractive to politicians. What he says, written down, sounds pure Sir Humphrey. But discussing the government's bill to regularise the tapping of email and compel access to encrypted computer files, he says wonderful things like: "I think the fuss is overstated. I think that the wilder allegations that nobody will come and do business in the UK are over the top.

"I think it reassuring that the Home Office is interested in finding a reasonable and practical solution. Some of the wilder statements have actually been unhelpful. The power to require keys or plaintext material only arises when something has been lawfully intercepted.

"Secondly, in all normal circumstances a company is required to hand over plain text rather than hand over keys. It's absolutely clear that nobody who is a legitimate, innocent person is going to have anything to fear."

He knew me for a Deadhead too, because we had met some weeks ago at a party thrown by one of the band's former lyricists, John Perry Barlow. I hadn't realised, though, that he had brought all 16 of the band's posthumous concert releases.

As a last paradox, he turns out to be musical, too. "I love opera, Wagner and Richard Strauss and that sort of thing. I play several instruments rather badly: guitar, classical guitar and mandolin.

"When I was leaving No 10 and gave a farewell party, we decided that rather than making a speech we'd have a song to the tune of Click Goes the Shears. Tony Blair made this speech saying, Well, thank you, and then I reached down and pulled up the guitar and mandolin. He looked absolutely horror-struck. I think he thought we would dragoon him into playing."

Instead, Allan, playing the mandolin, sang a comic duet with his wife.

webTitle: Greenpeace protesters occupy second Atlantic rig

fields.headline: Greenpeace protesters occupy second Atlantic rig
fields.trailText: Greenpeace activists yesterday occupied a second oil rig in Scottish waters within a week in the latest stage of the environmental group's protest at oil exploration in the Atlantic Ocean.
fields.body:
Greenpeace activists yesterday occupied a second oil rig in Scottish waters within a week in the latest stage of the environmental group's protest at oil exploration in the Atlantic Ocean.

The companies which own and operate the rig immediately went to court and were granted an interdict ordering four of the activists, who had attached themselves to the legs of the Sovereign Explorer, to end their protest. By early evening the protesters had left the rig.

The protest in the Cromarty Firth, near Inverness, began yesterday morning. It is understood that police were tipped off about the operation and 30 Greenpeace protesters were arrested before they could board the rig.

The Sovereign Explorer had been stowed in the firth over the winter and was being upgraded to make it suitable for drilling for oil in the Atlantic.

Last weekend, Greenpeace protesters boarded another rig berthed in the Cromarty Firth, the Jack Bates, just as it was due to be towed out to the Atlantic.

Yesterday's action was the latest round of a Greenpeace campaign against what it describes as Britain's over reliance on fossil fuels and the government's decision to allow exploration in the Atlantic frontier, an area of the ocean which houses coral reefs and is a breeding ground for rare species of whales.

The Sovereign Explorer rig is chartered to Marathon Oil but is owned by TransOcean FedCo For Ex (TSF).

Marathon has held a licence to drill in the frontier since 1997 and the rig was due to begin further exploration there later in the year.

"These activities are entirely within the law and sanctioned by the UK government. Greenpeace is all about soundbites and selective science. The rest of us have to live in the real world," said the spokesman.

Rob Gueterbrock, Greenpeace's climate and energy campaigns spokesman, said oil exploration in the Atlantic frontier was opposed by all of Britain's environmental campaign groups and he accused Marathon Oil of denying that fossil fuels were responsible for global warming.

"We already have more fossil fuels than we can ever burn if we are to limit global warming. The government should be looking at promoting renewable sources of energy - not this. They are backing the wrong horse," he added.

The two Greenpeace activists who climbed on to the Jack Bates rig on Sunday came down on Monday afternoon after Enterprise Oil won an interdict.

The protesters were spirited away in a motor launch by fellow activists and have still not been apprehended by police for questioning.

Enterprise Oil is seeking legal damages of £1m over the incident. But the Marathon Oil spokesman said that the company was not, at present, seeking damages.

webTitle: £1 and a bottle of whisky gains ancient castle

fields.headline: £1 and a bottle of whisky gains ancient castle
fields.trailText: One clan chief may be asking millions for his ancestral heritage, but another yesterday accepted £1 and a bottle of whisky. Under a deal signed yesterday, the Macneil of Barra has gifted Kisimul castle, one of Scotland's most historic homes, to Historic Scotland for 1,000 years.
fields.body:
One clan chief may be asking millions for his ancestral heritage, but another yesterday accepted £1 and a bottle of whisky. Under a deal signed yesterday, the Macneil of Barra has gifted Kisimul castle, one of Scotland's most historic homes, to Historic Scotland for 1,000 years.

The Macneils will retain ownership of the castle on the Hebridean island, but its day-to-day management will be in the hands of the government heritage agency. Macneil was enthusiastic: "Kisimul is a most romantic place which has great potential as a tourist attraction. The tides and the constant varying sea and light of the Hebrides give the castle an ever-changing, often magical, appearance."

Robert Lister Macneil, the chief's father, restored the castle between 1956 and 1970 with donations from clan members around the world, and the excess in the restoration fund will be made available to Historic Scotland.

The castle includes a great hall, dungeon and chapel. Little is known about its early years - estimates of its origin range from 1030 to the middle of the 15th century.

webTitle: Uproar at clan chief's £10m tag on Skye land

fields.headline: Uproar at clan chief's £10m tag on Skye land
fields.standfirst: Cuillins mountain range is mine to sell, says 29th MacLeod of MacLeod, as islanders and conservationists challenge his 16th-century charter
fields.trailText: From any angle the Cuillins look unassailable - a dark, saw-toothed ridge that dominates Skye, mocking those who come to test their mettle on the unforgiving terrain.
fields.body:
From any angle the Cuillins look unassailable - a dark, saw-toothed ridge that dominates Skye, mocking those who come to test their mettle on the unforgiving terrain.

But the market reaches everywhere, and John MacLeod, 29th chief of the clan MacLeod, is inviting offers in excess of £10m.

Scotland has the most concentrated pattern of land ownership in the world, and the sale has caused outrage. Conservation bodies are trying to pool resources to purchase the range; lawyers are being consulted to challenge the claim of ownership; and the Scottish executive, still considering reform of land legislation, has been urged to intervene.

Meanwhile, potential buyers from Britain and overseas are approaching property consultants FPD Savills with what are described as "novel" ideas for developing the land; a wealthy Californian even wants to turn it into a rainforest.

MacLeod, as the chief is known on the island, said yesterday that he had been forced to sell to raise £6.3m to repair the leaking roof of Dunvegan castle, the family seat. "It's just the most horrendous feeling," he said. "Part of me is almost actively hoping no one comes up with an offer."

Many on the island, however, are taken aback by his claim to the mountains. "Regardless of what MacLeod says about his feudal charter, there is substantive doubt about the validity of his title," said one land reform campaigner, Andy Wightman. "It is scandalous that in Scots property conveyancing lawyers blithely recognise a 16th-century charter."

MacLeod insists that the hills are his to sell. "Lawyers are lawyers, and they believe that I do own them." He has also been attacked for the asking price, as setting a dangerous precedent that would effectively price conservationists out of the market.

The rest of the Cuillin ridge is owned by the John Muir Trust which bought the 16,000 acres (6,500 hectares) swath from Ian Anderson, the singer of Jethro Tull, for £800,000 in 1994.

The trust has been in discussion with the Skye community and other conservation bodies to come up with a rescue deal.

"There is a strong feeling the trust should do something and the community wants to be part of that," said its director, Nigel Hawkins. "But we are not in a position to pay £10m, and never will be. A quarter of that is more realistic."

Mr Anderson has offered to spearhead any campaign. He sold to the trust because he believed an individual could not maintain it properly.

"It would be an unprecedented disaster if this ended up being purchased by a wealthy individual, particularly one from a non-UK country," the musician said. "It just seems to be a long shot that any individual would have the right resources on a personal and ethical level, as well as a land management level, to do the right thing. I will be as vociferous and objectionable as I am allowed to be. My advice to anyone considering a purchase is: Don't do it."

Savills says the successful purchaser must open up the mountains. "Aspic conservation is not the owner's style," said its spokesman, Guy Galbraith. "He is completely open to who buys it, a private individual or an institution. Some conservation groups have not been complimentary about the poor old owner. I wonder if they feel their case is being improved - the owner does have a choice of to whom he sells."

MacLeod rejected suggestions that the clan's diaspora should pay to repair Dunvegan, as well as denying rumours he wants to build a luxury hotel. "I would never sell from the point of view of a commercial enterprise. But, of course, if it raises serious money, that will allow me to start thinking about putting the finance into this part of the world that terribly needs it.

"I could not possibly ask the clan for money. It is my responsibility."

Mr Wightman said anger over the sale was unprecedented: "The Cuillins are basically as God left them, with a couple of pieces of medieval paper attached."

fields.headline: National roundup
fields.trailText: Barrister jailed for blackmail
fields.body:
Barrister jailed for blackmail

A barrister was jailed at the Old Bailey for a total of 15 months yesterday after pleading guilty to blackmailing a client and forgery to try to obtain credit from Harrods' bank. Judge David Paget told Carol Winston-Churchill, 47: "Your career as a lawyer is now over. You are disgraced and destroyed."

The court heard that Winston-Churchill,from Hampstead, north London, had been disbarred last month for unrelated matters of misconduct.

The judge said the sentences would have been higher had the offences not been 14 years ago. Winston-Churchill was to stand trial in 1987 but fled to Jamaica. Despite two warrants she returned to Britain three months later and worked as a barrister within a stone's throw of the Old Bailey until her arrest in June last year.

Fraudster jailed over racing storm

A former detective sergeant was yesterday jailed for 18 months at the Old Bailey for trying to extort money from the jockey Jamie Osborne.

Judge David Paget told Robert Harrington, 58, his actions were "a very serious perversion of all you stood for all your life".

Harrington, from Reading, Berkshire, was jailed for 18 months for obtaining £500 by deception from Mr Osborne and 18 months concurrently for corruption. He was found guilty of the charges last month.

He had denied the charges saying he had been acting undercover as an informer for officers and had hoped to infiltrate a race-fixing scandal.

The court was told that Harrington approached Mr Osborne after the jockey had been arrested in 1998 as part of an inquiry into a racing scandal after one of his rides was found to have been drugged. Although Mr Osborne was later eliminated from inquiries, Harrington persuaded him that he would be implicated unless he gave a police officer £2,000.

Mr Osborne, 31, told the court he was "appalled" and went to Scotland Yard. He was fitted with secret recording equipment to trap Harrington, who was acting as a private investigator.

At the end of the trial, which lasted five weeks, Mr Osborne, who is now a trainer, said: "I am very pleased that this unwelcome chapter in my life has ended. Many innocent people have been damaged by this case."

Mr Osborne was arrested in January 1998 after Avanti Express was found to have been doped during a race in which he rode him in 1997.

He sent ripples through the racing community as he revealed he had once been approached to pull up two favourites at the Cheltenham festival.

Mr Osborne had turned it down because he wanted to make a career in racing, but said he thought a man, named in court as a criminal, had been behind the offer of £20,000 which came when he was 19 and broke.

The following day, Mr Osborne named veteran jockey Dermot Browne as the person who approached him with the bribe.

Mr Browne contacted the defence team, claiming Mr Osborne had agreed the bribe.

Mr Osborne was summoned back to court where he angrily denied the allegations, calling them "absolute rubbish, a figment of someone's imagination".

She set up on her own in 1995, using the name Carol Winston, advising clients on business and conveyancing. Despite a drink-driving arrest, she was only detected when police looking through old warrants checked a list of barristers' names.

Adrian Darbyshire, prosecuting, said that in 1986 she had threatened to tell the employer of a wealthy Wall Street banker, David Brown, that he had been a "closet gay" and had tried to get her involved in a "bizarre relationship" with him and another man, after he asked her to return $150,000 (£100,000) he had given her. The same year, she used a letter purporting to be from her then head of chambers, Stuart Bates QC, to try to obtain credit from Harrods.

Patrice Wymore-Flynn, the widow of film star Errol Flynn, came from Jamaica to be a character witness, telling the court: "She has been devoted to her friends and totally devoted to her profession. It is totally incomprehensible."

Boy choked to death on grape

A Cardiff inquest heard yesterday how Zachary Hemani, three, accidentally choked to death when he swallowed a whole grape.

His mother, Karen Hemani, 30, struggled to dislodge the grape from her son's throat but when she failed he was taken to hospital, the inquest heard. Consultant Dirk Wilson treated the boy, and described how doctors battled to start him breathing again. He told the inquest: "A standard grape would be enough to block the airway of a child."

However, the boy had probably suffered severe brain damage, and died from multiple organ failure on January 3, two days later. He and his mother, who lives in Hemel Hempstead, Hertfordshire, had been visiting relatives in Swansea at the time. Coroner Lawrence Addicott recorded a verdict of accidental death.

After the inquest, Mrs Hemani said: "I would like to warn all mothers.

"You are so careful with everything else like sweets and nuts. You never dream that something as healthy as a grape could cause this."

Breakfast show DJ's early start

DJ Sara Cox breathed a sigh of relief yesterday after sneaking on air three days early for her first Radio 1 Breakfast Show.

Cox was not due to go on air until Monday but her desire to complete her first show prompted her into asking Radio 1 controller Andy Parfitt for the unscheduled debut.

She said: "I couldn't wait any longer. All week we've been doing shows as live but they've not been going out. It's quite hard to fake it, there's nothing like the thrill of knowing your friends and mum are listening, that's when the adrenaline gets going.

"For the past few months the point I've been looking forward to is the end of the first show, the handover to Simon Mayo at 9am. The hardest part was the first day and that's all over now," she added.

Cox, 25, originally from Bolton, kicked off her show by playing Robbie Williams' Let Me Entertain You and held a phone in about bizarre initiation ceremonies.

She joked to listeners: "I've already flushed my own head down the loo to get it over with."

After the show the former presenter for Channel 4's Big Breakfast said that the pressure to perform well on the first show would have been too much and she was keen to have a more low-key start."If I'd stuck to doing the first one on Monday it would have been too scary. It would have felt just too much like a test rather than a first show. Now I can relax over the weekend and I'm sure the fans of the show won't have minded."

Cox, who lives with Leeroy Thornhill of dance band the Prodigy, said the anxiety of the new show had caused a sleepless night. "I was just lying there with the adrenaline pumping. I could feel it coursing through me. Leeroy was still asleep and I just lay there next to him buzzing. I'd been dreaming that I was late."

Slimy routhe to future of computing

It may not be the most obvious, or pleasant, place to search, but slug slime could hold the key to building the next generation of super computers.

Researchers in Edinburgh believe the mucus layer left by the slimy creatures may provide the answer for scientists looking to build faster and more powerful computers, run not by electronics but chemically.

A team led by Christopher Viney at Heriot-Watt University in Edinburgh has discovered that slug slime contains a liquid crystalline layer with directional properties. It is the structure of the crystals in the slime laid down by a slug which allows another slug to "read" the direction its fellow shell-less mollusc, perhaps a potential mate, is heading. Professor Viney believes this may be fundamental in the race to develop chemical computers.

"The structure of the crystal in the slime has very little symmetry. This allows crystals pointing to the left to be distinguished from crystals pointing to the right - a property which would be essential to a chemical computer," he said.

At present a computer uses magnetised particles, where moments point up or down, or switches, which are on or off, to store binary information, but compared with the potential of a chemical computer this is bulky and inefficient.

"Basically a desk-sized chemical computer would be as powerful as today's mainframes," said Prof Viney.

Although it might seem a strange place in which to search for 21st-century advances, he said slug slime - which allows the creatures to both slide along rough surfaces and stick to smooth ones - might prove to have uses in other areas of science. Gerard Seenan

Warning as ticks move to the north

Scientists in northern England have recorded a marked rise in the population of blood-sucking ticks that feed on sheep, grouse - and tourists.

Ramblers and picnickers have been issued warnings by councils in coastal areas, where heathland and sea mist offer ideal breeding conditions for the spider-like Rhipicephalus bursa.

Attack often goes unnoticed until the ticks swell from a pinhead to the size of a pea as they gorge on blood.

Bites seldom cause more than irritation, but a few cases can give rise to Lyme disease, which has symptoms including rashes and swollen glands, leading to chronic tiredness and flu-like effects. Britain's first cases of Lyme disease were recorded some years ago in the New Forest, from where the insects began their march north.

"The ticks have become a problem because of the milder weather," said Mike Pratt of the North York Moors national park, where conservationists are also concerned about the parasites' predation on protected birds, such as the lapwing.

"Conservationists have found the young birds covered with ticks. A warm spring brings the things out of their hibernation, and they get breeding earlier." Martin Wainwright

Gun guard gets nine life terms

A former security guard was given nine life sentences at the Old Bailey yesterday after embarking on a shooting rampage as he drove away from police who had stopped him for an out-of-date tax disc.

George Knights, 42, of Feltham, west London, sped through streets near his home last May, firing at bus passengers, motorists and police while ramming cars as he tried to escape.

Judge Giles Forrester told him: "I have no doubt that you pose an unusually high degree of risk. You clearly have an extensive knowledge not only of firearms but also of explosives. Your interest is an unhealthy one and amounts to an obsession. It is without exaggeration miraculous that no one was hit."

Knights was convicted last month of 19 offences includ ing kidnap and possessing firearms and homemade grenades. As well as the life sentences, he was given a series of concurrent jail terms of up to eight years.

The judge praised the "bravery and calmness" of motorists caught up in the car chase.

Nicholas Wood, prosecuting, told the court that after police stopped Knights over the tax disc, he jumped out of his car and fired a self-loading pistol at them before driving off, still shooting. Swerving across the road to block a police Land Rover, he pulled out a Bushmaster assault rifle and shot the tyres out.

He drove through back streets of Hanworth, stopped at a junction and tried to flag down a woman driver, shouting at her. She drove off around his car, hearing gunshots behind her.

He then threatened a Dial-a-Ride bus, hijacked a BMW and took the driver of a Cavalier hostage before he was surrounded by armed police at his home. Police stormed the flat after hearing a gunshot and an explosion.

Britains hurt in Laos explosion

Four British tourists were among nine people injured in an explosion in Laos, the Foreign Office said yesterday. A British man was airlifted to hospital for emergency treatment and the other three, a woman and two men, were less seriously injured in the blast on Thursday night at a restaurant in the capital, Vientiane.

A German and a Laotian were also seriously injured and other tourists were treated for cuts and lacerations.

Witnesses reported that a grenade or bomb had been tossed from a motorcycle at the Kop Chai Deu restaurant.

Ginny Stein, a reporter with the Australian Broadcasting Corporation, said: "The scene was terrible."

She said the airlifted Briton was hit in the chest by shrapnel. He was flown to neighbouring Thailand for treatment.

The Foreign Office said that his injuries were not life threatening and that his family in Britain had been informed.

The other three Britons were treated at the local Mahosot hospital. Lisa Thomlinson

webTitle: Flash of a blade, then Noye sped off, court told

fields.headline: Flash of a blade, then Noye sped off, court told
fields.trailText: A witness to the alleged murder of Stephen Cameron in a road rage attack saw Kenneth Noye take a knife out of his pocket, hide it behind his back, then lunge forward and stab his victim in the chest, the Old Bailey heard yesterday.
fields.body:
A witness to the alleged murder of Stephen Cameron in a road rage attack saw Kenneth Noye take a knife out of his pocket, hide it behind his back, then lunge forward and stab his victim in the chest, the Old Bailey heard yesterday.

Noye, 52, then walked back towards his car and nodded at Alan Decabral, who was sitting in his Rolls-Royce.

"It was as if to say, 'That's sorted him out', " said Mr Decabral. "I did not know what to do. I've never seen anything like it before in my life."

Mr Decabral was giving evidence on the second day of the trial of Noye, who is accused of murdering Mr Cameron on May 19, 1996. Noye, of West Kingsdown, Kent, admits stabbing Mr Cameron, 21, but claims it was self-defence.

Mr Decabral said he was waiting at the traffic lights on a sliproad near the Swanley junction of the M25 in Kent where Mr Cameron was killed when he heard someone beeping a horn and turned to see a violent struggle between the two men.

Noye, the driver of a Land Rover Discovery, was fighting with Mr Cameron, the passenger in a red Rascal van driven by his fiancee Danielle Cable, the court heard.

Mr Decabral said the men were struggling for control of the driver's door of the van, a tussle which Mr Cameron won.

"Then it all kicked off," Mr Decabral told the jury. Noye threw the first punch, he said, and Mr Cameron retaliated.

The fight stopped and Noye, taking a step backwards, reached into the front right hand pocket of his trousers and pulled something out.

"He hid his hand behind his back," said Mr Decabral. "The guy standing in front of him would not have been aware of it. The knife was not open at first. Then I saw a flash. I realised it was a knife. I could see the sun glinting off the blade."

Mr Decabral said the weapon was possibly a flick knife, but it was hard to tell.

"He [Noye] then made a run at the younger man again, who punched him. The older man stabbed him in the chest. I saw him stab him.

"The young man staggered back, and fell against the front of the van. I heard him tell his girlfriend to get the number plate because he had been stabbed.

"I could see him [Noye] shut the blade with both hands and put it back in his right hand pocket. He nodded at me, as if to say 'That's sorted him out'.

"I thought I was dreaming. As soon as I saw the knife and I saw him get stabbed, I reached down for my phone and dialled 999."

Mr Decabral said Noye sped away from the scene "PDQ - pretty darn quick".

He tried to follow in his car, but lost him when Noye swerved across a line of traffic, the jury heard.

Stephen Batten QC, defending, said he believed Mr Decabral had been "quite seriously wrong" in his recollection of events, and asked whether he had read any of the press reports about the case.

Mr Decabral replied: "No, none of them. I only came here to say what I saw."

Another witness, Amanda Whelan, recalled hearing Mr Cameron's fiancee screaming hysterically: "Get him off, help, help." She told the jury Mr Cameron was pinned against the front bumpers of the van as he fought with Noye.

"The younger man was kicking at the older man. They were making contact with each other's bodies. I saw a flash but I assumed it was a watchband."

"I did not know what to do. I've never seen anything like it before in my life." Noye, of West Kingsdown, Kent, admits stabbing Mr Cameron, 21, but claims it was self-defence. Noye threw the first punch, he said, and Mr Cameron retaliated. The fight stopped and Noye, taking a step backwards, reached into the front right hand pocket of his trousers and pulled something out. webTitle: Vets link cats with risk of catching TB

fields.headline: Vets link cats with risk of catching TB
fields.trailText: Government vets yesterday said there may be "a real threat" of cat owners catching tuberculosis from their pets as the disease takes greater hold on Britain's cattle and wildlife.
fields.body:
Government vets yesterday said there may be "a real threat" of cat owners catching tuberculosis from their pets as the disease takes greater hold on Britain's cattle and wildlife.

One also warned of a greater risk of catching a strain now rare in humans from other sources if the infections in herds became more widespread.

Health officials are already monitoring TB incidence in farm workers because of the increasing potential for them to get the disease but the Department of Health could not say last night whether surveillance of the wider population, including owners of 8m cats, might be considered.

It also emerged last night that English Nature and the Countryside Council for Wales, want more research on whether dogs and cats might play an important role in spreading TB.

The vets insisted they were not being alarmist but their report on what is also a rare disease in cats seems to have caught civil servants by surprise. The RSPCA said there was no reason for pet lovers to be scared by the news.

The TB involved is Mycobacterium bovis, which in the 1930s killed 2,500 people a year and infected 50,000. It is thought now to affect around 40 people a year and may only become obvious years after infection. It can be caught through unpasteurised milk or by those working closely with cattle through droplets from sick animals. Symptoms include fever and coughing, sometimes with blood, and weight loss.

The strain was once common in humans. Now it affects mostly elderly people. TB in cattle, which affected only 143 farms 10 years ago, was confirmed in 515 herds in 1997. This rose to 740 in 1998 and provisional figures for last year suggest this rose to 872, although part of the increase is due to increased testing.

The Department of Healthsaid: "We are working closely with the Ministry of Agriculture to identify the potential for transmission to humans of all such diseases. Our view is M. bovis is a rare cause of TB in humans these days. We will continue looking at the risks."

The latest alert comes in an article by six members of the veterinary laboratories agency, responsible to the Ministry of Agriculture, who found M. bovis in the bodies of a badger and three cats which died on a small holding in west Cornwall, during 1998. It was in an area affected by cattle TB although no cattle had been on the property for many years.

They concluded: "Despite rare occurence of M.bovis as a cause of TB in humans in recent years, M.bovis infection in cats may pose a real zoonotic threat to their keepers."

He said: "We do not have any concrete evidence that the infection in cats has spread from cattle, or badgers, or any other wildlife source. What we are saying is the strain in that infection is the same strain that has occured in wildlife, in badgers, and in cattle."

The RSPCA said: "There is not a high risk, and don't treat your cat any differently." But a spokeswoman said neutering male cats cut the risk of them catching both the feline version of HIV and TB.

The government is involved in a controversial badger cull to established whether it is responsible for TB.

Elaine King, of the National Federation of Badger Groups, said: "This is typical of the way the Ministry of Agriculture moves the blame away from cattle at every opportunity. They are scapegoating badgers and other wildlife or domestic animals, while not considering whether infection could have come from cattle."

The federation, together with other wildlife groups, has demanded checks on whether cats and dogs as well as wildlife might help spread bovine TB, and research into other possible factors.

webTitle: Minimum wage level may be linked to inflation

fields.headline: Minimum wage level may be linked to inflation
fields.standfirst:
More about the minimum wage
The minimum wage explained
fields.trailText: The low pay commission may propose a mechanism to trigger annual rises to the national minimum wage, possibly by linking it to inflation or average earnings growth.
fields.body:
The low pay commission may propose a mechanism to trigger annual rises to the national minimum wage, possibly by linking it to inflation or average earnings growth.

Members of the nine-strong advisory body are to try to devise a formula for regular upratings, to begin after the 10p an hour increase to £3.70 set for October for the 1.5m-plus workers covered by the wage.

They will also consider evidence that the lower £3 figure for 18 to 21-year-olds, due to go up to £3.20 in October, has failed to encourage employers to train younger workers.

George Bain, the commission chairman, speaking on the eve of today's first anniversary of the minimum wage, said the body would review "the appropriate mechanism" for uprating, before the deadline in July 2001 to suggest another rise in October 2001.

Professor Bain said that, one year on, the minimum wage was "part of the fabric" of working life. Claims that it would cost thousands of jobs had proved unfounded, and even the Conservatives had dropped their opposition.

He claimed that few workers were short-changed on the minimum and Department of Trade and Industry figures show that only 10 companies have been taken to employment tribunals for underpayment. But the Citizens Advice Bureau and the Low Pay Unit have called for stronger enforcement and the closing of loopholes, including complex piecework calculations that were said to have left one woman packing cards at home for £3.70 a day.

The commission is believed to be against union calls to tie the rate to average male earnings, which would give between £4.07 and £4.79 an hour, depending on the data used. It is likely instead to study flexible options to stop earnings of the lowest paid falling in comparison to rises given other workers.

The government is not obliged to accept the commission's recommendations but would face the ire of union leaders and Labour MPs as well as the public if it rejected a clear proposal.

But regular rises might alarm the CBI, which dropped outright opposition after receiving assurances the minimum would be set at a modest figure.

October's increase to £3.70 will come after an 18 month interval, and a cabinet minister close to the commission hinted that the next rise, scheduled a year later, could be more than 10p.

Gordon Brown, the chancellor, and Stephen Byers, the trade secretary, agreed the 10p rise only after warnings of a revolt in Labour's heartlands.

webTitle: Brit art stars boost Livingstone campaign

fields.headline: Brit art stars boost Livingstone campaign
fields.standfirst: The London mayor: special report
fields.trailText: Ken Livingstone's bid to become mayor of London has been given a boost with many of the country's greatest living artists donating works to his campaign.
fields.body:
Ken Livingstone's bid to become mayor of London has been given a boost with many of the country's greatest living artists donating works to his campaign.

An auction of sculptures, drawings and paintings from the likes of Damien Hirst and Howard Hodgkin is expected to raise more than £100,000 when on Monday.

Mr Livingstone famously launched his election campaign with the battle cry: "Send me money."

The artists have responded by sending their art, said Peter Kennard, who is organising the sale at Gimpel Fils in central London.

The list of names who have given works reads like a who's who of contemporary British art: Antony Gormley, Sir Anthony Caro, Richard Hamilton, Maggie Hambling, Richard Wentworth, Richard Hamilton and Gillian Ayers.

The young stars of Brit art have also offered support. Tracey Emin has made a book dedicated to Mr Livingstone, while Hirst has donated one of his spin paintings. The Chapman brothers, Sarah Lucas, Mona Hatoum, Cornelia Parker and Matt Collishaw have also stumped up pieces for the cause. More than 50 artists have so far given pieces.

Support for Mr Livingstone is not confined to visual arts. The writers Tariq Ali, Howard Brenton and Andy De La Tour are staging a play called Snogging Ken at the Almeida Theatre , Islington, north London, from April 18 to 28.

fields.headline: Bridging Britain's social divide
fields.standfirst: Urban renewal: Multibillion-pound deal to tackle high crime, death rates and unemployment comes after exhaustive study of exclusion
fields.trailText: Ministers are preparing to unveil a multibillion pound neighbourhood renewal programme aimed at closing the widening gap between the levels of crime, unemployment, mortality, skills in Britain's 44 poorest districts and the rest of the country.
fields.byline: Patrick Wintour, Lucy Ward and Peter Hetherington
fields.body:
Ministers are preparing to unveil a multibillion pound neighbourhood renewal programme aimed at closing the widening gap between the levels of crime, unemployment, mortality, skills in Britain's 44 poorest districts and the rest of the country.

The districts are primarily in the inner cities, raning from Britain's poorest borough, Tower Hamlets in east London, to Manningham in Bradford.

In what will be the culmination of one of the most exhaustive studies into social deprivation and regenerative strategy, the Social Exclusion Unit will publish shortly its report National Strategy for Neighbourhood Renewal.

The report will form the central policy plank for the government in its attempts to retrieve the country's most disadvantaged neighbourhoods.

Some 18 separate studies have examined almost every aspect of community life and have assessed why a succession of local and central government departments have failed to tackle the drift of the dispossessed sections of society.

The strategy will allow ministers to deliver what Tony Blair has called "joined up government" with the exclusion unit criticising the piecemeal approach to local problems and instead suggesting more devolved power to allow locally-led solutions.

Among those solutions under consideration by ministers are giving the poorest wards, or estates individual improvement targets in an effort to provide proposed new individual neighbourhood managers incentives to raise the ambitions of communities.

Measures to be unveiled as part of the renewal programme will include more uniformed neighbourhood wardens on estates, a revival of inner city shopping, a new role for the Post Office in delivering banking and a national neighbourhood renewal centre to train up a generation of social entrepreneurs.

Among the institutions facing change are schools, which in poor areas will be transformed from 9am to 3pm services to wide-reaching community centres offering adult learning, extracurricular activities, health advice, parental guidance and sports and arts facilities outside traditional school hours. Each school will be asked to provide three hours extra study support per week.

The report also calls for a crackdown on anti-social neighbours, including placing persistent offenders in special residential homes.

Some social landlords recorded up to 285 complaints per 1,000 tenancies a year about the behaviour of neighbours and 75% of them considered this to be a serious problem.

Although the report admits its researches have revealed a huge information gap, research compiled since November 1998 from 18 separate policy action teams working under the eye of the SEU, has convinced ministers that the poorest estates have been falling behind.

Forty per cent of crime takes place in just 10% of areas and 10% of residents of inner-city areas are burgled once or more in a year - double the rate elsewhere. Anti-social behaviour is perceived by residents to be twice as high in deprived areas than nationally. Mortality rates are also a third higher than the national average.

The research has found a signigicant rump of 15 local au thority districts with very low employment rates of around 61.75% or below.

The renewal programme will propose halving the gap in unemployment between the 44 poorest districts and the remainder of the country.

Some of the recommendations including the delivery proposals - with supervision placed in the hands of a strengthened network of gov ernment offices in the eight regions, a proposal which will prove controversial.

But the report found: "No one has had responsibility for looking at neighbourhood renewal across the board either nationally or at a local level.

"There has been too little coordination at all levels of government and too many perverse incentives.

"Resources have often been inadequate. The wrong targets have been set. Some public organisations have consistently failed to provide an effective service. Regeneration programmes have failed to influence mainstream services."

Another plank of the report will be the need to devolve power down to local neighbourhoods - much smaller areas than those covered by metropolitan authorities.

Ministers want to provide communities with unprecedented levels of information via a series of "neighbourhood statistics", which would allow comparisons of comparable areas in terms of joblessness rates, school staying-on rates and exam results, crime and community facilities. Such information would be freely available in libraries and on the internet.

One source said: "This way any council ward in the country would be able to compare itself with the one next door or with the national average".

More statistical information will also allow the government to set specific improvement targets for individual areas rather than simply measuring them against national averages.

"This extra information and evidence will be a key tool for what is going on," said the source. "We can use it as a battering ram for improvement."

Already the Cabinet Office minister, Lord Falconer, one of the prime minister's closest friends, has been drafted into the Department of the Environment to coordinate regional strategy. This follows a damning report on disjointed government initiatives from the performance and innovation unit in the Cabinet Office.

The national neighbourhood renewal strategy will be the culmination of 18 months work by the SEU following the launch of a study programme by Mr Blair.

The deputy prime minister, John Prescott, is fighting for more cash from the Treasury in the forthcoming comprhensive spending review to drive forward his New Deal for Communities programme.

An £800m pilot programme in 17 "pathfinder"districts was launched 18 months ago - but the deputy prime minister's Department of the Environment is hoping that many other areas will soon be in a position to bid for funds.

Significantly, these pilot schemes - in areas with 2,000 to 5,000 people - are driven by local community groups rather than by town halls, although most are working in partnership with local authorities.

But ministers have been keen to encourage local partnerships and "active citizens" - rather than local councilloors - with a new breed of community enterprises.

The Social Exclusion Unit has talked of encouraging "dynamic local leaders with the power and resources to turn their community around".

With this in mind, the pathfinder schemes were labelled a "major shift of power and responsibility down to the neighbourhood level".

Scale of the problems in the poorest areas and how they might be tackled

Jobs

Fifteen local authority districts, mostly in major cities although some are former coalfields or seaside towns, have very low employment rates of 61.75% or below - more than 10 percentage points below the national average

Unemployment rates in the 100 worst of the country's 11,000 wards were up to 25 percentage points higher than average, with unemployment in the worst ward at up to 30%. In short, you are up to six times more likely to be unemployed in one of these 100 wards.

Recommendations include personal advisers, more outreach work, improvement to personal skills for the unemployed, and changes to benefit structure.

Skills

Too many adults have a poor experience of compulsory education, and are disinclined ever to learn again. Adult education and training is often hard to get to, intimidating or otherwise difficult for the socially disadvantaged.

Solutions include neighbourhood learning centres, more community generated training, and setting learning targets for communities

Enterprise

No national strategy exists for supporting enterprise in poor areas; business support is patchy. People in deprived areas find it difficult to raise capital. Self-employment is undervalued as a form of work.

A small business service should be set up to encourage starters, and the importance of enterprise in regeneration must be recognised by regional development agencies .

Housing management

Effective management in disadvantaged areas requires a wide range of services. Being an advocate for an estate and acting as a catalyst to pull in other services is as important as ensuring repairs on time.

Extensive decentralisation to local estate offices remains rare. Drawing up a clear and enforceable agreement about the roles of tenants and housing managers is essential.

Neighbourhood wardens

Crime is a major problem: 40%of crime is in 10%of areas. One in 10 inner city residents is burgled once or more in a year - double that elsewhere. Half of crime victims are repeat victims, accounting for 81% of recorded crime.

Estate wardens should not be given new powers, and councils and local police should have joint accountability for outcomes of warden schemes.

Unpopular housing

Six out of 10 English councils report low demand or unpopular housing stock. Social landlords report 8% (around 89,500) of their homes are unpopular. Such housing dislike and neighbourhood abandonment is increasing in public and private sectors.

Shopping

As superstores have gone from 457 in 1986 to 1,102 by 1997, across the country each day eight independent shops disappeared between 1986 and 1996, a fall overall of almost 40% between 1986 and 1997.

A community of 4,000 households each spending on average £66 per week would need to spend10% at the local shop, and its turnover would be £27,500 per week, more than £1m a year, indicating survival is possible. Such shops need better stocks and display, and some should be mobile.

Young people

Young people face a mix of problems - from poverty and unemployment to crime and poor health - but have been failed by fragmented services. At all levels including government, there is no "big picture" and, far from targeting the poorest, the state spends 14% less than average on young people in the most deprived areas.

The report recommends a youth unit to push a clearer strategy, led by at least two ministers for youth, and more coordination at local level. Fo cus should switch from crisis response to prevention.

Learning lessons

Community leaders in deprived areas were found to lack support and encouragement, while national policy makers had no personal experience of the problems.

There should be funding and training for ocal people to take the lead as "social entrepreneurs", improved training for local professionals in the challenges of poor neighbourhoods, and secondments for civil servants to disadvantaged areas. A development fund should give small grants to community groups for "social entrepreneurial activity".

Community self-help

Absence of strong communities can see social decay matched by physical decay, lack of hope, an exodus and, eventually, a "point of no return". A government commitment to supporting self-help was recommended, plus more involvement of churches and other faith communities in regeneration; reforming benefit rules that impede voluntary work; and more mentoring to provide role models for young people.

Arts and sport

Arts and sport can help poor communities, improving self-esteem, mental well-being and children's development. However, programmes focused on providers rather than users and were funded short-term.

It was recommended leisure activities get a bigger role in community regeneration, with more help from local authorities and from government funding for local regeneration. Schools should be available outside hours, and the lottery could fund community venues.

Financial services

This examined credit unions and banks, post offices and insurance. More than 2m adults, mostly jobless and on benefits, use no services. High crime may make insurance unaffordable, and banks have cut branches, leaving deprived neighbourhoods unserved. Some households cannot provide identity documents to open accounts.

Credit unions should be helped, as should "insurance with rent" schemes to cover poorer homes. Banks and building societies should be more accessible to poorer customers.

Anti-social behaviour

This was found to be a widespread and increasing problem, and twice as high in deprived neighbourhoods as nationally - ranging from dropping litter to serious harassment. It destroys lives and shatters communities. However, no one agency or government department is tackling the problem, making action ineffective.

The report recommends given the problem a high priority and better coordination at all levels; improved efforts at prevention and more use of powers - including anti-social behaviour orders and eviction. Zero tolerance for racial harassment.

Information technology

There is the danger of a digital divide. Lack of access reinforces disadvantage, slows progress at school, and blocks the path into the job market. In some estates, less than 50% of households have a phone, and computer ownership is lower still.

By 2002, each neighbourhood should have at least one community IT facility, all communities to have access to electronically delivered public services by 2008. And telecoms operators should offer more flexible tariffss with Oftel ensuring the poorest are not priced out of phone services.

Schools plus

This examined ways to extend use of schools for children and the wider community -breakfast clubs, homework centres and summercommunity activities. It set a target of three hours of extracurricular activities a week for pupils; extended hours at some schools to allow study support; and one-stop family support centres to serve pupils and their families. Stronger links were recommended between schools and communities, with "schools plus" teams to help parental and community involvement. Cash to promote supplementary and mother tongue schools. Young people to have more input, including through a youth consultation website.

Joining it up locally

Due shortly, this is expected to call for coordination between agencies in poor neighbourhoods. It could pave the way for central coordination, bypassing local authorities.

Better information

Also due shortly, this is expected to call for detailed information on small neighbourhoods of some 2,000 households based on council wards. Data, to be available locally in public libraries and on the internet, to include employment rates, school staying-on rates and levels of government spending.
