Some social landlords recorded up to 285 complaints per 1,000 tenancies a year about the behaviour of neighbours and 75% of them considered this to be a serious problem. Although the report admits its researches have revealed a huge information gap, research compiled since November 1998 from 18 separate policy action teams working under the eye of the SEU, has convinced ministers that the poorest estates have been falling behind. Forty per cent of crime takes place in just 10% of areas and 10% of residents of inner-city areas are burgled once or more in a year - double the rate elsewhere. Anti-social behaviour is perceived by residents to be twice as high in deprived areas than nationally. Mortality rates are also a third higher than the national average. The research has found a signigicant rump of 15 local au thority districts with very low employment rates of around 61.75% or below. The renewal programme will propose halving the gap in unemployment between the 44 poorest districts and the remainder of the country. Some of the recommendations including the delivery proposals - with supervision placed in the hands of a strengthened network of gov ernment offices in the eight regions, a proposal which will prove controversial. But the report found: "No one has had responsibility for looking at neighbourhood renewal across the board either nationally or at a local level. "There has been too little coordination at all levels of government and too many perverse incentives. "Resources have often been inadequate. The wrong targets have been set. Some public organisations have consistently failed to provide an effective service. Regeneration programmes have failed to influence mainstream services." Another plank of the report will be the need to devolve power down to local neighbourhoods - much smaller areas than those covered by metropolitan authorities. Ministers want to provide communities with unprecedented levels of information via a series of "neighbourhood statistics", which would allow comparisons of comparable areas in terms of joblessness rates, school staying-on rates and exam results, crime and community facilities. Such information would be freely available in libraries and on the internet. One source said: "This way any council ward in the country would be able to compare itself with the one next door or with the national average". More statistical information will also allow the government to set specific improvement targets for individual areas rather than simply measuring them against national averages. "This extra information and evidence will be a key tool for what is going on," said the source. "We can use it as a battering ram for improvement." Already the Cabinet Office minister, Lord Falconer, one of the prime minister's closest friends, has been drafted into the Department of the Environment to coordinate regional strategy. This follows a damning report on disjointed government initiatives from the performance and innovation unit in the Cabinet Office. The national neighbourhood renewal strategy will be the culmination of 18 months work by the SEU following the launch of a study programme by Mr Blair. The deputy prime minister, John Prescott, is fighting for more cash from the Treasury in the forthcoming comprhensive spending review to drive forward his New Deal for Communities programme. An £800m pilot programme in 17 "pathfinder"districts was launched 18 months ago - but the deputy prime minister's Department of the Environment is hoping that many other areas will soon be in a position to bid for funds. Significantly, these pilot schemes - in areas with 2,000 to 5,000 people - are driven by local community groups rather than by town halls, although most are working in partnership with local authorities. But ministers have been keen to encourage local partnerships and "active citizens" - rather than local councilloors - with a new breed of community enterprises. The Social Exclusion Unit has talked of encouraging "dynamic local leaders with the power and resources to turn their community around". With this in mind, the pathfinder schemes were labelled a "major shift of power and responsibility down to the neighbourhood level". Scale of the problems in the poorest areas and how they might be tackled Jobs Fifteen local authority districts, mostly in major cities although some are former coalfields or seaside towns, have very low employment rates of 61.75% or below - more than 10 percentage points below the national average Unemployment rates in the 100 worst of the country's 11,000 wards were up to 25 percentage points higher than average, with unemployment in the worst ward at up to 30%. In short, you are up to six times more likely to be unemployed in one of these 100 wards. Recommendations include personal advisers, more outreach work, improvement to personal skills for the unemployed, and changes to benefit structure. Skills Too many adults have a poor experience of compulsory education, and are disinclined ever to learn again. Adult education and training is often hard to get to, intimidating or otherwise difficult for the socially disadvantaged. Solutions include neighbourhood learning centres, more community generated training, and setting learning targets for communities Enterprise No national strategy exists for supporting enterprise in poor areas; business support is patchy. People in deprived areas find it difficult to raise capital. Self-employment is undervalued as a form of work. A small business service should be set up to encourage starters, and the importance of enterprise in regeneration must be recognised by regional development agencies . Housing management Effective management in disadvantaged areas requires a wide range of services. Being an advocate for an estate and acting as a catalyst to pull in other services is as important as ensuring repairs on time. Extensive decentralisation to local estate offices remains rare. Drawing up a clear and enforceable agreement about the roles of tenants and housing managers is essential. Neighbourhood wardens Crime is a major problem: 40%of crime is in 10%of areas. One in 10 inner city residents is burgled once or more in a year - double that elsewhere. Half of crime victims are repeat victims, accounting for 81% of recorded crime. Estate wardens should not be given new powers, and councils and local police should have joint accountability for outcomes of warden schemes. Unpopular housing Six out of 10 English councils report low demand or unpopular housing stock. Social landlords report 8% (around 89,500) of their homes are unpopular. Such housing dislike and neighbourhood abandonment is increasing in public and private sectors. Shopping As superstores have gone from 457 in 1986 to 1,102 by 1997, across the country each day eight independent shops disappeared between 1986 and 1996, a fall overall of almost 40% between 1986 and 1997. A community of 4,000 households each spending on average £66 per week would need to spend10% at the local shop, and its turnover would be £27,500 per week, more than £1m a year, indicating survival is possible. Such shops need better stocks and display, and some should be mobile. Young people Young people face a mix of problems - from poverty and unemployment to crime and poor health - but have been failed by fragmented services. At all levels including government, there is no "big picture" and, far from targeting the poorest, the state spends 14% less than average on young people in the most deprived areas. The report recommends a youth unit to push a clearer strategy, led by at least two ministers for youth, and more coordination at local level. Fo cus should switch from crisis response to prevention. Learning lessons Community leaders in deprived areas were found to lack support and encouragement, while national policy makers had no personal experience of the problems. There should be funding and training for ocal people to take the lead as "social entrepreneurs", improved training for local professionals in the challenges of poor neighbourhoods, and secondments for civil servants to disadvantaged areas. A development fund should give small grants to community groups for "social entrepreneurial activity". Community self-help Absence of strong communities can see social decay matched by physical decay, lack of hope, an exodus and, eventually, a "point of no return". A government commitment to supporting self-help was recommended, plus more involvement of churches and other faith communities in regeneration; reforming benefit rules that impede voluntary work; and more mentoring to provide role models for young people. Arts and sport Arts and sport can help poor communities, improving self-esteem, mental well-being and children's development. However, programmes focused on providers rather than users and were funded short-term. It was recommended leisure activities get a bigger role in community regeneration, with more help from local authorities and from government funding for local regeneration. Schools should be available outside hours, and the lottery could fund community venues. Financial services This examined credit unions and banks, post offices and insurance. More than 2m adults, mostly jobless and on benefits, use no services. High crime may make insurance unaffordable, and banks have cut branches, leaving deprived neighbourhoods unserved. Some households cannot provide identity documents to open accounts. Credit unions should be helped, as should "insurance with rent" schemes to cover poorer homes. Banks and building societies should be more accessible to poorer customers. Anti-social behaviour This was found to be a widespread and increasing problem, and twice as high in deprived neighbourhoods as nationally - ranging from dropping litter to serious harassment. It destroys lives and shatters communities. However, no one agency or government department is tackling the problem, making action ineffective. The report recommends given the problem a high priority and better coordination at all levels; improved efforts at prevention and more use of powers - including anti-social behaviour orders and eviction. Zero tolerance for racial harassment. Information technology There is the danger of a digital divide. Lack of access reinforces disadvantage, slows progress at school, and blocks the path into the job market. In some estates, less than 50% of households have a phone, and computer ownership is lower still. By 2002, each neighbourhood should have at least one community IT facility, all communities to have access to electronically delivered public services by 2008. And telecoms operators should offer more flexible tariffss with Oftel ensuring the poorest are not priced out of phone services. Schools plus This examined ways to extend use of schools for children and the wider community -breakfast clubs, homework centres and summercommunity activities. It set a target of three hours of extracurricular activities a week for pupils; extended hours at some schools to allow study support; and one-stop family support centres to serve pupils and their families. Stronger links were recommended between schools and communities, with "schools plus" teams to help parental and community involvement. Cash to promote supplementary and mother tongue schools. Young people to have more input, including through a youth consultation website. Joining it up locally Due shortly, this is expected to call for coordination between agencies in poor neighbourhoods. It could pave the way for central coordination, bypassing local authorities. Better information Also due shortly, this is expected to call for detailed information on small neighbourhoods of some 2,000 households based on council wards. Data, to be available locally in public libraries and on the internet, to include employment rates, school staying-on rates and levels of government spending.

fields.headline: Marine killed in training accident
fields.trailText: A training exercise turned to tragedy yesterday morning when a teenage Royal Marine recruit was shot and killed with live ammunition.
fields.body:
A training exercise turned to tragedy yesterday morning when a teenage Royal Marine recruit was shot and killed with live ammunition.

The dead recruit was named yesterday as Wayne Richards, 17, from South Wales. Described as "irrepressibly cheerful" and popular, he was in the ninth week of a three month training course at the Royal Marine training centre at Lympstone in Devon.

Civilian and military police have launched an investigation into the incident, which happened at around 5.30am yesterday on Woodbury Common, near Exmouth.

The shooting is thought by police to be the result of a mix up of blank and live ammunition, a mistake which has been responsible for at least one other training fatality on a similar exercise.

Ministry of Defence officials said recruits would normally carry standard issue SA80 rifles fitted with blanks during such night time exercises, but designated sentries armed with live ammunition would have been standing guard at various points around the training area.

An MoD spokesman said that there would also have been "safety numbers" - soldiers whose sole responsibility is to monitor the safe progress of an exercise - on duty throughout the training.

Armed guards have been provided for training exercises at Lympstone for almost a decade following terrorist threats made after the bomb blast that killed 11 young royal marine bandsmen in Deal, Kent in 1989.

Chief Superintendent Liam McGrath, the officer in charge of the investigation, said it was unusual for live ammunition to be discharged on Woodbury Common. Details of why it was involved in the recruit's death would be the subject of the police inquiry.

The scene of the shooting was sealed off yesterday as police officers and Royal Marine personnel carried out an inspection of the area.

Mr Richards is the fifth recruit to die during training at Lympstone since 1996. Since 1992 there have been 52 fatalities involving firearms in the army, but these include suicides.

The MoD said that while regrettable, accidents were unavoidable. "Military training by its very nature carries an element of risk," said the spokesman.

The commandant of the commando training centre, Brigadier Andy Pillar, described Mr Richards as a "very special young man".

He added: "He was hard-working, irrepressibly cheerful, very popular with both his fellow recruits and training team, and he undoubtedly had a bright future ahead of him in the Royal Marines. We are all deeply shocked and saddened by this terrible news.

"We are now doing all we can to support both Wayne's family and his fellow recruits during this very difficult time."

The training centre at Lympstone can accommodate up to 900 recruits at any one time, and runs one of the toughest induction courses in the military.

Recruits face a three-day pre-recruitment test, involving physical endurance and aptitude tests. As the training proper progresses the recruits are subject to constant assessment and the least able often are stood down to repeat a section of the training.

In the past, parents of soldiers killed in training incidents have expressed dissatisfaction with the inquiry procedure.

Army boards of inquiry are held in private and often staffed by senior members of the regiment involved in the accident.

The MoD confirmed that the inquiry into Mr Richards' death would be conducted by senior officers from the training base at Lympstone, but thought it unlikely they would be officers directly involved in the exercise.

Pauline Hawksley's son Robert was 29 when he was killed by friendly fire during a training exercise in Canada in 1994. Mrs Hawksley and her husband, David, were dissatisfied with the coroner's verdict of accidental death, and the memory of her treatment by the army is still fresh.

"My heart goes out to the family of this poor lad. You would expect the years would have made it easier to take but we are still very very angry," she said. "Robert's regiment were fantastic and still make an effort to keep in touch, but we were not happy at all with the way the MoD treated us."

Roll call of deaths during military exercises

 October 1998 Nathaniel Burton, 16, from Devon, attending Lympstone, died while wading through a pool during an exercise on Dartmoor

 February 1998 Richard King, 22, a Grenadier Guardsman, was accidentally shot dead when live bullets were wrongly mixed with blanks on night time training exercise at Sennybridge, Powys. A verdict of accidental death was recorded

 January 1998 Marine cadet David Vallance, 18, died of a heart attack while jogging to a firing range at Sandy Bay, near Exeter

 July 1998 Graham Holmes, 23, a promising cadet at the Sandhurst training base, dropped dead from heat exhaustion after embarking on a six-mile training run carrying 18kg (40lb) of equipment. An autopsy revealed he suffered a heart attack and internal haemorrhaging as a result of the endurance test

 July 1997 Andrew Charnock collapsed and died from heat exhaustion during a 30-mile training run on Dartmoor

 1996 Nigel Foster, 26, died after suffering a heart attack during a swimming exercise on Woodbury Common, Devon

 1994 Corporal Robert Hawksley, 29, and Corporal Martin Bailey, 25, were killed by friendly fire during an exercise in Canada when a 95lb mortar hit their trench. An inquest found their deaths were a result of mistakes and inaccuracies by those in charge. The officer in charge of the operation was acquitted of manslaughter at a court martial in 1996

 1994 Captain Chris Kelly, 26, was killed by colleagues in a mock battle in Kenya. Captain Kelly accidentally manoeuvred his platoon into the line of troops firing live ammunition. Despite contacting headquarters three times to inform them of his mistake, he was shot dead. An army inquiry recommended no action be taken against commanding officers

 June 1992 Lance Corporal Mark Richards died during a live firing exercise in Belize

fields.headline: In brief
fields.trailText: Prostate cancer survival rates up
fields.body:
Prostate cancer survival rates up

Survival rates for prostate cancer, which kills 8,500 a year, have risen for the first time since the early 1980s, the Office for National Statistics revealed yesterday.

The number of men still alive five years after being diagnosed with the disease increased from 42.2% in 1986-90 to 48.9% in 1991-93 in England and Wales.

Two stabbed in onion field fight

Thirteen foreign nationals were in custody yesterday after up to 100 farmworkers from Kurdistan, Pakistan, India, Afghanistan, Poland and Bosnia were involved in running battles in an onion field near Evesham, Worcestershire. Two workers were stabbed and several others injured.

Cup final attack: man charged

A man was charged yesterday in connection with an alleged attack on Leicester supporter Ruth Lelacheur during the 1999 Worthington Cup final against Tottenham Hotspur.

Jonathan Edmonds, 31, of Slough, Berkshire, was charged with affray and assault causing actual bodily harm after voluntarily going to Wembley police station in north London.

webTitle: The good life of a laboratory OAP

fields.headline: The good life of a laboratory OAP
fields.standfirst: This grandmother has found a way to meet friends, help society, and pay for cruises in the tropics. Here's how
fields.trailText: This grandmother has found a way to meet friends, help society, and pay for cruises in the tropics. Here's how.
fields.body:
When Flora Langstaff first stepped aboard a cruise ship with her husband Walter 27 years ago, she entered a wonderful new world. The Mediterranean ports at which they disembarked stunned her with their pungent smells and alien cultures; and she revelled in a luxury far removed from her life as a cook in a vast Leeds comprehensive school.

Nearly three decades on, Mrs Langstaff, now 81, has sought to satisfy the wanderlust kindled by those days in Lisbon and Barcelona by taking 10 cruises through the Med and the Caribbean.

Yet she is no affluent octagenarian - but a widow, living in a two-bedroom semi-detached former council house, who has hit upon a novel way of enhancing her war pension: Mrs Langstaff hires out her body to medical research.

Over the last decade, the great grandmother has been in eight drug studies for the Leeds-based clinical research company Covance, earning some £4,700.

Every 18 months or so, she willingly agrees to dose herself with medicine to treat everything from heart failure to high chloresterol, breast cancer to angina. The risks, she feels, are minimal, and the benefits high: for her most recent trial - for a drug for Alzheimer's disease - she earned £765.

It began when she saw an advertisement in the Yorkshire Evening Post, her local newspaper, asking for volunteers to take part in clinical trials. Partly inspired by altruism, and partly by her need to find some funds for double glazing, she contacted the company and became one of its oldest guinea pigs - a precious commodity, given that medical research, with its insistence on healthy, fit bodies, is predominantly the reserve of penniless students. Of Covance's 8,500 volunteers, only 150 are deemed elderly, while nearly three-quarters are between 18 and 45.

After losing two stone, she embarked on her first trial - for a drug to prevent heart failure - and her enthusiasm for her novel line of business was born.

"It's been wonderful," she says. "It's helped me to go on some lovely cruises which I wouldn't have been able to afford otherwise. I've been to the Caribbean seven times - Jamaica, the Bahamas, St Lucia - Greece, and Italy, and been on the QE2, Cunard's Jewel and Countess."

And the studies, during which she stays at the science company's research unit for up to 10 days each time, have an added allure: "I've also found it very sociable. You tend to make friends with the other people taking part in the trials - in fact I meet up with them each month. To be honest, I enjoy it for the company."

There are tens of thousands of clinical trials going on in Britain every year. Some are organised by academic research departments and others by pharmaceutical companies but the object in all cases is to amass evidence that a new treatment is safe and that it works. The data from the trials will be presented to the medicines control agency if the drug's developers seek a licence to put it on the market.

There are three stages to trials. New drugs are tested for safety first on animals, and then on a small group of human subjects such as Mrs Langstaff who are very closely monitored for any reaction to the drug. These healthy volunteers are paid for their time and the small element of risk or discomfort involved. Then the drug proceeds to what is known as a phase three trial to establish how well it works in a very large group of people who are suffering from the condition it is intended to treat.

Before each trial, Mrs Langstaff is given a rigorous medical, including blood and urine tests and an ECG to check her heart, and is presented with a list of all the possible side-effects of the drug. Covance also gets a report from the volunteer's GP and limits tests to one every four months.

Once in the unit, the pensioner has to endure up to 13 blood tests a day, taken through a tube into the vein, and is also woken in the night to give urine samples.

Yet, apart from longing for a cup of tea - caffeine is banned - she is unfazed by the potential risks. "The worst side-effect only tends to be a headache, and I've only once been sick - when I did the last Alzheimer's trial - and I was taken off it immediately. You can also pull out whenever you like."

As for the experience of staying at the research centre, which resembles a private hospital, it is something she relishes: "You feel looked after and it's nice and re laxing," she says. "You have a television in your room, there's a pool room, in the summer you can go and play croquet. You're kept busy all the time.

"If you're there for a week, a hairdresser comes in. I've had my feet done, and someone even came in to show us how to arrange flowers."

So, is it like a health farm? She laughs off the idea. "I wouldn't know, love, I've never been to one."

Lest it sound too hedonistic, Mrs Langstaff is keen to point out that she also wants to do something for the general good. "I've become more interested in that in the past few years after my sister- in-law developed Alzheimer's. I tend to think that, if it will help people who are really ill, this is worth doing."

And she knows that when she next gets together with the other senior citizens she has met through the trials, one question will preoccupy them. "We keep wondering: when will the next trial come along?"

Test timetable

June 89: heart failure £495

Nov 89: cholesterol £480

Sept 90: blood clots £550

May 92: Alzheimer's £570

June 93: breast cancer £420

June 95: angina £720

June 96: Alzheimer's £665

Nov 98: Alzheimer's £765

Total £4,665

And she knows that when she next gets together with the other senior citizens she has met through the trials, one question will preoccupy them. "We keep wondering: when will the next trial come along?" fields.headline: Two mad tea parties
fields.trailText: Alan McGee offered to buy it, Londoners launched a campaign to save it, but nothing can stop the BBC's rebranding impulse, so on Sunday night GLR was finally put to rest and on Monday BBC London Live 94.9FM took its place.
fields.body:
Alan McGee offered to buy it, Londoners launched a campaign to save it, but nothing can stop the BBC's rebranding impulse, so on Sunday night GLR was finally put to rest and on Monday BBC London Live 94.9FM took its place.

Non-Londoners can be forgiven their who-cares yawns, but GLR wasn't just any old BBC local radio station - it had a central place in the mythology of radio. It is where Chris Evans, Danny Baker and Chris Morris started out. It was also quirky and played good music, though recently it often sounded thin and amateurish, without the resources to respond properly when big news like the Paddington train crash broke.

In some respects the new station is no different from the old. The lively, crisp Robert Elms is still there, and the station's fans have persuaded the BBC to allow it to play more specialist music than permitted on the other BBC local stations. Yet with network radio being so Londoncentric anyway, the role of a London local station is unclear. And the new breakfast show with Paul Ross and Clare McDonnell tries to cover news and sport with jokes but no music - a golden combination that everyone would like to crack. On the evidence of week one, it remains elusive.

When it worked, Curiouser and Curiouser (Radio 4) was one of those ingenious ideas that shifted the relationship between a book and the world. Matt Thompson took five passages from Alice in Wonderland and linked them with contemporary life. The mad hatter's tea party became the starting point for a glorious investigation into tots and tea. Alice's prim statement that she never makes personal remarks was spliced with allegations by a real-life child that her brother eats his bogies. It made one see the Carroll oeuvre less as surrealism or satire and more as a convincing portrait of the modes and codes of childhood.

Even curiouser, someone else was sporting with Carroll's Alice on the airwaves last week. Paul Oakenfold's Urban Soundtrack on the Galaxy network had Kylie Minogue - yes - reading bits of Alice against Oakenfold's mixed soundtrack. "Jackanory for the chemical generation", they call it. Minogue turned in a surprisingly skilful performance, not in the least stage school yet full of interesting character voices. I wish I could offer up profound aperçus about the interplay between text and music, but my main reaction was shock at hearing Alice act as a musical trigger, and on commercial radio, too - a spacey wonderland as unexpected as any Alice came upon. The next soundtrack, on April 29, is Neil Tennant reading The Picture of Dorian Gray, on the five Galaxy stations and www.galaxyfm.co.uk.

The Songs of the Earth series (BBC World Service) provides another rich coupling of words and music. Roger Fenby's feature on Exits and Entrances cut together Japanese men and women speaking about their experience of bereavement and childbirth with Toru Takemitsu's choral music to make a powerful piece about the drama of life and the acceptance of death.

webTitle: Clean up peerage system, Blair told

fields.headline: Clean up peerage system, Blair told
fields.standfirst:
Lords reform: special report
New Labour in power: special report
fields.trailText: The row over the appointment of 33 new working peers intensified last night when Tony Blair faced calls from his own side to "clean up" the system, while Lady Jay, leader of the House of Lords, described the nomination of the Tory treasurer and donor Michael Ashcroft as "stinking".
fields.body:
The row over the appointment of 33 new working peers intensified last night when Tony Blair faced calls from his own side to "clean up" the system, while Lady Jay, leader of the House of Lords, described the nomination of the Tory treasurer and donor Michael Ashcroft as "stinking".

Lady Jay went on the offensive amid Conservative claims that Mr Blair's nominees were "cronies" and as senior Labour backbenchers expressed strong reservations over the extent of prime ministerial patronage.

It was a day of attack and counter-blast over the appointment of 20 Labour, nine Liberal Democrat and four Conservative peers.

Mr Ashcroft, recommended by William Hague, the Tory leader, made it on to the list only after agreeing to unprecedented conditions that he move back from Florida to become a permanent resident in Britain this year, before taking up his seat.

On BBC Radio 4's PM programme, Lady Jay was asked why Mr Blair's nominations included former donors to the Labour party as well as hereditary peers who had previously lost their right to sit in the house, in a move that "rather stinks" of an era Mr Blair had promised to end.

Demanding to know which of Mr Blair's nominees were "stinking", she insisted that Labour donors on the list were not in the same league as Mr Ashcroft, adding: "The stinking nomination is, if you want to put it in those terms, from Mr Hague."

Peter Bradley, Labour MP for the Wrekin, last night wrote to Mr Hague demanding answers to 16 questions as to how the nomination came about.

Earlier, Lord Cranborne, former leader of the Conservatives in the Lords, attacked the nomination of Mr Ashcroft as "an affront to the dignity and standing" of parliament.

But Lord Strathclyde, current Tory leader in the Lords, told BBC Radio 4's Today programme that the row over Mr Ashcroft's peerage was a smokescreen to draw attention away from the prime minister's other appointments as working peers, which he claimed were an attempt to pack the House of Lords with his own supporters.

Labour unease over the appointments was clear yesterday, although the government claims that they are necessary to move towards a "broad balance" in the Lords - to end Tory dominance and reflect each party's share of the vote at the last election.

Anthony Wright, Labour MP for Cannock Chase and chairman of the all-party constitutional and parliamentary affairs committee, said the controversy underlined the need for ministers to press ahead with the second stage of Lords reform.

He called for the link between the honours system and service in the second chamber to be broken to avoid further "contamination", as recommended this year by the royal commission on Lords reform, chaired by former Conservative cabinet minister Lord Wakeham.

His comments echoed widespread concern that the government has stalled on Lords reform after removing most of the hereditary peers.

Tony Benn, Labour MP for Chesterfield, denounced the appointments as a "throwback 500 years to when the king nominated all the peers".

webTitle: Blair banks on five new pledges

fields.headline: Blair banks on five new pledges
fields.standfirst: New Labour in power: special report
fields.trailText: Tony Blair's cabinet began the long countdown to the next general election yesterday when it agreed on five "unifying" themes designed to draw together a vote-winning coalition embracing middle England and Labour's traditional heartlands.
fields.body:
Tony Blair's cabinet began the long countdown to the next general election yesterday when it agreed on five "unifying" themes designed to draw together a vote-winning coalition embracing middle England and Labour's traditional heartlands.

At a special all-day cabinet meeting at Chequers, ministers backed an election battleplan concentrating on: employment opportunities for all; tackling child poverty through help for families; strong public services; security in retirement; support for business.

The blueprint, outlined by Gordon Brown, made no specific policy recommendations, but sources said the intention was to prevent the Conservatives from driving a wedge between those on low incomes and middle-class voters.

The chancellor warned that Labour would be falling into a Tory trap if it thought different policies were needed for its core vote than for the rest of the country.

Mr Blair, keen to show that Labour would have a radical agenda for a second term, is planning an updated version of Labour's 1997 pledge card - the easy-to-remember "five early pledges" that helped clinch his election landslide. But the final list, which will be unveiled nearer the probable election date of May or June 2001, is likely to be more "aspirational" and less specific than in 1997.

A news blackout was being imposed on yesterday's session. But key Blair aides, led by David Miliband, head of the Downing Street policy unit and his "second term" team, have been canvassing ideas among party analysts and friendly thinktanks such as Demos and the Institute for Public Policy Research.

The pledge card - with its commitments on the economy (including no rise in income tax rates), health, education, crime and jobs - was judged a campaign success in 1997. But some of the more specific pledges, notably to cut the NHS waiting list to 100,000 below the Tory figure, have proved hard and costly to fulfil. Pollsters record growing voter disappointment over public services, especially health and public transport.

Mr Brown, who is in charge of the general election campaign and is determined not to let William Hague force the government into a false choice, said Labour should capitalise on the big boost to health spending over the next four years announced in the Budget by campaigning on the slogan of "strong public services for the many, not tax cuts for the few".

Mr Hague has put a tax-cutting guarantee at the heart of his election campaign, whereas both Labour and the Liberal Democrats believe voters want any extra money to be spent on better services.

Mr Blair is said to be taking personal charge of NHS reform, which Alan Milburn is starting to implement with tough decisions. The first test comes in the elections for councils and London mayor on May 4.

Labour's chances of repeating its 1997 landslide will be severely damaged if the party focuses exclusively on its heartland vote, Mr Brown told colleagues yesterday.

Some, including David Blunkett, Chris Smith and Robin Cook, feel that Mr Brown has not done enough to court Labour's core voters - who could abstain with devastating results in Labour marginals.

Others, such as John Prescott, believe that the message has been tailored too much to first-time middle-class voters - the so-called middle England vote. The chancellor believes it is a false choice and that Labour must have a unifying theme: providing evidence that it can deliver to both middle England and those on low incomes.

Even Mr Brown has begun to acknowledge that his budgets have quietly redistributed resources towards the poorest, just as No 10 recently admitted that the overall tax burden has risen. Yesterday, informed sources said, Mr Brown admitted Labour must address the charge that it is more spin than substance.

It must also ward off voter cynicism that would suit the Tory tactic of saying politicians are powerless to change things and are only in it for themselves, he emphasised. Other ministers agreed.

Backbench MPs and former ministers such as Peter Kilfoyle and Doug Henderson have argued that Labour's failure to focus on its core working-class vote is draining support in its heartlands.

Some ministers agree that the Blairites have been too cautious in their drive to win voter trust for a second term - and that they can now afford to be more radical.

Labour's battleplan

 Employment opportunities for all

 Tackling child poverty through help for families

 Strong public services

 Security in retirement

 Support for business

webTitle: D for science, E for French, A for rock-star antics

fields.headline: D for science, E for French, A for rock-star antics
fields.trailText: Lost in music
fields.body:
By his own admission, Mick Jagger was not a model schoolboy: he was far too interested in music and the local girls' school to waste time studying. So his invitation back to Dartford Grammar School to unveil a new performing arts centre bearing his name smacks of hypocrisy. It is one of many instances of an educational institution taking questionable credit for something it probably played no part in. Did Dartford give lessons in Pouting, Pretending to Be the Reverend Robert Wilkins, Pissing Against Walls, and Confectionery, Marianne Faithfull and You: Fourteen Different Uses? No, thought not.

More worrying, however, is Jagger's total capitulation to all this toadying. "If we [the Rolling Stones] had enjoyed a facility like this it would have made all the difference," he commented. "We used to practise in bedrooms and garden sheds." What kind of "difference" is he talking about? Does he mean that, nurtured by a poncey "arts" facility, the Stones wouldn't just have been the best band in the world in 1969, they would have been even better? Or does he mean that they would have been a bunch of mollycoddled dilettantes with no drive, no itch, no angst-filled past to pig out on for inspiration?

Don't you get it, Mick? Special things germinate in garden sheds and bedrooms that could never evolve on a do-it-by-numbers course set up for would-be performers. Old-fashioned art courses (you know, the kind where you draw and paint and stuff) might have worked as launchpads for daydreamers like the Who's Pete Townshend, but only to give them the impetus to drop out and drift off into other areas.

Basic education works as fuel for budding rock stars, for anyone ambitious and arty, precisely because most of it is lacklustre, because it's a struggle, and because it's hard to seek out people on your wavelength and thrilling when you finally do. Modern performing arts courses are just the first step towards How to Emulate Richard Ashcroft's Hair seminars and Be the Drummer From Hepburn in Five Easy Steps tutorials. If you're enrolled on one of them, you're already on the production line, being moulded by The Man, before your career has started. Heroes are awfully hard to trust these days, and Mick Jagger is yet another who seems to have limited recollection of the vital ingredients which shaped him.

webTitle: British Beauty yet to be born

fields.headline: British Beauty yet to be born
fields.standfirst: The press raved about our great British Oscars triumph, but  Stuart Jeffries doesn't see it that way. He hopes our new Film Council will give us something genuine to celebrate
fields.trailText: The press raved about our great British Oscars triumph, but Stuart Jeffries doesn't see it that way. He hopes our new Film Council will give us something genuine to celebrate
fields.body:
Earlier this week, Britain scored a major cultural triumph. We really put those Yanks in the shade. But don't take my word for it. Consider the Sun's splash headline "Brits Cained 'Em!" Or the Daily Mail's "All Things Brit and Beautiful". Or the London Evening Standard's "Brits Storm the Oscars", a headline supported with a photograph of Brit Michael Caine and American Kevin Spacey waving statuettes.

But the patriotic hoopla didn't end there. In the Commons, Tom Clarke served up a nice fat lob for the film minister to smash away. "Does my honourable friend agree that she should be beaming with pride at last night's brilliant British successes in the Oscars?" Unsurprisingly, film minister Janet Anderson did agree. "We have a pool of excellent skills and talent here, and it is no wonder that more and more people want to make their films in Britain."

But the truth behind this misplaced flag-waving is that the Brits did not storm the Oscars. Oscar night was for the most part an evening of American triumphs in which a few token Brits got dragged along on the US's coattails, as happens year after year. The Cider House Rules, in which Michael Caine plays an abortionist, is based on an American novel, directed by an American, and produced in the US with mostly American actors. American Beauty, though winningly directed by a Briton, was written by an American, starred a cast of marvellous mostly American actors, and was produced with US money. Moreover, the film's central theme - the spiritual rebirth of a suburban man and wife in Nowheresville, USA - was surely tailored to US sensibilities.

Patriots will reply that there were some genuinely British triumphs at the Academy Awards. It is true that a British film won the best documentary award, but this is, for good or ill, a marginal Oscar. It is also true that Phil Collins won an award for best song, but when a mawkish tune for a Disney movie becomes an example of a nation's cultural renaissance, it's time to put the Union Jacks back in mothballs.

In the Commons, Anderson pointed to another supposed triumph: Mike Leigh's Gilbert and Sullivan film Topsy-Turvy won two minor awards. But this is an example of Hollywood marginalising British culture. Oscars get dished out to British films mostly when they are costume dramas that support the heritage industry. No British films about the way we live now, depicting our lives in ways we might recognise, were honoured at the Academy Awards. Nor will they be: the US doesn't understand, nor care much about, modern Britain.

Since 1990, British films, actors and film-makers have won 21% of all the major Oscars and 18% of all the major prizes at Cannes. These are not extraordinary figures for a small developed nation that has an entrée into the vast US film production market because of the simple fact that its citizens speak English. But year after year, with mounting desperation and declining plausibility, papers and the government cite the Oscars as a barometer of our cultural achievement.

British films that step outside heritage movie-making hardly ever get nominated. Even The Full Monty or Secrets and Lies, both critically and popularly successful abroad, were ignored by the academy. Think of, say, Lynne Ramsey's marvellously humane Ratcatcher, set in the Glasgow slums in the 70s, or Michael Winterbottom's Wonderland, which, for all its failings, strove passionately to depict present-day London in all its seedy glamour, and thus alienated it from being appreciated by Americans. These films, visually and perhaps even in terms of their spoken language, are too intrinsically foreign for the academy to comprehend, let alone reward with statuettes.

When the Hollywood academy looks at Britain, it sees the country with John Major's eyes, the rose-tinted eyes of a nostalgist hankering after the return of a never-never land of warm beer and cricket on village greens, perhaps with a bit of doublet and hose, iambic pentameter and Dickensian sentimentality thrown in for good measure. It does not see Britain in the terms that Tony Blair described this week, a Britain of many communities and a country of several nations.

Here Blair was launching a new patriotism, one that is problematic for the reasons argued by Norman Davies in his recent book, The Isles: the UK is fracturing and our national identity can hardly be expressed in works of art, since we don't have one. That is why so many of the genuinely good British films about this modern country retreat into the shattered communities of a fractured nation- the Glasgow slums, the London underbelly, the Sheffield unemployed.

Today the new Film Council starts its work under the chairmanship of Alan Parker. This body is charged with distributing £150m in grant in aid and lottery funding over three years. The council's brief is to help develop a sustainable UK film industry, which, given the history of lottery funding for British film since 1996, is quite a challenge. Get Real, Babymother, Keep The Aspidistra Fly ing, Downtime, Crimetime - these were some of the dreadful films that lottery punters have supported, and hardly anybody wanted to see. When Parker was appointed to the chair of the British Film Institute three years ago, he reckoned one of the big issues was "whether you can go to your local multiplex and see a British film made by a British film-maker". No amount of Oscar "triumphs" of the kind that took place in California on Sunday night will make that possible.

But what sort of films will Parker's council be funding? More that are terrible whatever your standards? More that win awards for best make-up and show Britain as it never was for American philistines and British conservatives? Films that speak only to tiny demographics? Or maybe he should just plough the money into Hollywood, and thus help facilitate the annual farce by means of which Britons get a fix of misplaced patriotic sentiment.

Perhaps, instead, Parker might achieve something far more difficult and desirable: to help us to see on screen a Britain that is something more than a 51st state, to make us watch something less nostalgic than another busts-and-bustles costume drama, and, most difficult of all, to encourage us to see something that shows that Britain is not splintering into small groups that are hardly on speaking terms. Then we might have something to celebrate.

Moreover, the film's central theme - the spiritual rebirth of a suburban man and wife in Nowheresville, USA - was surely tailored to US sensibilities. Patriots will reply that there were some genuinely British triumphs at the Academy Awards. It is true that a British film won the best documentary award, but this is, for good or ill, a marginal Oscar. It is also true that Phil Collins won an award for best song, but when a mawkish tune for a Disney movie becomes an example of a nation's cultural renaissance, it's time to put the Union Jacks back in mothballs. In the Commons, Anderson pointed to another supposed triumph: Mike Leigh's Gilbert and Sullivan film Topsy-Turvy won two minor awards. But this is an example of Hollywood marginalising British culture. Oscars get dished out to British films mostly when they are costume dramas that support the heritage industry. No British films about the way we live now, depicting our lives in ways we might recognise, were honoured at the Academy Awards. Nor will they be: the US doesn't understand, nor care much about, modern Britain. Since 1990, British films, actors and film-makers have won 21% of all the major Oscars and 18% of all the major prizes at Cannes. These are not extraordinary figures for a small developed nation that has an entrée into the vast US film production market because of the simple fact that its citizens speak English. But year after year, with mounting desperation and declining plausibility, papers and the government cite the Oscars as a barometer of our cultural achievement. British films that step outside heritage movie-making hardly ever get nominated. Even The Full Monty or Secrets and Lies, both critically and popularly successful abroad, were ignored by the academy. Think of, say, Lynne Ramsey's marvellously humane Ratcatcher, set in the Glasgow slums in the 70s, or Michael Winterbottom's Wonderland, which, for all its failings, strove passionately to depict present-day London in all its seedy glamour, and thus alienated it from being appreciated by Americans. These films, visually and perhaps even in terms of their spoken language, are too intrinsically foreign for the academy to comprehend, let alone reward with statuettes. When the Hollywood academy looks at Britain, it sees the country with John Major's eyes, the rose-tinted eyes of a nostalgist hankering after the return of a never-never land of warm beer and cricket on village greens, perhaps with a bit of doublet and hose, iambic pentameter and Dickensian sentimentality thrown in for good measure. It does not see Britain in the terms that Tony Blair described this week, a Britain of many communities and a country of several nations. Here Blair was launching a new patriotism, one that is problematic for the reasons argued by Norman Davies in his recent book, The Isles: the UK is fracturing and our national identity can hardly be expressed in works of art, since we don't have one. That is why so many of the genuinely good British films about this modern country retreat into the shattered communities of a fractured nation- the Glasgow slums, the London underbelly, the Sheffield unemployed. Today the new Film Council starts its work under the chairmanship of Alan Parker. This body is charged with distributing £150m in grant in aid and lottery funding over three years. The council's brief is to help develop a sustainable UK film industry, which, given the history of lottery funding for British film since 1996, is quite a challenge. Get Real, Babymother, Keep The Aspidistra Fly ing, Downtime, Crimetime - these were some of the dreadful films that lottery punters have supported, and hardly anybody wanted to see. When Parker was appointed to the chair of the British Film Institute three years ago, he reckoned one of the big issues was "whether you can go to your local multiplex and see a British film made by a British film-maker". No amount of Oscar "triumphs" of the kind that took place in California on Sunday night will make that possible. But what sort of films will Parker's council be funding? More that are terrible whatever your standards? More that win awards for best make-up and show Britain as it never was for American philistines and British conservatives? Films that speak only to tiny demographics? Or maybe he should just plough the money into Hollywood, and thus help facilitate the annual farce by means of which Britons get a fix of misplaced patriotic sentiment. Perhaps, instead, Parker might achieve something far more difficult and desirable: to help us to see on screen a Britain that is something more than a 51st state, to make us watch something less nostalgic than another busts-and-bustles costume drama, and, most difficult of all, to encourage us to see something that shows that Britain is not splintering into small groups that are hardly on speaking terms. Then we might have something to celebrate.

fields.headline: From tyrant to martyr
fields.standfirst: There's a dazzling clarity to the RSC's production of Richard II, says  Michael Billington
fields.trailText: There's a dazzling clarity to the RSC's production of Richard II, says Michael Billington
fields.body:
A great adventure has begun. Over the next year the Royal Shakespeare Company is to stage all eight of Shakespeare's Histories in chronological sequence. It kicks off with Steven Pimlott's fiercely intelligent, modern-dress Richard II in the Other Place, converted by David Fielding into a space resembling a white-walled squash-court or science lab: a perfect setting for this masterly dissection of kingship.

Modern dress, even when stylised with lots of maroon and grey maxi-coats, creates problems for this most ceremonial of plays, one that is steeped in medieval myth and that shows the notion of the king as God-sanctioned monarch giving way to personal ambition and legalistic statecraft. But Pimlott and his designer, Sue Willmington, pull it off in various ways. They suggest Richard presides over an already divided kingdom: one in which rancorous bullies confront each other in the lists at Coventry, with lethal axes. They make good use of symbolic props, including a long wooden casket which variously becomes throne, vertical mirror and coffin. Above all, with the aid of Simon Kemp's bright, overhead strip-lighting, they give the work a strong European dimension: it becomes a Brechtian analysis of the nature of power.

One could pick holes in the execution: I distrust the modern habit, already seen in Macbeth this week at London's BAC, of plucking lines from the fifth act to use as a choric refrain. But the abiding impression is of dazzling clarity. Samuel West's Richard moves from heedless tyrant to Christian martyr with absolute, and absolutist, conviction. Donning crown and ermine when it suits him, West shows the raging wreck that lurks beneath: he lunges at the prophetic John of Gaunt like a berserk thug and, having been likewise ticked off by the Duke of York, promptly makes him Lord Governor.

West also captures Richard's accelerating self-consciousness - he wraps himself in the national flag for the Westminster deposition scene - and mordant irony: his cry to Bolingbroke of "Here, cousin - seize the crown" ripples with taunting ambiguity. I have known more lyrical Richards: what West conveys is the character's progress from Ceaucescu to Christ.

David Troughton's Bolingbroke is also brilliantly effective: an overweening politician who cloaks driving ambition under a sense of wrong - "I am a subject and I challenge law" - and who swiftly dispatches Richard's followers with a bullet through the brain. But, having staged his takeover, Troughton also captures the hermetic isolation of power, making redundant the decision to end the play with the opening lines of Henry IV Part One. David Killick's dithering York, Christopher Saul's Machiavellian Northumberland and Adam Levy's armed-to-the-teeth, SAS-style Harry Percy lend unflinching support.

The production, since the Histories will have a variety of directors, may not provide a pattern for the future. It does, however, rescue Richard II from medieval pageantry and reveal its modern relevance as a study of the way revolution often begets tyranny.

 In rep at The Other Place, Stratford-upon-Avon (01789 403403), till October 5.

webTitle: Yonder lies the dawn over some clear bookshelves

fields.headline: Yonder lies the dawn over some clear bookshelves
fields.trailText: A dance to the music of the sky | Cooking the looks | ...like obstreporous children
fields.body:
With five piles by my bedside, of which three are now stacked on the floor, I decided it was time to hand over enough books to the Oxfam shop to clear at least 20 feet of domestic shelf-space. I don't think that it is only because I come from a book-intensive family that I feel an atavistic unease at throwing out any printed volume. In some deep but confused way, giving a copy of The Coffee, Tea Or Me Girls to charity feels like the first step on the slope to Nazi library bonfires.

Mere foolish sentimentality. The money I save by not buying more shelves will go on purchasing fine novels, stirring biographies, challenging works of philosophy and More Erotic Dots, Vol. III. So, out go all works with the name Nigel Rees or Gyles Brandreth (except for Brandreth's very funny political memoirs). Out with that series of grim novels about third world people having a terrible time, which I ordered by phone in a drunken moment while watching public TV in the US. The 10p each book will fetch can buy some of the food so graphically missing in the fiction. Away with those unwanted coffee table books on Georgian pottery where friends and family have left the original £29.99 price on the cover but have taken off the sticker "This book bargain, £1.99", leaving the tell-tale gummy patch behind. All books with bumpy covers (The Screaming Day; Bandits Four-Ten; Yonder Lies The Dawn) go, along with all Top Anecdotes Of The After-Dinner Speakers, and Cooking The Books: Favourite Recipes of Chartered Accountants.

And yet, it's so much harder than I expected. I can't lose that one; it came from a dear friend who often visits. One day I might need to refer to Sir Norman Fowler's memoirs, and every home should have the works of Thomas Love Peacock, though the chances of any of us opening it are more or less nil. The Good Food Guide for 1987 has a wonderful nostalgic charm. Nobody reads William Hope Hodgson these days, but I might when I'm 70. It's been awful. So far I have tossed out less than 30 inches; more than 17 feet to go.

 One set of volumes which definitely stays is A Dance To The Music Of Time by Anthony Powell, who died this week. I didn't meet him, but my father did, when he went to talk with Powell for TV. The film crew having been dispatched to trough at the village pub, my father was invited to stay for lunch. "I don't know if you know," said Powell, slightly alarmingly, "that Lady Violet shares blood with Jane Austen." He was making a point about genealogy, rather than vampires. Later the same event appeared in Powell's memoirs. He had been bemused by my father's practice of tucking his napkin into his collar, and couldn't work out whether it derived from his working-class upbringing in Leeds, or his more recent bourgeois existence in Paris. Such a topic could have kept his narrator Nick Jenkins going for at least two-thirds of a page.

 Touching moment on Channel 4 the other night. Oliver James was interviewing Margaret Cook and made a disparaging remark about her former husband's looks. She muttered: "I found him attractive." Mr James looked shocked and startled. But Robin Cook is an intelligent, witty and adventurous man. Why should a woman see no further than his vandalised garden-gnome visage? I used to know a terrifically ugly man who was a great hit with women. "Give me 10 minutes," he would say, "and I can talk away my face".

 More letters about northwestern food. A number of readers have written to say that the cream cracker sandwich is no eccentricity, but a popular children's bedtime treat. The bland, heavily buttered bread contrasts with the crisp cracker filling, and is ideally washed down with a mug of warm, full-cream milk. I can't talk; when not in Northern Ireland I had the job of chip butty monitor in the Guardian's Manchester news room. You had to go to the canteen at 5.30 prompt when the first scalding hot chips arrived. This was vital, since they melted the butter which then dripped all over the typewriters and, combined with the spongy white bread, made a delectably sodden mess in the mouth. Such a diet was much more dangerous than anything which might crop up in Belfast.

Meanwhile, Neil Smith writes from Wigan: "Please don't leave the enticing subject of Wiganers (nb, not Wiganites) without mentioning the ultimate local delicacy - the Wigan kebab. This is three pies on a stick."

 The Ulster Unionists have decided they won't countenance the RUC having to change its name. Thanks, guys. I've mentioned before the political dependency culture of Northern Ireland. The only reason the UU's can, like Violet Elizabeth Bott, thcweam and thcweam until they're thick is because they've learned that there is nothing whatever they can do which will make us throw up our arms and abandon them. Not long after Bloody Sunday Willie Whitelaw, the first Ulster secretary, warned everyone privately that if the Unionists rejected the new constitutional package, the British people would finally lose patience. They did, but we didn't. Like obstreporous children, they know that in the last resort their parents won't throw them out. Nor need the Nationalists be as smug as they invariably sound on the Today programme. If Britain did what they claim to desire, they would be left alone with a million furious, heavily armed Protestants, and I'd like to see Martin McGuinness handle that little problem.

fields.headline: The last word on Speciesism
fields.standfirst: Animals are not brethren, they are not underlings; they are other nations, caught with ourselves in the net of life and   time. - Henry Beston
fields.trailText: Animals are not brethren, they are not underlings; they are other nations, caught with ourselves in the net of life and time. - Henry Beston
fields.body:
A striking fact now rendered familiar, even platitudinous, by the triumphs of recent genetic science is how closely all living things are related. Humans share more than half their genes with worms and fruit-flies, and almost all their genes with chimpanzees.

Yet this intimate familyhood of life does not stop people from spearing worms on to fish-hooks, or testing drugs on chimpanzees. Nothing surprising there, you might say, given the way humans treat humans; in the face of gas chambers, racism, war and other avocations, what chance has a monkey or a cow? There are lessons to be learned from the way humans justify their treatment of animals, not least of those evolutionarily closest to them - the apes.

Apes, especially gorillas, have long been demonised in film and literature. Their similarity to us is used not as proof of kindred, but as a means of symbolising the supposed bestiality within us. Thus when Dr Jekyll drinks his potion he exposes a mythologised savage inheritance; his hands grow hairy, his brow beetles, his teeth enlarge: he becomes a horrifying gorilla-man. If it is not violence it is stupidity which marks the ape, betokened by tree-swinging, armpit-scratching and gibbering.

You insult a person if you call him an ape. Yet apes are intelligent, inquisitive, affectionate and sociable, with capacities for suffering and grief that match our own, and with a grave beauty and dignity which recalls Schopenhauer's remark that "There is one respect in which brutes show real wisdom when compared to us - I mean their quiet, placid enjoyment of the present moment." There is a parallel between our excuses for maltreating apes and those for maltreating fellow humans.

We locate a difference that we find threatening or that we despise; we thereby make the other fully Other, so that we can close the door of the moral community against him, leaving him outside where our actions cannot be judged by the same standards as apply within. Racism and speciesism are thus the same thing - they are myths about what belongs and what is alien. In their book The Great Ape Project, published some years ago, Paola Cavalieri and Peter Singer entered a plea for humankind to "admit our fellow Great Apes - the chimpanzees, gorillas and orang-utans - to the same moral community as ourselves, thereby according them rights to life, to liberty, and to protection against torture - especially the kind of torture inflicted in the name of scientific research".

In the face of the genetic and behavioural evidence, there is no good reason why the moral respect and consideration that applies between humans should not apply between humans and apes. But note: the moment that the boundaries of morality are extended in this way, there is no obvious place to stop. All animate nature comes within the purview of ethics; and that, arguably, is as it should be. The world divides into vegetarians and those that eat them. Thoreau wrote, "I have no doubt that it is a part of the destiny of the human race, in its gradual improvement, to leave off eating animals, as surely as the savage tribes have left off eating each other."

There are plenty who argue that it is not immoral to eat a cow, especially if it has lived well beforehand. Lovers of cats and dogs would think it cruel to eat their pets, though, and once again the reason is the boundary: cats and dogs, horses and even hamsters, have become quasi-citizens of the human world, and our treatment of them is premised on the same kind of concern for their interests as we show to other humans. We would not crowd dogs into a closed lorry as we do sheep when they are sent on long export journeys; that is a happy fact.

But it is an unhappy fact that we crowd sheep into lorries, for sheep can suffer thirst and panic just as dogs - and humans - do. Humanity's record with animals is poor. "We have enslaved the rest of the animal creation," wrote Dean Inge, "and have treated our distant cousins in fur and feathers so badly that beyond doubt, if they were able to formulate a religion, they would depict the Devil in human form." Some think that sentimental do-goodery over animals is a distraction from more significant moral matters.

Perhaps; but a person's integrity is never more fully tested than when he has power over a voiceless creature; and the route from pulling wings off flies to committing crimes against humanity is not a notably circuitous one.

webTitle: Every pas de deux tells a story

fields.headline: Every pas de deux tells a story
fields.standfirst: The success of Houston Ballet shows that audiences are lapping up good old-fashioned narratives - but is that good for the dance?  Judith Mackrell  reports
fields.trailText: The success of Houston Ballet shows that audiences are lapping up good old-fashioned narratives - but is that good for the dance? Judith Mackrell reports
fields.body:
For a man who has overseen one of the biggest success stories in ballet, Ben Stevenson remains rather deprecating about the form that has helped make his reputation. Since being appointed artistic director of Houston Ballet, he has commissioned and choreographed the most old-fashioned of things: three-act story ballets. It may not wash with the dance purists, but Stevenson's approach has put Houston on the ballet map, establishing it as a feature on the touring calendar - it comes to London next year - as well as managing to secure a devoted local audience.

When the English choreographer was appointed by Houston Ballet, its facilities amounted to little more than a studio with toilets doubling up as changing rooms. Twenty four years on, the company luxuriates in the same air conditioned grandeur as Houston's banks and shopping malls, with a purpose-built base and a $72m lyric theatre that it shares with Houston Opera. This dramatic upscaling has been partly funded by oil-dollars, but Stevenson has been crucial to the equation too. It's a success story that Houston is mighty proud of.

Yet when I talked to Stevenson about the appeal of works such as Peer Gynt, Dracula and Cleopatra (which had just sold out for its opening two-week run) he muttered in a most un-Texan way, about "bread-and-butter ballets". It was clear this was more than a lingering English defensiveness. For while the full-length story ballets have proved a golden milch cow for Houston, he is aware that some may see the form as compromised, even defunct.

The 20th century had an ambivalent relationship with the story ballet. The leisurely, fairy-tale conventions of the 19th-century classics in which a Swan Queen would mime in elaborate gestures that "yonder lies the lake of my mother's tears" are no longer viable models. And it has been hard for choreographers to find new ones.

Some of the greatest full-length ballets of the last half century have been led by scores, notably Prokofiev's Romeo and Juliet and Cinderella. These are lyric flights of the imagination that allow choreographers to give rein to their traditional art, yet they have a more contemporary edge than the historic scores of Tchaikovsky. (Though AMP's Matthew Bourne has proved that it is possible, with radical reinterpretation, to make even these new again.)

But there is only one Prokofiev, and few composers write suitable music for full-length story ballets: John McCabe, who provided the scores for David Bintley's Edward II and Arthur, sound-paints dramatic effects with dash and vividness, but his music is typical in its lack of dance impulse and variety.

Literature, more than music, has been the major source of inspiration in recent decades, with choreo-graphers shamelessly raiding their libraries in search of stories. Cyrano, Far From the Madding Crowd and Great Expectations are among the many classics to have been set on pointe. But even though their creators have updated their narrative methods beyond the pantomime of the 19th century they've rarely overcome the fact that dance remains stubbornly bad at detailed description and analysis. All too often complex textual scenarios get reduced to dumbshow, with a body language either wincingly simple or so obtuse as to leave the audience stranded.

William Tuckett, whose version of Arthur Miller's Crucible is soon to be premiered by the Royal Ballet, acknowledges that dance is "very bad at dealing with the specifics of narrative". In his last ballet, Turn of the Screw, he remained faithful to the plot of Henry James's novella and kept "coming up against brick walls. There were so many things I couldn't do." His strategy has been increasingly to edit out most of the "narrative cogs".

With The Crucible he has not tried to re-tell Miller's play, but has "abstracted the text and messed around with it". It is not a poor imitation of literature but a creative reinterpretation in which dance is free to do what it is best at, namely explore the relationships between characters. Tuckett points to the cliche-ridden depiction of sex scenes in novels and suggests that dance, with its rich ambiguity, can create "a poeticised image of emotion" that is much easier for "everyone to empathise with".

Significantly, he works on these ideas within the format of a single act: he doesn't attempt to spin his story out over a full evening. Yet while the shorter format suits dance and prevents ballets from lapsing into the bland interludes and Polyfiller crowd scenes that are the curse of the overextended three acter, such brevity does not always suit the general public.

Companies such as Houston know that the ordinary punter at the ballet does not just want a familiar title to reassure them (the crucial "name recognition" that Stevenson admits sells a season); they also like to settle into a solid evening's show, with a juicily absorbing plot and a parade of eye- catching sets and costumes.

This is exactly what Stevenson gives them. One of the first qualities that struck me about the $1.2m Cleopatra was the old-fashioned lushness of its staging. Thomas Boyd's sets and Judanna Lynn's costumes have the epic opulence of a Cecil B De Mille movie, with an expensive colour palette of pink, turquoise and gold and a series of show stopping effects - including Cleopatra's entrance, silhouetted against a giant desert sun, in which the barge she is seated in opens out like a phoenix spreading its wings.

The music sounds as if it were purpose- written in about 1900 - a fusion of exotic local colour, melodic dance passages and plangent characterisation. In fact it is a cunning arrangement of excerpts from Rimsky-Korsakov's concert and operatic music, and aficionados won't be surprised to learn that it was written by John Lanchbery, the world's master at turning bits and bobs of existing music into coherent ballet scores. His arrangements have facilitated some of the most successful story ballets in the modern rep, including works by Ashton and MacMillan, and it is due in part to his wizardry that Stevenson, while moving at a brisk trot through the climaxes of Cleopatra's life, produces, along the way, so much memorable dance.

Stevenson admits that creating full-length story ballets can be frustrating for the choreographer because the steps are the last thing he can consider. "I feel more like a theatre director," he says. His first task will always be to construct the scenario for his composer, his second to work through the staging with his designers, his third to make the dance. Yet even creating the steps involves other obligations. A ballet like Cleopatra has several changes of scene and one of his basic jobs is to conceal the joins and organise the dancers to move around the props. He also has to keep flagging up the plot, so that however lyric his dance imagination it has to remain grounded in dramatic logic. This obligation towards clarity is one reason why so many story ballets look formulaic. In a pure dance work choreo-graphers are free to experiment with style and structure. In story ballets they have to make themselves understood.

Tuckett, however, feels that the more literal-minded members of the public have been catered for for long enough. He admits to worrying about his audience's ability to follow the compressed action of his own Crucible. But he takes courage from film audiences, "who have become incredibly literate at understanding very fragmented plots". Certainly the finest moments in Stevenson's Cleopatra are those where the action pauses to let the dance get deep under his characters' skins. Perhaps if the public stopped looking for novels or plays on pointe then choreographers would be freer to do their job. The story ballet may not be dead, just waiting for its audience to catch up.

 William Tuckett's The Crucible opens at The Royal Opera House, London WC2 (0171-304 4000), on April 12.

webTitle: On a wing for a prayer

fields.headline: On a wing for a prayer
fields.standfirst: Religion in the UK: special report
fields.trailText: "Can anybody give me a word to describe prayer?" Up goes the hand of a tough-looking lad hunched in a chair at the back of the confirmation class: "Boring, sir."
fields.body:
"Can anybody give me a word to describe prayer?" Up goes the hand of a tough-looking lad hunched in a chair at the back of the confirmation class: "Boring, sir."

I took his point entirely. His view of prayer was a daily response to a remote God surrounded by angels and archangels, and a host of celestial baggage from a past age. To the theologically literate, such a view presents formidable difficulties. To the boy, it was utterly incomprehensible.

Can anything be salvaged here? I doubt it. To engage in dialogue with such a being involves the participant in complex philosophical and mental gymnastics. Not only do you have to posit the existence of such a deity, you then have to flesh out this God with the only available tool, namely a compendium of archaic theological language. So he becomes eternal, transcendental, all-powerful and arbitrary.

Then you have to thrash out an appropriate response to this formidable martinet. Because of his daunting demeanour, we tend to fix on a self-effacing approach peppered with silence, humility, fear and a bit of pleading. We verbalise our relationship by using antiquated and highly technical ecclesiastical language. Try reading the Creed.

In an attempt to revivify a God, Christian tradition has homed in on the imagery of the Heavenly Father. Alright, the argument goes, you can't communicate with a philosophical idea, but you can tell your heavenly father all that is nearest to your heart, and ask his forgiveness for wrongdoing.

This approach is a non-starter. Inevitably you end up with a projected Freudian father figure clothed with the biblical attributes of anger, pity, vengeance, judgment - and, just occasionally, love. It conjures up a picture of the "God of the stained-glass window", and smacks of white robes, bushy beards and beetling brows. My youngsters found it risible.

What next? The Christian church, desperate to salvage something from the wreckage, tunes in to a third possibility - Jesus of Nazareth, the historical God-Man, whose teachings and exploits are infallibly related in the gospels.

At first, the argument looks sound. Anyone can have a conversation with a carpenter. But then the seed of mystification creeps in. Surely not with one who lived 2000 years ago and was the product of a virgin birth. And even less with the one who was executed on a cross and came alive again. There is no mileage in any of this - as I soon found out. My rundown on God, the Father, and Jesus, the Saviour, elicited a robust response from my youngsters. "Do you really believe in all this rubbish, sir?"

Is that it then? Is Christian prayer no more than a philosophical fool's game, or an absurd attempt to converse with an Olympian-type God - half human, half divine?

There is an alternative. Prayer can be viewed as an existential colloquy, an ongoing dialogue with the perceived world, a conversation with what lies four and square before our eyes. The dialogue can be internal, and may emerge as an emotional response to the physical world. You slog your way to the summit of Helvellyn, and feel that gut-wrenching surge of emotion as the vista unfolds. "I've done it!" is real prayer. Prayer from the heart.

The response may spring from adversity. As you lie in a hospital bed, your heartfelt longing to get better - to thrive and "be" - is an unspoken plea to the universe, (God?) to treat us with reverence and a modicum of kindness. Our interactive dialogue with the world is a continuous prayer.

The response may be physical, such as an exuberant sexual communion with another man or woman, or it takes on an aesthetic shape - as when we are, for example, uplifted by music. The dialogue can be external, exemplified in our daily speech.

On the surface, such interchanges may appear no more than insignificant snippets of conversation. But if we unpack their deeper meaning, so the interchanges are transformed. They become ejaculations of thanksgiving, compassion, pity and hope, the basic elements of all prayer. Everyday dialogue has become prayer.

So does it work? I experimented on my hapless confirmation candidates by telling the story of a four-year-old Italian girl who fell down a well. I piled on the emotions thick and fast, describing the rescue attempts and her eventual death in darkness, fear, isolation and pain.

"Any comments?" Up went the hands. "Felt sorry for her mum and dad . . . wicked . . . awful to be shut up in the dark . . . made me cry." On and on went the compassionate, agonised responses. "In that case," I said, "you were praying." And for the first time that evening, they sat bolt upright, interest on their faces.

The Christian church should debunk its outmoded concepts of the deity, take pantheism firmly on board and set God right in the heart of human experience. Then, our youngsters might start listening.

 David Bryant is a former Anglican vicar living in Yorkshire
