fields.headline: Gisele Freund
fields.standfirst: Photojournalist recording the human condition - 'I want to show what is close to my heart, man's joys and sorrows, his hopes and fears'
fields.trailText: For too long, the work of the photographer Gisele Freund, who has died aged 91, has been hidden from history. Written out of In Our Time, the official record of the Magnum agency (although she joined in 1947, only a year after its foundation), she likewise fails to appear in any of the histories of women photographers, or in anthologies of 20th-century interviews and biographies, including even Helmut and Alison Gernsheim's Concise History Of Photography.
fields.body:
For too long, the work of the photographer Gisele Freund, who has died aged 91, has been hidden from history. Written out of In Our Time, the official record of the Magnum agency (although she joined in 1947, only a year after its foundation), she likewise fails to appear in any of the histories of women photographers, or in anthologies of 20th-century interviews and biographies, including even Helmut and Alison Gernsheim's Concise History Of Photography. In fact, her body of work is considerable, spanning 50 years across Europe and the Americas.

Born in Berlin, Freund was forced to flee to Paris in 1933, when an anti-Hitler plot, in which she was involved, was discovered. She enrolled at the Sorbonne, shifting her studies from the history of art to photography. After the occupation of Paris, she fled south to Lot and joined the resistance.

A Jew and an anti-fascist, she used, first, the protection of Adrienne Monnier, who had published her doctorate on 19th-century French photographers; then came the invitation to Argentina from Victoria Ocampo, founder-editor of Sur, probably the most significant literary magazine in Latin America. He had met her in Paris, and published her portraits.

Through Monnier's circle, largely gyrating around Sylvia Beach's left bank library-cum-bookshop Shakespeare and Co, Freund had made a powerful reputation with her cybachromes of such literary luminaries as Joyce, Woolf, Malraux (who comforted her with his opinion that "if one isn't revolutionary in one's youth, one isn't worthy of being an adult"), Breton, Beckett, Sartre, de Beauvoir, Ionesco and Cocteau.

While establishing her reputation as a portraitist in literary circles, Freund also published material in Life magazine, which had been launched in 1936, and, unlike European magazines of the time, used colour. Her reportages and portraits also regularly appeared in Weekly Illustrated and Picture Post in Britain, in Vu and Paris-Match in France, and in Du in Germany. In 1937, she married a Frenchman, Pierre Blum, from whom she was divorced after the war.

During her exile Freund became a stills photographer and film producer with the Louis Jouvet theatre company in Argentina and Chile from 1943-44, then worked for the France Libre propaganda services in Buenos Aires from 1944-45. She also continued her freelance career, and, until 1954, covered the whole of Latin America for Magnum.

She was prevented from visiting the United States until the 1970s. Her political past - and that of such communist friends as the Chilean poet Pablo Neruda and the Mexican painters Frida Kahlo and Diego Rivera - were out of kilter with the mood of McCarthyism and the cold war. She continued her reportages across countries and classes, covering the lives of Bolivian tin miners, British shipyard workers, Japanese fishermen, Canadian trackers, Patagonian Indians - and Paris fashion shows, exhibiting widely in many of the places she photographed.

She had returned to live in Paris after the war, and there accrued a considerable collection of prestigious awards. She became president of the French Federation of Creative Photographers in 1977, gaining the Grand Prix Na tional des Arts in 1980. President François Mitterrand appointed her an Officier des Arts et Lettres in 1982 and Chevalier de la Légion d'Honneur the following year.

Germany, too, recognised her contribution, particularly in her pioneering colour work. In 1963, she contributed to a major show of French portraiture in the 20th century, and in 1977 held her first retrospective in Bonn, winning the German Society's cultural photography prize in 1978. A decade later, the Berlin Werkbund-Archiv honoured her with a retrospective, and in 1989 she was appointed doctor honoris causa at the National Museum of Photography at Bradford University.

Freund also wrote and illustrated numerous books, including James Joyce In Paris: His Final Years (1965), The World And My Camera (1970), and the enormously influential Photography And Society (1980). It was here that she returned to her early passion - and the subject of her first studies - "because the diversity of social problems fascinate me".

She was always clear that "it is not my intention to create works of art or to invent new forms. I merely want to show what is close to my heart - man, his joys and sorrows, hopes and fears.

"I believe that a good basic training in sociology and psychology, a mastery of foreign languages and the ability to come to terms with all situations are more important for a professional photojournalist than attendance at a school of photography. But the most important quality of all is the ability to love people."


 Gisele Freund, photojournalist, born December 19 1908; died March 31 2000

fields.headline: Alexandra Kolarz
fields.trailText: Alexandra "Shura" Kolarz, who has died aged 87, became one of the most influential figures in the Trades Union Congress, working behind the scenes on international issues and bringing her extraordinary insight to bear on the crucial area of east-west relations after the second world war, at a time of political tension.
fields.body:
Alexandra "Shura" Kolarz, who has died aged 87, became one of the most influential figures in the Trades Union Congress, working behind the scenes on international issues and bringing her extraordinary insight to bear on the crucial area of east-west relations after the second world war, at a time of political tension.

While never remotely a sympathiser with Soviet communism, she was a tireless advocate of building up relations, not shutting the door. Her linguistic gifts ensured that official Soviet interpreters could never stray from objectivity. She sometimes had to arrange the visits of people for whom she had no time, such as Alexander Shelepin in 1975, then head of the Soviet trade unions, but formerly of the KGB. To compensate, she would surrepetitiously facilitate, for example, a delegation to see the film Doctor Zhivago, at a time when the book was still banned.

Shura was born Alexandra Lipovskaya in Kharkov, the most Russianised area of eastern Ukraine, and had a turbulent childhood. There was Polish blood on her mother's side, Russian on her father's, and the family was living in Moscow at the time of the 1917 revolution. Her uncle, Samuel Lipovsky, had been a financial adviser to Kerensky's government, and when this collapsed, the decision was that Shura's immediate family should not follow the others into exile, but remain behind to look after their interests. The resulting experience of Soviet communism moulded her outlook for the rest of her life.

Her private education gave her fluent French and German, such rare qualifications in the USSR at the time that, instead of university, she found herself, at 16, as liaison officer for foreign visitors to the Soviet trade union headquarters, arranging visits for foreign notables, including George Bernard Shaw.

Shura began writing poetry and distributing it in typescript, an early form of samizdat. Though she never fully developed her creative gift, in retirement she wrote an autobiography of her Russian years, dictating the last few pages on her deathbed. In 1933 the family abandoned Russia for good. Her uncle had established a successful textile enterprise in Paris, and she was able to study Chinese at the Sorbonne.

After marrying Walter Kolarz, a German-speaking Czech who was in serious trouble with Hitler's regime, in 1939, the couple escaped to England. Walter settled into a career at the BBC central research unit at Bush House, while Shura's work was curiously parallel at the TUC.

Shura and Walter had long abandoned their religious roots (Orthodox and Catholic respectively). Gradually, however, they returned to faith, leading to the publication of Walter's epoch-making Religion In The Soviet Union (1961). Even before her retirement, she took in hand the archives of the Keston Institute (as it would eventually be called). Intrepidly - she never drove or took the Underground - she made the difficult journey into the Kent countryside each week to give her services, bringing her logical mind to bear on classifying the rich resources on religion in the Soviet Unuion and the rest of the communist bloc.

She became a founding member of the SDP, but eventually returned to New Labour. Her long retirement, however, was marked by devotion to charitable causes, such as organising the Westminster talking newspaper for the blind.

However, all Shura's enterprises paled beside her overwhelming gift for friendship. She would know, with uncanny insight, what you had been up to, and would give you the wisest counsel. You would leave her wonderful little Russian house in Maida Vale feeling refreshed, and determined in your next course of action.

Her origins were deep in the kind of Russian social democracy which Lenin destroyed, with such devastating consequences that they are felt even today. Her husband died in 1962; she is survived by her only son, Nicholas.

fields.headline: Bruce Bernard
fields.trailText: I first encountered Bruce Bernard around 1972, when he became picture editor of the Sunday Times magazine; I was very new to magazines and, for reasons I could never really fathom, he offered me his old job as picture researcher. I like to think it was because he recognised a maverick streak within me, which reflected his own approach to photography.
fields.body:
I first encountered Bruce Bernard around 1972, when he became picture editor of the Sunday Times magazine; I was very new to magazines and, for reasons I could never really fathom, he offered me his old job as picture researcher. I like to think it was because he recognised a maverick streak within me, which reflected his own approach to photography.

Coming as I did from a typically cerebral middle-class background, Bruce was a revelation. For a start, he was passionate; to hear him roaring with disgust at some work which displeased him was scary indeed, especially if the photographer responsible was in the vicinity.

One of the highlights of my early days on the magazine was being dispatched by the art director, Michael Rand, to seek out Bruce in Soho well after the normal extended lunchtime hours of that time - he had disappeared with a crucial colour transparency required for an imminent deadline. I found him, veering with a funambulistic stagger, as Samuel Beckett so eloquently put it, towards his second home, the French Pub. Ever the professional, somehow he produced the transparency from his top pocket and dispatched me with emphatic instructions "to make sure they use it well."

I hesitate to claim that Bruce taught me everything I know but, without doubt, he opened my eyes to another way of seeing. I learned that it was possible to view photography not just as illustration to text, but as a form of journalism in its own right. Through him, I experienced that it was possible, as a non-photographer, to encourage and cajole photographers into producing memorable and lasting work.

The early 1970s was a magical time to be on the Sunday Times magazine, an era before the paramountcy of TV was established, when photojournalists of the calibre of Don McCullin and Leonard Freed brought back fresh and revealing stories from the outside world.

All this washed off on me, but if I attribute one overwhelming influence to that period, it was Bruce's conspicuous message that it was possible to care deeply about photography and visual journalism - a lesson that has brought both him and me into cantankerous deep water ever since.

webTitle: Docked former PM puts faith in coastal cruise

fields.headline: Docked former PM puts faith in coastal cruise
fields.standfirst: Ousted from office and convicted of bribery, Silvio Berlusconi sails back into the centre of Italian politics
fields.trailText: Six years after he was expelled from office and engulfed in scandal, Silvio Berlusconi set sail last night in a 37,000-tonne luxury liner to try to seduce Italy and recapture power.
fields.body:
Six years after he was expelled from office and engulfed in scandal, Silvio Berlusconi set sail last night in a 37,000-tonne luxury liner to try to seduce Italy and recapture power.

The so-called ship of dreams left Genoa for a comeback tour, reinforced by a fleet of aircraft and buses that will criss-cross Italy in an unprecedented electoral campaign.

Returning to his roots as cruise ship crooner, the media tycoon unveiled the 202-metre (663ft) vessel as the nerve centre of his Forza Italia party.

Its cargo of supporters, media, bunting and high expectations will be greeted by brass bands and fireworks at 10 ports. The aim is to reclaim Mr Berlusconi's tarnished glamour in time for the regional government elections on April 16.

Rainsplattered but euphoric supporters on the quayside said it was time to repay their leader's persecution by a conspiracy of leftwing politicians and investigating judges.

Victory in the regions over the faltering centre-left national government would pave the way for a general election and Mr Berlusconi's restoration as prime minister, they said.

The vessel, the Excellent, has been renamed Azzurra - the ship of freedom - for its £1m two-week rental.

Segments of Mr Berlusconi's media empire have drooled over its swimming pools, conference centre, gymnasium, casino bar, shops and restaurants: all part of the permanently tanned tycoon's aura of being a winner.

In fact, a tour yesterday revealed some of the 387 cabins to be cramped and without showers.

An aide confided that, despite the hype, hiring the ship had more to do with logistics than symbolism. "We don't shout about it, but it will actually save us money by transporting everybody together."

For the canvassers left on land, no detail has been overlooked. They have been issued with sunglasses, badges, scarves and ties. Mr Berlusconi has ordered them to smile at all times, avoid contentious issues, and compliment voters on their appearance.

"Make sure you have some sweets on you to ward off bad breath, and maintain proper dental hygiene. Keep a handkerchief in your pocket to dry your hands. If you go into a dirty public lavatory, always clean it afterwards, in case people think that it was you who dirtied it."

Opponents who once mocked Mr Berlusconi's tactics as kitsch have turned queasy as opinion polls show them to be working. His alliance of centre-right parties is leading the government coalition by 58% to 31%, and his own party Forza Italia is likely to consolidate its position as the biggest party. However, new election rules make it impossible to predict the outcome of the 15 regional ballots, in which three quarters of the electorate can vote.

"These elections are extremely important. If Berlusconi wins he'll claim that as a mandate to be made prime minister," said James Walston, a political scientist at the American University of Rome.

Mr Berlusconi, 63, was ousted as prime minister in 1994 after nine tempestuous months in office.

He is appealing against two convictions for false accounting and bribery and faces 10 other charges, but the pendulum is swinging against the magistrates whose "clean hands" investigations brought down the political establishment. Voters are disillusioned with the inconclusive trials and suspect that not all the judges are politically impartial.

While the government coalition has been alienating voters by its in-fighting, Mr Berlusconi has been refining his image.

"He's a much better politician now. He seems calmer, more capable. Some of those who wouldn't trust him six years ago now may be willing to take the chance," said Claudio Lodici, a political scientist.

"He's always been a good communicator. He's got charm, that famous smile, a tone that people like. And he's self-made, so that helps him to look like an outsider."

Mr Berlusconi, savaged in 1994 for appointing irresponsible ministers, has striven to reassure the electorate by naming respected technocrats as his ministers-in-waiting.

He has rebuilt essentially the same alliance that fragmented then, although this time Forza Italia is stronger and expected to wield more control.

But Umberto Bossi, leader of the xenophobic Northern League, exacted a price this week for his inclusion in the potential coalition by persuading Mr Berlusconi to back a crackdown on immigration which drew comparisons to Jörg Haider's Freedom Party in Austria.

A draft law calls for a two-to-six-months prison term for any would-be immigrants caught trying to enter Italy illegally for the third time, and for Italy to block aid to countries that failed to discourage immigrant smuggling.

One Forza Italia party member, Giulio Tremonti, suggested sinking the dinghies smugglers use to ferry would-be immigrants across the Adriatic.

webTitle: Cognac on the rocks is not to be sniffed at

fields.headline: Cognac on the rocks is not to be sniffed at
fields.trailText: Connoisseurs may be spluttering through their moustaches and into their balloon glasses, but after years of decline cognac is back in vogue - thanks to an unlikely attempt to take the most aristocratic of French spirits out of the gentleman's club and into the techno party.
fields.body:
Connoisseurs may be spluttering through their moustaches and into their balloon glasses, but after years of decline cognac is back in vogue - thanks to an unlikely attempt to take the most aristocratic of French spirits out of the gentleman's club and into the techno party.

"It's a small patch of blue in a grey, grey sky," said Bernard Guionnet of Bnic, the national cognac association, announcing an unexpected 14% increase in sales last year, "but it's our only hope.

"I'm afraid our salvation lies in such appalling heresies as cognac-and-Coca Cola."

In the past decade sales of what was once the world's favourite after-dinner tipple have slumped by nearly a third from a peak of 157m bottles in 1989. First the Asian market collapsed, then Europeans began turning their backs on a drink they thought fit only for what Mr Guionnet calls "crusty old men in armchairs".

The decline has proved catastrophic in the cognac region, where one in three producers have given up the struggle, 10,000 hectares (25,000 acres) have been taken out of production, and the French government spent about £4m last year alone paying hundreds of growers to tear up their vines and plant Sauvignon grapes.

The crisis was exacerbated by the fact that cognac companies continued to over-produce even when it was clear that it was not selling: according to Mr Guionnet, the millions of gallons of young VSOP and Three-Star cognac held in stock today amount to seven or eight times what the industry is likely to sell in a year.

Desperate to reverse the trend, Bnic commissioned consumer surveys, organised tastings, and decided that the only answer was to drag the noble Napoleonic drink downmarket.

Since the beginning of last year bottles and labels have been redesigned, products renamed, and promotional events organised in student bars. Bnic has spent £3m on a psychedelic advertising campaign designed to appeal to a younger, more trend-conscious public.

"It seems to be working," admitted one dubious cognac producer, Jean-Louis Brillet. "Shameful as it is, apparently cognac-on-the-rocks, cognac-and-ginger and cognac-and-tonic are what young people are actually drinking in smart clubs these days.

"I think we're even selling the stuff on the internet."

webTitle: East Germans revive Red rite of passage

fields.headline: East Germans revive Red rite of passage
fields.standfirst: To the dismay of the Protestant church, the young are flocking to a communist era coming-of-age ceremony
fields.trailText: Thousands of east German teenagers will become adults today at communist-style atheist confirmation ceremonies, which are enjoying a popular revival throughout the region, despite strong opposition from conservatives and the Protestant church, which dismisses them as "ritualised nostalgia".
fields.body:
Thousands of east German teenagers will become adults today at communist-style atheist confirmation ceremonies, which are enjoying a popular revival throughout the region, despite strong opposition from conservatives and the Protestant church, which dismisses them as "ritualised nostalgia".

The Jugendweihe, marking the transition from adolescence to adulthood, enjoyed a state-enforced heyday under communism, when 90% of young east Germans swore an oath to defend socialism and the country's "unbreakable" ties with the Sovet Union.

Now, 11 years after the fall of the Berlin Wall, it is undergoing an unexpected rebirth in the five federal German states which previously formed the Democratic Republic.

The ceremony is virtually unknown in west Germany.

This spring more than 93,000 east German 14-year-olds are due to attend Saturday morning Jugendweihe ceremonies.

This is 20% more than in 1993, and the organisers predict that the number will continue to rise.

"Parents want their children to mark this important phase of their life with a ceremony," said Sabine Deponte, head of the privately funded Jugendweihe organisation in Chemnitz, formerly Karl-Marx-Stadt.

"If they are not religious, and many east Germans aren't, then the Jugendweihe is the obvious choice," she added.

The conservative Christian Democratic party refuses to support the Jugendweihe, because of its previous communist links, but the ceremony's new-found popularity in the east has led politicans from other mainstream parties to speak at its ceremonies.

At 11am sharp last Saturday a cross-section of 200 east German 14-year-olds were on parade in Chemnitz city hall, where they were shortly to become officially recognised as adults.

Dancers pranced about to a Michael Jackson tune pumped out by the uniformed 1st Chemnitz Youth Brass Band, while a girl compere told the assembled adolescents and their parents: "The Jugendweihe is a must for freaks."

Mrs Deponte's 10-minute address to the gathering was peppered with warnings about the dangers inherent in the capitalist "elbow society" that had sprung up in eastern Germany since the collapse of communism.

"The new competitive system means that parents and children have far less time for each other than they did in the old days," she said.

The teenagers then lined up on a floodlit stage and waited. One by one their names were called out with the words: "We congratulate you on the occasion of your Jugendweihe."

One by one they stepped forward one pace to be awarded a single red rose and a book entitled Saxony is Young.

"It was almost the same as it was under communism, except there was no longer the oath to defend socialism," said Dietmar Beyer, a Siemens worker whose 14-year-old daughter Juliane had just completed the ceremony.

"Most of my schoolfriends took part today. I didn't want to be left out," Juliane said.

Like the other teenagers, she was looking forward to a present of cash from her parents. Her classmate Thomas Rottlof was intent on buying a computer with the cash.

"The Jugendweihe was socialism's answer to church confirmation," said his grandfather Siegfried.

"As our family is not religious, it was the obvious choice for us, even though socialism has gone," he added.

Although today's Jugendweihe has been stripped of its communist ideology, the steady increase in its popularity deeply worries Germany's Protestant church, which is currently attracting only 16% of east German adolesecents to its regular confirmation services.

"We expected the Jugendweihe to evaporate with the collapse of communism," said Andreas Fincke, a Protestant theologian, who has carried out a recent study on the Jugendweihe, "but it is becoming increasingly popular.

"For many east German families the ceremony symbolises a rejection of west German values and means that they don't have to commit themselves to the church," he said.

Dr Fincke was one of a minority of east Germans who refused to take part in the Jugendweihe during the communist era.

"My punishment was not being allowed to go to grammar school. People have forgotten how much suffering was connected with the Jugendweihe," he said.

Nevertheless, the ceremony has managed to divide church opinion. Some want the church to continue offering standard but more "individualised" confirmation to adolescents. Others want to compete by offering a Protestant version of the Jugendweihe.

"Some think we should try to beat them at their own game," Dr Fincke added.

Before 1989, those undergoing the Jugendweihe were asked: "Dear young friends, are you ready as true patriots to continue to deepen the firm friendship with the Soviet Union, to strengthen the brotherly ties with socialist countries, to fight in the spirit of protelarian internationalism, to protect peace and defend Socialism against every imperialist attack?" They answered: "Yes - this we swear."

"As our family is not religious, it was the obvious choice for us, even though socialism has gone," he added. Although today's Jugendweihe has been stripped of its communist ideology, the steady increase in its popularity deeply worries Germany's Protestant church, which is currently attracting only 16% of east German adolesecents to its regular confirmation services. "We expected the Jugendweihe to evaporate with the collapse of communism," said Andreas Fincke, a Protestant theologian, who has carried out a recent study on the Jugendweihe, "but it is becoming increasingly popular. "For many east German families the ceremony symbolises a rejection of west German values and means that they don't have to commit themselves to the church," he said. Dr Fincke was one of a minority of east Germans who refused to take part in the Jugendweihe during the communist era. "My punishment was not being allowed to go to grammar school. People have forgotten how much suffering was connected with the Jugendweihe," he said. Nevertheless, the ceremony has managed to divide church opinion. Some want the church to continue offering standard but more "individualised" confirmation to adolescents. Others want to compete by offering a Protestant version of the Jugendweihe. "Some think we should try to beat them at their own game," Dr Fincke added. Before 1989, those undergoing the Jugendweihe were asked: "Dear young friends, are you ready as true patriots to continue to deepen the firm friendship with the Soviet Union, to strengthen the brotherly ties with socialist countries, to fight in the spirit of protelarian internationalism, to protect peace and defend Socialism against every imperialist attack?" They answered: "Yes - this we swear."

webTitle: US acts against abuse in private juvenile jail

fields.headline: US acts against abuse in private juvenile jail
fields.trailText: The US justice department has taken unprecedented emergency legal action to protect from "life-threatening conditions" the inmates of a juvenile prison in Louisiana run by a corporation which also manages jails and immigration detention centres in Britain.
fields.body:
The US justice department has taken unprecedented emergency legal action to protect from "life-threatening conditions" the inmates of a juvenile prison in Louisiana run by a corporation which also manages jails and immigration detention centres in Britain.

The department is asking a Baton Rouge district court to intervene to stop guards at the prison in Jena abusing the young boys in their custody.

The jail is run by the Wackenhut Correction Corporations, which is a partner through its subsidiary Premier Prison Services in four private British prisons, in South Yorkshire, Nottinghamshire, Durham and Scotland.

Wackenhut was in the news last year when riots broke out in a prison it ran in New Mexico and its contract to run a prison in Texas was cancelled after a string of incidents in which inmates were abused.

But the abuses in Jena may be the worst uncovered so far. A justice department investigation found that guards regularly beat the inmates with batons, hurled teargas grenades into their barrack-like dormitories, and subjected them to long periods in solitary confinement.

David Utter, director of the Juvenile Justice project of Louisiana, a civil rights group which represents some of the inmates, said the legal action was "extraordinary".

"In fact it is the first time in the history of the statute that it has been done. You can only do it if you think the conditions are life-threatening, and they are really horrendous," he said

After a series of complaints, the justice department toured the Jena juvenile prison and found that many of the 276 boys held there had no shoes or blankets and were constantly hungry.

Many had attempted suicide or deliberately hurt themselves to get into the prison infirmary and beyond the reach of the guards.

Wackenhut, founded by George Wackenhut, a billionaire former FBI agent, has grown in recent years to be the world's largest commercial prison operator.

It runs 56 institutions in the US, Britain and Australia, and its shares are traded on the New York Stock Exchange.

The corporation has issued a statement saying that the justice department experts were misled by "exaggerations and mis-statements of facts" by the inmates.

Their findings, the company said "do not accurately reflect the condition of the facility today".

A local judge, Mark Doherty, did not agree, and last month he removed six teenage boys from the prison after he found that they had been brutalised by guards, kept in solitary confinment for months, and deprived of shoes, blankets and medical care.

One inmate released by his order, a fifteen-year-old from New Orleans, had tried to commit suicide 20 times by swallowing razor blades or hanging himself with a sheet.

Mr Doherty, a Republican, said the prisoners "wound up in a place that drives and treats juveniles as if they walked on all fours".

"These young people deserve to be treated like human beings, not animals".

Mr Utter said his group had been "astonished" by the extent of the abuses at Jena.

"The only thing I can chalk it up to is to arrogance: they had incredible political connections and they clearly thought they could get away from it," he said yesterday.

fields.headline: In brief
fields.trailText: French soldier kills officer
fields.body:
French soldier kills officer

A French paratroop lieutenant has been shot dead by a subordinate in the tension-wracked north Kosovo city of Mitrovice, the French army said. The victim, 29, who was killed late on Thursday, had arrived in the city on March 20. His attacker was described as an enlisted soldier, also recently arrived.
- Reuters, Paris

Teenage girls kill boy, 10

Two runaway Russian girls, aged 13 and 14, slashed a 10-year-old homeless boy to death with broken glass because they thought he had robbed them of 50 roubles (£1.25), Itar-Tass news agency said. The girls, who left the body in a street in a small town near the Plesetsk space launch pad, in the arctic Archangel region, were later arrested.
- Reuters, Moscow

Crowds storm Durban court

Police deployed troop carriers and dogs after hundreds of protesters tried to force their way inside a Durban court where three men yesterday faced charges over a nightclub teargas attack last week that led to the death of 13 children in a stampede. A bail appplication was postponed to next Thursday after two defence lawyers withdrew. Police suspect rivalry between club owners as a possible motive.
- Reuters, Durban

webTitle: Freedom keeps Roman youth tied to apron strings

fields.headline: Freedom keeps Roman youth tied to apron strings
fields.trailText: The plane was at 15,000ft and still climbing steeply when the two dozen teenagers decided it was time to unbuckle their seat belts, snap on their sunglasses and go cruising the aisles.
fields.body:
The plane was at 15,000ft and still climbing steeply when the two dozen teenagers decided it was time to unbuckle their seat belts, snap on their sunglasses and go cruising the aisles.

Four girls headed down the back for a smoke, others opened the overhead baggage compartments to mooch in their bags, and the boys jostled in the walkway, all acting as if the Boeing, which had yet to clear the clouds, was a cafe.

Two apoplectic Greek cabin crew raced into the melee, flapping their arms and shouting for the teenagers to sit down. It was an unequal battle. These were Roman kids back from a school trip, with critical mass.

They continued to lounge, defiantly but without aggression, until the plane levelled out and the stewards appealed to their two teachers. But instead of adding their adult authority to crush the rebellion, the teachers grinned, shrugged and told the stewards to relax.

Oh to be a Roman child. The treats in store. The attention, the adventures, the fun. From its debut a Roman baby is the object of endless kisses, pats and cooing. Relatives jostle for a first glimpse. Shop assistants abandon customers to pinch its cheek. Old ladies offer sweets.

Infanthood heralds more treasures, because total strangers will share the parents' delight at the walking and talking marvel. Few Roman families have more than one child, so there is no need to share the limelight with brothers or sisters.

Department stores are stuffed on Saturday afternoon with mothers buying clothes for and with their children, who show little sign of being mortified by the maternal taste. Parents want, and pay for, their children to look gorgeous. Sexy, in fact.

"Those jeans are not tight enough," said one mum, and her 15-year-old boy could only agree.

It seems to be a candy-cotton world of indulgence and freedom. And from a Greek air steward's point of view it is. But it is not. For some sons the indulgence never ends, but Roman youth is shackled in ways that its peers in London or Paris would find oppressive.

Most university students never finish their degrees. Flawed teaching, poor administration and overcrowding are usually blamed, but a refrain I've often heard is that their courses, especially business-related ones, were chosen by their parents.

A friend and his wife are having a struggle to buy a flat because so few properties come on the market. The reason? Landlords will rent but not sell, because they want to be able to pass on properties to their offspring, as a wedding present.

The path to employment often winds back home. Small, family-owned businesses are the economy's backbone. Tycoons and butchers groom their offspring to take over. Jobs in the state sector are allocated by examination, but in reality the system is riddled with nepotism and clientism.

For the teenagers in the Boeing, the flight to Rome passed in a medley of chatter, posing, swapping seats, smoking and flirting.

After picking up their baggage, they were greeted in the arrivals hall by excited parents. Final kisses, and off they went. Following their parents to a future not of their own making.

fields.headline: Famine threat to 12m Africans
fields.standfirst: UN in $200m aid plea as drought and war take toll
fields.trailText: A new famine, threatening 12m lives across seven countries, is looming in the Horn of Africa following prolonged drought and continued conflict, the United Nations warned yesterday.
fields.body:
A new famine, threatening 12m lives across seven countries, is looming in the Horn of Africa following prolonged drought and continued conflict, the United Nations warned yesterday.

The crisis raises the spectre of a repeat of the famine 15 years ago that claimed close to 1m lives in Ethiopia. It led to a massive but belated international aid operation, led by Bob Geldof's Live Aid concert, after the BBC broadcast haunting television pictures of entire villages withering and starving to death.

Once again most of those at risk are in Ethiopia, where aid workers say children are already dying by the score from hunger and illnesses related to malnutrition. The prime minister, Meles Zenawi, said 8m people faced starvation.

The UN deputy emergency relief coordinator, Carolyn McAskie, said that unless foreign donors moved quickly to get large scale food deliveries under way the region could face disaster.

"The rains that have come thus far have been sporadic and uneven, and the prospects for rains in May and June are uncertain," she said. "We are facing the real prospect in two months from now of another catastrophe which can be averted with the right kind of donor assistance. We all remember the images of suffer ing of Ethiopians from 15 years ago and we cannot afford to imagine such a scenario again."

The UN has appealed for about $200m (£126m) to feed people across the Horn. Besides Ethiopia, the other countries at risk are Eritrea, Somalia, Sudan, Kenya, Uganda and Djibouti.

The UN secretary-general, Kofi Annan, is dispatching the head of the World Food Programme as a special envoy to highlight fears of a repeat of the famine in the mid-1980's. Catherine Bertini will visit some of the affected countries in a fortnight.

Ethiopia's 'disaster preparedness and prevention commission' blames two years of drought, sporadic heavy rains, frost, black beetle and crop damage by hail for the food crisis. But the continuing war between Ethiopia and Eritrea, the prolonged civil war in Sudan and the conflict in Somalia have contributed to the threat of famine in the Horn.

Efforts to negotiate and end all three conflicts have failed so far. The border war between Ethiopia and Eritrea appears likely to flare again in the coming weeks which would further hamper relief efforts. Fighting has already complicated food deliveries to refugee camps by closing the Eritrean port of Assab and forcing aid through Djibouti. But the port would not be able to handle large-scale deliveries if the food crisis were to worsen sharply.

Talks to end Sudan's civil war between the Islamic government in Khartoum and SPLA rebels in the south drag on. The latest focus has been on the degree of self-determination for southern Sudan and the application of shari ah law in the mostly Christian region.

Both sides have extended a 'humanitarian ceasefire' by three months to allow aid deliveries but the rebels allege that government air raids have continued.

In Somalia the faction leader, Hussein Aideed, has rejected the latest peace plan on the grounds that the reconciliation programme is "not clear".

Eight aid workers from various agencies were killed in southern Sudan in March, probably by rebels of Uganda's Lord's Resistance Army. The UN halted its air and ground operations in southern Somalia on Thursday after shots were fired at one of its aircraft.

A statement from the UN headquarters in New York made clear that the difficulties faced in launching a relief operation were more than outweighed by the dangers of doing nothing.

"Without increased donor support for immediate food relief assistance the international community may be confronted with the sort of food crisis the region tragically had to deal with 15 years ago," the UN said. "It is urgent that pre-emptive measures are now taken to avert such a catastrophe."

Famine in the Horn

1888-1889: Famine caused widespread devastation

1916-1920, 1927-1928 and 1934-1935: Localised famines

1969-73: Famine claimed 300,000 lives in Ethiopia

1977-78: War and drought in eastern Ethiopia forced nearly 1m people to flee into Somalia

1984-85: Famine in Ethiopia killed almost 1m people and forced hundreds of thousands to leave their homes.

1993: Widespread famine in Somalia brought on by civil war

1994: About 10,000 Ethiopians died in a food crisis

webTitle: Japanese volcano spews silent cloud of ash

fields.headline: Japanese volcano spews silent cloud of ash
fields.trailText: Mount Usu in northern Japan erupted yesterday with barely a sound, sending a blue-grey plume of molten rock and ash above the crater and rolling down the snow-quilted slopes.
fields.body:
Mount Usu in northern Japan erupted yesterday with barely a sound, sending a blue-grey plume of molten rock and ash above the crater and rolling down the snow-quilted slopes.

Ash dusted silent, evacuated villages. The only noise was from warning sirens and from ambulances and police cars cruising in search of damage.

Further away, people streamed into the streets and climbed on to rooftops to watch and photograph the cloud that rose to a height of two miles in two hours.

But those who were not looking out of a window would barely have noticed that Usu's 732m cone had blown its top.

"I didn't hear anything," said Norimichi Nagao, who works in the nearby city of Date, on Japan's northern island of Hokkaido. "I didn't even know that there was an eruption until I saw it on television."

Almost immediately after the eruption, volcanic ash began to rain down on nearby towns. Residents downwind were soon enveloped in the pungent smell of sulphur.

There were no immediate reports of damage or injuries. But more than 11,000 people who were evacuated from Usu's base, 475 miles north of Tokyo, earlier this week faced another night in rescue centres, as officials warned that it was too early to say the danger had been averted.

A snowfall last night increased concern about mud and landslides. There were fears that Usu could spew a mix of gas and rocks, called a pyroclastic flow, that would incinerate everything in its path.

The prime minister, Keizo Obuchi, said the evacuees might have to stay for a while at makeshift centres. If so, the government would consider building temporary housing.

At the centres, families sat on blankets spread out to mark their private space. Some put up cardboard partitions, but there was little else to give them any privacy.

webTitle: Boy, 6, whispers court denial that he shot girl

fields.headline: Boy, 6, whispers court denial that he shot girl
fields.trailText: With little more than his eyes and nose visible over the witness stand, a six-year-old boy denied that he shot dead a girl in his first-year class at primary school. He blamed another pupil in year one.
fields.body:
With little more than his eyes and nose visible over the witness stand, a six-year-old boy denied that he shot dead a girl in his first-year class at primary school. He blamed another pupil in year one.

The boy testified at a preliminary hearing for a young man who lived in the same house, Jamelle James, 19, who is accused of carelessly storing the semi-automatic handgun that the boy allegedly used to kill Kayla Rolland on February 29. Mr James is charged with involuntary manslaughter; there are no charges against the six-year-old.

The boy had to be coaxed into the witness box and barely spoke above a whisper for the 45 minutes he was on the stand. Judge John Conover chatted with the boy and his eight-year-old brother about sports and television to assess whether they were competent to take the stand.

Before the boys testified, all cameras and microphones were ordered out, as was a sketch artist.

The six-year-old testified that he had seen Mr James playing with the gun and he showed how Mr James twirled it in his hands. The prosecutor had to copy the hand motions for the judge because the boy in the witness box was too short to be seen.

The boy said he had seen the gun and some coins in a shoebox in Mr James's room - an answer he gave after prosecutor Daniel Stamos reminded him that was what he had told police.

The boy said he remembered Kayla being shot. But when asked if he shot her, he shook his head "no," and blamed another boy to whom he said he had given the gun.

"I wasn't playing with the gun, I wasn't," the boy said.

The eight-year-old testified that his younger brother had showed him a gun at home before school on the morning Kayla was killed.

webTitle: Debt campaigners send plea to Blair

fields.headline: Debt campaigners send plea to Blair
fields.standfirst:
Debt relief: special report
Jubilee 2000
fields.trailText: Debt campaigners yesterday called on Tony Blair to rescue a landmark deal aimed at reducing the debts of the world's poorest countries.
fields.body:
Debt campaigners yesterday called on Tony Blair to rescue a landmark deal aimed at reducing the debts of the world's poorest countries.

Jubilee 2000 wants the prime minister to put debt relief on the agenda of the next meeting of the Group of Seven leading economies, to be held in Japan in June. Last September the G7 pledged radical expansion of debt relief measures for the world's poorest countries, but the campaigners say progress has stalled.

The campaigners say only five of the 11 countries which were to have had loan burdens reduced by this month's meeting of the World Bank and International Monetary Fund are on target for cuts.

"The prospects for progress before the end of the millennium year are equally alarming," Jubilee 2000 said. The G7's target is for 24 countries to have received debt relief by the end of 2000, but Jubilee 2000 say only 14 are likely to make that deadline.

fields.headline: City briefing
fields.trailText: Retailers form net alliance
fields.body:
Retailers form net alliance

Tesco, Safeway, Marks & Spencer and Kingfisher yesterday joined six other European and American retail groups to form an online alliance with combined sales of $300bn (£188bn).

The web-based Worldwide Retail Exchange is a network designed to link and match retailers with suppliers. It is expected to lower supply chain costs for all participants.

Founding members of the exchange - which also include Casino, Ahold, Albertson's and K-Mart - will each hold 5% of the new company's share capital. The remaining equity will be reallocated when it is known how many other retailers wish to join the exchange.

Details of the new exchange came just days after Sainsbury revealed it had joined GlobalNetXchange, along with Carrefour, Sears and American supermarket group Kroger. It claims to be bigger than the WRE, with $200bn of purchasing power - equal to about $350bn of sales.

Art auction inquiry widens

US regulators have broadened their investigation of fine-art auction houses by requesting information from Butterfields, the bricks-and-mortar seller owned by eBay, the online auctioneer. EBay yesterday revealed that the US justice department had asked Butterfields to provide documents on "discussions, agreements or understandings with other auction houses". The request is understood to relate to the department's three-year investigation into alleged price-fixing at Sotheby's and Christie's, the world's two largest auction houses.

The investigation has prompted the resignations of the president and chairman of Sotherby's although no charges have yet been made.

Yahoo faces investigation

Yahoo, the internet portal, faces an investigation by the US federal trade commission following allegations that it has breached consumer protection regulations.

Consumer groups have raised concerns about the protection of online privacy in recent months. The company could incur hefty fines if it is found to have misused personal information on its website.

Xerox shreds 5,200 jobs

Copier company Xerox yesterday announced 5,200 job cuts as part of a $625m (£392m) restructuring programme. Xerox said the restructuring would yield savings, net of costs, of about $95m this year and $300m next year.

The company expects recent currency movement will offset most of the savings this year but this would position the company "for mid- to high teens earnings growth in 2001".

The restructuring will touch nearly every area of the business and will mean that about one in 10 jobs will be cut in middle and upper management.

fields.headline: A Country Diary
fields.standfirst: Rotherham, South Yorkshire
fields.trailText: The sun has just crept above the hill behind Canklow and the mist is still rising off the canal; a ground frost lies heavily everywhere, especially below the angle of the sunís rays.
fields.body:
The sun has just crept above the hill behind Canklow and the mist is still rising off the canal; a ground frost lies heavily everywhere, especially below the angle of the sunís rays.

A cock pheasant cackles, creating a commotion. Peering around an earth bank, I see the cause. A fox, its back to me, is standing, ears pricked, staring at the pheasant sitting up the bank a few yards distant. Pheasant has seen fox and fox knows it, not least because pheasant is telling fox so in no uncertain terms. With apparent nonchalance, fox turns away, towards me and trots a short way. The wind is in my face, so the fox wonít pick up my scent, but I am silhouetted against the sky. Watching me closely, the fox advances a few steps, stops and stares, weighing me up. A few more steps, another hesitant halt, then, a dash for a gap at the bottom of the fence and fox is gone, across the open ground and into a clump of brambles.

Half an hour later, as I stroll slowly, listening to the exuberant bird song, enjoying the morning sun, a movement to my left claims my attention. The fox is now searching among grassland and brambles in a large hollow. Meandering across the ground, it inspects every likely tussock of grass, lest it conceals a vole or other prey item. Working slowly up the slope towards the track above, it slows, then peeps cautiously over the edge. A lone rabbit sits on the far side of the track, perhaps 30 feet away. The fox lowers its body, still watching, weighing up the options, the chances of success. It tenses, like a sprinter on the blocks. Launching forward and upwards, the scrabbling feet raise dust clouds behind them.

The rabbit, however, is no longer there. It seemed to sense the danger just a split second before the attack, and bolted for a nearby burrow. Accepting defeat once again, the fox sniffs around the edge of the brambles whence the rabbit disappeared, then lopes off along the track, around the corner and out of sight.

fields.headline: Pearson wins Dorling Kindersley
fields.trailText: Dorling Kindersley, the book publisher brought to its knees by wildly overestimating the popularity of last year's Star Wars film, yesterday agreed to a £311m bid from media group Pearson.
fields.body:
Dorling Kindersley, the book publisher brought to its knees by wildly overestimating the popularity of last year's Star Wars film, yesterday agreed to a £311m bid from media group Pearson.

Directors of the group recommended the bid to shareholders after effectively putting itself up for sale in January. Co-founder and chairman Peter Kindersley will make £100m from the deal and take a back seat role in the company going forward.

Mr Kindersley, 58, who founded the company in 1974 with Christopher Dorling said there had been several bidders but added that Pearson was "overwhelmingly the most sensible company to sell to". Other bidders were thought to include Flextech, Granada, Bertelsman and Hachette, the French publisher.

Dorling Kindersley horrified investors at the beginning of the year when it warned that it had been left with 10m copies of unsold books on Star Wars - The Phantom Menace. Mr Kindersley said the Star Wars episode had been a "wake-up call" but maintained it had not been the reason for the sale of the business.

He said: "What happened with Star Wars was just an aberration. The truth is that we have built a huge portfolio of quality content, including health, travel, education, children, gardening and we weren't in a position to exploit it online. It would have needed hundreds of millions and the risk profile was just to high for us as a family still owning 30% of the business."

Pearson, he said, was a good buyer because the group whose assets range from Penguin books to the Financial Times had already demonstrated its commitment to the internet. The acquisition is likely though to lead to job losses among Dorling Kindersley's 1,200 staff.

The offer is at 430p in cash per Dorling Kindersley share, representing a 47% premium to the price the day before the company announced it was seeking a buyer.

Pearson chief executive Marjorie Scardino said Dorling Kindersley had found its "natural home" within its new owner. The illustrated reference business complemented Penguin as well as adding its content to Pearson's online businesses. It would also provide the basis for fact-based and educational programmes for Pearson Television.

"Its imprint is one of the most respected in the world and its assets have unique potential in the online environment," she said. "We aim to invest in its brand and its content so that it has a great future both on and offline."

Dorling Kindersley also announced its half-year results, which showed a £25m pre-tax loss for the six months to December 31 against a £4.7m profit in the previous year.

webTitle: Care group claims dirty tricks drove down share price

fields.headline: Care group claims dirty tricks drove down share price
fields.trailText: The serious fraud office has been asked to look into allegations that a "dirty tricks" conspiracy accelerated a crash in the share price of nursing homes group NHP and drove it to seek takeover offers.
fields.body:
The serious fraud office has been asked to look into allegations that a "dirty tricks" conspiracy accelerated a crash in the share price of nursing homes group NHP and drove it to seek takeover offers.

Officials from the SFO have met NHP representatives to examine evidence including transcripts of telephone con versations between one of the group's investment banks, Dresdner Kleinwort Benson, and two property executives. The transcripts, seen by the Guardian, show the property directors suggesting that a fraud has been perpetrated on NHP's bondholders. They urge DKB to take up the concerns with the Department of Trade and Industry as well as the SFO and City regulators.

The meeting took place on Thursday as the merchant bank Robert Fleming was finalising a list of possible bidders for NHP and the nursing homes group finalised crucial banking facilities. Robert Wardle, assistant director of the SFO, has taken the unusual step of writing to NHP denying that it has received any complaint against the company or that an investigation has been launched.

The fraud watchdog has also been handed a dossier which purports to link press coverage, some of which NHP claims was inspired by a campaign of misinformation, with sharp falls in the company's share price.

A complaint that a property company was orchestrating a campaign to undermine NHP's share price and make it vulnerable to takeover was recently sent to the Royal Institution of Chartered Surveyors by Rotherham-based Interna tional Project Consultants, a management consultancy.

NHP has suffered from financial pressures in the care industry which intensified following changes in government requirements on staffing levels.

Although NHP reported sharply higher profits of £18m last year its share price has fallen by three-quarters over the past 12 months. This partly reflects concerns about the unconventional method used to value NHP's estate of 340 care homes but the company claims it also demonstrates the success of a whispering campaign in the City.

The transcript of conversations with NHP's financiers including warnings that the bank could be "sanctioning fraud" and suggestions that the bank's position was "precarious" for appearing to be implicated in something not above board.

fields.headline: Japan starts to spend again
fields.trailText: Japan took another painful step towards recovery yesterday as news of a long-awaited pick-up in consumer spending boosted market spirits despite unemployment reaching a new high.
fields.body:
Japan took another painful step towards recovery yesterday as news of a long-awaited pick-up in consumer spending boosted market spirits despite unemployment reaching a new high.

The lengthening dole queue failed to dampen growing optimism in financial markets about economic recovery, with the yen hitting a record high of 98 against the euro on the back of expectations that Monday's Tankan business survey will be bullish for growth.

But the hangover from the economy's return to recession in the middle of last year is forcing companies to shed the hundreds of thousands of workers in an attempt to improve profitability. The jobless rate climbed to a 50-year high of 4.9% in February, up 0.2 of a point on the previous month.

The finance minister, Kiichi Miyazawa, warned that the rate was on course to pass the 5% mark because many new graduates will join the ranks of the jobless this month.

The dismal news cast a cloud over figures showing that personal consumption, the main driving force in the economy, was increasing after a six-month slide.

An increase in overtime payments and the statistical quirk of an extra leap-year day helped to push spending by wage earning households up by 3.8%.

The Japanese government is under increasing pressure over the economy. It has racked up a record public sector debt of more than 120% of national income through its attempts to kick start the economy.

fields.headline: Hamleys profits take a tumble
fields.standfirst:
E-finance: special report
Hamleys
fields.trailText: Hamleys, the London toy store, yesterday disclosed a huge plunge in full-year profits - but new chief executive Simon Burke insisted performance was now improving.
fields.body:
Hamleys, the London toy store, yesterday disclosed a huge plunge in full-year profits - but new chief executive Simon Burke insisted performance was now improving.

The Regent Street store, which has got through three chief executives in three years, recorded pre-tax profits after one-off costs of just £670,000 in 1999 - compared with £6.4m a year earlier. The group had turned in a loss in its first half.

At the operating level, full-year profits for the group's continuing businesses - Hamleys and its high-street offshoot, Toystack - were down from £6.3m to £4.2m.

Sales growth in the second half was 4.5% in Regent Street, while the Toystack chain saw like-for-like sales up 6.7%.

But business at Hamleys' satellite stores - at Heathrow and Schiphol airports, the Eurotunnel terminal and in Covent Garden - were down 16%. The Eurotunnel store, which had been hit by the change in duty-free rules, has been closed. The group's loss-making House of Toys concessions in Debenhams stores have also been shut.

Hamleys' investors have had a bumpy ride. The shares, which three years ago were changing hands at 450p, yesterday closed down 5p at 132p.

The store is being dragged into the modern retail world by Mr Burke, who was previously Virgin's record stores' chief.

webTitle: It is decision time for DKB

fields.headline: It is decision time for DKB
fields.standfirst:
E-finance: special report
Deutsche Bank
fields.trailText: Banks could pay dear for delay
fields.body:
Banks could pay dear for delay

Dresdner Bank and its merger partner, Deutsche Bank, are coming under increasing pressure to decide the fate of the investment banking business Dresdner Kleinwort Benson in the coming week.

The two banks have given themselves until Easter to make a decision as to whether they will keep DKB or dismember it and sell some of the parts. A complete disposal looks unlikely, despite the ritual line that all options are open. But with both banks due to report annual figures next week - Deutsche on Thurs day and Dresdner the following day - neither will be able to avoid questions about DKB's fate.

If the banks are unable to come up with an answer they might find the reportedly relatively small numbers of staff who have voted with their feet swelling rapidly. In Germany staff had to resign by the close of business yesterday or wait until the end of the next quarter but in London there are no such restrictions. There is hardly a surfeit of investment bankers in the City. Many of DKB's staff might already be sitting on job offers. The sooner employees are told what is going to happen to their bit of the business - and to them - the better both for all concerned.

The two boards need to be able to produce a decision for another reason: to show why they did the merger in the first place. True, the strategy for their respective retail operations was sorted out from day one: they are to pass under the Allianz umbrella. The boards now need to produce the specifics of how they will produce value for shareholders across the broad range of operations. What happens at DKB will be an important part of that strategy.

Airbus thrust

The news that Airbus Industrie is talking to Mitsubishi Heavy Industries about possible collaboration over plans for the 600-seat super jumbo 3XX could have important ramifications.

That there are talks, albeit at an exploratory stage, is no surprise. DaimlerChrysler, a key part of the European Aeronautic, Defence and Space company (EADS) which owns most of Airbus, has just bought a controlling stake in Mitsubishi Motors, an affiliate of Mitsubishi Heavy Industries, so the lines of communica tion cannot have been difficult to establish.

Given the size of the A3XX project - development is expected to cost $12bn - it is natural that Airbus should look for others to share the risk. If a Japanese company were an important part of the A3XX team that might help sell the project to Japanese airlines. The main factor for determining whether Airbus goes ahead with the A3XX will be whether it can get enough airlines to sign up to buy the new aircraft before Airbus gets into the heavy spending end of the development programme.

Establishing links with Mitsubishi over the A3XX would at least help put the European group on a more equal footing with arch-rival Boeing when it comes to Japanese alliances. Boeing has links with Mitsubishi as well as two other Japanese aerospace companies: Kawasaki and Fuji Heavy Industries.

If it helped persuade Airbus bosses - still negotiating towards turning the aircraft maker into an integrated company by the end of this year - to go ahead with the A3XX it would take the rivalry with Boeing on to a new level.

Bad trade-off

Pascal Lamy left Beijing yesterday minus a deal on China's World Trade Organisation membership. The sticking point, it appears, is foreign ownership. Brussels wants China to sweep aside the bamboo curtain and allow capitalists in to control its businesses. China, for the moment, is holding out.

The lure of a deal to bring the world's largest market into the global trading system will no doubt see talks resume soon. But this week's negotiations add weight to the case made by critics of the global trading system that it is business as usual despite the wave of opposition to trade liberalisation which emerged last November in Seattle.

There were ringing declarations that Seattle was a "wake-up" call on the need to listen to civil society on trade issues. But, instead of taking the opportunity to discuss China's human rights record this week, the EU has gone to the wire over whether foreigners should be allowed to own 51% of Chinese firms, or 49% as Beijing would prefer.

If public faith in the multilateral trade system is to be restored, ground rules need to be set. Without bowing to the protectionist instincts roused among some western trade unions when developing countries exploit their one comparative advantage - cheaper labour - it should be made clear that non-democratic countries such as China cannot expect the same trade privileges as democratic ones. Trade is a means to an end - human development - not an end in itself.

Establishing links with Mitsubishi over the A3XX would at least help put the European group on a more equal footing with arch-rival Boeing when it comes to Japanese alliances. Boeing has links with Mitsubishi as well as two other Japanese aerospace companies: Kawasaki and Fuji Heavy Industries. If it helped persuade Airbus bosses - still negotiating towards turning the aircraft maker into an integrated company by the end of this year - to go ahead with the A3XX it would take the rivalry with Boeing on to a new level. Bad trade-off Pascal Lamy left Beijing yesterday minus a deal on China's World Trade Organisation membership. The sticking point, it appears, is foreign ownership. Brussels wants China to sweep aside the bamboo curtain and allow capitalists in to control its businesses. China, for the moment, is holding out. The lure of a deal to bring the world's largest market into the global trading system will no doubt see talks resume soon. But this week's negotiations add weight to the case made by critics of the global trading system that it is business as usual despite the wave of opposition to trade liberalisation which emerged last November in Seattle. There were ringing declarations that Seattle was a "wake-up" call on the need to listen to civil society on trade issues. But, instead of taking the opportunity to discuss China's human rights record this week, the EU has gone to the wire over whether foreigners should be allowed to own 51% of Chinese firms, or 49% as Beijing would prefer. If public faith in the multilateral trade system is to be restored, ground rules need to be set. Without bowing to the protectionist instincts roused among some western trade unions when developing countries exploit their one comparative advantage - cheaper labour - it should be made clear that non-democratic countries such as China cannot expect the same trade privileges as democratic ones. Trade is a means to an end - human development - not an end in itself.

webTitle: Future of tech issues in doubt

fields.headline: Future of tech issues in doubt
fields.trailText: The heat under the technology sector has been turned up and the meltdown of the business-to-consumer stocks has accelerated. One company finds itself in the hottest part of the fire - America's leading online music retailer, CDNow. If the bears are to be believed, it is merely months from extinction.
fields.body:
The heat under the technology sector has been turned up and the meltdown of the business-to-consumer stocks has accelerated. One company finds itself in the hottest part of the fire - America's leading online music retailer, CDNow. If the bears are to be believed, it is merely months from extinction.

This week the Nasdaq dropped 9%. In Europe, Germany's Neuer Markt plunged 14% and Britain's Techmark 100 fell 5%, leaving it 25% below the record posted only three weeks ago.

Commentators have searched frantically for explanations of this sudden reversal in investment fashions. This scramble for understanding is vital for it may reveal the answer to the question on every investor's lips: is this a blip in a rising trend or the end of the great bull market in tech stocks? Those hoping that these words will lead them directly to the Holy Grail should stop reading now. Only time can provide the answer to a problem whose resolution lies as much in the collective psyche of investors as in the "fundamentals" of the new technology industries.

That psyche has been subjected to repeated shocks in the past few weeks. Each shock has chipped away at investor perceptions of financial normality. Gradually what was taken for granted as immutable fact - that the valuation of tech shares was readily explicable and sustainable - is now cast into doubt.

A recent article in Barrons has contributed greatly to the new mood of insecurity among technology devotees. Its impact has been such that its arguments have been repeated and amplified in the financial press across the globe. I make no apology in joining the band of regurgitators.

Barrons commissioned a study of the cash flows of quoted US internet stocks. In an article titled "Burning Up", it revealed that on the basis of balance sheets and income and spending pat terns at the end of last year, many were only months from exhausting their financial resources. CDNow was alleged to have only one month's cash left.

At the time of publication CDNow shares were 80% below their record high. Alarmed, the company put Barrons straight on a few facts. This week the American financial journal reflected the company's input and corrected its analysis - not one month but seven months from burn-out. CDNow shares responded by halving again.

The hunger for cash afflicting the business-to-consumer internet companies should come as no surprise. Their services are new and expensive to construct. The only constant in an ever-shifting landscape is the necessity for vast marketing spend to stake territorial claims. And consumers are reluctant to spend money on what many regard as a free utility.

None of this would matter were investors willing to fund the build-up of tomorrow's online consumer giants. However, as traditional consumer companies have fought back with their own web strategies, it has become apparent that many are knocking spots off their upstart rivals.

Investor reaction has been to sell consumer internet stocks, in the process choking off one key source of cash for continued business development - equity fundraising. If they are not to simply fizzle out of business, many will need to seek strategic investment from other companies, possibly through full-scale takeovers.

With their core brands so strong, it is difficult to envisage bricks-and-mortar businesses paying significant premiums for net brands. However, they may be able to pick up some bargains at fire-sale prices. CDNow is a good brand. In time it may become great. But maybe not to the benefit of its shareholders.

This should all be seen as a natural development in an industrial revolution - and not necessarily unhealthy at that. Investment in the new technologies should always have been viewed as (ad)venture capitalism.

Impossible though it might seem to some, the shakedown is if anything more exciting than the original trip to the stars that the tech stocks experienced. The greatest opportunities in markets are always presented when panic is in the air and asset prices are adjusted with insufficient discrimination.

Four pieces of advice for investors. First, remember that technology will continue to revolutionise the real world. Second, invest in net stocks breaking into profit but whose share prices have been clobbered. Third, back those stocks able to come to market in today's adverse climate. But fourth, don't forget I've no better idea than the next person whether this is just a blip or the end.

Edmond Warner is chief executive of Albert E Sharp Securities

webTitle: And still providers refuse to admit scale of the shortfall

fields.headline: And still providers refuse to admit scale of the shortfall
fields.trailText: Is your endowment in shortfall? We asked the providers to reveal the numbers off target, assuming future investment growth of 6% a year. The results show that the numbers in potential shortfall have escalated dramatically since our last survey in October - and how some insurers are refusing to disclose the scale of the problem.
fields.body:
Is your endowment in shortfall? We asked the providers to reveal the numbers off target, assuming future investment growth of 6% a year. The results show that the numbers in potential shortfall have escalated dramatically since our last survey in October - and how some insurers are refusing to disclose the scale of the problem.

Standard Life: More than 530,000 of Standard Life's 1.2m endowment policies fall short at 6%. At the 8% marker, less than 20,000 are lacking. The company will start writing to customers in June with information on how their endowments are performing and what they need to do. All customers should get a letter this year.

Legal & General: L&G refused to give out figures for how many of their 1.1 million endowment policies are in shortfall. Since February it has written to 650,000 customers and plans to write to the rest this year.

Scottish Amicable: The company has 850,000 policies but was unable to say how many are in shortfall. It will begin writing to customers at the end of April.

Friends Provident: Friends Provident has 750,000 policies but won't comment on how many are in shortfall. The society will write to customers between April and the end of the year informing them of how much their policies are underperforming.

Norwich Union: Norwich Union has 640,000 mortgage endowment policies but said it can't say how many are underperforming at the 6% and 8% mark. As required by the Financial Services Authority it will be conducting a review of the policies over the year and will start writing to its customers in April.

Royal Insurance and Sun Alliance: At the end of 1999 RSA estimated that 120,000 of its 600,000 endowment policies were in shortfall at 6%. It plans to start writing to customers with information. The company will send out reprojections towards the end of the May.

CGU Life: Some 400,000 of CGU's 600,000 policies are in shortfall by 6% - 1,071 are in shortfall at 8%. However, the company says most of the shortfalls are for small amounts, such as £2 a month, and is promising that providing future investment earnings average 6%, it will top up the endowments at maturity. If investment earnings go below 6% customers will only be asked to make up the difference up to 6%. CGU says it has already started writing to policyholders with the new projections and information on the promise.

Scottish Life: Of its 600,000 endowment policies it expects around 200,000 to show a shortfall at 6%. The company was unable to tell us when they will begin writing to their customers.

Lloyds TSB: A staggering 80% of Lloyd's TSB's 300,000 endowment mortgage policies are thought to be in shortfall at 6% and will need to increase their premiums by between 25% and 40% to stay on target. The company will start writing to its policyholders in June.

Prudential: Just under 100,000 of Prudential's 275,000 endowment policies fall short at the 6% mark and will need a premium increase of around 10%. At the 8% mark around 6,000 policies are in shortfall. If you're a Prudential customer, expect a letter any time now

AXA Sun Life: At the 6% mark, some 70% of AXA Sun Life's 200,000 endowment policies fall short by about 20% of the target amount. At the 8% mark most are OK. The company is about to begin writing to its customers with reprojected figures for the shortfalls.

Scottish Provident: The company has 197,000 policies but was unable to say how many were in shortfall or when it will be writing to customers.

Allied Dunbar: Of its 190,000 endowment policies, Allied Dunbar estimated 110,000 are in shortfall at 7%. The company has started calculating the shortfalls at the 4%, 6% and 8% mark and will write to customers with reprojections between April and December.

Eagle Star: When Eagle Star Life did its calculations last September it found 90,000 of its 160,000 policies in shortfall at 7%. The company is now in the middle of calculating the shortfalls at the 4%, 6% and 8% mark and will begin writing to customers with the reprojections this month.

Pearl: Pearl declined to comment on how many of its 150,000 endowment policies are in shortfall, but said it will be writing to all of its customers this month.

Barclays Life: The company has 120,000 policies but was unable to tell us how many were in shortfall or when it will be writing to customers.

Royal London: Royal London has 86,000 policies of which around 12,000 are in shortfall at 6% and only 1 at 8%. At the 6% mark, the average shortfall is £1570 or 5% of the target amount.
